||||||MIMIKO, Nahzeem Oluwafemi|M|The foreign policy implications of Nigeria's economic crises, 1975-1989. ||||||Ph.D|O. C. Nwokedi.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, International Relations|1992. |||OAU|||||xiii, 320p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This study set out to examine the specific implications of Nigeria's economic crises, with a view to showing whether or not a re-orientation actually occurred in foreign policy as a result of the economic crises. In doing so, the study focused on the process and nature of Nigeria's decline from the relative economic buoyancy of most of the 1970s to a state of economic bankruptcy which has attained unprecedented proportions since 1986.  Thereafter, the study undertook a critical examination of Nigeria's foreign policy between 1975 and 1989, especially as it related to the liberation question, non-alignment, and economic integration in the West African sub-region.Primary data were collected through the informal interview technique. The technique was used to obtain information from top serving and retired government functionaries, private sector individuals, and politicians, connected with Nigeria's foreign policy process; and foreign diplomats serving in Nigeria. Archival and other relevant documents were also subjected to content analysis. These were supplemented with data collected from secondary sources mainly through library research.The study elucidated more clearly than before the nature of the linkage between economic factors and foreign policy. It showed in this respect, that a nation's commitment to its foreign policy goals and objectives need not fluctuate with the vagaries or bouts of crisis or buoyancy in its economy. The research has also provided a framework for the study of the foreign policies of structurally dependent countries like Nigeria which constitute the majority of state actors in the contemporary international system.On the basis of the mass of data collected and analysed, the study found out that while Nigeria's economic crises engendered a change of style in its foreign policy, they did not fundamentally alter the substance of its foreign policy. More specifically, the economic crises did not compromise the nation's traditional commitment to the liberation struggle, and to integration. The crises strengthened Nigeria's basic economic alignment with the Western market economy countries, a situation that has continued to promote the traditional foreign policy orientation of accommodation and/or friendship with the latter on almost all issues.The implications of these findings are two fold. First, Nigeria, is expected to continue to champion the cause of liberation in Southern Africa, and economic integration in West Africa inspite of the economic crises. Second, as long as Nigeria remains within the prevailing global capitalist economic system, the economic crises are expected to continue to foster close political and economic relations and alignment with the Western countries.|Theses Collection|Nigeria's economic issues/foreign policy/liberation/non-alignment/economic integration/informal interview technique/Western market economy*||||||NASSAR, Moshood Lanrewaju.|M|Study of the Nigerian bank for commerce and industry in the financing of small businesses in Nigeria.|||||| Ph.D.| O. Omopariola.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Management and Accounting|1992.|||OAU|||||xv, 288p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The need for adequate capital to finance small business has been a subject of intense but unresolved debates in the literature.  This informs the study which examined the operational pattern and socio-economic environment of the small-business financing scheme of the Nigerian Bank for Commerce and Industry (NBCI) with a view to appraising the performance.Data were collected from a sample of 244 small-scale businesses that were located in various states of the Federation. This represented about 50% of the beneficiaries as at 1987. Interviews were also held with the officials of the bank at its headquarters and zonal and branch offices.  Other sources of data included official records and other publications from the Financial Institutions.  The data were analysed using regression analysis, ratio analysis and descriptive statistics such as frequency distributions.Results of the analysis revealed a wide supply gap in meeting the effective demand of the clients.  In terms of sectoral spread of the investments, the results showed that Food and Building materials Subsector got the highest sanctions with 32.1% of the total value of all approved projects, while the metal fabrication subsector got 3.6% of the total sanctions.On the whole, the investment in equity of the clients projects have been lower than loan financing.  With respect to financing initial capital and expansion, the study revealed that the Bank's role has been more significant in the latter than in the former.  On the inter-relationship between the size of repayment and some socio-economic variables of the enterprise, the Pearson correlation analysis showed positive correlation between repayment and the number of product lines, retained earnings, the amount borrowed and the frequency of supervision by credit officials. On the whole, the analysis sustained the hypotheses that the small enterprises supported by NBCI were under capitalized and that the extent of under capitalization is related to supply gap.|Theses Collection|small-business financing/Financial Institutions/small-scale businesses/socio-economic variables/Bank's role/Financial Institutions/retained earnings*||||||POPOOLA, Adedotun Tajudeen. |M|The structure and context of the valuation of new ordinary shares in the Nigerian primary stock market.|||||| Ph.D. | O. Omopariola. //  O. L. Oludimu.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Management and Accounting |1992|||OAU|||||xvi, 313p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This study examined the evolution and performance of the   It investigated the factors that had the greatest bearing on the development of the market, and focused on the issue of underpricing which is widely believed to exist in the market.Primary information was obtained from the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), the Nigerian Stock Exchange (NSE), and the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN).  This information included reports on the evolution of and developments in the capital market, the daily official list of the Nigerian Stock Exchange, and the return on treasury bills.  Published reports obtained from the SEC and the CBN were used to obtain the operating and performance characteristics of sampled companies particularly from their prospectuses, and comparative information on what obtains on the stock markets of selected African countries from the literature.  Descriptive and inferential statistical tools were used in analysing results.On the issue of underpricing of new ordinary shares, the values of the ordinary shares of 35 previously unlisted companies as fixed by the SEC between 1977 and 1986 were compared with their subsequent performances on the NSE.  This represented 79.5% of the number of companies listed during the period, and 41.2% of the total number of companies listed by December, 1988.The findings indicated the indigenisation effort as the single, most important factor that contributed positively to the growth of the Nigerian capital market.  An apparent underpricing of new issues was detected, but this disappeared on an adjustment of the values for changes in the general economic situation.  On the other hand, the values suggested by the issuing houses consistently outperformed the market. The study did not support the viewpoint that the SEC should no longer price new issues, and recommendations, derived from the study, were made for the development of the stock market.|Theses Collection|Nigerian primary stock market./Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)/Nigerian Stock Exchange (NSE)/Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN)/ treasury bills/ indigenisation/ordinary shares / Nigerian capital market*||||||AWOTOKUN, Adekunle Meshack. |M|Legislative control of the executive in Nigeria under the second republic 1979-1983||||||Ph.D|O. M. Laleye.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo Universsity, Public Administration|1992.|||OAU|||||xv, 319p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This thesis examined the nature of legislative control of the Executive arm of government during the Second Republic (1979-1983).  This was in the light of the failure of Nigeria's second attempt at operating a viable democratic political system.  The fall of the Second Republic raised some questions as to how and why the Presidential model which had been considered a better alternative to the parliamentary system also failed.  Attempts at explaining the demise of the Republic tend to suggest that the Executive arm was largely responsible.It was against this background that this study was undertaken to determine the extent to which the Executive arm was committed to upholding the ideals of public accountability and administrative responsiveness during the period examined. The study also attempted to determine the extent to which the legislature had succeeded or failed in performing its constitutional responsibility of controlling the Executive as prescribed in the Constitution.Primary data were collected from Hansard, Reports of the various Legislative Houses, Government publications and interviews.  Secondary data were collected, Reference materials as well as newspaper reports.The study discovered that Legislative Control of the Executive was weak during the Second Republic.  This weakness was traced to: the colonial legacy of Executive Supremacy, contradictions in the constitution and in its operation, inexperience of legislators; misuse of the impeachment mechanism; the power of political parties over legislators and corruption, among others.Finally, the study made some policy recommendation which could help in strengthening legislative control of the Executive during the Third Republic.  For instance the study proposed that there should be a review of the 1989 Constitution with the aim of having full-time legislators.  It was also recommended that elections into the legislature be conducted every six years in contrast to the Executive term of four years.  This would enable the legislators develop a stable system within which to perform their functions.  It would also help them to acquire some degree of expertise in areas of public policy!. This will help the present and future political actors to internalise the ideas of accountability, responsibility and responsiveness which in the final analysis determine the legitimacy and stability of regime types.  Finally, it was recommended that a number of modern facilities such as well equipped libraries, computers should be placed at the disposal of law makers.|Theses Collection|legislative control/Second Republic (1979-1983)/ Presidential model/parliamentary system/public accountability/administrative responsiveness/1989 Constitution/impeachment mechanism/ public policy*||||||ADEMOYE, Buraimo Atanda.|M| Output and hectarage responses of grain crops to price changes in Nigeria. ||||||M.Sc.| A. A. Adesimi.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Agricultural Economics|1992.|||OAU|||||  ix, 75p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This study investigated through multiple regression analysis, the factors responsible for the annual variability in the hectarage sown to, and output obtained from major grain crops in Nigeria. The broad objective of the study is to analyse the factors causing annual fluctuations in the hectarage and output of the grain crops in Nigeria.Time-series data for the period 1965-1988 were used.  The data were obtained from the publications of the Federal Office of Statistics and the Central Bank of Nigeria. The data were analysed using the ordinary least squares (OLS) multiple regression techniques.Guinea corn and millet farmers expectedly react positively to expected producer prices of the crops.  However, maize and rice farmers react negatively to expected producer prices, due to inconsistent government agricultural policy.Guinea corn and millet compete effectively with groundnuts and cotton for resource - use, as indicated by the negative signs of their co-efficients.  In like manner, maize and rice compete with yam and cassava.  Farmers allocate their land for the cultivation of food grains mainly for subsistence purposes, as farmer population which is the risk aversion co-efficient carry positive signs.  Average rainfall during the critical period of growth of the grain crops was positively associated with the output of grain crops.The Structural Adjustment Programme (SAP) has no significant impact on the supply response of grain crops yet.  This result is probably due to the fact that SAP was operational for only three out of the twenty-three years covered by this study. Thus, a quantitative and effective measurement of its effect at this time is premature.  The hectarage and output responses of the grain crops are mostly price inelastic, both in the short and long-runs.The postulated explanatory variables, namely, own-producer prices, price of substitute crops, farmer population, time trend, and rainfall accounted for between 46% and 72% of the variability in the hectarage and output responses of the grain crops as indicated by the value of the co-efficient of determination (R2).  The unexplained part (between 28% and 54%) of the supply response of grain crops farmers could be attributed mainly to inconsistent agricultural policy.  Other reasons include expectation problems; lack of credit; shortage of labour and capital; hired labour; old age of farmers and land tenure.|Theses Collection|multiple regression analysis/variability/grain crops/hectarage/Federal Office of Statistics/Central Bank of Nigeria./ordinary least squares (OLS)/ Structural Adjustment Programme (SAP)/time trend/farmer population/substitute crops/land tenure/hired labour*||||||ISIJOLA, Olaniyi Clement|M|Factors influencing the supply of agricultural credit by commercial banks in Nigeria.||||||M.Sc.|O.L. Oludimu.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Agricultural Economics|1992.|||OAU|||||xii, 148p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The main objective of this study was to determine factors influencing agricultural lending of commercial banks.  The study was expected to identify significant factors influencing the supply of agricultural credit by commercial banks and their implications on government food self-sufficiency objectives were expected to emanate from the study.Data for the analysis came primarily from Central Bank of Nigeria publications such as the Annual Report and Statement of Accounts, Economic and Financial Review, Bullion and Agricultural Credit Guarantee Scheme Fund Annual Report and Statement of Accounts.The Ordinary Least Square Regression method was used to estimate the coefficient of the parameters included in the specified regression models. The results obtained reveal that interest rate on agricultural production loan was significant and positively influenced the volume of credit supplied to the agricultural sector, over the studied period, by the commercial banks.  However, liquidity ratio of the commercial banks and the Central Bank prescribed minimum rediscount rate emerged significant and both negatively influenced the volume of credit supplied to agricultural sector over the studied period.Based on the results obtained from the study, the following policy recommendations were made: that government should continue to prescribe the interest rate on agricultural production loan; that Central Bank should persuade the commercial banks to come together and establish revolving-term loans which should be insured from the liquidity controls; and that government should also employ other budgetary measures such as price stabilisation and taxation allowance.The major contribution of this study to knowledge was that, the results obtained from this study revealed that it was the economic variables (nominal interest rates, Central Bank prescribed rediscount rate and liquidity ratio) rather than government programmes (Agricultural Credit Guarantee Scheme and Rural Banking Scheme) that significantly influenced the supply of agricultural credit by commercial banks.|Theses Collection| agricultural lending/commercial banks/government food self-sufficiency objectives/Central Bank of Nigeria/Annual Report/Statement of Accounts/Economic and Financial Review/ Ordinary Least Square Regression method/interest rate/ liquidity ratio/agricultural production loan/liquidity controls*||||||LADOKUN, Abiodun Emmanuel. |M|Maize yield fluctuations as related to resource use efficiency in Ijaye area of Oyo State.||||||M.Sc.|B. Awoyomi.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Agricultural Economics|1992|||OAU|||||xiii, 127p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This study looked into the influence of specific factors on yield variability and empirically determined productivity differences and efficiency among maize farmers in Ijaye area of Oyo State. The primary data for this study were obtained from a cross-sectional survey of 125 farmers drawn from Ijaye, Alabata, Ajobo and Onikete villages through the use of structured questionnaires. Regression analysis was used to identify factors that caused yield variations between "OAR" and "Non-OAR" program farmers and among the four village locations.  Analysis of variance (ANOVA) method was used to determine whether significant differences exist in the seed variety used by the two groups of farmers.  Marginal analysis techniques was used to measure efficiency of resource use of the farmers.The regression result showed that hired labour and cost of seeds were the significant factors that caused yield variations among "OAR" farmers whereas family labour, cost of seeds and cost of other purchased inputs were significant factors among "Non-OAR" farmers.  Across the four villages, cost of seed was the most significant and positive factor while family labour was only significant in Ajobo village.The ANOVA results indicated that seed variety was not statistically significant in explaining yield variations between OAR farmers who planted TZSR-W and "Non-OAR" farmers who planted the local variety. The reason adduced for this was the failure of the farmers to adopt the program as a whole package.  It was also indicated that village location has no significant influence on maize yield variations across the villages considered.Maize yield for the two groups of farmers and for the four village locations was inelastic with respect to the explanatory variables.  The sum of the input coefficients for the "OAR" and "Non-OAR" which indicate return to scale were 0.742 and 0.809 respectively.  And for the four villages, Alabata, Ijaye, Onikete and Ajobo, the values were 0.475, 0.839, 0.681, and 0.94 respectively. This is an indication that farmers in these groups and villages have not used the inputs beyond the rational production stage.The marginal analysis results showed that the "OAR" farmers used only seed input efficiently, while the "Non-OAR" used all the resources inefficiently. Among the villages, apart from Ajobo which used family, hired labour and seed input efficiently, all the other villages used only seed input efficiently.|Theses Collection|Maize farmers/Regression analysis/Analysis of variance (ANOVA)/ marginal analysis*||||||OSIFODUNRIN, Olufemi Adedotun.|M|A study of costs and returns in pig production in Ibadan, Nigeria.||||||M.Sc|B. Awoyomi||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Agricultural Economics|1992|||OAU|||||vii, 93p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The study investigated the costs and returns of pig production in Ibadan as a way of elucidating the potentials of pork as a protein supply source in Nigeria. Data was collected from 30 pig farmers in Ibadan using pre-tested questionnaires. Data analysis involved descriptive, regression, budgetary and break-even analysis.The common breeds reared were the Large White, Landrace, Duroc and Crossbreeds. Only 2 farms had local breeds in addition to the exotic ones. All farmers used the intensive system of management. All farmers used the intensive system of management.  All the farmers had secondary occupation. 46.7% of the farmers did not have weighing balances.  37% of the farms had less than 100 pigs, 40% had between 100-200 pigs and 23% had over 200 pigs, with a mean of 176 pigs for all the farms.Regression analysis showed that age, pig farming experience and educational attainment of the pig farmers were important factors having a positive influence on management ability of the farmers.  76% of the variation in management ability of the farmers were explained by the independent variables stated above. The budgetary analysis revealed that the total variable cost constituted the bulk (83.33%) of the total cost of production among the farms, the value being largely dominated by feed cost (43.23%), veterinary cost (22.68%) and labour cost (11.82%).  The total variable cost per pig among the farmers was N182.90 while the fixed cost per pig was N37.24, thus making a total cost per pig of N22.14.The study revealed an established cost per pig of N226.29 and the operational cost of N182.90 per pig. The price per pig was N425.44 while the net revenue or profit per pig was N204.61 for the farms.  Though the budgetary analysis revealed profitable pig farming enterprises, the break-even analysis showed that only 60% of the farms were able to cover their cost of production with the revenue generated and were still left with some surplus.  The break-even quantities ranged from 43-372 pigs while the actual quantity ranged from 35-550 pigs.  The mean break-even quantity was 151 pigs. The break-even result led to the suggestion that farms with low but positive margins of safety and those with negative margins of safety should decrease their variable and fixed costs.  They should also expand their farms in terms of quantity of animals produced in order to increase their profits or reduce losses.  To aid the farmers in achieving these suggestions, problems such as high feed cost and scarcity of drugs have to be dealt with.|Theses Collection| pig production /protein supply/Large White/Landrace/Duroc/ Crossbreeds/management ability/feed cost/veterinary cost/labour cost/profitable pig farming enterprises/*||||||OGUNDELE, Kikelomo Olukemi.|F|Adoption of home improvement practices by women in Osogbo area of Osun State.|||||| M.Sc.|A. The study investigated the level of awareness of the practices introduced, the communication channels, the teaching methods employed, the level of satisfaction derived from the adoption and problems hindering complete adoption of the practices.The study covered ten Local Government Areas in which thirty-three towns and villages were chosen through systematic random sampling procedure.  Structured interview schedule was used to collect information from one hundred and ten women participants in June and July, 1991.Statistical methods were used in analysing the data. Chi-square and correlation analyses were used to determine the relationships between dependent and the independent variables.  The results showed that the welfare agents and radio were popular sources of awareness of the home improvement practices. Over 60% of the respondents completely adopted about 80% of the practices recommended. More than 50% of the respondents indicated satisfaction with the adoption of all the ten practices disseminated.  The reasons given for dissatisfaction with practices not completely adopted, ranged from non-availability of fund and materials in the immediate surrounding to other personal reasons.The study also showed that there was significant relationship between adoption level of home improvement practices and age, level of education, marital status, farm/non-farm occupation, minor occupation, religion and feeding pattern.Furthermore, correlation analysis showed positive and significant association between adoption levels of respondents and their income, formal education, cosmopoliteness, contact with welfare agents and social group membership. Phil.|E. A. Laogun.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Agricultural Extension and Rural Sociology|1992.|||OAU|||||xvi, 233p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The Oyo State Agricultural Development programme was designed to support increased agricultural production in the state. There were many improved agricultural technologies and farm information available in the programme but the extension communication for dissemination of these improved agricultural technologies between research and extension workers on one hand, and between these agencies and farmers of the programme has not been studies.The specific objectives of the study were to examine the organizational structure of the programme so as to identify those involved in disseminating farm information and agricultural technologies, to identify the stock of improved agricultural technologies available and to determine channels of communication between the research and extension workers and between these agencies and the farmers.  For the respondents, the study was to determine their socio-economic characteristics which have influence on their frequency of contact.To achieve the stated objectives, data for the study was collected between November, 1990 and March, 1991 from the following number and categories of respondents, 9 research workers, 150 village level extension staff and 120 registered farmers of the programme. Two sets of questionnaires were administered to research workers, and a randomly selected samples of extension workers.  Interview schedule was used to collect information from randomly selected samples of programme registered farmers.  Participant observation was also used as data collection technique. The data collected were analyzed and subjected to statistical analyses with the use of chi-square, correlation analysis and multiple regression analysis.The findings showed that Subject Matter Specialists constituted a link between the research workers and the village level extension workers, while the village extension agents were responsible for face-to-face contacts and communication with farmers in the programme.  "Personal contact" "meeting" and "group discussion" were the main channels of communications of agricultural information and technologies. However, the use of mass media such as daily newspapers, magazine, journals, radio and television has not yet been institutionalized as sources of farm information in the programme.There was a positive and significant correlation between the following characteristics of extension agent, age, level of education attained, official status, length of service in the programme and years of experience and frequency of contact between research and extension workers, while the age of farmer, level of education of farmer, years of farming experience and knowledge of extension agent's name had significant relationship with the frequency of contact between extension agent and farmers in the programme.It was recommended that the programme should strengthen the research organs and extension service at farmers' level, and innovative educational techniques should be employed to increase opportunities for communication of farm information. Provision of adequate transport facilities for village level extension agent, and the establishment of more Agro-chemical and farm service centres in the programme area were also recommended.|Theses Collection|agricultural technologies/chi-square/correlation analysis/multiple regression analysis./sources of farm information/Agro-chemical/innovative educational techniques*||||||OYE, Michael.|M|The directorate approach to rural development.  A study of the Directorate of Food, Roads and Rural Infrastructure (DFRRI) in Nigeria||||||Ph.D.|J. Ade Alao||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Agricultural Extension & Rural Sociology|1992|||OAU|||||xxiii, 323p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Nigeria has been plagued with the introduction of several abortive approaches to rural development since independence.  Hence the setting up of DFRRI by the present Federal Military Government had raised eyebrows in some circles.  Some were concerned that the Directorate of Food, Roads and Rural Infrastructures (DFRRI) would fail just as its predecessors. Others felt that it was trying to grapple with too many rural problems without facing the realities of lack of funds and expertise.  Criticisms about the quality of DFRRI's projects and their usefulness to rural communities were increasing. It was, therefore, necessary to carry out an independent evaluative study of the programme to bring out facts which could answer the questions raised. To do this, the study investigated DFRRI's organizational setup, the extent of its achievements, and the attitudes of the rural populace to the organization.Four states, Oyo, Kwara, Plateau and Rivers were selected by stratified random technique.  Among the many aspects of the programme, feeder road construction, potable water supply and rural electrification were appraised.  Nonparametric statistics such as achievement indices, percentages, means, frequency counts, Spearman Rank Correlation (r), MannWhitney U test, KolmogorovSmirnov twosample test, ChiSquare and Kendall Coefficient (W) were used to analyse data from 462 rural respondents and DFRRI officials. The study has shown that DFRRI has made appreciable progress in the provision of rural feeder roads, potable water and electricity.  Within its short life, and given its prevailing constraints, the organization has been able to triple the rate of providing rural feeder roads.  Its Rural Water and Sanitation (RUWATSAN) scheme has had a positive impact on rural life, particularly in Kwara State where the incidence of guinea worm and other waterborne diseases has been appreciably reduced.  The provision of electricity has made life more comfortable to many rural communities. The study estimated that about 6,699 kilometres of roads were either reconstructed or newly constructed by DFRRI, while 17,056 kilometres were rehabilitated.  Five thousand and fiftyfour (5,054) rural communities have been reached with potable water, while 208 communities were linked with the national electrical grid. Detailed study of the selected states revealed DFRRI's outstanding weaknesses.  The most serious of these has been DFRRI's failure to adequately mobilise rural people for its projects.  This has led to the organization's inability to utilize local knowledge, manpower and other resources in its programme. Consequently, many rural communities have not seen the need to maintain infrastructures provided for them. Financial constraints have also been a great handicap to DFRRI's programme; some roads and wells have been left uncompleted and therefore, useless to rural communities.    Recommendations have pointed to the fact that DFRRI should have an overall policy of mobilizing and coordinating already existing organizations would then add their resources to DFRRI's to bring about the much desired rural upliftment.|Theses Collection|rural development/stratified random technique/Financial constraints/Directorate of Food, Roads and Rural Infrastructures (DFRRI)/rural electrification/potable water supply/ feeder road construction*||||||IDOWU, Olubunmi Alabi.|M|Evaluation of palm oil sludge, cowpea testa and extracted fermented corn by-product for chickens||||||M.Sc. | E.B. Sonaiya.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Animal Science|1992|||OAU||||||||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Four main studies were conducted.  A survey of rural poultry production in two selected locations was carried out in the first study.  Structure questionnaires (administered in Yoruba) were used.  More women (56% of respondents) were involved in poultry keeping. Mean flock size was 16, while increase in flock size was mainly by hatching. Extensive management system was practised by all.  Supplementary feeding of grains e.g. maize, and some crop by-products was practised.  Major constraint to production was Newcastle disease.  Productivity was at an average of 9 eggs per clutch and 3 clutches per year.  Modifications in housing, feeding and health management may improve chicken productivity at village level.Experiment II involved determination of voluntary intake of extracted fermented corn by-product (Corn starch residue, CSR), palm oil sludge (POS) and Cowpea testa (CT) by individually housed 15 cockerels, on a cafeteria choice basis.  The results indicated higher consumption of CSR (43.2g DM/bird/d) than CT (9.96g DM/bird/d), which was the least.  Consumption of CSR was similar to that of commercial growers mash (44.2g/DM/bird/d).  Corn starch residue is thus palatable to the birds.Experiment III was a six week study to investigate the effect of feeding a non-conventional ration (NCR) formulated mainly from the three tested feedstuffs in the proportions of POS, 35%; CSR, 55%; CT, 8% and 2% bone meal, on cockerels performance.  Forty-five Harco cockerels were allocated to three treatment rations: Ration 1, 100% commercial growers mash (CGR); Ration 2, 50% CGR + 50% non-conventional ration (NCR); Ration 3, 100% NCR.  The crude protein and energy levels of rations were: ration 1,12.7% and 2.321.76 ME kcal/kg; ration 2, 13.1% and 3,101.96 ME kcal/kg; ration 3,12.0% and 3,804.4 ME/kcal.  Mean daily feed intake was 95.0, 92.0 and 37.7g/bird for rations 1,2 and 3 respectively.  Rations 1 and 2 were similar in growth rate and feed utilization efficiency. Total replacement of growers ration with that made from non-conventional feedstuffs at the proportions used, is not viable.Experiment IV was an on-farm feeding trial to study the effect of supplementing NCR on the performance of free ranging chickens.  A total of 165 chickens were allocated to three treatment groups: (T1) 0. (T2) 30 and (T3) 60g supplemental feed/bird/d.  Usual management practices were followed in T1, while in T2 and T3 only feed supplementation was made in addition to what the chickens obtained from scavenging.  There was low consumption of the supplemental feed by T2 chickens (8.10g/bird/d); consumption by T3 birds (38.0g/bird/d) declined with time, as T2.  Average body weight gain was 0.013, 0.007 and 0.012g/gb.wt/d.  The supplemented non-conventional feed at 30g/day did not differ from those of unsupplemented scavenging chickens.  In this study, feed supplementation did not improve performance of scavenging chickens as expected.|Theses Collection|rural poultry production/poultry keeping/hatching/Extensive management system/extracted fermented corn by-product (Corn starch residue, CSR)/chicken productivity/crude protein/non-conventional ration (NCR)/feed utilization efficiency/ growth rate/consumption/scavenging chickens/*||||||OLORI, Victor Enishede.|M|An evaluation of two ecotypes of the Nigerian indigenous chicken.||||||M.Sc.|E.B. Sonaiya // O. Akinokun||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Animal Science|1992.|||OAU|||||x, 95p. |||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The growth performance and egg characteristics of two eco-types of the Nigerian indigenous chicken (NI) i.e. the Yoruba (YR) from the south-west and the Fulani (FU) from the north were evaluated.  The body weight and shank length of one hundred and twenty FI chicks were measured weekly for ten weeks.  Records of feed intake were also kept.  Records of 45 days egg production were kept for 61 hens housed in cages.  Sixty eggs of various shell colours were collected from the parent population for analysis monthly for seven months.  The dimensions of each egg, its weight and the weight of its components were measured as well as the shell thickness.  The proportion of the various egg components, shell density, shape index, surface area and weight per unit area were calculated.  Data compilation and analysis were done using D-Base IV and Statistical Analysis Systems (SAS) computer software respectively.The result showed that the FU was 27% heavier (P>0.05) than the YR at all ages.  The FU grew faster by 1.4g daily and had longer shanks.  The YR was more variable in body weight (Cv = 25.4% vs 17.4%).  The feed per gain ratio was 5.5g and 5.3g for the YR and FU respectively.  Hen housed egg production was 31.2% for the FU and 32.9% for the YR.  The mean egg weight was 37.6g with no difference between the ecotypes (P<0.05).  The ecotypes also did not differ (P<0.05) in other egg characteristics were affected (P<0.05) by the age of the laying flock, hen plumage and shell colour.The study shows that the YR and FU are different in body size but not in egg production and egg characteristics.  Egg composition and shell quality however depended on the length of lay.  The NI chickens laid both white and tinted eggs which are different in some characteristics.|Theses Collection|egg characteristics/body weight/shank length/feed intake/D-Base IV/Statistical Analysis Systems (SAS)/shanks*||||||TADESE, Olukayode Adewale|M| Growth and development of the body and reproductive tract of the female rabbit from birth to puberty.||||||M.Sc. | Babajide Somade.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Animal Science|1992.|||OAU |||||ix, 112p. |||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Rabbits possess various outstanding attribute and have great potential in meeting world food needs particularly in underdeveloped tropical countries. However, there is a need for more research to be undertaken for a more thorough exploration of all aspects of the animal performance under tropical conditions.  This study was, therefore, aimed at investigating some of the changes that characterise the growth of the body and reproductive tract of the female rabbit from birth to puberty.Linear parameters of the body and organs of the reproductive tract of 60 female rabbits slaughtered at ages 0, 28, 42, 56, 70, 84, 112, 126, 140, 168 days and on the first day after mating were measured.  Means and standard errors for all the parameters were computed and data were further subjected to one-way analysis of variance, and linear, polynomial, and allometric regression analysis.Most parameters of the carcass showed slow initial growth rates until 84 days after which growth became more rapid.  However, dressing %, lean: bone ratio, lean content and bone content of the carcass had lower growth rates than the body throughout the period of the experiment.The rate of ovarian growth was low (0.775) although positive in the first 42 days of life while the uterus and oviduct showed negative growth rates during the same period.  All 3 organs showed highest positive growth between 126 and 168 days.  Mating significantly increased the weights of the ovary and oviduct but did not affect the uterus. Furthermore, uterine and oviducal weight were most highly correlated with ovarian weight between 126 and 168 days and in the first 84 days of life while there was no significant correlation between the weight of the ovary and uterine or oviducal lengths except between birth and 42 days.The results of this study indicate that the growth of the body of the rabbit can be divided into 3 main phases: The first 6 weeks of life; the next 8 weeks (up to day 98); and the last 10 weeks (until 168 days), while the growth of the reproductive tract can be divided into 4 stages of development: from birth to 42 days; 42-98 days; 98-126 days; and a variable interval between 126 days and the time of mating.|Theses Collection|Rabbits/underdeveloped tropical countries./puberty/carcass/ovarian growth/Mating /*||||||ADEBAYO, Timothy Abiodun.|M|Pilot scale trials on Guinea hen weed Petiveria alliacea L. (phytolaccacea) as mosquito larvicide.||||||M.Sc.|Julius I. Olaifa.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Plant Science|1992.|||OAU ||||| x, 57p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The effects of the aqueous extracts and turbid distillate of Petiveria alliacea (L) (Phytolaccacea) on three mosquitoes Anopheles gambiae (vector of malaria parasites), Aedes aegypti (vector of the virus causing yellow fever) and Culex pipiens fatigans, vector of Wuchereria bancrofti were investigated in the laboratory (Temp. 2530oc , RH. 45-70%) and in the field.  The procedure involved a test of the larvicidal activities of the extracts of P. alliacea on the 2ndinstar larvae of the three species of mosquito.  The larvae were exposed to different concentrations (1, 3, 5 and 10% (v/v) of the extracts in 500cc beakers in the laboratory and in artificial ponds 135 x 60 x 50 cm in the field.  All treatments were replicated 3 times.  Further, bioassays were carried out to investigate whether the extracts had any deterrent effect on oviposition in the gravid females of the three species of mosquitoes, and a test on the eggs of the mosquitoes for possible ovicidal effect of the extracts.It was observed that both the aqueous extract the turbid distillate were larvicidal to the 2ndinstar larvae of the test mosquitoes in the laboratory.  A concentration of 10% (v/v) aqueous extract caused 100% mortality in all the larvae while 10% (v/v) of the turbid distillate caused 100% mortality of the larvae of Ae. aegypti and Cx. pipiens fatiqans respectively and 61% mortality of the larvae of An.  gambiae. In the field, there was no adult emergence from any of the ponds treated with 10% aqueous extract.  The activity of the turbid distillate in the field was lower than its activity in the laboratory. The 10% concentration of the distillate showed effective oviposition deterrence to gravid females of Ae. aegypti and Cx. pipiens fatigans but none of the extracts was ovicidal. The study has shown that the extracts of P. alliacea could be used as a larvicide and oviposition deterrent to gravid females at breeding sites of mosquitoes.|Theses Collection|aqueous extracts/turbid distillate/Anopheles gambiae (vector of malaria parasites)/larvicidal/larvicidal/ pipiens fatigans/An.  gambiae/*||||||ADEGBITE, Adefemi John.|M|Effect of methods of establishment, planting date and population density of amaranth grain production. |||||| M. Phil.|O.A. Akinyemiju||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Plant Science|1992|||OAU ||||| xii, 91p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Effect of methods of establishment, planting date and population density on grain amaranth production were investigated.  Field studies were carried out to evaluate the influence of methods of establishment, planting date and population on the agronomic performance of the three Amaranthus species: Amaranthus cruentus L., A. hybridus L., and A. hypochondriacus L.  Also investigated in the screenhouse were the appropriate herbicides for controlling weeds in grain amaranths.The results showed that the Amaranthus species performed better in the early season than in the late season.  Generally, sends planted with sawdust emerged earlier than in the other methods of establishment.  Drilled, hillplanted and transplanted plants grew taller, had more inflorescences and produced higher grain yield than sawdusttreated plants.Generally, the amaranth species performed better in the May and June planting dates than in the August or September planting dates. plants were taller with more branches, longer inflorescences, larger leaf area and better grain yields in May and June than in August and September plantings.  Grain yield per plant was highest at 40,000 plants/ha. However, the highest grain  yield/ha irrespective of the species and date of planting was obtained at the highest population density of 160,000 plants per ha. A. hypochondriacus produced the highest grain yield of 917 and 886 kg/ha in May and June, respectively at 160,000 plants/ha.  In the screenhouse, the amaranthus species responded  similarly to the herbicide treatments; alachlor, diuron, metolachlor, and metribuzin were phytotoxic to the amaranth plants when applied preemergence, irrespective of the time of application, while imazaquin was lethal to the plants.  Alachlor, diuron, metolachlor and metribuzin applied postemergence were slightly toxic to the plants.  However, the toxicity symptoms disappeared later and subsequent growth and grain yield per plant were not adversely affected.  Bentazon was slightly toxic to the plants irrespective of the time of application and this toxicity was also overcome at the later stage of growth.  At the two times of application, fluazifopbutyland sethoxydim were nonphytotoxic to the plants irrespective of the species.  The plants treated with bentazon, fluazifopbutyl and sethoxydim, irrespective of the time of application, had similar length and dry weight of inflorescence and grain yield per plant with the control, indicating that these herbicides can be used selectively weed control in grain amaranth.|Theses Collection|grain amaranth production/inflorescences/hypochondriacus/Bentazon/Alachlor/diuron/metolachlor /metribuzin*||||||EVBUOMWAN, Felix Osaruironomwan.|M|Effect of herbicides and water regimes on weed control in a flood irrigated rice field at Itoikin in Epe Local Government area of Lagos State.||||||Ph.D.|||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Plant Science |1992|||OAU |||||xii, 87p. |||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|A survey of weed species and evaluation of four rice (Oryza sativa L.) herbicides: piperophos (O Odipropyl) s2methylpiperidicino carbonyl methylphosphoroditionate) + propanil (N(3,4dichlorophenyl) propanamide), bentazon (3(lmethylethyl)  (1H)2,1,3benzothiadiazin  4(3H) one 2,2dioxide) + propanil, Oxadiazon (3(2,4dichloro5(lmethylethoxy) Phenyl)5(l,ldimethylethyl1,3,4oxadiazol2(3H) one) + propanil and propanil alone applied at two weeks after sowing rice were carried out over two cropping seasons in the Itoikin flood irrigated rice project of OgunOsun River Basin Development Authority. Piperophos + propanil was applied at the rate of 3.9 kg a.i/ ha and 7.8 kg a.i/ha, bentazon + propanil at 4.0 kg a.i./ha and 8.0 kg a.i/ha, oxadiazon + propanil at 2.0 kg a.i/ ha and 4.0 kg a.i/ha, as well as propanil alone at 2.9 kg a.i/ha and 5.8 kg a.i/ha.  The most effective herbicides from these trials were thereafter evaluated under shallow (7.5 cm  10 cm) and deep water regimes (10 cm  17 cm) at four and six weeks after sowing rice. The results showed that Echinochloa colona (L.) Link and Cyperus rotundus L. were the most abundant and persistent weed species.  These two species were the least controlled by all the herbicides evaluated.  Among the herbicides, bentazon + propanil at 8.0 kg a.i/ha and piperophos + propanil at 3.9 and 7.8 kg a.i/ha were the most effective based upon the level of weed control and rice grain yield; the performance was not significantly different from the hand weeded control.  Piperophos + propanil at both rates applied at six weeks after sowing rice and under deep water regime gave the highest grain yield of 4 metric tons/ha. Following identification of the noxious weed species (F. colona and C. rotundus) from the field experiments, morphological and physiological responses of E. colona, C. rotundus, Ageratum conyzoides L. and Oryza sativa L. to a postemergence application of propanil were studied in order to understand the basis of their differential tolerance to the herbicide.  Propanil retention on the plant surface, uptake into the tissues and translocation to the subterranean parts of the four plant species were evaluated.  The leaf angle, leaf area, stomata density and distribution, presence of trichomes on the plant surface, thickness of epicuticular wax of the plant species were also studied.  Propanil residue in the plant tissues were determined using a precalibrated uv/vis spectrophotometer at 248 nm; the leaf area, leaf angle and stomata density were determined quantitatively, while the presence of trichomes on the plant surfaces, stomata distribution and thickness of epicuticular wax were observed under a high powered (x400) compound microscope.  Photomicrographs of the transverse sections (20 um) of the leaves of the four plant species were also taken for more detailed study.Results showed that A. conyzoides retained more propanil on the leaf surface than the other plant species; it also translocated more propanil to the stem and root than the other species.  Uptake into the plant tissues was also are in A. conyzoides than the other plant species.  Only A. conyzoides possessed trichomes on the plant surface; it also had the thinest epicuticular wax. These factors may be responsible for the observed susceptibility of A. conyzoides to propanil toxicity in the field.  There was limited or no translocation of propanil to the stem and root of E. colona, O. sativa and C. rotundus. It is inferred that the low retention of propanil on the leaf surface, little uptake into the plant tissues and limited or no translocation of propanil to the roots of E. colona and C. rotundus are important factors responsible for the tolerance of these weeds to propanil.|Theses Collection|weed species/Echinochloa colona (L.)/Cyperus rotundus L./Propanil retention/trichomesPhotomicrographs/ A. conyzoides/C. rotundus/E. colona/propanil.*||||||KING, Abu Bakarr.|M|Secondary school principalship and management challenges in a period of economic recession in the Gambia.||||||M.A. Ed.|Adekola Junaid.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Educational Administration and Planning |1992.|||OAU |||||ix, 138p. |||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. A validated questionnaire was used for the collection of data from 240 respondents.  Two hundred and two or 84.17% of them completed the questionnaires. Each of the null hypotheses generated for the study was tested at 0.05 level of significance using Chisquared statistical analysis.  For each of the four hypotheses, there was a significant difference between the frequency of responses for and against identified challenges relating to principals' administrative role, personnel, financial and school plant management.The results of the analyses showed that there was an increase in the number of unqualified teachers in the secondary schools during the period of economic recession in the Gambia. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The performance of two maize hybrids (832213 and 84258) and an open  pollinated variety (TZSRW1) that are currently grown in Nigeria was evaluated for optimum grain yield performance.  The objectives were to evaluate the response of the maize varieties to three stand densities: one, two and three plants per stand; to determine the optimum number of plants per hill for achieving maximum grain yield; and to determine the most appropriate withinrow spacing that would give optimum grain yield performance of the maize hybrids.The experimental area was ploughed and harrowed the maize, varieties were sown using four withinrow spacings of 24, 30, 40 and 60cm, and one between  row spacing of 71cm. For each withinrow spacing there were one, two or three plants per hill. Each plot consisted of four rows, 6m long.  The early and the late season plantings were carried out in 1988 on two locations whose soils had been subjected to continuous cropping for about ten years at the Obafemi Awolowo University Teaching and Research Farm.The experiment was replicated three times and the experimental design was a Randomized Complete Block (RCBD) with factorial arrangement. Data on agronomic traits included the following parameters: daysto50% tasselling and daysto50% silking, plant height and ear height measurements, ear number per ha field weight, shelling percentage and grain yield per ha.  All data were subjected to analysis of variance.  Significant means were separated using the least significant difference (Lsd) test.  A regression analysis was performed to determine the nature of yield response of maize varieties at the different withinrow spacings at one, two or three plants per hill. The maize cultivars differed significantly in their grain yields and number of ears per plot. The openpollinated variety (TZSRW1) and the white hybrid (832213), gave the highest grain yields and the highest number of ears, ha1 optimum economic grain yields were achieved at one plant per hill (r2 =0.90) using 24 cm withinrow spacing to give 55,555 plants hal and at two plants per hill (r2 =  0.71) using 30 cm withinrow spacing to give 88,888 plants ha-1. There was no significant difference in the grain yield values obtained at the two plant population levels.  Therefore, optimum economic grain yield can be obtained in this ecological zone by planting at a withinrow spacing of 24 cm and at one plant per hill, giving 55,555 plants, ha1|Theses Collection|hybrids/agronomic traits/Randomized Complete Block (RCBD)/silking/tasselling/cultivars/*||||||NURUDEEN, Owolabi Oladeji.|M|Effects of long-term cultivation and fertility management on soil physical characteristics.||||||M.Sc.|P.O. Aina||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Soil Science|1992|||OAU |||||xiii, 118p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Effects of 22 years of continuous cultivation and fertility management on some physical characteristics (particle size distribution, dispersion ratio, bulk density, total porosity, water infiltration and water retention) of Iwo soil were studies.  The study was aimed at evaluating changes in these soil characteristics and also to analyse their spatial dependence as may have been affected by cultivation.  Two adjacent sites (cultivated and forest-fallow) were selected and used for this study.  To enable the use of geostatistical technique, soil sampling was carried out at regular intervals of 2m (except for infiltration test run at 8m interval) on transects established along two principal directions (North-South and East-West).Results from the study indicated coarser texture, reduced aggregate stability, increased density (1.2 to 1.6 Mgm-3) and reduced total porosity (54 to 38%) as a result of long-term cultivation.	These adverse changes in soil conditions resulted in significant reduction in soil infiltrability (87 to 28 cm/hr) and water retention (28 to 18%).  Increased rate of NPK fertilizer application, particularly single Nitrogen treatments aggravated soil degradation.Spatial analysis by geostatistical technique indicated that soil properties under forest-fallow had no spatial structure.  However, under cultivation, soil density, total porosity, clay and sand contents were anisotropically spatially dependent within a range of 32m. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The main focus of this study was to appraise the planning and administration of adult literacy education programme in terms of its efficiency (as judged by the adequacy of the production resources) and effectiveness (as judged by the quality of learners' result at the end of the cycle) in Ife North, South and Central local government areas of Osun State. The study also examined the number of organised groups coopted into the programme and the level of their involvement. It investigated the difference between the programme's planning and administration in the three local government areas.Two hundred and ten subjects were selected for the study. Stratified random sampling technique was used in the selection which involved Local Inspectors of Education (LIE), Local Adult Education Officers (LAEO), Adult Literacy Education Programme Supervisors (ALEPS), Adult Literacy Education Instructors (ALEI) and adult learners grouped into regular client (RC), the droppedout (DOG) and graduated ones (GRG).  The study lasted eight months, May  December 1991, and it involved eighteen literacy centres equally chosen from both towns and villages in the three local Government areas.  Questionnaires, Observation Sheets, Oral Interview and Achievement tests otherwise called  End-of-Cycle test were used to collect data for the study.  The data collected were analysed using simple percentages one way analysis of variance (ANOVA) and ttest for all the hypotheses generated for the study.  All the hypotheses were tested at 0.05 level of significance.The results of the study revealed that the extent of preparation, consultation and adoption given to the programme in the studied areas was inadequate.  Only four organised groups were involved in the programme and their involvement rate was 25.13%.  No qualified typist was employed and the Local Adult Education Officers were the 'alpha and omega'. Thus, the coordination of some administrative activities were hindered. The performance of adults in the programme was also hardly fair (X=33.06%). Test plants were raised in the screenhouse and five actively growing seedlings per test plant were mechanically inoculated with each of the isolates.  Five differential hosts namely: Chenopodium amaranticolor, Dattura stramonium, physalis angulata, P. floridana and P. peruviana were used to distinguish the four isolates into symptomatologically distinct strains. PVMVM infected all the five differential hosts.  It infected C. amaranticolor locally and D. stramonium, P. angulata, P. floridana and P. peruviana systemically.PVMVB infected four of the differential hosts systemically namely:  D. stramonium, P. angulata, P. floridana and P. peruviana but failed to infect C. amaranticolor. PVMVS a lso infected four of the differential hosts.  It infected C. amaranticolor locally and P. angulata, P. floridana and P. peruviana systemically but failed to infect D. stramonium.   PVMV6B failed to infect any of the five differential hosts.The four isolates of PVMV were also differentiated by the type of symptoms that they induced on some susceptible test plants.  D. metel, Nicotiana glutinosa x N. clevelandii and N. tabacum cv.  Local showed good symptomatological differences. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The study examined the relationship between principals' management styles and tutors' task performance in the Schools of Nursing and Schools of Midwifery in Oyo State.  It was designed to find out differences in the response of the subjects concerning the management styles of their school principals and the tutors' level of task performances when the subjects were grouped according to status, gender and type of schools.A purposive sampling technique was used to select 550 students and 100 nurse tutors from the 11 Schools of Nursing and Schools of Midwifery. The investigator used a 45item questionnaire tested for reliability and validity to elicit response from the 650 subjects. A structured interview was also used to collect additional information from the school principals of the respondents on the type of management styles they perceived of themselves.  Data collected were analysed using descriptive statistics, Pearson's correlational analysis, and test to determine statistically significant difference in the subjects responses at 0.05 level of probability.The findings from the study showed that there was a low and insignificant positive relationship between principals' management styles and tutors' tack performance (r = 0.36) while a moderately positive although statistically insignificant relationship was found between participatory tendency management and task performances (r = 0.50). The responses relating management styles with tutors' task performance varied according to status and type of schools of the subjects.  Furthermore, a moderately positive, but statistically insignificant relationship existed between management styles and cognitive component of task performance (r = 0.48). However, this contrasts a low and insignificant but positive relationship between management styles and interpersonal relations (r = 0.34), and very low and insignificant but positive relationship between management styles and professional competence (r = 0.17).  Further analysis revealed significant differences between the responses of the subjects from the Schools of Nursing and Schools of Midwifery on the principals' management styles (t = 2.77), and tutors' task performances (t = 6.64) respectively. The  study also showed significant differences between the tutors and students' responses to the principals' management style items (t =  1.99), and the tutors' task performance instrument (t = 4.89). Lastly, a significant difference was reported between the male and female subjects' responses on the tutors' task performances (t = 2.67), contrary to no significant difference found between the two sexes on principals' management style instrument (t = 0.17).   |Theses Collection|Midwifery/probability/professional competence/cognitive component/interpersonal relations/task performance/*||||||ADEGBULUGBE, Afolake Adefunke|F|Correlates of problem solving behaviours of undergraduate students.||||||M.A. Ed.|A. The correlates examined were sex, age, academic ability and academic specialisation.  Four null hypotheses were postulated for the investigation. The sample for this study consisted of 306 undergraduate students of the Obafemi Awolowo University lleIfe, Nigeria.  They were chosen by stratified randomisation from four faculties of the university, namely Faculties of Arts, Law, Science, and Health Sciences. The Research Instrument for the study was the problem Solving Inventory (P.S.I.) which is used to assess people's perception of their personal problem solving behaviours and attitudes. The data obtained were analysed using the point biserial and eta correlation coefficients. The result of the study indicated that there is a significant relationship between the age of students and their personal problem solving behaviour (P < 0.05). Specifically, students of different age groups differ in their problem solving behaviour which tends to compare with age.  The result of the study also showed that there is a significant relationship between the academic ability of students and their problem solving behaviour (P < 0.05). In essence, students of high academic ability are better in their problem solving behaviour than students of average or low academic ability.  Furthermore, the result of the study indicated that there is no significant relationship between the sex of students and their problem solving behaviour (P > 0.05). The study also revealed that there is no significant relationship between the problem solving behaviour of students and their academic specialisation in Art or Science. The study revealed that age groups and varying academic abilities, unlike academic specialisation and sex, should be considered in differential counselling for undergraduate students.|Theses Collection|null hypotheses/stratified randomisation/point biserial/eta correlation/differential counselling*||||||AWOYELE, Ireti Folasade.|F|The influence of some personal and psychological variables on vocational exploratory behaviour of secondary school students in Ondo State.|||||| M.A. Ed.|J.A. The study also examined the influence of psychological variables such as interest and values on the vocational exploratory behaviour of its subjects.The subjects of the study were 500 students selected through stratified random sampling, from five secondary schools in Ondo State.  School class and gender of subjects were the criteria for stratification.  The instrument used for data collection was a SelfConstructed Vocational Exploratory Behaviour Inventory which was adequately tested for validity and reliability. Data gathered were analysed using ttest, parametric ANOVA and Correlations. All hypotheses were tested at 0.05 level of significance.The results of the study showed that there are statistically significant differences in the vocational exploratory behaviour of male and female subjects (P < 0.05 (S)).  The male subjects of the study exhibited significantly higher vocational exploration than the females. Similarly, age of subjects was found to bear significant influences on their vocational exploration (P < 0.05(NS)).
