Adejumo //Y. Onibokun||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Educational Foundations and Counselling|1992||| OAU |||||x. 177p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This study investigated test item bias in 80 multiple items of Junior Secondary Certificate Examination (JSCE) Mathematics.  It compared biased items obtained from Transformed Item Difficulty (TID), ThreeParameter Item Characteristic Curve (ICC3) and Scheuneman chi square approaches.  The result of the JSCE Mathematics administered to 4,390 candidates in 41 Federal Government Colleges in Nigeria was the unit of analysis.  The primary objective was to see if any bias was likely to occur by using any of the three selected techniques based on group membership.Factor analysis was done on the JSCE Mathematics items to determine if the items could be considered unidimensional.  The three methods were used to examine item bias separately using the malefemale, urbanrural and ChristianIslamic comparative groups of the sample.  The factor analysis revealed oblique rotation correlational values that ranges between 0.177 and 0.023. This signifies statistical independence as well as  undimensionality of the 80 JSCE Mathematics items.The TID analysis indicated deviance in the rank ordered delta values among the three sets of discrete groups.  The trend of relationships among the malefemale, urbanrural and ChristianIslamic comparative groups were 0.916, 0.959 and 0.968 respectively.  This relationship did not support the bias evident in the rank ordered delta values comparison.  Similarly, the ICC3 analysis established bias in the estimated parameters categorization across the three dichotomised groups.  The bias was confirmed in the similarity of the ICC3 base line bivariates across the three dichotomised groups. The Scheuneman chi square analysis confirmed bias among the JSCE Mathematics items at df = 3; p < 0.05. A congruent relationship was established among the extreme items identified as biased in each of the comparative groups by the respective bias techniques.  The agreement among the detection methods revealed that the identification of biased items is not a random process.  This therefore showed that, there is an evidence of consistent bias in JSCE Mathematics items upon which the selected methods converge. The Scheuneman chi square and TID detection methods were found to be conceptually and computationally simple and reliable, while the ICC3 approach was discovered to be a thorough, technical and complex procedure.|Theses Collection|Transformed Item Difficulty (TID)/ThreeParameter Item Characteristic Curve (ICC3)/Scheuneman chi square/dichotomised groups/congruent relationship*||||||FAWOLE, Adekunle Nathanael.|M|Evaluation of the readability of selected secondary school mathematics textbooks in Oyo and Ondo States.||||||M. A. Ed.| J.A. Adejumo||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Educational Foundations and Counselling|1992|||OAU |||||xii, 103p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The purpose of this study was to evaluate the readability indices of three selected mathematics textbooks and the perception of the subjects of the study on the readability of the mathematics textbooks.  Subjects were 301 senior secondary school two (SSS II) students selected by stratified sampling in seven secondary schools from seven local government areas in Ondo and Oyo States.  A rating scale was used to find out subjects' evaluation of the textbooks while the Fry graph readability method was employed to determine the readability of the textbooks.  Three passage from each textbook were sampled for this purpose.  The data obtained were analysed using descriptive statistics.The response of the students on the rating scale revealed that the authors of the selected textbooks did not show areas where the text materials were applicable in various out-of-school situations.  Their responses further indicated that the vocabulary used in the textbooks was not within the students' level of understanding, and words were not repeatedly used to bring about better understanding.  Further, their ratings showed that the sheets of the textbooks were thin and easily tore off and their covers were not durable.  Many of the sentences were too long and statements were clumsy.  While the students' responses on the rating scale indicated that the examples provided at the end of each section were inadequate and not easily understood. It also showed that the exercises in the textbooks were not very related to the examples preceding them and were generally more than necessary.However, the responses of the students on the rating scale with regard to cartoons, maps, graphs, charts, tables, and other pictorial sources in the textbooks revealed that they were helpful to their understanding of mathematics.  The letter prints of the textbooks were observed to be bold and clear and sizes of the type were legible.  Hence, fluent reading was made easy.  The responses of the students on the rating scale showed further that the design of the letters, lighting and ink colour were good enough and sizes of the margin and of the pages were moderate.  Also, the text materials were found to progress from simple to the more difficult and success in one learning task was able to reinforce subjects to progress to another.  Finally, the Fry graph readability technique indicated that the textbooks were appropriate for the age of the class of student readers for which they were written.|Theses Collection|readability indices/Fry graph readability/vocabulary*||||||OYELADE, Ayotunde Francis.|M|Exploration of developmentalism and its relevance to secondary school education in Oyo State. |||||| Ph.D. |A.I. Aladejana. //A.S. Onyehalu||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, |1992.|||OAU|||||xii, 218p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The purpose of the study was to conduct an explorative philosophical analysis into the term developmentalism in order to find out if it can properly be regarded as an ideology, or a philosophy of education, and if it has relevance to Secondary School education in Oyo State.  The concept of an ideology and the concept of a philosophy of education were therefore compared with the concept of developmentalism to find out if developmentalism is an ideology or a philosophy of education. Moreover the implementation of the concept of developmentaliam (such as implementation of moral education, vocational, scientific, and technological education) was analysed to find out if developmentalism is a relevant to Secondary School education in Oyo State.Data were collected through the use of relevant library materials interview reports and analysis of concept of developmentalism in education, particularly in Oyo State Secondary school education. Philosophical method was used to analyse the data collected. Thus language analysis of concepts like 'development', 'developmental education', 'developmentalism', and 'philosophy of education' was used to clarify and determine the limits of concepts and find out the relationship between developmentalism and secondary school education in Oyo State.  In this regard, phenomenological analysis, formal logic and argument by analogy were used to analyse the data.It was found that developmentalism is an eclectic educational theory based on the educational theories already available in the philosophies of realism, pragmatism and cultural reconstructioniam. Developmentalism however places much emphasis on the development of the Third World through the activities of the schools. It maintains that the schools should champion social reform activities that would urgently promote the development of our society.  Such activities should include the promotion of indigenous technology vocational orientation as well as scientific, religious, and moral instructions. In effect, developmentalism tends towards eventual identification with cultural reconstructionism.  In addition, developmentalism was found to be relevant to secondary school education in Oyo State because of its emphasis on the development of the wholechild (that is the development of moral, scientific, technological, vocational, religious, and other aspects of the child).  While Oyo State Secondary School education actually encourages scientific, technological vocational and religious developments of the child, it does not seem to sufficiently encourage moral, social, emotional, and agricultural developments.  Finally, library facilities and mass education which are needed for a thorough-going secondary education are not adequately provided.|Theses Collection|explorative philosophical analysis/developmentalism/phenomenological analysis/formal logic/argument by analogy/philosophies of realism/pragmatism/cultural reconstructioniam*||||||OYETUNJI, Lydia Olutoyin. |F|An evaluation of cognitive tasks in selected nursery schools in Ondo State.|||||| M. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The study evaluated the cognitive tasks taught in the nursery schools in Ondo State.  The research investigated the cognitive tasks that are taught in the nursery school under the dimensions of perception, conception and language. The cognitive tasks were measured against the stipulation of the Nigerian Education Research Council (NERC).  The study also investigated whether the appropriate teaching aids for cognitive tasks are made available in the nursery schools.The subjects of the study were one hundred and twenty nursery schools employees, comprising of 24 headteachers and 96 classroom teachers.  Twenty four nursery schools located in eight local government areas of Ondo State were selected to ensure that all areas of the state were adequately represented.  The instrument used in the study consisted of the checklists and one questionnaire.  The checklists were the Teaching Aids Availability Inventory (TAAI) and the Teaching Aids Usage Inventory (TAUI) while the questionnaire was the Cognitive Tasks Questionnaire (CTQ).  The instruments were personally administered by the investigator. The resulting data were analyzed using percentages, chisquare tests, ttest and the analysis of variance (ANOVA) at the 0.05 level of significance.The results of statistical analysis showed that 50% of the nursery schools do not carry out cognitive tasks recommended by the Nigerian Educational Research Council. There is also a general neglect of tasks geared towards the development of perception in the child.  As regards the availability of teaching aids, the results reflected nonprovision of cognitive teaching aids in 50% of the nursery schools used.  The frequency with which teachers engage the pupils in cognitive tasks was also found to be influenced by teachers experience, teacher's gender, teacher's qualification and the type of school but was not influenced by the age of the teacher. On the ability of the teachers to make proper use of teaching aids, the results showed that this was dependent on experience of the teacher but independent of teacher's gender, teacher's age, teacher's qualification and type of school.|Theses Collection|cognitive tasks/perception/conception/Nigerian Education Research Council (NERC)/analysis of variance (ANOVA)/chisquare tests/*||||||OKOBI, Chike Paul.|M|Effects of audio-taped enrichment segment in teaching the structure of English on students performance in a college of education.||||||M.A. Ed.|J.I. The experimental design used was pretest posttest control.  Five hypotheses were generated for the study. The subjects were four hundred junior secondary school (JSS) two students who were randomly selected from secondary schools in Ilesa Local Government area of Osun State. They were divided into two equal groups. The first group was experimental group, and the other the control group. Using their last promotion examination scores in mathematics, each of the two groups was categorised into high, average and low ability subgroups. The instrument used for collecting data was a fortyitem multiple choice achievement test designed and validated by the researcher. After the pretest, the experimental group was taught relevant mathematical terms in solid geometry for two weeks. The remaining four weeks were used in teaching both the experimental and the control groups selected topics in solid geometry. The posttest was administered to the two groups after six weeks.  Data collected was subjected to the ttest and Ftest analyses.The comparison of the performances of high ability subjects in the two group revealed that those who were taught mathematical terms were significantly better than those who were not taught the terms, at P <0.05. In the case of the average ability groups the same result as above was obtained at P < 0.05.  The low ability subjects also performed significantly better than those in the control low ability group at P < O.05. The comparison of the two groups on the whole showed that those who were taught mathematical terms performed significantly better than their counterparts who were not taught the terms at P < 0.05. However, within the experimental group, the results showed that there were significant differences in performances in correlation to the ability groups at P < 0.05. The subjects were randomly assigned into three equal groups, two of which were the experimental groups and the other the control group. The three groups were exposed to the same topics in geometry using different instructional techniques for each group.The first group was exposed to geometry using the teacherconstructed geometrical models.  The second group was taught the same way but was in addition encouraged to construct its own geometrical models. The third group which served as the control, was taught the same topics using the traditional method without the use of any aid. The experiment lasted for a period of six weeks.The instrument used was a fortyitem multiple choice achievement test based on geometry. The three groups were pretested before the commencement of the experiment.  One way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was computed to find out if their mean performance was significant.  The result of the ANOVA showed that the groups had the same mathematical background before the experiment.  The effect of teaching geometrical models on the experimental groups was found using the 't' test statistics.The results of the study showed that students who were taught using geometrical models performed significantly better than those that were taught using traditional method (P < 0.05).  Students who constructed geometrical models also performed significantly better than those that were exposed to traditional method (P < 0.05). The study further revealed that there is no significant difference in the mean performance of the two experimental groups (P < 0.05). E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Home assignment is one of the major components of a lesson plan.  A lesson plan is assumed to be incomplete if the teacher does not make provision for home assignment. However, not much systematic effort has been made on examining the relationship between home assignment and students' achievement in Social Studies at the Junior Secondary Schools (JSS). This study is, therefore, an attempt at examining the effects of home assignment on JSS achievement in Social Studies. Specifically, it examined the effects of two types of home assignment namely, Study Guide Questions and Guided Inquiry, on students' achievement in two units of social studies syllabus for JSS Class II. It also examined the relative effectiveness of study guide questions and guided inquiry on students' achievement in social studies.  The study involved 300 students and nine social studies teachers from nine JSS Class II in Ilesa Local Government area.  These schools were randomly selected from twenty-one co-educational JSS which had been clustered into three zones using proximity as the criterion.  Two research instruments, the course units and a fifty item achievement test based on the two units were used for the study.  The course units were on development and social changes in Nigeria over time. The achievement test was used both as a pretest and post-test. The scores in the pretest and the posttest for the three groups were collected and analysed using the one way analysis of variance and the ttest for pairwise comparison.  All the research hypotheses were tested at probability level of 0.05.The results of the hypotheses tested showed that students performed better in Social Studies at JSS when classroom teaching was complemented with specific home assignment than situations where no definite assignments were given. It was also discovered that students' achievement was better when study guide questions were used than when learners were not given definite home assignment.  Similarly, learners in the guided inquiry performed better in the achievement test than their counterparts without home assignment.  Finally, students who used the study guide questions of home assignment performed better than students who used the guided inquiry type of home assignment. |Theses Collection|lesson plan/Guided Inquiry/co-educational/pairwise comparison/hypotheses/probability*||||||BORODE, Grace Oluwatoyin.|F|Effect of team teaching on performance in mathematics and physics among secondary school students in Oyo State||||||M.A. Ed.|S. A. Ed.|S.M. Opeola||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Special Education & Curriculum Studies|1992.|||OAU |||||viii, 94p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|In the past, apprentices in / and crafts like blacksmithery, wood carving, hunting and dyeing were mainly illiterates.  Modern Crafts like motor mechanic works, panel beating and motor electrical works are supposed to require rudiments of formal education with the acquisition of relevant skills. This research was therefore designed to determine the relevant knowledge of  physics that could help roadside motor mechanic apprentices in their job.The subjects were one hundred and nine motor mechanic apprentices randomly selected from Ile-Ife and Ibadan.  Sixtytwo of them completed secondary school while thirtythree were dropouts and the remaining fourteen were primary school leavers.  Seventyeight of them were taught essential principles in Physics and automechanics.  The remaining thirtyone apprentices formed the control group. Three research instruments were used. A questionnaire on personal data and practical performance were administered to each apprentice and his master.  In addition, a twentymultiple choice questions were used as preand post tests and an instructional package on essential physics for motor mechanics. The experiment lasted for six weeks. The four hypotheses generated were tested using Fratio and 't' test statistical techniques. Significance level was put at the P=0.05. The results indicated that apprentice motor mechanics who completed secondary school education performed better in their practical work than their counterparts who have lower educational background.  Assessment by the master mechanics revealed that they could identify spare parts and tools better than those with lower educational background.  They were also found to be superior in devising tools.  The apprentices who completed Secondary School and used the instructional package performed better in the posttest than their counterparts who did not use the package.  The apprentices who did not complete secondary school education but used the package also performed better in the posttest than their counterparts who did not use the package.  The performance in the posttest revealed that apprentices who completed secondary school education grasped the physics and automechanic principles taught in the parttime course than both the dropouts of secondary school and the apprentice that attained only up to primary six.|Theses Collection|apprentices/vocations/crafts/blacksmithery/wood carving/hunting/dyeing/motor mechanic/panel beating/motor electrical works/rudiments/instructional package/automechanic principles*||||||OSUNADE, Christiana Bolatipe.|F|The outcome of grouping method on the achievement of secondary school students in chemistry in some local government areas in Oyo state.||||||Ph.D. |S.M. Opeola.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Special Education & Curriculum Studies|1992. |||OAU |||||xv, 165p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The study investigated the outcomes of a systematic approach to the use of small group method in the teaching of Chemistry at the Senior Secondary School level.  The objective was to determine the effect of group method on the performances of students in some Local Government Areas in Oyo State.The subjects were seven hundred and eight Senior Secondary class one (SSI) students randomly selected from fourteen secondary schools in Oyo State.  They worked in three types of groups.  The first group was named WorkingInGroup (WIG) while the second group was named WorkingWithGroup (WWG).  The two groups served as the experimental groups.  The third group was named the IndividualLearningTechnique (ILT) which was the normal classroom setting serving as the control group.  After putting the students into the small groups, the Junior School Certificate Examination (JSCE) results were used to classify them into ability groups.  There were two instruments developed and validated for this study.  The first was "Chemistry Achievement Test" (CAT) which was a multiplechoice test used for the pretest and posttest.  The second was the Instructional package to guide each type of group.  The hypotheses generated were tested using such statistical analysis as ttest, One Way Analysis of Variance (ANOVA), and Scheffe test where applicable.At P = 0.05 significant level, the outcome of using the small group method was the significant differences recorded in the performance of those who worked in small groups when compared with the performance of those in the control group.  The achievement of those who worked in small groups improved and it was better than those whose classes were left in tact.  This was shown by the significant differences recorded in their performance in the posttest. ln the selfassigned small groups, the BelowAverage students benefitted more from smallgroup method than the AboveAverage students in the same type of group.  This was manifested by their performance which improved so much that in the posttest there was no difference between their performance and that of the AboveAverage students.  Generally, the achievement of the students who chose their own group members was better than the achievement of those whose members were teacherassigned.  This was shown by the significant difference recorded in the performance of the Below Average Students in the selfassigned small groups when compared with the performance of the BelowAverage Students in the teacherassigned small groups.  The Posttest scores showed that performance of the BelowAverage students in the selfassigned small groups compared favourable with the performance of the AboveAverage students in the same type of group.|Theses Collection|WorkingWithGroup (WWG)/WorkingInGroup (WIG)/IndividualLearningTechnique (ILT)/Chemistry Achievement Test(CAT)/hypotheses/Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)/Scheffe test/*||||||TYAGHER, Stephen Tsenongo.|M|A comparative study of the codes of practice (BS 8110: 1985 and NCPI 1: 1973) in the design of building structures.||||||M.Sc.|O.T. Olateju.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Building|1992.|||OAU |||||xviii, 286p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The research compared the performance of a reinforced concrete building structure, designed according to the British Code (BS 8110: 1985) and the Nigerian Code (NCP 1: 1973), at the ultimate and serviceability limit states.  The principles of plastic analysis and design incorporated in the British Standards: BS 8110 (1985) Part 1, Part 2 and Part 3: "Codes of practice for the Structural use of Concrete" were studied and applied to design a reinforced concrete building structure.  The same building was designed according to the Nigerian Code of Practice NCP1 (1973).  The comparison at the ultimate limit state was in terms of the plastic moments and the collapse loads; while that at the serviceability limit state was in terms of deflection, stresses and strains in both concrete and reinforcement.  A comparative analysis of the two designs obtained was then carried out in terms of safety and costs.The result indicated that the plastic moments given by the design according to BS 8110:1985 were 25.40KNm for the slabs and 118.30KNm for the beams.  The corresponding values for NCP 1: 1973 were 26.97KNm and 120.20KNm.  The collapse loads for bs 8110:1985 for the slabs and the beams were 18.50KN/m2 and 65.30KN/m2.  The plastic moments and the collapse loads given by BS 8110:1985 were, in principle, sufficiently close to the corresponding values given by NCP 1:1973.The serviceability limit state indicated that the design according to BS 8110:1985 gave lower deflections, lower strains, and lower stresses in concrete than the design according to NCP 1:1973.  Hence, BS 8110:1985 required less steel to resist the stresses.  The cost analysis indicated that the design according to BS 8110:1985 was N8,645.00 cheaper than that of NCP 1:1973. This represented about 3.3% of the total cost of the design. It was therefore concluded that while both codes produced satisfactory structures, BS 8110:1985 structure was cheaper and therefore more affordable.|Theses Collection|reinforced concrete building structure/serviceability limit states/Nigerian Code of Practice NCP1/*||||||JAIYEOBA, Taiwo Abimbola.|F|Landscape planning and management strategies for recreational centres in Ibadan metropolis.||||||M.Sc. |J.B. Falade.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Urban & Regional Planning| 1992.|||OAU|||||xiv, 145p. |||||||Endglish||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Most Nigerian urban areas are impoverished with recreation centres,  Despite this, the factors affecting leisure pursuits are on the increase and the demand for recreation is rising. Due to this fact, many people seek to satisfy their recreation demands by patronising these few recreation centres.  The results of this are congestion of the centres, overutilization of the existing facilities and landscape degeneration, One of the objectives of this study is to evaluate landscape planning concepts and management techniques for the recreation centres. Another objective is to study the landscape planning and management problems of these centres. The assessment of patronage level and factors affecting recreation pursuits is the third objective while the suggestion of planning strategies and design concepts aimed at improving recreation Centre's landscapes forms the last objective.Ibadan was chosen for this study because of its status as a major Nigerian urban area and as a state capital. The research methodology involves the administration of two sets of questionnaire to secure information from the management and visitors at recreation centres, The collected data were analyzed using the frequency distribution statistical method, the crosstabulation method, chisquare analytical method, and the Pearson Correlation Coefficients.The study reveals that the recreation centres lack adequate facilities that can meet the rising demand for recreation.  The existing facilities lack good maintenance and the landscapes of the centres face serious problems, both physical and financial.  The centres according to findings attract more visitors than they can cope with which has great consequences on the landscape and the facilities.  It is revealed that more urban recreation centres need to be provided and the existing ones improved. Various suggestions and recommendations are made based on the findings.  It is expected that the recreation needs of the urban dwellers will be adequately met if there is increase in the number of recreation centres, if there is provision of more facilities and if the management of the centres operate effective and efficient system of organization.|Theses Collection|recreation centres/leisure pursuits/congestion/crosstabulation method/chisquare analytical/Pearson Correlation Coefficients./urban area*||||||FANIRAN, Felix Olukayode.|M|The changing pattern of paralytic poliomyelitis in selected hospitals in Oyo State, Nigeria. ||||||M.Sc.|V.C.B. Nwuga.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Physiotherapy|1992|||OAU||||| xvi, 135p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Mass immunization strategy has been adopted in eradicating Paralytic Poliomyelitis in many parts of the world.  In Nigeria, previous mass immunization exercises appeared to be ineffective since occurrence rates of paralytic poliomyelitis continue to increase yearly. It is therefore necessary to evaluate the Expanded Programme on Immunization (EPI) currently being implemented in Oyo State in order to determine its effectiveness. The purpose of this study was to investigate the impact of the EPI on  paralytic poliomyelitis with a view to recommending appropriate measures to the Oyo State Government on how to finally eradicate the disease.Six hospitals were selected from the four geographical zones of the State.  A total of 4,339 polio cases recorded in the admission registers of the six selected physiotherapy departments and a total of 2,280 casenotes were studied. The monthly/annual occurrence rates and the percentage of paralytic polio to total patient load were determined from the records obtained through the admission registers. Other relevant information such as patient's sex, muscle groups and vaccination history were reviewed from the case notes.The data was analyzed using descriptive and inferential (Chi-square test) analysis. The results showed that the monthly incidence rate was 17 cases per million population for Oyo State while the annual incidence rate was 201 cases per million population.  This study found that the annual incidence of the disease decreased by 50.6% within the period 198089 with an average of 5.06% per annum.  The predicted percentage reduction for 1990 was projected to be 55.7% which is higher than the 50.0% predicted by the Federal Government indicating that the immunization programme has been effective.On Sex and age distribution, it was observed that children who were one to two years old constituted the largest group affected both before and after the EPI. There was, however, a significant increase (P < 0.05) among the over 3 years old after EPI.  Although males were more affected than females, there was no significant difference (P > 0.05) between the sexes. The mostly affected muscle group was the quadriceps both before and after the EPI.  At least two muscle groups were attacked per patient.  The  percentage of paralytic polio to total patient load ranged between 9.8% to 15.8% as against 3040% previously quoted in literature. It was also found that there was a significant difference (P < 0.001) between the vaccinated polio groups before and after EPI.The significant reduction in occurrence of paralytic polio in this study was attributed to the mass immunizations programme. The success of the programme was due to the  Mass Social Mobilisation Strategy. The study recommended:(i)	the setting up of a standing research committee to monitor the immunization programme with respect to paralytic polio,(ii)	the need to sustain the present programme so that the  incidence would remain permanently lowered,(iii)	That the immunized age group (02 years) be extended to (05 years),(iv)	Physiotherapists should take greater interest in the EPI.|Theses Collection|immunization/Paralytic Poliomyelitis/Expanded Programme on Immunization (EPI)/physiotherapy/vaccination/ Mass Social Mobilisation Strategy.*||||||OYELADE, Emmanuel Oguntoye|M|The practice of Islam in Yoruba land 1830-1983.||||||Ph.D. |I.A. Akinjogbin||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, History|1992.|||OAU|||||xv, 522p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This thesis aimed at investigating the various elements in Islam and Yoruba religious culture that had been, and are still been employed by Yoruba Muslims of Western Nigeria to foster unity, peace, and progress in a pluralistic society.  It further attempted an assessment of the factors and their effects on the expansion of Islam in Western Nigeria.  The thesis also aimed at correcting certain misconception about Islamic faith.The methodology employed included a comparison and an evaluation of both written and oral information; a phenomenological method which tries to assess the thought-patterns, emotional feelings, and practical responses of the various religious groups constantly interacting in the study area.  It also included a sociological approach which employs sociological methods of evaluation.  It further involved a documentary method used for analysing both primary and secondary sources.  Among the primary sources used were oral data and archival documents such as colonial reports, newspapers and mission reports.  These were supplemented by secondary sources such as magazines, articles, theses, long essays, and works by historians, sociologists, politicians, religious scholars and legal specialists.It was found that Yoruba Muslims were tolerant, accommodating and progressive.  As a result, they won the admiration of the traditional worshippers.  This led to the peaceful expansion of Islam.  It was further found that the attitudes of Yoruba Muslims were firmly rooted in their liberalist and universalist views of God as king and provider for all human beings. In addition, the Quranic views about and His followers, the Muslims' loyalty to the Yoruba cultural heritage, and the acceptance of the realities of common socio-political aspirations of the Yoruba, all helped to foster unity, peace and progress in the heterogenous society.  The consequence of the above factors was that both Christian leaders and colonial administrators were well-disposed to Muslims.  They encouraged the Muslims to accept Western education and British rule.  As a result, the Christians lost the monopoly of Western Education as well as the jobs of the civil service.  Another consequence of the above factors was that Yoruba Muslims participated freely in festivals, inter-religious marriages, and accepted positions of authority as kings and rulers in Yoruba communities.|Theses Collection| Islam/pluralistic society/phenomenological method/liberalist/universalist/heterogenous society*||||||OYEYEMI, Yoonus Adetoyeje.|M|Effects of aerobic training on cardiovascular responses during head-down inversion. ||||||M.Sc.| J. A. Balogun//A. A. Ajayi||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Physiotherapy|1992|||OAU|||||xxii, 187p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Physical therapist employ tilting and headdown postures in certain therapeutic procedures.  Currently, the effect of patients physical fitness on cardiovascular responses during inversion therapy remain unexplored. This study was therefore designed to investigate the effects of aerobic training on cardiovascular responses during waist level headdown inversion. A 2 (groups) by 3 (time frames) experimental design was employed. Twentyone healthy male volunteers (23.42.1 years old) participated in the study.  The estimated maximal oxygen uptake (VO2max) determined using the Cooper's 1.5 miles run test. Twentyfour hours later, the subjects reported in the laboratory and assumed a quiet pronelying position for one hour on the inversion device. Subsequently, the heart rate (HR), systolic blood pressure (SBP) and diastolic blood pressure (DBP) were monitored for 10 minutes each in pronelying position and during headdown inversion from the waistline.  From the HR and blood  pressure measurement, the purse pressure (PP), mean arterial blood pressure (MBP), ratepressure product (RPP) and baroreflex sensitivity (BS) were derived using standard formulae. The subjects assigned to the experimental group (n = 10) were subjected to a 6 weeks aerobic exercise programme.  The exercise intensity was such as to increase heart rate to 6085% of the subjects age predicted maximal heart rate.  Subjects in the control group (n = 11) did not undergo any physical training. The estimated VO2max of all the subjects and their  cardiovascular responses during inversion were again examined at the third and sixth week of the study. Statistical evaluation was by a 2  factor repeated measures analysis of variance.  An alpha level of 0.05 was adopted in the study. There was a significant (p < 0.05) increase in HR,SBP, DBP, MBP, and RPP; and decrease in PP during headdown inversion.  Following six weeks of aerobic training, the subjects' estimated VO2max increased significantly (p < 0.05) from 47.717.06 ml. kg-1 min-1 to 56.914.23 ml. kg-1 min-1. No cardiovascular learning effect was noticed following repeated inversion procedures. The HR and RPP responses during inversion, as well as the resting HR were significantly (p < 0.05) following aerobic training. However, SBP, DBP, PP, MBP and BS were unaffected by aerobic training. The above findings suggest that improved aerobic fitness is associated with less stress being placed on the heart during headdown inversion.Based on the above findings, it is recommended that the headdown inversion procedure should be utilized with caution because of the marked increase in cardiovascular responses and decrease in PP obtained during inversion.  For safety purposes, it is necessary to monitor the cardiovascular responses of high risk subjects before, during and shortly after inversion therapy.  A knowledge of the patients aerobic fitness may assist the physical therapist in estimating the patients tolerance to headdown inversion.     |Theses Collection|Physical therapist/therapeutic/cardiovascular/aerobic/pronelying/systolic blood pressure (SBP)/diastolic blood pressure (DBP)/mean arterial blood pressure (MBP)/ratepressure product (RPP)/baroreflex sensitivity (BS)/olerance*||||||ADOGAME, Afeosemime Unuose.|M|The pentecostal movement among the Akoko-Edo people of Bendel State 1932-1982.|||||| M.A.|B. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The thesis examined the genesis, growth and development of the Pentecostal Movement among the Akoko-Edo people, Bendel State of Nigeria between 1932 and 1982.  Three Apostolic groups of Churches were focused on, namely: The Apostolic Church (T.A.C.), Christ Apostolic Church (C.A.C.) and Apostle Babalola Christ Apostolic Church (A.B.C.A.C.) or First Christ Apostolic Church (F.C.A.C.).The similarities, differences and the divisive trends among these Pentecostal groups were examined. The relevance of this movement to the rapid social change in the Akoko-Edo area was also brought into limelight.  The methodology adopted for the analysis and interpretation of data were the historical method and the hermeneutical phenomenological approach. The research was also based on oral and library sources and documents. This study revealed that ritual recognition is given to nature by the C.A.C. and A.B.C.A.C. whereas this is not the case in the other Pentecostal Movements with similar doctrine.  This makes their worldwide different from the other Pentecostal. Through the use of consecrated water, Christianity is being indigenised to suit the traditional culture.It was further discovered the A.B.C.A.C. broke away from the C.A.C.  not on doctrinal issues but factors such as administrative excesses, personality clashes. However, apart from some differences in the polity and doctrines, they seem to share common religious convictions.
