E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The thesis attempted  an exposition of Ifa divination as well as models of revelation manifested through prophecies, glossolalia, dreams, visions, auditions  and trances within some Aladura Churches in Ile-Ife.  It also sought to highlight the comparative elements of revelation in Aladura Christianity and Ifa divination in Yoruba religious tradition. The study further attempted to demonstrate the significance of interaction between Yoruba traditional religion and Aladura Christianity.The methodology employed is a combination of phenomenological approach and comparative analysis.  Worship services, ceremonies and rituals were observed in some selected Aladura Churches in IleIfe for a period of two years.  These religious manifestations were analyzed and then compared with Ifa divination.  Relevant literature including books, journals, newspapers and archival materials were also consulted.The study revealed that there are similarities between revelation in Aladura Christianity and in Ifa divination. These similarities are in the areas of invocation, in the use of the spoken words as well as in the diagnosis and the prescription of solutions to human existential problems.  The study also revealed that the apparent points of divergence could be found in the different claims of the source of their powers, in the paraphernalia of the two systems and in certain areas of their practices.The thesis concluded that the spirituality of the Yoruba is the basis upon which Ifa divination practice and Aladura models of revelation operate.  The relevance of this finding is that such a model of religious pluralism and interaction is essential to societal harmony and integration.|Theses Collection|Religion/Ifa divination/prophecies/trances/christianity/worship services/ceremonies/rituals/ *||||||OLAYINKA, Bolaji Olukemi.|F|A feminist-hermeneutical approach towards understanding the roles of some old testament valiant women.||||||M. A.|D. O. Olayiwola||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Religious Study|1992.|||OAU |||||ix, 186p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This study attempted a contextualization of the roles of three valiant Old Testament women in contemporary Nigerian Society, with special reference to the Better Life for Rural Women Programme. It also attempted a comparative analysis of the roles of three prominent women in Nigeria's historical past, namely: Emotan of Benin, Moremi of Ile Ife and Queen Amina of Zaria. A Feminist-Hermeneutical approach was adopted in the study particularly in the understanding of the meaning of 'ishshah in the Ancient Near East, the Old Testament and the Nigerian Cultural Society. In addition to a critical review of relevant literature, the oral interview method was adopted, based on an interview guide. The size selected for interview were twentyfive which included rural women, "Better Life Programme" officials, some members of Women Organisations in Nigeria and members of the Academic Community. The study revealed that women in different cultures and different periods perform similar roles  and are ascribed similar status in most human societies worldwide.  It also showed different ways in which women have exerted themselves in predominantly patriarchal societies.The study has given us an insight into the roles played by biblical women and how their roles could be contextualized and thus made meaningful in our contemporary Nigerian Society. The study concluded that since men and women were created equal in God's design and play complementary roles, women should be given the opportunity to contribute meaningfully to the development of the society.|Theses Collection|contextualization/comparative analysis/Feminist-Hermeneutical approach/'ishshah/patriarchal societies*||||||OGUNWALE, Joshua Abiodun|M|Ayewo awon afo onitumo pon-na ninu awon iwe kan ninu ede Yoruba.||||||M. A. | E. T. Olowookere.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Yoruba Language & Literature|1992.|||OAU |||||ix, 116p.|||||||Yoruba||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The main aim of this thesis was to examine ambiguities in some Yoruba literacy texts. Specifically, the study attempted to account for the transient nature of meaning by providing a framework for the triadic interaction that must exist between contexts, linguistic expressions and interpretations.  In addition, the thesis attempted a comparison of ambiguity with other semantic forms and proposed a classification of ambiguities.The methodology employed included the use of oral interviews among the native speakers of Yoruba language, and a critical study of poetic, prose and dramatic works in the Yoruba language, using Kress and Odell's Paraphrastic Criterion as a framework for descriptive analysis.  The study also used the method of classification based on the parameters of location, context, derivation and nature of the luci of ambiguity.  A contrastive analysis of ambiguity and various semantic forms such as anomaly, paraphrase, vagueness and synonymy was carried out.The thesis established that context specifications which are performed by qualifiers and modifiers in Yoruba are crucial to semantic output in the language.  The thesis also found that ambiguity is a product of a language system and linguistic behaviour. It was established that good orthography, paraphrasing and context specification are potent mechanisms for disambiguation.The thesis concluded that ambiguity, as a semantic form, could make the users of constituents as well as sentences more elastic and so refuted the popular belief that ambiguities are always a linguistic nuisance.|Theses Collection|Yoruba literacy texts/triadic interaction/linguistic expressions/comparison of ambiguity/poetic, prose and dramatic works/Kress and Odell's Paraphrastic Criterion/potent mechanisms for disambiguation*||||||YAKUBU, John Ademola|M|The proper law of contract.||||||Ph.D.|I.O. Agbede||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Law|1992.|||OAU |||||xxix, 320p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This work examined the development of private international law rules relating to contracts. The operation and adequacy of various theories formulated to cater for international contract problems were also examined. The modern formulation of the proper law of contract was subjected to critical legal flak. In order to appreciate the problems inherent in the practical application of the proper law of contract approach, standard form contracts device was discussed and equipment leasing contract was analyzed to show the fallacy in the conception that there is usually mutual  agreement that a contract should be governed by a particular law.The judicial inert and mechanical application of laws by the courts as well as inadequate statutory provisions to cater for contract problems were exposed to show the need for revaluation of existing rules and principles.Materials for this work were derived from primary and secondary sources.  Primary sources in this respect are private international law statutes, municipal statutes and court decisions. The secondary sources of information in respect of this work were derived from textbooks and articles in learned journals. Following our findings, this study concluded that the courts should not adopt a mechanical approach in determining the proper law. The courts should consider the facts of each case so that the decision of the court in each case would be in accordance with the dictates of justice.  We also advocated the need for the enactment of statutes in Nigeria to take care of commercial activities of international dimension.  We have also advocated the need to have more formalised economic cooperation not only in the West African subregion but also in the Continent of Africa in the face of current global economic depression.|Theses Collection|private international law/proper law of contract/legal flak/municipal statutes/judicial inert/global economic depression./private international law statutes*||||||ALEBIOWU, Gbenga.|M|Formulation studies on Datura metel Linn leaf as antispasmodic drug.||||||M.Sc|M.N. Femi-Oyewo||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Pharmaceutical Chemistry|1992|||OAU|||||xvi, 162p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Datura metel Linn (Solanaceae), a common medicinal plant in Nigeria, is an official substitute for Datura stramonium (foreign to Nigeria) and used as an antispasmodic drug because of its hyoscine content.  There is obvious possibility of utilising Datura metel leaves for local drug production in Nigeria if its formulation, toxicity and efficacy are established.D. metel powdered leaf has been formulated into compacts using wet granulation process. The effects of changes in particle size of D. metel powder and binder volume were studied.  Four different binders viz: polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP), gelatin, cassava starch and acacia were each used at concentrations of 25%w/w to determine the effect of binder type and concentration on the compacts formulated. The resulting granules were analyzed for mean size, size distribution and friability and their compacts tested for hardness, disintegration, friability and assayed for hyoscine content.The necessary toxicological test prior to plant drug formulation using D. stramonium as control was carried out of virgin female mice. Suspensions of both plants were administered to the mice and their toxicity assessed from histopathologic abnormalities observed in the small intestine, kidney and liver of the mice. Preliminary clinical trial was done using nonplacebo controlled cross-over method on the formulated compacts.  The antispasmodic efficacy of the compacts was compared with Buscopan (R), a known antispasmodic agent and the results analyzed using non-parametric statistics.Bigger and less friable granules resulting in stronger and less friable compacts with longer disintegration time were produced as the powder size, binder volume or concentration was increased.  Cassava starch, PVP and gelatin proved to be very good binders for D. Metel powder producing granules and compacts of good physical properties which remained stable on storage.  The physical properties of compacts with acacia binder varied significantly on storage.  The formulation factors considered; powder size, binder type and concentration did not affect the hyoscine content in the compacts.  Hyoscine content was found to be 0.23% and 0.30% in D. metel and D. stramonium respectively.  The D. stramonium was found to be relatively more toxic than D. metel and the observed histopathologic abnormalities were dose dependent.  The efficacy and duration of action for both Buscopan (R) and D. metel compacts were found to be statistically similar.|Theses Collection|Datura metel Linn (Solanaceae)/Datura stramonium/antispasmodic/hyoscine/polyvinylpyrrolidone/nonplacebo/Buscopan.*||||||EZEOMAH, Emenike|M|Bioavailability studies on different brands of quinine in man.||||||M.Sc.|F.A. Ogunbona.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Pharmaceutical Chemistry|1992. |||OAU|||||xi, 88p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The emergence of strains of plasmodium falciparum resistant to chloroquine and other antimalarial drugs has resulted in a renewal of interest in the use of quinine to treat severe cases of falciparum malaria. The bioavailability of three formulations of this drug, Quinine dihydrocholoride (intravenous solution), quinine sulphate capsule and quinine sulphate (Plain) tablets, were investigated in 12 healthy male volunteers in a randomised sequence, using a specific and sensitive reversedphase HPLC method. In a single dose study, 600mg of the capsules and plain tablets were administered orally after overnight fasting, and 600mg of the dihydrochloride in 500ml normal saline solution was given as a continuous intravenous infusion at constant rate over four hours. The results of this study indicate that the plasma quinine levels (AUC) for the dihydrochloride, sulphate capsules and tablets were 133.732.4, 92.9333.7, and 69.24.9 ugml-1 hr [Mean  S.D.] respectively. Quinine by intravenous infusion resulted in higher plasma levels than oral dosing. The plasma quinine concentrations during administration of the capsules and tablets were not significantly different (P > 0.05). The elimination halflives were 12.53.7, 10.72.4 and 10.080.9 hrs [mean + S.D.] for infusion, capsules and tablets respectively. The tmax and Cpmax were 2.70.8 hrs, 6.73 ugml-1 hr and 2.80.8 hrs, 4.60.4 ugml-1 [Mean  S.D.] for the capsules and tablets respectively. No significant differences were noted in the above parameters (P > 0.05).  However, inter and intrasubject variations were observed. The absolute bioavailability (F) were 0.880.6 and 0.710.4 [Mean  S.D.) for the capsules and tablets respectively.|Theses Collection|plasmodium falciparum/bioavailability/intravenous infusion/antimalarial drugs/quinine/Quinine dihydrocholoride/capsule/tablets.*||||||IBEWUIKE, Joseph Chukwuemeka. |M|Synthesis of some 1,3-diaryl-2-propanol derivatives. ||||||M.Sc.|F.O. Ogungbamila.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Pharmaceutical Chemistry|1992. |||OAU|||||xiii, 155p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.| 1,3-Diaryl-2-propanols are novel flavonoids of rare occurrence in nature. Scientific interest in their spectrum of bioactivities and structure-activity profile has prompted the search general synthetic route to 1,3Diaryl2propanol.  This work has explored one such route starting from chalcone which are the biogenetic precursor of 1,3Diaryl2propanol.The investigated synthetic route involved the conjugate reduction of chalcone to the corresponding hydrochalcols and their subsequent dehydration to 1,3diarylpropenes. Oxymercurationdemercuration of the 1,3diarylpropenes was expected to furnish the desired 1,3diaryl2propanol. Three chalcone, namely, chalcone, 2methoxychalcone and 2', 4', 3trihydroxychalcone were synthesised in 86.5, 83.7 and 40.6% yield, respectively, by ClaisenSchmidt condensation of appropriate starting materials.The major product of the direct hydride reduction of a chalcone was found to be the dihydrochalcol, although the reductions were complicated by a multiplicity of products. In addition, the yield of the dihydrochalcol in lithium aluminium hydride reductions was increased in the presence of a transitionmetal halide such as copper (I) chloride. The chalcone were reduced to the corresponding dihydrochalcones in good yield by catalytic transfer hydrogenation using tetrahydrofuran as solvent, cyclohexene as the donor, 10% Palladium-Charcoal as the catalyst, with an optimum reduction time of four hours.  Phenolic groups were found inert, while ferric chloride was observed to promote the conversion of the chalcone to the 1,3diarylpropane derivative, during transfer hydrogenation.Sodium borohydride adsorbed on alumina was found to be a more efficient reducing agent than the hydride alone, and quantitatively reduced the dihydrochalcones to the dihydrochalcols.  Dihydrochalcols may thus be most conveniently prepared by catalytic transfer hydrogenation of chalcone to the dihydrochalcones, followed by reduction with sodium borohydride adsorbed on alumina.Dehydration of the dihydrochalcols by oxalic acid gave the corresponding 1,3diarylpropenes as the major products.  Alternative dehydration  procedures using iodine and ferric chloride, respectively, were found inferior to oxalic acid dehydration. The 1,3diarylpropenes were found unreactive under the standard  oxymercurationdemercuration conditions.  Analogous experiments with the closely related stilbene revealed that the unreactivity may be intrinsic to alkylbridged diphenyl systems. The proposed synthetic route has thus been shown to be feasible up to the penultimate step, yielding the postulated 1,3diarylpropenes.  However, the unreactivity of the 1,3diarylpropenes to oxymercuration implies that an alternative rehydration procedure is required. If this is achieved, then a general synthetic route to 1,3diaryl2propanol starting from chalcone would have been developed.|Theses Collection|1,3-Diaryl-2-propanols/flavonoids/chalcone/biogenetic precursor/hydrochalcols/Oxymercurationdemercuration/2methoxychalcone/2', 4', 3trihydroxychalcone/tetrahydrofuran/cyclohexene/Palladium-Charcoal/Phenolic/ferric/oxalic.*||||||KEHINDE, Ibiyemi Oluyemisi.|F|Synthesis of novel quinoline derivatives. ||||||M.Sc. |J.O. Oluwadiya.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Pharmaceutical Chemistry|1992.|||OAU|||||ix, 105p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Quinoline derivatives have been used extensively in medicine. Quinine, one of the naturally occurring quinoline is used as an antimalarial drug. Its structure forms the template for the synthetic antimalarials, for example, chloroquine and amodiaquine.Quinoline have found usage as antiamoebic agents, for example, vioform.  They have also been used as antimicrobial agents, for example, nalidixic acid and its derivatives. Quinoline have been obtained using the classical Skraup method or its synthetic variations.ln this work, quinoline have been prepared through novel routes using the ClaisenSchmidt method to form 2'aminochalcones which are the starting materials for the preparation of the quinoline. The 2'aminochalcones underwent acid catalysed cyclocondensation reaction to form 2,3dihydro2phenyl4-quinolones. Sodium Borohydride reduction of the dihydroquinolones in alcohol gave 2,3dihydro2phenyl4quinolols which underwent catalytic dehydration reaction with toluene suffonic acid in toluene at reflux to give two products viz, 2phenyl quinoline and [1H]2,3,4tetrahydroquinolines in fairly good yields instead of the theoretically expected 2phenyl2hydro[IHIquinoline.The structures of the synthesized compounds were unambiguously proved by use of physicochemical techniques, viz, lr, 1H13C Nmr and Ms. The amino group of the chalcone and quinolones appeared in the lr spectra at 32903420 cm1 while the carbonyl functions were prominent at 16201720cm1. The aromatic C=C absorption appeared at 15901610cml. The hydroxyl groups of the quinolol appeared at 32503380cm1. The 1Hnmr spectra of all the compounds are consistent with the proposed structures. The 13C nmr spectra for the quinolones showed the presence of carbonyl carbon at 192194 ppm while the Omethoxy carbon appeared at 5659 ppm. The mass spectra of all the compounds showed molecular ion, M+, consistent with the molecular weight of the compounds but of varying intensities. The molecular ions of the chalcone, quinolones, quinolols were not the base peak ions but the molecular ion, M+, of the quinoline and the tetrahydroquinoline appeared as the base peak ions. It is therefore obvious that the quinoline and the tetrahydroquinolines are more stable than the starting materials, i.e. chalcone and the intermediate products, quinolones and quinolols.|Theses Collection|Quinoline/antimalarial/amodiaquine/antiamoebic/vioform/nalidixic/Skraup/2'aminochalcones/cyclocondensation/toluene suffonic.*||||||OYEGUNJU, Isiaka Akinloye.|M|A study of the use of corn chaff (eeri-ogi) as tablet distintegrant. ||||||M.Sc.|E.O. Akala.  ||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Pharmaceutical Chemistry|1992.|||OAU |||||xiii, 160p. |||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Maize (Zea mays L.) is an important cereal crop in Nigeria with an estimated production of 2.0 million tones per annum. Recently, there has been an increase in the demand for maize in food, pharmaceutical, brewing, malting and textile industries. Consequently, maize starch (used as disintegrant and binder in tableting) has become very expensive.  This has dictated the need to search for locally available raw materials that are not expensive for use as tablet  disintegrants in pharmaceutical dosage form design.Corn chaff (a bye product of Ogi preparation from maize) was prepared from Zea mays L. (streak resistant white type two). Various concentrations of the chaff were incorporated into tablet formulations using two drugs: paracetamol and chloroquine phosphate.  The disintegrant properties of the chaff as well as the effect of the mode of incorporation of the disintegrant were evaluated.The results of the physical properties of corn chaff relevant to good tablet disintegrating properties, when compared to maize starch showed that corn chaff has a good potential as a tablet disintegrant. The effect of disintegrant concentration (corn chaff and maize starch) on tablet properties was investigated. Tablets prepared with the two disintegrants were of uniform weight. For paracetamol tablets, changes in disintegrant concentrations led to changes in tablet crushing strength. For chloroquine phosphate tablets, change in disintegrant concentration had no statistically significant effect on tablet crushing strength.Tablet disintegration time decreased with increase in disintegrant concentration (corn chaff and maize starch) for chloroquine phosphate and paracetamol tablets. Increase in disintegrant concentration led to increase in dissolution rate of chloroquine phosphate tablets while the dissolution rate of paracetamol tablets seemed not to be affected appreciably by increase in disintegrant concentration.Change in the mode of incorporation of disintegrants from internal to internal/external and to complete external led to decrease in tablet crushing strength and disintegration times of paracetamol and chloroquine phosphate tablets in that order while the dissolution rate increased.  The shape of Wagner plot for the effect of mode of incorporation of disintegrant on dissolution rate of paracetamol and chloroquine phosphate tablets were also affected by change in the mode of incorporation of the disintegrant.  For the two disintegrant tested, external mode of incorporation showed superiority over the internal and the internal/external methods. Corn chaff performed as efficiently as maize starch as tablet disintegrants in the two drugs tested.|Theses Collection|cereal/dosage/Corn chaff/chloroquine phosphate/Wagner plot/drugs.*||||||OGUNTI, Erastus Olarewaju. |M|Establishment of pharmacopoeial standards for cassia alata and cassia podocarpa leaves. ||||||M.Phil.|A.A. Elujoba.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Pharmacognosy|1992.|||OAU|||||xiii, 155p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Cassia alata Linn. and Cassia podocarpa Guill. et Perr. (Caesalpinaceae) growing well in Nigeria possessed laxative properties as a result of their content of anthraquinone derivatives.  The two plants are currently part of the list II plants of the OAU/STRC requiring further studies for the African Pharmacopoeia.  Toxicological studies on C. podocarpa showed close similarity with senna (C. acutifolia), an official laxative.  Since the bioactivity and toxicity had already been known, these Cassia species especially C. podocarpa would be qualified for standardization.Cassia alata and Cassia podocarpa were collected from four different locations during the dry and rainy seasons.  The leaves were dried at 55oC and powdered to give coarse and moderately fine powder grades.  The powders were stored in amber bottles in a cool dry place prior to analysis. Sections were cut from the fresh leaves for histological studies. The ash and extractive values were determined using standard methods.  The laxative activity, using Cassia acutifolia as reference, was evaluated.The results showed valuable diagnostic features in both the surface preparations and transverse sections of the leaf.  C. alata possessed a single row of palisade cells as compared to C. podocarpa with two layers of palisade cells.  Significant differences which will aid identification of the species and detection of adulteration in commercial samples also existed in the vein-islet and veinlet termination numbers, palisade ratio and stomatal indices.  Based on percentage wet faeces and at 500mg/kg, C. podocarpa possessed comparable laxative activity to sema in rat but possessed a much higher activity than C. alata.  At higher doses (above 500mg/kg) C. alata also showed significant laxative activity.  This suggested that C. alata could also be used as a laxative drug at much higher doses.  These results had supported the possibility of incorporating C. alata and C. podocarpa leaves as official drugs in the future edition of African Pharmacopoeia as a result to local drug production from these Cassia species.|Theses Collection|Cassia alata/Cassia podocarpa Guill/laxative/anthraquinone/Pharmacopoeia/Toxicological/palisade/stomatal indices/Cassia acutifolia *||||||BABI, Ebai Emmanuel. |M|The effect of specific hepatotoxins on biliary excretion of quinine.||||||M.Sc. |P.A.F. Dixon.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Pharmacology|1992.|||OAU |||||xiv, 124p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The effect of pretreatment with specific hepatotoxins on the biliary excretion of quinine was studied in male albino Wistar rats, by measurements of the following: bile flow rate (BFR); amount of quinine excreted in bile (QEB); amount of quinine excreted in urine (QEU); and amount of quinine recovered in plasma (QRP).The animals were distributed randomly into groups of six. For the chronic study some animals were pretreated with 0.25ml/Kg intraperitoneally (i.p.) twice weekly, at interval of four days, for eight weeks to induce cirrhosis. Whereas in the acute study other animals were pretreated with single doses of carbon, tetrachloride (0.5ml/Kg, i.p.) bromobenzene (1.6ml/Kg,i.p.) or allyl alcohol (0.025ml/Kg,i.p.] to generate toxic hepatitis.  Control animals were treated with equivalent dose of saline.  Quinine (10mg/Kg,i.p.) was given 24 hours prior to collection of bile and plasma. The urine collected within 24 hours of administering quinine as well as the bile and plasma were analyzed for quinine and its metabolises by High Performance Liquid Chromatographic method.BFR tended to be suppressed in all the hepatotoxintreated rats but the reduction was statistically significant (P < 0.05) with allyl alcohol alone.  Pretreatments with the hepatotoxins also caused an increase in QEB, though not statistically significant. However, judging from their metabolic ratios (i.e. unchanged quinineto  quinine metabolite ratios), there was significant decrease (P < 0.05) in metabolism of quinine in all pretreatment groups.The level of QEU or QRP was only significantly high (P < 0.05) in cirrhosis.  The metabolic ratios as measured from plasma samples also showed significant decrease (P < 0.05) in the metabolism of quinine in cirrhosis alone. However, metabolic ratios computed from the urine samples indicated significant decrease (P < 0.05) in quinine metabolism in all pretreatment groups. The results of this study suggest that reduction in hepatic biotransformation of drugs in pathological conditions of the liver, is associated with decrease in BFR: this in turn has important pharmacological and toxicological implications for drugs with very high biliary clearance.  Further clinical studies will be necessary to clarify this hypothesis. |Theses Collection|hepatotoxins/albino Wistar/plasma/cirrhosis/hepatitis/urine/metabolic/pharmacological and toxicological.*||||||OSONIYI, Rafiu Omolaja|M|Factors affecting the formation of prostaglandin-like compounds in cell-free extract of ocimum gratissimum (linn.) labiatae. ||||||M.Sc.  |F.D. Onajobi.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Biochemistry|1992.|||OAU|||||xi, 97p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Prostaglanddin synthetase from different kinds of animal tissue has been well studied.  Little is however known about the from plant sources.  This study aims at out some of the factors affecting the biosynthesis of prostaglandinlike substances by Q. gratissimum leaf homozenate.  The factors include pH, buffer concentration and type of buffer.It is hoped that the results of this study will afford a comparison of the plant "prostaglandin synthetase" with prostaglandin synthetase from animal sources. Leaf homogenates prepared in TrisHCl and phosphate buffers of varying pH values and concentrations were incubated with 14CArachidonic acid in the presence of hydroquinone and reduced glutathione as cofactors, ethyl acetate extracts of the incubation mixtures were then subjected to column and ThinLayer Chromatographic analysis, using a liquid scintillation counter to measure radioactivity.Silicic acid column chromatography produced two radioactive product peaks, B and C which were combined and resolved by Thin Layer Chromatography into three components J, K and L corresponding to prostaglandins F, E and A respectively.  The greatest amount of prostaglandinlike compounds formation occurred at pH 7.0 in both buffers.  TLC analysis however revealed different pH optima for each of the components J, K and L. Using TrisHCl, optimum production of the PGElike product, K, occurred at pH 8.0, while optimum production of J, the PGFlike product occurred at pH 7.5. There was no appreciable difference in the amount of L, the PGAlike compound formed between pH 7.0 and 8.0. Using phosphate buffer, there were apparently two pH optima for the formation of each of the products J, K and L, one around pH 6.5 and the other at pH 8.0. When the buffer concentration was varied, the activity of the enzyme increased slightly with increasing TrisHCl concentration, while in phosphate, there was an optimum buffer concentration of 0.15M.These results indicate that the pH optimum for the formation of PGElike compounds in O. gratissimum is similar to that in animal tissues.  Furthermore, TrisHC1 buffer may be preferable to phosphate buffer for the formation of prostaglandinlike compounds by O. gratissimum leaf homogenate since it is possible to manipulate the pH of the buffer to favour the production of a particular kind of product and TrisHCl apparently does not inhibit this enzyme system.|Theses Collection|Prostaglanddin/biosynthesis/prostaglandinlike/homozenate/14CArachidonic/hydroquinone/glutathione/O. gratissimum/enzyme.*||||||AYODELE, Muyiwa Segun. |M|Cytogenetic and reproductive studies on some species of vernonia schrep (asteraceae) in Nigeria.  ||||||Ph.D.|Omotoye Olorode||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Botany.|1992.|||OAU|||||xiii, 290p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The relationship of growth forms, morphological characteristics, genetic and reproductive to the ecology of species were identified and investigated in selected species of the genus Vernonia.Fifteen species of Vernonia were collected from different geographical and ecological zones of Nigeria. Data were assembled on the habit, habitat and community of the species of Vernonia. Measurements of relevant vegetative and reproductive characters were made. Meiotic and mitotic (including karyotypic) data were obtained from flower buds and roottips using standard squash techniques.  Photomicrographs were taken from good preparations. Hybridization studies were conducted on garden populations of some species. Some data on morphological attributes were subjected to appropriate statistical tests.The study shows that some species of Vernonia thrive in a number of habitats while others are restricted to some geographical locations. Vegetative and reproductive attributes are either peculiar to particular species and by the species in various habitats or they are peculiar to certain habitats cutting across various species found in the habitats; characters in the latter category are clearly convergent adaptive responses to the environment. Certain attributes which vary minimally between habitats were for taxonomic purposes.Fruit dispersal is mainly a colonization function.  The discrepancy between high seed production and scanty populations of some species is accounted for largely by seed wastage arising from non-availability of suitable germination sites.  The widely acclaimed high seed production in herbs is more of a function of the overall and cumulative production by plants in the community rather than by individual plants.  Adaptations for safety and variable dormancy of propagules were identified as important germination strategies in Vernonia.The chromosome numbers of V. perrottetti Sch. Bip., V. tenoreana Oliv., V. stenostegia (Stapf) Hutch & Dalz., V. kotschyana Sch. Bip., V. conferta Benth. (2n = 20) and V. ambigua Kotschy. & Peyr. (2n = 40) are reported for the first time.  Some karyotypic attributes correlated with certain vegetative and reproductive characters and these correlations exist irrespective of the growth-form differences.  The specialized attributes of herbs with lower chromosome number compared with the less specialized attributes in herbs with higher chromosome number, indicate that x = 9 basic number is more derived than x = 10.  A smaller chromosome number and heterogeneity in size of chromosomes are more correlated with derived characters than the smallness of size of chromosomes or the level of asymmetry of karyotype.The interaction of environmental factors among themselves and with organisms and the responses of genetic material, are two conditions responsible for the trends in the evolution of adaptive strategies in Vernonia. These two conditions, in Vernonia as in other natural groups, enable the identification of characters common to the genius, characters peculiar to particular species and characters which are products of similar adaptive responses of different species to particular selection pressures in the environment. These observations provide a synthetic appraisal of karyological, vegetative and reproductive characters in the selected species of Vernonia.|Theses Collection|Growth/ecological zones/Meiotic/mitotic data/hybridization/habitats/Vegetative reproduction/chromosome/morphological/genetic/ecology/Vernonia/taxonomic/Meiotic/mitotic/dormancy of propagules/chromosome/karyotypic/heterogeneity/asymmetry of karyotype. *||||||NWOKEOCHA, Chinyere Constance.|F|Botanical and cytogenetic studies of some African accessions of a wild rice (oryza punctata kotschy ex steud.).||||||M.Sc. |J.O. Faluyi.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Botany.|1992.|||OAU|||||xiv, 136p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|A total of 29 accessions consisting of local and other African accessions of Oryza punctata Kotschy ex Steud. were studied for their agrobotanical characteristics, chromosome numbers, foliar epidermal and nodal anatomical features. Exploration in south-western Nigeria revealed the exclusive occurrence of tetraploid O. punctata in Ipetumodu, Moro, EdunAbon, Sekona and IleIfe. These populations were found in swampy locations under shade. The Ipetumodu population is however, thriving in a habitat made open by the activities of man. Observations over two seasons on this population revealed that regeneration is from rootstocks at the onset of the rains. There is also evidence to show that seedlings in open, flooded habitat have difficulty in establishing.  No diploid was found in all the populations sampled.Chromosome studies revealed normal meiosis with regular bivalent paring, suggesting that the polyploids are amphidiploids. Asynchrony of meiotic stages was observed in different anthers. diploids showed economy of pollen production, earlier maturity reduced biomass but high seed set. These characteristics show that they are rstrategists.  The distribution of ploidy levels showed that the diploid is widespread, the ranges of the diploids and tetraploids overlap with some degree of symparty, tetraploids have spread beyond the range of diploids. All these suggest that the tetraploid O. punctata is a young diploidscomplex.Based on the anatomical and morphological studies, seven indices were found to distinguish between diploid and tetraploid O.  punctata: leaf breadth  the leaves of diploid O. punctata are narrower (c. 1.5cm) than the leaves of polyploids (c. 1.9cm2.3cm); culm diameter  culms of diploids are generally thin (c. 0.3cm) while those of polyploids are broad (c. 0.4cm0.5cm); spikelet length and breadthspikelets of diploids are longer (c. 6mm7mm) with length: breadth ratio > 3 than in polyploids (c. 5mm6mm) with length: breadth ratio < 3; awn length--diploid awns are generally longer (c. 55mm84mm) than polyploid awns (c. 20mm30mm); basal cell of microhairs--basal cells are about twice the length of apical cells in diploids but only slightly longer in polyploids; prickle hairs are sparse in the intercostal zone of the diploids but are abundant in the intercostal zone of the tetraploids.  Short cells are abundant and mostly paired in the intercostal zone of diploids whereas they are sparse and mainly solitary in polyploids. From the agrobotanical studies, the potentials for the improvement of cultivated rice existing in O.  punctata are quite low.|Theses Collection|Oryza punctata Kotschy ex Steud/chromosome/foliar epidermal/Exploration/tetraploid/diploids/diploids/agrobotanical.*||||||UBOM, Rufus Matthias. |M|Structure and distribution of isoberlina craib and stapf woodlands in Kainji lake national park.||||||Ph.D.|A.O. Isichei.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Botany.|1992.|||OAU|||||xxv, 348p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|lsoberlinia woodlands form a definite and distinct vegetation type within the Kainji Lake National Park. They are widespread and are the most frequent woodland communities found associated with plinthite and quartzite ridges.  Their structure and distribution form the subject matter of this work. The aim was to examine and describe the structure and distribution of these woodlands with a view to elucidating the environmental factors affecting their abundance and distribution.Sixtyseven woodlands were identified in the Park.  Twentyeight of them were sampled for density, basal area, crown cover and height of woody plants <= 3m high.  Each woodland plot was divided into five belt transects.  A centralline transect was laid in each belt transect and percentage canopy cover and grass basas cover were taken at every metrepoint along the transect.  Elevation, slope angle and slope direction were measured in each sampling plot.  Vegetation profiles were drawn for twelve plots chosen for soil study.  Soil pits were excavated and soil colour, concretion, consistence, structure root distribution and nature of boundary described.  Soil samlples from each horizon were collected, airdried, ground and analyses, for texture, pH, exchangeable acidity, organic carbon, exchangeable cations, available phosphorus and total nitrogen.Relationships between pairs of vegetation and environmental variables were analyzed by bivariate correlations. Principal component analysis (PCA) was used to examine variation in vegetation, species relationships, and gradients in soil variables.  Variation in woody and grass species among plots was analyzed by analysis of variance.  Multiple regression analysis (MRA) was used to predict models for vegetation and species responses to environmental variables.  The patterns of joint structure between vegetation and environmental variables were investigated by canonical correlation analysis (CCA).Results showed that Isoberlinia woodlands had uniform structure.  They were made of almost the same woody and grass species with no statistically significant difference among plots in terms of taxonomic composition.  Woodland height increased down the slopes of ridges, and canopy cover was < 70%.  The undergrowth was sparse.  Soil texture varied between sandy loam and sandy clay loam with abundant concentrations.  Soil chemical properties showed variation in distribution: high on surface soils and low in subsoils.  Variation in some chemical properties (for example organic carbon and percent clay) correlated with density height, basal area and crown cover of Isoberlinia and associated species.  PCA of vegetation-environmental variables identified primary and secondary nutrient and topographical gradients to which Isoberlinia and its associates responded.  CCA defined the direction of variation in the structure of vegetation and species with environmental variables.  MRA gave predictive models for vegetation and responses of species to environmental factors.  It identified percentage silt, Mn, Fe, Na, slope direction and elevation as environmental gradients establishing and distributing Isoberlinia woodlands.  These gave information on the ecological optimum and amplitude of some species. The above accounts show that the structure, abundance and distribution of Isoberlinia woodlands are influenced by variation in soil and topographical properties.  Management of these woodlands should be considered as they provide wildlife refuge. |Theses Collection|lsoberlinia woodlands/plinthite/quartzite ridges/centralline/bivariate/taxonomic/subsoils/Isoberlinia/amplitude.*||||||AKINDAHUNSI, Afolabi Akintunde. |M|A study of the chemical causes of goitre in Akoko and Ilesa areas of South-Western Nigeria. ||||||Ph.D. |S.R.A. Adewusi.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Chemistry|1992. |||OAU|||||xvi, 172p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The present study was designed to investigate chemical causes of goitre.  Akoko and Ilesa (in Southwestern Nigeria) were chosen as study areas on the basis of earlier epidemiological studies indicating goitre endemia in Akoko, and Ilesa as control.Urine of subjects used in this study was analyzed for thiocyanate, iodine, urea and creatinine, while serum was analyzed for triiodothyronine (T3), thyroxine (T4), Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and thyroxinebinding globulin (TBG). Water samples collected from study areas (rain, streams and wells) were analyzed for iodine content. Both raw food types and typical meals of subjects were analyzed for iodine, % protein, gross energy, cyanide and glucosinolates.  Sample table salt was analyzed for iodine.The mean levels ( SEM) of the analytes were: Akungba: iodine (9.600.44 ug/dL), creatinitie (0.120.01 g/dL), thiocyanate (1.090.07 mg/dL), urea (1.230.11 g/dL), T3 (107.043.4lng/dL), T4 (7.090.33ug/dL), TSH (10.540.36 uU/ml) and TBG (35.263.24 ug/ml); Oke Agbe: iodine (8.210.94 ug/dL), creatinine (0.120.02 g/dL), thiocyanate (0.760.06mg/ dL), urea (0.820.11 g/dL), T3 (127.076.55ng/dL), T4 (8.780.70 ug/dL), TSH (7.590.35 uU/ml), and TBG (31.152.60 ug/ml); Ifewara: iodine (13.770.61 ug/dL), creatinine (0.120.Olg/dL), thiocyanate (0.550.05 mg/dL), urea (1.300.10 g/dL), T3 (192.835.34 ng/dL), T4 (10.990.45 ug/dL), TSH (4.450.26 uU/ml) and TBG (35.041.27 ug/ml); Erinmo: iodine (13.640.45 ug/dL), ceatinine (0.140.01g/dL),thiocyanate (0.740.08mg/dL), urea (1.220.08g/dL), T3 (132.764.43 ng/dL), T4  (11.840.77 ug/dL) TSH (3.340.37 uU/ml), and TBG (36.701.33 ug/ml).  The study confirmed significant regional variations in the urinary levels of iodine and thiocyanate while there was no significant regional difference in urea and creatinine levels.  Analysis of urinary iodine/thiocyanate ratio revealed that subjects from Akungba and Oke Agbe had abnormal conditions with values less than 7, the normal conditions.  Akungba and Oke Agbe had 30.6 and 24.6%, respectively, while Ifewara and Erinmo had 4.2 and 3.6%, respectively. For iodine/creatinine ratio, analysis further revealed that subjects from Akoko area had abnormal conditions; < 50.  Akunba and Oke Agbe had 14.3 and 29.2%, respectively, while Ifewara and Erinmo had 4.2 and 3.6%, respectively.  Urinary thiocyanate/creatinine ratio showed that Akoko area had values greater than 12.  Akungba and Oke Agbe had 42.4 and 25.0%, respectively, while Ifewara and Erinmo had 4.2 and 1.8%, respectively. Serum T3/T4 ration revealed that Akoko area had values greater than 25.  Akungba and Oke Agbe had 14.3 and 6.7%, respectively while Ifewara and Erinmo had 4.2 and 0.0%, respectively.  Values obtained for all the ratios analyzed would confirm goitre prevalence in Akoko area.Food analysis also revealed low iodine and protein intake in the study areas.  The mean iodine content ranged from 22.50 to 42.00 ug/kg while the mean % protein ranged from 2.44 to 5.27. Similarity in the iodine and protein in the two study areas, and the low consumption of cassava in Ilesa area which has low incidence of goitre, would implicate high cassava consumption in the prevalence of goitre in Akoko area.For the animal model used to confirm iodinedietary cyanideprotein synergism, animals on high cyanide, low iodine and protein, had bigger thyroid weights than the control. In addition, diets containing Amaranthus viridis, a highglucosinolate containing vegetable, had thyroid weights greater than the control.  Therefore, glucosinolate could be a factor in the Akoko goitre endemia since the Akoko area consume significantly higher Amaranthus viridis than the Ilesa area.|Theses Collection|goitre/epidemiological/thiocyanate, iodine, urea and creatinine/serum/triiodothyronine (T3), thyroxine (T4), Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and thyroxinebinding globulin (TBG)/cyanide/cyanideprotein synergism/Amaranthus viridis/glucosinolate.*||||||DUROSINMI, Lateefat Moyosore. |F|Synthesis, characterization and some properties of aminophosphonic acids.||||||Ph.D. |I.A.O. Ojo, W.J. Ige.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Chemistry.|1992.|||OAU|||||xxi, 210p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Attention was focused on possible new routes of synthesis of aminophosphonic acids and most importantly the coordination chemistry of aminoalkylaminomethanephoshoric acids, (NAMPA) which is being reported for the first time.  The dipolar nature of the NAMPA series of acids and the surfactant activity of N8AMPA and N12AMPA were also investigated.Six of the NAMPA acids, NH2(CH2)nNHCH2PO3H2 (n = 2,3,4,6,8,12) were synthesized by condensing chloromethylphosphoric acid with the corresponding diaminoalkanecompound. The syntheses of the aminoalkanephosphonic acids, (NAPA), NH2(CH2)nPO3H2 (n = 2,3), were carried out by reacting triethylphosphite with Nbromoalkylamine hydrobromide in alcoholic sodium hydroxide followed by hydrolysis. The glycine analogue, aminomethylphosphonic acid, (NH2CH2PO3H2) was prepared by esterifying chloromethylphosphonic acid with  triethylorthoformate, condensing the ester with potassium phthalimide followed by acid hydrolysis. The acids were characterised using infrared spectroscopy, elemental analysis, chemical methods (by derivatization with phenylisocyanate) and macroscopic physical methods such as melting point and conductivity.  Elucidation of the possible coordination sites with metals, composition of the metal complexes as well as possible structures of the metal complexes of both NAMPA and NAPA were investigated using ultraviolet/visible spectro photometry, infrared spectroscopy, potentiometry and conductometry.  The pKa profiles for the NAMPA and their Nphenylurea derivatives were obtained from potentiometric titrations while the surfactant activity of the higher homologues was determined by conductometry.Aminophosphonic acids are white crystalline compounds with high melting points.  They are soluble in water, dilute hydrochloric acid and sodium hydroxide. The yields of the phenylisocyanate derivatives were moderately high (6070%). Series of absorption curves, elemental analysis and infrared spectra data indicating the complexing abilities of NAMPA and NAPA were obtained.  The results show that N2 and N3AMPA form complexes with metal ions in the ratios 1:l and l:2 in aqueous solution as well as in the solid state.  Similarly, aminopropylphosphonic acids, (N3APA), gave the 1:2 complex.  N4AMPA and N6AMPA gave a moleratio of 1:4 (metalAMPA).  The infrared spectra, conductance measurements, nonderivatization of the metal complexes with  phenylisocyanate confirm that the N-AMPA acids, NH2(CH2)nNHCH2PO3H2 act as bidentate ligards via the two nitrogen atoms.On the other hand, the phosphonate group seems to be involved in the coordination of the NAPA acids, NH2(CH2)nPO3H2, to the central metal ion.  Potentiometric titrations carried out on NAMPA and their Nphenylurea derivatives confirm that they are zwitterionic in nature with pKa ranging from 3.2 to 11.8.  For the Nphenylurea derivatives, the pKa values are lower. The critical micelle concentration (c.m.c.) of N12AMPA has a lower value than that of N-8-AMPA and the addition of substrate (urea and sodium benzoate) increases the c.m.c. The implication of these results is that the aminophosphonic acids are potential analytical chelating agents which can be used to detect and estimate metal ions in solution.|Theses Collection|aminophosphonic/aminoalkylaminomethanephoshoric/chloromethylphosphoric/diaminoalkane/Elucidation/spectroscopy, potentiometry and conductometry/surfactant/Aminophosphonic/Nphenylurea.*||||||FADIRAN, Amos Olutola.|M|Micellization of triton x-100 and its catalysis of the aquation of some iron (II) phenanthroline complexes in nonaqueous solvents.|||||| Ph.D.|W.J. Ige||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,  Chemistry|1992|||OAU  |||||xxvi, 210p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The study is an investigation of how the nature of the solvent medium, the nature of the complex, the presence of additives and the concentration of the surfactant, complex and additives influence the micellization of Triton X-100 and its catalysis of the aquation of some chosen Iron (II) phenanthroline complexes.  Results obtained thereof can be used to predict likely influence of both the additives and surfactant on similar systems, and extended to the possibility of employing them to enhance the shelf-lives of some drugs.The critical micelle concentrations (c.m.c) of Triton X-100 were determined with the aid of an Abbee Refractometer.  Spectrophotometric techniques were used to obtain the kinetic data.  All readings were taken at a controlled temperature of 250.1oC.  The c.m.c. of Triton X-100 was determined in acetone dopped with substrate free water and water containing Sodium Hydroxide (NaOH), Sulphuric acid (H2SO4), Urea ((NH2)2CO) and sodium benzoate (C6H5COONa), as substrate in separate runs.  The c.m.c. versus [substrate] profiles of Triton X-100 in acetone in substrate free H2O and in aqueous NaOH, H2SO4 are similar, decreasing non-linearly with c.m.c. at low [substrate], and approaching saturation at higher [substrate].  However, the c.m.c. - [substrate] profiles in the presence of Urea and Sodium benzoate are structured, exhibiting a minium at low [substrate] <= 1.0 x 10-4 but invariant at high [substrate] >= 5.0 x 10-4 mol.dm-3.Log(c.m.c) decreases linearly with increasing E, suggesting formation of bigger micelles in solvents of higher dielectric constants.  Similar correlations of Grunwald's constant, the f' - factor and the vapour pressure with log(c.m.c.) show a linear decreases in conformity with the E-log(c.m.c.) profile. The Ky - [surfactants] (% v/v) profiles for the aquation of the complexes in acetone and ethylene glycol show the characteristic features of micelle-catalysed reactions. Maximum catalytic factors: Ky(max)/Ky(min):, of 3.5 x 103, 198.3 and 162.2 are obtained for the aquation of Fe(Ph2Phen)32+,Fe(Me2Phen)32+ and Fe(Me4Phen)32+ respectively in acetone, while the values for the same complexes in ethylene glycol are 14.0; 24.0 and 5.6 respectively.  Observed catalysis is attributed to premicellar activities, micellar evolution, and the reduced mobility as well as the suitable orientation of both the complex and water molecules in the micellar water pool of Triton X-100 in these media.Aquation rates of Fe(Ph2Phen)3 in acetone are enhanced by H2O, C6H5COONa and NaOH as additives, while they are inhibited by H2SO4, (NH2)2CO and Na2SO4.  Aquation rates of the complexes which are generally (Ca:103 - fold) faster in acetone than in water, are attributable to the evolution of different micellar types and aquation mechanisms.  Generally, aquation rates were also found to be dependent on complex hydrophobicity.|Theses Collection|additives/surfactant/micellization of Triton X-100/Iron (II) phenanthroline/critical micelle concentrations (c.m.c)/Abbee Refractometer/Spectrophotometric/Sodium Hydroxide (NaOH)/Sulphuric acid (H2SO4)/Urea ((NH2)2CO)/sodium benzoate (C6H5COONa)/hydrophobicity.*||||||IKHIDE, Priscilla Onoiribholo|F|Absorption and fluorescence studies of some 6-alkyl-2-naphthols self-assembly monolayers on solid substrate.||||||M.Sc. |C.A. The objective includes the synthesis of 6-alky-2-naphtols on quartz glass by spontaneous self-assembly method, the measurement of the absorption and flourescence spectra of the films to give information on how the luminescent properties of 2-naphthol have been modulated by the alkyl chains and the liquid crystalline phase in which it is situated.Friedel  Crafts acylatation of 2methoxynaphthalene, followed by HuangMinlon reduction of the resulting 6acyl2methoxynaphthalene gave 6alkyl2methoxynaphthalene. 6alkyl2naphthols were finally obtained by demethylation of 6alkyl2methoxynaphthalenes.Observed contact angles of water on the films were interpreted as arising from the presence of hydroxyl groups exposed on the surface ofthe films. Akanni||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,  Chemistry|1992|||OAU  ||||| xii, 139p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This work reports the conductance of some metal carboxylate systems and the enthalpy/entropy of phase transition of the systems.  The objective was to study the physical properties of new compounds (10-hydroxyoctadecanoates and 9,10dihydroxy octadecanoates of lead, zinc, cadmium and mercury) with a view to examining their usefulness as materials with potential  technological applications.10hydroxyoctadecanoic acid was first prepared by the oxidation of cis9Octadecenoic (oleic) acid and this was subsequently used to prepare the carboxylates of lead, zinc, cadmium and mercury.  The electrical conductances of the salts were measured as functions of temperature in a cell made of platinum. The thermograms of all the samples were obtained with a PerkinElmer Differential Scanning Calorimeter (DSC7) calibrated with indium metal. The temperature, enthalpy and entropy of phase transformation for lead, zinc, cadmium and mercury 10hydroxyoctadecanoates and 9,10dihydroxyoctadecanoates were obtained.  The discussion on the Differential Scanning Calorimetric (DSC) data was facilitated by the visual observation of the melting behaviour of the salts on an optical microscope.The plot of logarithm of conductivity against inverse absolute temperature was found to be linear for zinc(II) 10hydroxyoctadecanoate while a similar plot for lead(II) 10hydroxyoctadecanoate showed a maximum. The maximum was interpreted in terms of the interaction of lead ions with the hydroxyl groups of the carboxylate chains.  The same Arrhenius plot for cadmium(II) 10hydroxyoctadecanoate showed a discontinuity and this was explained to arise from exhibition of phase transition by the salt. The DSC thermogram and the optical observation on a polarising light microscope confirmed this deduction. Cadmium and mercury dihydroxyoctadecanoates appeared to pass through solid  > solid phases which then transformed to mesophases before they eventually melted into the liquid phase.  Zinc dihydroxyoctadecanoate melted directly to the liquid state but the cooling process produced an intermediate solid phase that the DSC distinguished to be different from the initial solid phase.  All the metal 10 hydroxyoctadecanoates studied except cadmium melted directly to the liquid phase. Some intermediate mesophases were found to be sufficiently stable over a fairly wide temperature range to merit their uses as liquid crystals for possible technological applications.Comparison of the results of these studies with the existing data on metal carboxylates suggested that it is not practical at the moment to predict the melting mechanism of these systems and the need for the systematic study of their phase behaviour is recommended.|Theses Collection|carboxylate/conductance/enthalpy/entropy/10hydroxyoctadecanoic/cis9Octadecenoic (oleic)/PerkinElmer Differential Scanning Calorimeter (DSC7)/polarising light microscope/Zinc dihydroxyoctadecanoate/ melting mechanism*||||||ODUNUSI, Adepeju Olubamwo.|M|Isolation and characterization of some diterpenoids from Euphorbiaceae family.||||||Ph.D.  |C.O. Fakunle//L. Ogunkoya.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,  Chemistry.|1992.|||OAU|||||xv, 138p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Plants of Euphorbiaceae are used as sources of drugs. The biological activities of this family are attributed to their diterpenoid constituents.  This study was therefor designed to isolate and characterise diterpenoids from some species of the Euphorbiaceae.  Latex of Euphorbia lateriflora Schum. & Thonn. and root bark of Euphorbia kamerunica Pax were collected at Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife while the root bark of Euphorbia poisonii Pax was collected along Ilorin-Jebba Road in Kwara State.The latex and the root bark were extracted with methylated spirit and extract partitioned into the petroleum spirit and ether fractions.  These fractions were then subjected to column and multiple preparative thin layer chromatography.  The pure compounds isolated were analysed using infra-red spectroscopy and proton and carbon-13 nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy.Four compounds were isolated from the latex of Euphorbia lateriflora. These are new jatrophane-like diterpenoids. A pentacyclic triterpenoid gult-5-en-3/B-ol was isolated from the root bark of Euphorbia kamerunica and the root bark of Euphorbia poisonii also gave another triterpenoid, butyrospermol.  The four jatrophane-like diterpenoids isolated from Euphorbia lateriflora can exhibit some of the biological activities of the diterpenoids as has been reported in some other Euphorbia species.  These compounds may also be responsible for some of the reported medicinal activities of the plant.|Theses Collection|Euphorbiaceae/diterpenoid constituents/latex/ether fractions/carbon-13 nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy/infra-red spectroscopy/proton/pentacyclic triterpenoid/triterpenoid/butyrospermol*||||||OGUNFOWOKAN, Aderemi Okunola.|M|Determination of phthalate esters in surface waters of South-Western Nigeria.||||||M.Sc.|O.S. Fatoki||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,  Chemistry|1992. |||OAU  |||||xix, 165p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The levels of phthalate esters in rivers of SouthWestern Nigeria in some selected treated potable waters were studied with the aims of developing a simple and efficient procedure for the gas chromatographic analysis of phthalate esters and also to measure and identify the sources of these esters in surface and treated waters. The study areas covered are Oyo, Ondo, Osun, Ogun, Lagos and Delta states.  Water samples were collected during December 1990 to July 1991. Phthalate esters in all these simples were determined using Liquidliquid extraction, column chromatographic and gas chromatographic analytical techniques. Extraction of samples were carried out using dichloromethane as the extractant. The sample extracts were concentrated and run through alumina adsorbent column. Elution efficiencies of eluates on alumina adsorbent was determined using several solvents. The concentrate was first 'cleanedup' by washing with nhexane to remove all free hydrocarbon contaminants.  Phlthalate esters were then eluted from the column using appropriate solvent after trial with the following solvent and solvent mixture: 100% benzene, 100% ethylacetate and benzene:ethyl acetate mixture 95:5 (v/v); 50:50 (v/v) and 5:95 (v/v) respectively. 100% ethyl acetate gave the best result.Generally, all the water samples analysed contain abundance of phthalate esters.  Dimethyl, Diethyl and Dibutyl phthalates (UMP, DEP and DBP) were identified among other phthalates. Rivers in Ogun state contain an overall mean of DMP 129.04  34.54 mg/l, DEP 121.70  23.60 mg/l and DBP 152.47  40.21 mg/l and a range of (89.66  154.20 mg/l, 96.12  126.33 mg/l and 125.73  198.71 mg/l for DMP, DEP and DBP respectively.
