The levels of their phthalates ranged from (18.52  119.95 mg/l, 26.52  538.10 mg/l and 9.82  293.73 mg/l) for DMP, DEP and DBP respectively.The levels of phthalates obtained for treated waters of SouthWestern  Nigeria  191.10  105.90 mg/l DMP, 417.60  35.69 mg/l DEP and 637.85  50.69 mg/l DBP are indications that drinking waters also contain abundance of phthalate esters. These levels of phthalate esters can be judged to give cause for concern because their levels exceeded the UnitIed States Environmental Protection Agency water criteria of 3 ug/l above which they become carcinogenic.|Theses Collection|phthalate esters/gas chromatographic/dichloromethane/alumina adsorbent/nhexane/Dimethyl/Diethyl/Dibutyl phthalates/carcinogenic*||||||SORIYAN, Oladega Omopariola. |M| An improved kinetic model of micellar catalysis.||||||Ph.D.|Jide Ige.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,  Chemistry|1992.|||OAU  |||||xxvii, 226p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|In this work, a kinetic model of micellar catalysis of more general application for 1,10phenanthroline complexes of Iron(II) is proposed.  The complexes were synthesised by known methods and charaterised by U.VVisible spectra.  The kinetics studies were investigated using SP8400 U.VVisible Pye Unicam spectrophotometer. Rate constant  (ky)  [SDS]T profiles obtained using this model showed good agreement with experimental data.  There was excellent agreement between the equilibrium constants derived from kinetic data and Scatchard plots.  Inhibition was observed for the aquation of Fe(Me4phen)32+ in both alkaline and acidic media contrary to the overall catalysis observed for Fe(phen)32+ in acidic medium. The inhibition factors ranging from 2.0  9.8 were obtained in the presence of added salts.The aquation reaction was controlled by the micelle-Iron(II) conplex interaction. The bound Fe(II) complex is better stabilised with respect to dissociation in neutral medium as shown by the comparatively higher value of the binding constant in this medium.  In Fe(Me4phen)32+, the binding constant was 5.00 x 105 dm3 moll   in neutral medium while it was 4.05 x 104 and 1.20 x 105 dm6 mol-2 in alkaline and acidic media respectively. In Fe(pheri)32+ the binding constant was 1.70 x 104 dm3 mol-1 in neutral medium while in alkaline and acid media it was 1.30 x 104 and 3.06 x 105 dm6 mol-2 respectively.  The higher value in acidic medium is a reflection of the inaccurate fit of the model at low SDS concentration for Fe(phen)32+. The rate constant (ky) increased with increase in electrolyte concentration due to increase in dielectric constant of the system. This decreased the hydrophobicity leading to a corresponding decrease in the binding constants.  There is a direct correlation between the hydrophobicity of Fe(II) complex and the binding constant. Pre-critical micelle concentration association constant (Km)  decreases with salt concentration.  Km values varied from 1.32 x 104  4.47 x 106 in the presence of SO4 while in benzoate, it varied from 2.70  4.47 x 106. B, the equilibrium constant for the binding between Fe(phen)32+ and SDS varied from 7.82 x 108  4.77 x 1010 dm3 mol1 in SO42, 1.58 x 105  4.80 x 107  dm3 mol-1  in C6H5COO, 0.87 x 102  2.00 x 105 dm3 mol-1 in (But)4N+, 3.89 x 102  4.27 x 102 dm3 mol-1 in Mc4N+ and 4.78 x 104  6.31 x 102 dm3 mol-1 NH4+ as the concentrations of the ions decreases. The structure in the ky  [SDS]T profiles is due to favourable thermodynamic/ hydrophobicitic/ electrostatic binding between Fe(II) complex and SDS monomer aggregates coupled with the decrease in activity of water in the micellar phase.The extinction coefficients of the bound micelle-Fe(II) intermediate were found to be 19, 900, 19200 and 18,700 mol-1 dm3 cm-1 in neutral, 1.00 x 10-4H+ and 1.00 x 103 OH- media respectively.  The rate constants for the formation of micelle -  Fe(II) intermediates were 1.22 x 102 S1 (neutral medium), 3.11 x  x 102 S1(1.00 x 104 mol dm-3 H+) and 2.30 x 103 S1(1.00 x 103 mol dm-3OH-).  The corresponding reverse rate constant    (k1) for the dissociation of the intermediate to give an unbound metal complexes were 2.44 x 108 S1 (neutral medium), 2.59 x 107 S1 (1.00 x 104 mol dm-3 H+) and 5.11 x 108 S1 (1.00 x 103 mol dm-3OH-).|Theses Collection|micellar catalysis/ SP8400 U.VVisible Pye Unicam/binding constant/electrolyte concentration/dielectric constant/hydrophobicity/thermodynamic*||||||MAZA, Danjuma Dan-Adam|M|application of solid state nuclear track detection to uranium/thorium estimation in rocks and biological samples.||||||M.Sc.|F.A.N. Osadebe||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,  Engineering Physics|1992.|||OAU  |||||x, 80p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Charged nuclear particles produce trails of radiation damage in their passage through dielectric materials.  These trails, the density of which is a measure of the flux of the nuclear  particles and so of the concentration of the nuclides generating the particles, can be revealed by chemical etching or by viewing the dielectric materials with an electron microscope. The purpose of the present study is to develop this technique of solid state nuclear track detection locally and to employ it in the estimation of uranium and thorium concentrations in local rocks, guava fruits and beans seeds. The rocks and the biological samples used in this work were collected from tin mines and areas surrounding tin mines respectively in SabongidaKanar and Barakin Ladi, Jos Plateau. Some background rock samples were also collected from IleIfe, Nigeria.  Each sample was ground to a fine powder and pressed into pellets.  For rock samples, polyethyene oxide powder was used as a binder.  The alpha particles emitted by natural uranium and thorium in a sample and in a standard glass were recorded by LR115 cellulose nitrate detector films placed in intimate contact with the alpha emitters.  After chemical etching, the alpha track densities due to sample and standard glass were evaluated by visual counting under an optical microscope.  A comparison of these track densities and a knowledge of the uranium and thorium concentrations in the glass standard permitted the concentrations in the samples to be deduced.  The evaluation of the track densities by visual counting was found to be very tedious, timeconsuming and prone to error. Therefore for further development of this technique, a jumping spark counter was constructed and made operational.  The counter permits an automatic counting of the nuclear tracks in a thin solid state detector in a few seconds. The working characteristics of the counter was determined by counting, both visually and with.the counter, the tracks of fission fragments recorded by Makrofol KG solid state nuclear track detectors.  A detailed analysis of the operational modes of the counter was carried out  using the method of Laplace transform.The combined concentrations of the uranium and thoriurn in the samples analysed were found to be in the range 4 to 42 ppm by weight.  This applies to samples from the Jos Plateau and from IleIfe.  These results suggest that there is apparently no serious radiation hazard from the radioactivities of the rocks and biological materials around the tin mines of the Jos Plateau.|Theses Collection|chemical etching/electron microscope/uranium/thorium concentrations/fission fragments/Makrofol KG solid state nuclear track detectors/Laplace transform/radioactivities*||||||ADEYEMI, Gabriel Oladapo.|M|Highway geotechnical properties of laterised residual soils in the Ajebo-Ishara geological transition zone of Southwestern Nigeria.||||||Ph.D.|B. O. Ako||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,  Geology & Applied Geophysics|1992.|||OAU  |||||xxxii, 342p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Laterite soils derived from sandstones, migmatitegneiss and quartzschist in the AjeboIshara area that fringes the contact between the basement complex and sedimentary rocks in Southwestern Nigeria were studied as highway subgrade and fill materials. Although the study particularly focussed in the influences of the pedogenic factors of parent rock and topography on the geochemistry, mineralogy and the engineering properties of the soils, it was also aimed at establishing the geotechnical basis for the stability of flexible highway pavenment in the study area.Topographical and geological mappings were done in order to isolate sampling localities.  Clay mineral analysis of soils collected from test pits was carried out through X-ray diiffractometry while the major elements' geochemistry was done using Xray fluorescence spectrometer.  Geotechnical tests such as grain size distribution, plasticity, compaction, California Bearing Ratio (CBR) and unconfined compression tests were carried out using the British Standard procedure 1377.     The investigations have shown that the major elements' geochemistry, clay mineralogy and engineering properties of the studied soils were controlled by the soilforming factors of parent rock and topography. For instance, the amount of kaolinite varied from about 54% in sandstone-derived soil to about 95% in quartzschistderived soil. The amount of ferric oxide also varied from about 7% in sandstonesoils and quartzschistsoils to 16.28% in migmatitegneisssoil.  Higher percentages of kaolinite and ferric oxide were found in soils along gentle slopes than in those along flat sites in most of the studied soils. This explains why soils along gentle slopes are less plastic than those in flat sites.  The soils are generally wellgraded with the amount of fines ranging from about 18% in quartzschistderived soils to about 74% in migmatitegneissderived soils.While a weak positive correlation of 0.004 was established between the amount of kaolinite and ferric oxide, a negative correlation of 0.58 was found between the percentage kaolinite and silicasesquioxide ratio.  Both the amount of ferric oxide and kaolinite showed positive correlations (0.24 and 0.29 respectively) with strength in term of CBR. Based on the values of conpaction parameters, amount of degradation of grains and strengths of compacted soils, the American Association of State Highways and Transportation Officials level was adjudged to be more suitable than the West African level for compacting each genetic soil studied.The degree of stability of the flexible highway pavement in the study area was found to increase with the kaolinite content (51.62% in unstable and 87.91% in stable zone), kaoliniteillite ratio (14.62 in unstable and 23.63 in stable zone), CBR (5.2% in unstable and 26.3% in stable zone) and unconfined compressive strengths of the foundation soils. Implicit in this study is the direct relevance of a knowledge of clay mineralogical assemblage of lateritic soils by highway engineers prior to the design of stable roads.|Theses Collection|migmatitegneiss/quartzschist/pedogenic factors/geotechnical basis/X-ray diiffractometry/kaolinite/migmatitegneissderived/silicasesquioxide ratio/lateritic soils*||||||ALI, Mohammed Sarki|M|Determination of regional velocity structure and interpretation of surface seismic data over Northwest Port-Harcourt.||||||M.Sc.|M.A. Olorunniwo||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,  Geology & Applied Geophysics|1992|||OAU |||||xv, 230p.||||||| English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Seismic Common Depth Point (CDP) reflection and well log data collected onshore Niger delta, between longitudes 6o 45' and 7o 0'  and latitudes 5o O' autd 5o 10', northwest of Port-Harcourt have been used to determine seismic regional velocity, subsurface geologic structures and possible hydrocarbon association in the area. Twentyfive, sixteenfold coverage seismic records of five seconds twoway reflection time, of lengths ranging from 9.8 kilometres to 29.0 kilometres, covering an area of about 500 square kilometres were mapped into four major horizons bounding five layers.  DixKrey equations were used in obtaining the seismic formation velocities and thicknesses of the layers encountered in the area.The study of Isochron maps of the surfaces of the layers reveal a central ridge in the NESW direction in addition to the regional southward dip. The Isopach maps indicate layering of beds with thickening, lensing and unconformities.  The structural analysis of the study area shows a subsurface structure which is elongated ridge striking approximately NE  SW with two major fault trends:  NW  SE and E  W respectively. The result of the velocity studies show a velocity character which increases with depth.  The velocity increases gradually from 2,200 m/s at 2100 metres depth to about 7,000 m/s at 7,000 metres depth. Also, there are lateral velocity variations with large scale velocity anomalies which could be due to lithology, facie changes, or depth related.  Layer2 at an average depth of 2,800 metres show a lateral variation from 2,200 m/s to 4,500 m/s.  Layer3 at an average depth of 3,750 metres has an interval velocity range of 2,500 m/s to 6,400 m/s.  Layer4 at an average depth of 5,000 metres has an interval velocity range of 3,800 m/s to 7,000 m/s.  The velocity anomalies are used to delineate changes in subsurface lithology and existence of possible hydrocarbon saturated formations.  The results of the velocity and structural analyses have been interpreted to determine characteristic hydrocarbon trapping mechanisms in the area.|Theses Collection|Seismic Common Depth Point (CDP)/DixKrey equations/hydrocarbon trapping mechanisms/Isopach/hydrocarbon association/geologic structures*||||||BABALOLA, Lamidi Olabode.|M|Micropaleontological study of Konko-1 and Obokun-3 wells, Western Niger Delta.||||||M.Sc. |M.B. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Ditch cutting samples from Ronkol and Obokun3 wells, offshore Western Niger Delta obtained from the Gulf Oil Company of Nigeria Limited (Chevron) OML (89) were processed and analysed for   foraminiferal and palynological investigations.  The study was aimed at determining the ages of sediments, stratigraphic ranges of foraminiferal and palynomorph taxa present in these wells and also to attempt biostratigraphic zonation, infer the depositional environments and correlate the penetrated strata.Seventyseven samples were processed for Foraminifera and thirtyseven shaly samples of these were processsed for palynomorphs using standard foraminiferal and palynological sample processing techniques respectively.  The recovered Foraminifera and Palynomorphs were studied with the aid of relevant microscopes and literature materials.  On the basis of the physical characteristics and log characters of the sediments in the penetrated intervals, three informal lithological units denoted A,B and C which are correlative with the Benin, Upper and Lower Agbada Formations respectively were delineated.Thirty-five planktonic and three hundred benthonic foraminiferal species were identified.  Based on the diverse foraminiferal species, four planktonic foraminiferal zones ranging from the N16 to Nl9 Zones of Blow (1969, 1979) and three informal benthonic foraminiferal zones were established. The planktonic foraminiferal zones from the base to the top are: Globorotalia acostaensis (N16), Globorotalia dutertrei/Globorotalia plesiotumida (N17), Globorotalia margaritae (N18) and Globigerina nepenthes (Nl9) Zones whilst the informal benthonic foraminiferal zones are: Lenticulina limbosus/Uvigerina peregrina, Florilus incisus/Nonion bouanum and Amphistegina gibbosa/Amiphstegina radiata zones. One broad palynological zone, the Amphistegina gibbosa/Amiphstegina radiata zone of Germeraad et al (1968) which is  divided into two informal subzones, the Echiperiporites estelae and  Laeviqatosporites sp.  Zones was also recognized.  The recognition of these foraminiferal and palynological zones assigns a Late Miocene to Early Pliocene age to the penetrated strata of these wells.The environmental interpretations deduced from the lithological characters, foraminiferal and palynomorph associations of the studied intervals showed that the sediments of Konko1 and Obokun3 wells were deposited in environments ranging from continental to the lower bathyal. The paleotemperature of the sea during the Late Miocene to Pliocene in this part of the Western Niger Delta was estimated to be in the range of 18.3oC to 20.2oC.  This indicates warm water environments.|Theses Collection|foraminiferal and palynological investigations/biostratigraphic zonation/penetrated strata/Globorotalia acostaensis (N16)/Globorotalia dutertrei/Globorotalia plesiotumida (N17)/Globorotalia margaritae (N18)/Globigerina nepenthes (Nl9)/Lenticulina limbosus/Uvigerina peregrina/Florilus incisus/Nonion bouanum/Amphistegina gibbosa/Amiphstegina radiata/Amphistegina gibbosa/Amiphstegina radiata/Echiperiporites estelae and  Laeviqatosporites sp/palynological/Miocene to Early Pliocene/lithological/foraminiferal and palynomorph/Konko1 and Obokun3/bathyal.*||||||ENIKANSELU, Pius Adekunle. |M|Inversion of seismic traveltime data over Oredo field, Niger Delta area of Nigeria.  ||||||M.Sc.|M.A. Olorunniwo.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,  Geology & Applied Geophysics|1992.|||OAU||||| xvi, 177p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Three  parallel seismic reflection sections and three wells situated on each of the seismic lines over portion of Oredo field, Niger delta, about latitude 5oN and longitude 5.5oE have been studied to establish major subsurface horizons, unravel complex geologic structures, extrapolate velocity distribution and ascertain possible hydrocarbon association in the study area.The twelvefold coverage, 5.0 second seismic sections of length 12.95 kilometres each were analysed into two or three reflection horizons corresponding to three or four layers and depth range of 1,727 and 4,633 metres. Interval velocity structure can be grouped into three: 19242215 m/s; 2286-4068 m/a and 26603700  m/s corresponding to sand with shale intercalations, sandstone with shale alternations and dominant shale respectively. The lateral variation in velocity are attributable to facies changes.The well logs comprising lithologic and porosity tools were subjected to both qualitative and quantitative analysis. The preliminary comparison tests of formation water resistivity quotient, formation factor quotient and porosity quotient yield corresponding values of 1.19, 17.86, and 0.62, for well 7 and 7.97, 335.42, and 0.32 for well 3 which indicate hydrocarbon presence at depth intervals 2450 and 2630 metres for well 7, and 2140 and 2340 metres for well 3. The confirmatory resistivity ratio tests revealed a moveable hydrocarbon saturation upto 0.75, 0.97 and 0.60 for wells 7, 3 and 4 respectively.The sonic logs were integrated to yield the timedepth curves for seismic wave propagation in the area. The constructed timedepth curves for seismic wave propagation in the area show a largely linear relation with depth in the twoway traveltime range 0.44 to 2.68 seconds which was extrapolated to total depth (TD) using nearsurface Dix velocities. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Available records of 234 boreholes located in the basement Complex and sedimentary terrains of Ogun State have been studied with the aims of evaluating the groundwater resources of Ogun State and suggesting strategies for the economic exploitation of groundwater resources for the development of Ogun State. Eightytwo of the 234 boreholes studied are located in the basement terrains, the others are located in the sedimentary terrain.Overburden thicknesses, aquifer depths and thicknesses and the types of aquifers and aquifer conditions are studied using the available borehole lithologic logs. Total borehole depths, static water levels, well yields, groundwater quality and transmissivity values are analysed.  Statistical analyses are presented in the form of ranges, averages, tables and figures with the aims of understanding and finding representative values for well and aquifer properties in both the basement and sedimentary terrain of Ogun State.Transmissivity values are analysed using 3 methods: Theis curve matching, Theis recovery and CooperJacob graphical methods.  Transmissivity values computed for aquifers located in the basement using these methods range from 1.60 - 5.76 m2 day-1, 1.46  2.68 m2  day-1 and 0.61  7.40 m2 day-1 respectively. For aquifers located in the sedimentary rocks, transmissivity values calculated using the 3 methods range from 6.10  16.85 m2 day-1,  0.53  1130.65 m2 day-1 and 0.43  33.72 m2 day-1 respectively.  Storage coefficients could not be calculated because there were no observation wells in the study area. The main source of groundwater in Ogun State is from precipitation.  The average annual precipitation computed for Ogun State is 1314 mm  155 mm, and about 12 percent of the annual rainfall in Ogun State goes into the ground to replenish groundwater annually.  Generally in Ogun State, the yields of wells in areas underlain by basement rocks are lower than the yields of wells in areas underlain by sedimentary rocks. Yields of wells in areas underlain by basement rocks range from 0.40  36.3 m3 hr-1 with an average of 6.53 m3 hr-1. The average yield of wells that tapped Ewekoro formation is the lowest; 20.13 m3 hr-1  17.50 m3 hr-1. Groundwater of Ogun State is good for most domestic agricultural and industrial usages. From consideration of water use based on 0.0045 m3  day-1  to 0.027 m3  day-1  from rural to urban setting and water quality, there is enough groundwater in the basement and sedimentary terrains of Ogun State that can adequately serve the domestic needs of the majority of the people of the State. |Theses Collection|sedimentary terrains/aquifer depths/lithologic logs/transmissivity/CooperJacob graphical methods/sedimentary rocks range from 0.40  181.61 m3 hr-1/alluvial.*||||||KOLA-OJO, Olumuyiwa Olubusuyi. |M|A study of seismic hydrocarbon indicators over Obodo area in Niger Delta. ||||||M.Sc.  |M.A. Olorunniwo.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Geology & Applied Geophysics|1992. |||OAU||||| xiii, 258p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Seventeen seismic sections and a suite of geophysical logs from six wells from the Obodo area of Niger delta have been interpreted for structures and hydrocarbon prospects. Seven faults and four seismic horizons (at depths of about 1300m, 1760m, 2900m and 3260m respectively) were picked. These horizons divide the study area into five layers Layer 1 is the Benin Formation, layers 2, 3 and 4 constitute the Agbada Formation and layer 5 is the Akata Formation.  Layer 1 has a thickness of about 1300m.  Layer 2 has a thickness range of 440m to 720m and an interval velocity range of 2200m/s to 2600m/s.  Layer 3 ranging in thickness from 760m to 1440m has an interval velocity varying from 2700m/s to 3500m/s.  The thickness of layer 4 varies from 500m to 900m and its interval velocity ranges from 3000m/s to 4600m/s.  Layer 5 extends from a depth of about 3260m downwards.The isopach maps of layers 2 and 3 show a general increase in the thickness from the northeastern to the southwestern direction.  This implies that the layers generally dip towards the southwest.  Layer 4 thickens towards the west and east directions from the central part of the area. This signifies a contemporaneous deposition of the layer with the growth of the anticlinal structure in the area.  With the aid of the isochron and interval velocity maps, possible hydrocarbon zones within layers 2, 3 and 4 were indicated.Two sands  the upper and lower sands  with average thickness of 200m and 400m respectively were identified as the potential oil reservoirs of the entire study area.  The upper sand occurs within layer 3 while the lower sand is found in layer 4. The study of amplitude, velocity and reflectivity of the sands as seismic hydrocarbon indicators, show that part of the sands were presented as relatively strong amplitude reflections on the seismic sections with their velocities and reflectivities varying widely.The interval and fluid velocities of the upper sand vary from 2400m/s to 3400m/s and 800m/s to 1800m/s respectively.  Reflectivities of the top and bottom of the sand range from 0.01 unit to 0.06 unit and 0.01 unit to 0.10 unit respectively. The interval and fluid velocities of the lower sand vary from 3000m/s to 4600m/s and 1200m/s to 2300m/s respectively.  Reflectivity of the sand range from 0. 01 unit to 0.14 unit at the top and 0.04 unit to 0.22 unit at the bottom.Based on this study, part of the northern and southern sections of the area were delineated as possible hydrocarbon producing zones of the two sands and hence of the entire area. This was confirmed by the numerous oil wells located within these delineated zones.  More oil wells are therefore recommended within these zones especially on the lower sand where only one well has so far been drilled.|Theses Collection|seismic/geophysical logs/hydrocarbon/ isopach maps/anticlinal structure/isochron/Reflectivity.*||||||OKOH, Andrew Fabian. |M|Source rock evaluation and oil-source rock correlation in Parabe-35 and Mina-3 wells, Niger Delta. ||||||M.Sc. |J.I. Nwachukwu.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Geology & Applied Geophysics|1992. |||OAU|||||xiii, 128p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|A total of 46 ditch cuttings and two crude oils sampled from depths of 9243078m (303010100ft) and 10733279m (350010760ft) in Parabe35 and Mina3 wells respectively, offshore western Niger Delta, have been studied.  The purpose of the study was to evaluate shales of the two wells for their source rock potential and correlate crude oils from these wells with their possible source rocks. The samples were analysed by standard organic geochemical techniques which include chemical analysis of shales, petrographic study of isolated kerogens and gas chromatographic analysis of nalkanes of shale extracts and crude oils.Total organic carbon, soluble organic matter, saturated hydrocarbons and genetic potential for Parabe-35 shales range respectively from 0.9  4.3%, 4983228 ppm, 12112163 ppm and 0.6-5.76 mg/g, while the corresponding values for Mina3 shales are 0.64.0%, 5393487 ppm, 1401838 ppm, and 0.455.73 mg/g. These values show that the hales contain adequate organic matter and qualify as good oil and gas source rocks.Organic petrography of the kerogens shows that amorphous, terrestial and recycled organic matter vary respectively from 4671%, 2952% and 27% for Parabe35 shales, and from 4774%, 2648% and 15% for Mina3 shales.  A plot of whole rock hydrogen index against oxygen index on a Van Krevelen  type diagram shows the dominance of type III organic matter, with a few mixed type II  III kerogens. Pristane/phytane, pristane/nC17, and phytane/nC18  ratios were found to vary respectively from 0.621.52, 1.001.17 and 0.681.25 for Parabe35 shales and 1.211.77 1.752.20 and 0.610.99 for Mina3 shales. These values are consistent with the dominantly terrestial organic matter in the sediments. The range of vitrinite reflectance values (Parabe: 0.180.50%; Mina: 0.230.48%) indicate that the shales are immature to marginally mature.Attempts at source rockoil correlation using gross hydrocarbon  ompositions, saturate/aromatic ratios and nalkane distribution patterns indicate that the shales are not the source of the crude oils, which probably migrated from beyond total depths in the two wells, through major growth faults. |Theses Collection|petrographic/isolated kerogens/chromatographic/Organic petrography.*||||||SOMOYE, Adesina Olusegun.|M|Biostratigraphy and paleoecology of the foraminifera of Erema-4 and Ubeta-3 wells of Niger Delta area of Nigeria. |||||| M.Sc.  |M.B. Salami.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Geology & Applied Geophysics|1992. ||| OAU ||||| xiv, 253p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This research project is aimed at the lithostratigraphic, biostratigraphic, and palecologic analyses of Brema-4 and Ubeta-3 wells in the Niger Delta sedimentary basin. The stratigraphic sequences penetrated by the two wells have been established while stratigraphic distribution of the Foraminifera of both wells which provides information about age, zonation and paleoenvironmental interpretations of these sediments has also been determined.A total of one hundred and nineteen, and one hundred and fifty-two ditch cutting samples from Erema-4 and Ubeta-3 wells respectively were processed for their foraminiferal contents using standard micropaleontological procedures. Ninety-eight species of Foraminifera were recovered and identified from Brema-4 well while fifty-eight species were from Ubeta-3 well.The stratigraphic sequences penetrated by Erema-4 and Ubeta-3 wells in the Niger Delta subsurface have been divided into three lithologic units: A, B and C which are correlative to the already established Benin and Agbada formations of authors. On the basis of the planktonic foraminiferal associations of the fossiliferous Units B and C, an Early to Middle Miocene age has been assigned to the sediments of both wells.  In addition, three planktonic Foraminifera zones have been established for both wells.  These are the Globigerinoides quadrilobatus primordius - Globorotalia kugleri zone; Globigerinoides trilobus - Globigerinatella insueta zone; and the Orbulina suturalis - Globorotalia peripheroronda zone.Also three informal benthonic Foraminifera zones have been established each for Erema-4 and Ubeta-3 wells.  These benthonic zones are facies equivalents in the two wells.  The benthonic Foraminifera zones of Erema-4 well are Eponides eshira - Lenticulina rotulata zone; Textularia panamensis - Uvigerina sparsicostata zone; and Florilus incisus - Heterolepa pseudoungeriana zone while those of Ubeta-3 well are Textularia panamensis - Planulina foveolata zone within which occurs the Uvigerina - Bulimina acme zone; Hanzawaia surattoni - Heterolepa pseudoungeriana zone; and the Hanzawaia strattoni - Ammonia beccarii zone.A paleodepth of deposition of about 0 - 700 metres has been inferred for the studies area on the basis of the recovered Foraminifera.  A warm tropical paleotemperature of between 12.3oC - 30oC has also been deduced.  The paleosalinity of the sea in which these sediments were deposited has been inferred to be between 20% and 40%.|Theses Collection|lithostratigraphic, biostratigraphic, and palecologic/stratigraphic/Foraminifera/lithologic/planktonic/Globigerinoides quadrilobatus primordius - Globorotalia kugleri zone; Globigerinoides trilobus - Globigerinatella insueta zone; and the Orbulina suturalis - Globorotalia peripheroronda zone/paleosalinity .*||||||ADENUBI, Adeyinka Adesola. |M|Distribution pattern of bacteria and fungi in the Dodo North mangrove forest soil of the Niger Delta. ||||||M.Sc. |O. Odeyemi.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,  Microbiology|1992. ||| OAU|||||xiv, 162p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The microbial biota of the Dodo North mangrove zone of the Niger Delta have not been characterized due to its inaccessibility and minimal agricultural value.  The aim of the present work was to assess the total microbial load of the soil, determine the populations of aerobic and anaerobic bacteria in relation to the organic matter content and pH of the soil. The dominant bacterial and fungal species were identified by standard identification methods. A total of eight traverses, each 800m long and 200m apart were cut with a middle trace (baseline) running across the eight traces. Sampling with auger was done using systematic grid pattern, and at each observation point samples were taken at 0  15cm and 1530 depths.  The wet and dry season samples were collected in October and the following February respectively. Bacteria and fungi enumeration and isolation were done by dilution plate count method, using nutrient agar for bacteria and malt extract agar for fungi. Bacterial isolates were identified by morphological and biochemical characterization while fungal isolates were identified through cultural and morphological properties. The effects of season and soil depth on the bacteria and fungi distribution were assessed using Students' ttest at 5% level of significance, while correlation coefficient at 5% level of significance was used to know the effect of pH and organic matter content of the soil on the bacteria and fungi distribution. Chromic acid digestion method was used for the soil organic matter analysis while soil pH was determined using Glasselectrode pH meter Kent EIL 7020.Aerobic bacterial population at 0  15cm depth of the Dodo North mangrove forest soil ranged from 1.7 x 104 to 5.0 x 107/g of dry weight soil during the wet season and 1.0 X 105 to 2.6 x 107/g during the dry season.  The population of aerobic bacteria at 15  30cm depth ranged from 1.0 x 104 to 5.6 x 106/g and from 1.0 x 104 to 8.3 x 106/g during the wet and the dry seasons, respectively. Anaerobic bacterial population ranged between 2.0 x 105  and 2.9 x 107/g during wet season and between 1.0 x 105 and 1.2 x 107/g during the dry season.  At 15  30cm depth, the population of anaerobic bacteria ranged from 4.0 x 105  to 5.0 x 106/g during the wet season and from 0 to 9.8 x 106/g during the dry season. Fungal populations ranging from 0 to 2.0 x 106/g and 0 to 1.2 x 106/g were obtained at 0  15cm depth during the wet and dry seasons respectively.  At 15 - 30cm depth, the fungal numbers ranged between 0 and 5.6 x l05/g and 0 and 5.9 x 105/g during the wet and the dry seasons respectively. Bacteria and fungi distributions were not significantly affected by seasonal changes. Aerobic bacteria population was significantly higher within the 0  15cm depth than the 15  30cm depth.The pH of the highly acidic soil ranged from 3.4 to 4.0 and from 1.9 to 3.5 during the wet and the dry seasons, respectively at 0  15cm depth.  At the 15  30cm depth, the pH values ranged from 2.3 to 3.8 during the wet season and from 1.75 to 3.1 during the dry season. The organic matter content of the 0  15cm depth of the soil was between 18.19 and 33.10%, and from 21.01 to 35.20% during the wet and the dry seasons respectively.  At the 15 - 30cm depth, figures ranging from 16.00 to 35.00% and 18.00 to 34.85% were obtained during the wet and the dry seasons, respectively. Out of the thirty-eight bacterial species isolated in the soil, Bacillus sp. accounted for 42.11%, Enterobacter sp. 15.79% and Pseudomonas sp. 13.16%.  Others included Flavobacterium sp. (7.89%),  Cytophaga sp. (7.89%), Azotobacter sp  (7.89%) and Pelodicyton sp (5.26%).  The dominant fungal species isolated were Aspergilus sp. which accounted for 37.5% of the total fungal isolates. Other species were Trichoderma, Penicillium, Syncephalastrum Rhizopus, Mucor, Botryodiplodia, Curvularia, Fusarium, Botrytis and Neurospora with 6.25% occurrence each. The highly acidic and waterlogged soils of the Dodo North area of the Niger delta are very richly endowed with high levels of organic matter and high densities of aerobic and anaerobic bacteria, as well as fungi.|Theses Collection|microbial biota/morphological/Chromic acid/Glasselectrode pH meter Kent EIL 7020/Aerobic bacterial/Bacillus sp. accounted for 42.11%, Enterobacter sp. 15.79% and Pseudomonas sp. 13.16%.  Others included Flavobacterium sp. (7.89%),  Cytophaga sp. (7.89%), Azotobacter sp  (7.89%) and Pelodicyton sp (5.26%)/*||||||ADENUGA, Adeyinka Yetunde.  |M|An investigation of the distribution, seasonal variation and antibiotic sensitivity variation and antibiotic sensitivity pattern of the bacteria Flora of the Dodo river in the Niger Delta region in Nigeria.||||||M.Sc. |G.O Babalola.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,  Microbiology |1992. |||OAU|||||xii, 149p. |||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The bacterial flora of the Dodo river in the Niger Delta area was investigated with the aim of assessing the predominant aerobic, anaerobic and coliform bacterial population with respect to their distribution, seasonal variation, sensitivity to antibiotics and some physical and chemical properties of the river.Samples of water from thirtyone sampling stations along the course of the river and its adjoining creeks were taken in sterile bottles.  Surface water samples were taken on the surface (by a dip) while bottom water samples were taken using water sampler. The wet and dry season samples were collected in October, 1989 and February, 1990 respectively.  The enumeration and isolation of bacteria were done by dilution plate count technique.  Estimation of coliform bacteria population was done using the Most Probable Number technique while the assessment of physical and chemical properties were done using International Standard methods, Predominant bacterial isolates were identified using standard bacteriological methods.  Antibiotic sensitivity testing was done on Mueller Hinton agar using commercial antibiotic sensitivity discs.  The statistical analyses employed were the Students' ttest and Correlation Coefficient test as appropriate.The aerobic bacterial population for surface water during the wet and dry seasons ranged from 5.0 x 101 to 8.7 x 104 cfu/ml while in the bottom water the population varied from 5.00 x 101 to 4.08 x 104 cfu/ml during both seasons.  Anaerobic bacterial population during the wet and dry seasons for the surface water ranged between 1.00 x 102 and 6.95 x 104 cfu/ml while the range was between 1.000 x 102 and 2.405 x 104 cfu/ml for the bottom water.  Total coliform count for surface water during the wet and dry seasons was between 0 and >1840/ml while the count was between 0 and 1840/ml in the bottom water during both seasons. Faecal coliform counts for the wet and dry seasons varied from 0 to 2/ml in both surface and bottom water samples. Surface and bottom water temperature ranged between 26.5 and 31.7oC during the wet and dry seasons. The pH of the surface and bottom water during the wet and dry seasons varied between 5.9 and 7.1.  Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD5) values recorded for the surface and bottom water in the wet and dry seasons were between 0 and 5.3mg/l.  During the wet season, BOD5 value for the bottom water samples correlated positively (P < 0.05) with aerobic bacterial population. The organic matter content of the surface and bottom water ranged between 0 and 34.6mg/l during the wet and dry seasons.The bacteria isolated belonged to the genera Azomonas,  Flavobacterium, Azotobacter, Klebsiella, Aeromonas Pelodicyton, Aerococcus, Enterobacter, Staphylococcus, Proteus, Flexiibacter, Cytophaga, Micrococcus, Escherichia, Pseudomonas,  Achromobacter and Bacillus.  All the isolates were sensitive to tarivid (ofloxacin), and most of them exhibited different combinations of multiple resistance to other antibiotics. The observed high occurrence of multiple antibiotic resistance (MAR) should be a cause for concern especially if it is associated with the resistance factor which is involved in the transfer of antibiotic resistance from strain to strain by cellular contact.|Theses Collection|predominant aerobic, anaerobic and coliform/thirtyone/coliform/Mueller Hinton agar/Anaerobic bacterial population/Faecal coliform/zomonas,  Flavobacterium, Azotobacter, Klebsiella, Aeromonas Pelodicyton, Aerococcus, Enterobacter, Staphylococcus, Proteus, Flexiibacter, Cytophaga, Micrococcus, Escherichia, Pseudomonas,  Achromobacter and Bacillus.  *||||||ADEWUMI, Titilayo Olufunke.|F|A study of the factors contributing to microbial contamination of clean surgical wounds at the Obafemi Awolowo University Teaching Hospitals Complex, Ile-Ife. ||||||M.Sc. |K.A. Ako-Nai//O. Adejuyigbe.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,  Microbiology |1992. |||OAU|||||xiii, 128p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Postoperative wound infection is the major cause of increased morbidity and prolonged hospitalization of surgical patients. The risk of infection developing in surgical wounds is dependent on a number of factors including patient, personnel and the environment. The study was undertaken to determine the importance of patients, personnel and airborne microbes in the operating room as sources of intraoperative contamination of clean wounds at the Obafemi Awolowo University Teaching Hospitals Complex, IleIfe.A total of one hundred and one patients were monitored for postsurgical clean wound infection in this study. Swabs of the anterior nares of patients and attending surgical staff were cultured on blood and mannitol salt agar, while samples of incision site of patients were obtained with sterile cotton tipped applicators prior to skin closure and plated on blood agar.  Aerial  contamination of the operating suite was assessed by exposing settle plates containing various bacteriological media. Inanimate items in the operating room were routinely swabbed and plated on blood agar. Bacterial isolates were identified by bacteriological methods, while fungal isolates were identified based only on their cultural and morphological characteristics.  Phage typing of Staphylococcus aureus isolates recovered from patients and attending surgical staff was performed using the present international set of typing phages and the antibiotic sensitivity patterns of these strains were determined by the agar diffusion method.The incidence of clean wound infection in this study was 1.98% and a mortality rate of 2.97% was observed. The mean colony count per plate per hour (c.p.h) of microbes on settle plates ranged from 1. 1  49.4 and 0.9 - 74.6 colonies in the operating room and exit area of the operating suite respectively. No correlation was found between the total number of bacteria and the incidence of postoperative clean wound infection. The nasal carriage rates of Staphylococcus aureus isolates among patients and attending surgical staff were 12.8% and 17.9% respectively. The phage typing of the Staphylococcus aureus isolates recovered from patients and attending surgical staff revealed that group III and non typeable strains were predominant. All the Staphylococcus aureus isolates were resistant to penicillin, while 55.6% were resistant to tetracycline. In addition, 17.2% and 13.8% were resistant to chloramphenicol and streptomycin respectively. Sixteen percent of the wound swabs taken prior to skin closure showed bacterial growth but none of these wounds developed infection.The study revealed that coagulase negative staphylococci were the  predominant organisms associated with clean wound colonization and that sources of intraoperative bacterial contamination of the wound were the patients microflora and the operating room air.|Theses Collection|morbidity/airborne microbes/intraoperative/Swabs of the anterior nares/incision/bacteriological/morphological/Staphylococcus aureus/coagulase negative staphylococci.*||||||BAKARE, Mufutau Kolawole. |M|Evaluation of microbial biota and potential crude oil degradation in two acid soils of the Niger Delta. ||||||M.Sc. |O. Odeyemi.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,  Microbiology |1992. |||OAU|||||xiv, 109p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The microbial ecology of the soil in Niger Delta has not been studied in great detail.  In view of possible oil spillage in the area, this study was undertaken to determine the microbial popuIation in relation to the organic matter content and pH of the soil, and to determine the potential ability of the isolated bacteria, actinomycetes and fungi to degrade crude oil. Two sampling sites were selected (AkieweOweh and Uvwiamuge) . Each site was divided into four traverses of 2.50m long.  Soil samples were collected at 25m interval along the transect at 015 cm and 1530 cm depths.  Bacteria, actinomycetes and fungi were enumerated using the dilution and pour plate technique.  The soil pH was determined electrometrically while the method of Walkley and Black was used to estimate the organic matter content.  The effect of soil depth on distribution of the microorganisms was determined by students ttest while the effects of organic matter and pH on distribution was determined by correlation coefficient. The population of aerobic bacteria plus actinomycetes in the topsoil (015 cm) ranged from 7.0 x 104 to l.7 x 106  and 3.0 x 105 to 1.6 x 107/g in AkieweOweh and Uvwiamuge respectively. The population of bacteria plus actinomycetes in the subsoil (1530 cm) ranged from 2.0 x 104 to 8.1 x 105 and 6.8 x 105 to 6.8 x 106/g in AkieweOweh and Uvwiamuge respectively. The anaerobic bacterial counts of the topsoil and subsoil for AkieweOweh ranged from 1.0 x 104 to 6.5 x 105 and 2.5 x 104 to 4.3 x 105/g respectively while the counts for Uvwiamuge ranged from 4.2 x 105 to 3.2 x 106 and 3.0 x 105 to 3.4 x 106/g for the topsoil and subsoil respectively. The  population of fungi in AkieweOweh and Uvwiamuge ranged from 0 to 1.6 x 105 and 2.0 x 105 to 5.0 X 105/g respectively in the topsoils.The pH values of the topsoil and subsoil ranged from 4.0 to 5.3 and 3.8 to 4.8 respectively in Akiewe-Oweh while the pH ranged from 4.0 to 4.8 and 4.8 to 5.3 for topsoil and subsoil respectively in Uvwiamuge. The organic matter content ranged from 0.27 to 3.76% and 0.13 to 4.9% in the topsoil of AkieweOweh and Uvwiamuge respectively.Thirtytwo species of bacteria and actinomycetes grouped into seven genera were isolated from the areas studied. These genera included Bacillus, Pseudomonas, Staphylococcus, Enterobacter, Flavobacterium, Acinetobacter, and Nocardia. The eighteen bacterial isolates utilizing crude oil were identified as species of Bacillus, Pseudomonas, Enterobacter, Acinetobacter and Nocardia. The prominent fungi isolated from the soil samples included species of Aspergillus, Penicillium Fusarium, Mucor, Rhizopus and Trichoderma.  Four fungal isolates that grew on crude oil medium were species of Aspergillus and Mucor.  This study revealed that bacteria, actinomycetes and fungi capable of utilizing hydrocarbons are present in the two acid soils from the Niger Delta area of Nigeria.|Theses Collection|microbial ecology/actinomycetes/Bacillus, Pseudomonas, Staphylococcus, Enterobacter, Flavobacterium, Acinetobacter, and Nocardia/Aspergillus, Penicillium Fusarium, Mucor, Rhizopus and Trichoderma. *||||||OGUNKEYE, Olusola Olusesan.|M|Verticial distribution of petroleum degrading bacteria in Asejire water reservoir, Oyo State, Nigeria. ||||||M.Sc. |S.O. Ajisebutu.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,  Microbiology |1992.|||OAU|||||xviii, 179p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The removal of oil that has been accidentally or purposely spilt into the environment is of great concern to the petroleum industry.  The possibility of employing micro-organisms for the degradation of petroleum and its derivatives in minimizing contamination due to oil leaks and spills has prompted a number of investigators to study the process in the laboratory.  The present study was undertaken to determine the presence of autochtonous petroleum degrading bacteria and their vertical distribution pattern.  The distribution was also studied in relation to season and some physicochemical properties of the water that could affect the distribution of petroleum degrading bacteria in the habitat.The water samples were collected from six different sites using Kemmerer water sampler.  The most probable number (MPN) method and oil agar medium were employed for the enumeration.  The physicochemical properties of the water reservoir were determined by international standard methods.  The true petroleum degrading bacteria observed on oil agar medium were identified to the generic level by standard bacteriological methods. The variations in bacterial population was determined by analysis of variance, while the relationship between petroleum degrading bacteria and nitrate distribution was determined by correlation coefficient.Autochtonous petroleum degrading bacteria was observed in all the water samples collected from all the sites chosen in the water reservoir. The vertical distribution of the petroleum degrading bacteria followed a descending order pattern from the surface to the bottom of the water. The mean MPN values ranged between 23/100cm3 to 1,100/100cm3, while the mean count ranged between 15cfu/cm3 to to 1.8 x 103 cfu/cm3.There were seasonal variations in the petroleum degrading bacteria populations.  Highest mean counts of petroleum degrading bacteria obtained during the dry and onset of the rainy season were 3.88 x 102 cfu/cm3 and 1.80 x 103 cfu/cm3 respectively, while 2.85 cfu/cm3 was the highest count) obtained during the rainy season.  Statistical differences were observed for bacterial counts at different depths.  The petroleum degrading bacteria population during the onset of rainy season were significantly different from those of dry and rainy seasons.  The quantity of the physicochemical properties observed affected the distribution of the petroleum degrading bacteria.  The mean dissolved oxygen and temperature values obtained ranged between 3.lmg/1 and 8.9mg/1 and 20.5oC and 33oC respectively.  While the mean value of nitrate was between 0.4mg/l and 5.7mg/l. The surface water samples which contained higher values of dissolved oxygen and temperature, attracted higher counts of petroleum degrading bacteria.  Positive correlation coefficient was observed between petroleum degrading bacteria and nitrate ions during the wet season.Eight genera of bacteria were identified as true petroleum degrading bacteria. The commonly encountered  genera include Serratia,  Bacillus, Enterobacter, Flavobacterium, Proteus, Pseudomonas, Alcaligenes and Aeromonas.  Asejire water reservoir contained enough autochtonous petroleum degrading bacteria throughout its depth to cope with a moderate spill, even though the quantity varies.|Theses Collection|autochtonous/physicochemical/Kemmerer water sampler/Autochtonous/Serratia,  Bacillus, Enterobacter, Flavobacterium, Proteus, Pseudomonas, Alcaligenes and Aeromonas.*||||||OKOH, Anthony Ifeanyin. |M|Effect of the extract of bitter leaf (vernonia amygdalina) on the production of beer from sorghum grains using saccaromyces carlsbergensis. ||||||M.Sc.  |G.O. Babalola//M.O. Ilori.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,  Microbiology |1992. |||OAU|||||x, 121p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Barley and hops are the main raw materials for the production of alcoholic beverages obtained from fermented grain malts.  However, both barley and hops are imported from overseas, a venture that is very expensive and hence the encouragement for the promotion of the search for local substitutes.  Sorghum has been found to be a suitable alternative to barley but one of the major problems in its use is that of microbial contamination. Bitter leaf extract imparts bitterness, exhibits antimicrobial activity and is edible, hence it has been considered as a possible alternative to hops.  This research was therefore designed to confirm the antimicrobial ability of the bitter leaf extract and assess its possible application in reducing microbial load during the processing of sorghum for beer production and hence its effect on the growth and some properties of Saccharomyces carlsbergensis. The extract of the bitter leaf was obtained with methanol.  Isolation and enumeration of microbial load was done by spread plate technique, while the susceptibility testing was done by the cupplate agar diffusion method.  The brewer's yeast cell size, colony size and budding were determined by standard measurement techniques.  The effects of the extract in sporulation of the yeast, sugar uptake and alcohol production were investigated. The physical, chemical and biochemical analysis of the sorghum malt, wort and beer were determined by standard methods.  Statistical methods were employed in the analysis of the data. Four bacteria in the genera Bacillus, Clostridium, Aerococcus and Micrococcus isolated from the sorghum grains were susceptible to the bitter leaf extract. However, the bitter leaf extract was not effective against fungi at the concentrations tested.  The lethal time (LT50) of OXF6571 was shortened by 66min using 64.4mg/ml of the bitter leaf extract.  The net growth of brewer's yeast and the rate of increase in cell size was enhanced by the bitter leaf extract while budding was not affected. Sporulation was induced by the bitter leaf extract.Efficiency of utilization of sugar for biomass production was highest for sucrose and this increased with increase in the concentration of the bitter leaf extract. Glucose and maltose were however better utilized for alcohol production.  Steeping of sorghum grains in water, 500ppm formaldehyde and 30mg/ml bitter leaf extract for 18 hours reduced the bacteria load about to 60, 193 and 849 fold respectively.  The fungal population was virtually unaffected by water or the bitter leaf extract. Major specific and unique properties of the sorghum malt, wort end beer were not significantly affected by the bitter leaf extract. The implication of this wort is that the bitter leaf extract can be applied as an antibacterial agent in the processing of sorghum malt as well as a substitute for hop without exerting any appreciable deleterious effect on the quality of the beer produced.|Theses Collection|fermented grain malts/Sorghum/Saccharomyces carlsbergensis/Bacillus, Clostridium, Aerococcus and Micrococcus/deleterious.*||||||OYEDEJI, Solomon Kolawole. |M|An epidemiological survey of conjunctivitis caused by bacteria in neonates in Ile-Ife. ||||||M.Sc.  |G.O. Babalola.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,  Microbiology.|1992. |||OAU |||||xi, 133p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Neonatal conjunctivitis is a disease of the newborn and may result from septic infection of the conjunctiva before, during or after birth by bacteria, chlamydia, viruses and fungi.  This study was designed to investigate the bacteria aetiologic agents of the disease in three outpatient clinics in IleIfe, examine the prevalence of the disease, find out the pattern of antibiotic susceptibility of the bacteria isolates and to assess a few anthropometric data such as age and sex of the neonates, socioeconomic status of parents as possible predisposing factors which may influence the rate of occurrence of the disease.Four hundred and two neonates between the age range of 116 days were sampled during the study period, out of which 300 had purulent eye discharge, while the remaining 102 were sampled as control subjects.  For the isolation of bacteria, purulent exudate from the eyes of the infected neonates was taken using sterile swab stick and streaked directly on preformed sterile agar media such as blood agar, mannitol salt agar, MacConkey agar and chocolate agar.  The inoculated media were transfered to the laboratory within 23 hours of sample collection for further studies.  Bacterial isolates were identified based on their cultural, morphological and biochemical characteristics, while their antibiotic susceptibility patterns were determined by the broth microdilution method as specified by the National Committee for Clinical Laboratory, Approved Standard.A total of 268 cases (89%) were positive for bacterial isolation among the 300 clinical cases; while 20 (19.69%) of the 102 control subjects showed bacterial growth.  Statistical analysis revealed an association between isolation of bacteria and the occurence of clinical neonatal conjunctivitis (P < 0.01). Due to nonavailability of ThayerMartins medium, Neisseria gonnorrhoeae could not be isolated.  However, the 301 bacteria isolates obtained were made up of Staphylococcus aureus 130 (43.2%), Staphylococcus epidermidis  41 (13.6%), Pseudomonas aeruginosa 36 (12.0%), Staphylococcus hominis 28 (9.3%), Klebsiella spp. 23 (7.6%) and Staphylococcus salprophyticus 14 (4.7%).  Escherichia coli 9 (3.0%), Pseudomonas fluorescens  7 (2.3%), Staphylocossus warneri 7 (2.3%) and Staphylococcus xylosus 6 (2.0%). All the strains of bacteria isolated were susceptible to tarivid (ofloxacin) (MIC range 0.92  14.71 ug/ml) and relatively resistant to gentamicin, ampiclox, ampicillin, streptomycin, tetracycline and chloramphenicol. The incidence of the disease was higher among the females 142 (53.0%) than the males 126 (47.0%) but this was not significant and more clinical cases were recorded within 14 days age group compared with the other age groups, although this was also not statistically significant.  One hundred and Eightythree (61%) of the 300 symptomatic neonates were from the illiterate parents, 36 (12%) from the educated elite parents, 30 (10%) from the low income group parents and 51 (17%) from parents of unknown designation.  This distribution pattern based on socioeconomic status of parents was statistically significant (P < 0.01). Thus, the socioeconomic status and environmental sanitation could be factors which can influence the prevalence of the disease.Arising from this study, Staphylococcus aureus was established as the predominant aetiologic agent of neonatal conjunctivitis in IleIfe and its environment.  However, the new drug tarivid (ofloxacin) would be the best choice, if it can be found applicable for use in infants.  It is recommended that prophylaxis by the use of potent antibiotics, improvement of environmental sanitation both in the community and the hospitals as well as the education of nursing mother be encouraged to reduce the occurrence of the disease.|Theses Collection|Neonatal conjunctivitis/chlamydia/aetiologic/anthropometric/purulent exudate/blood agar, mannitol salt agar, MacConkey agar and chocolate agar/Staphylococcus aureus 130 (43.2%), Staphylococcus epidermidis  41 (13.6%), Pseudomonas aeruginosa 36 (12.0%), Staphylococcus hominis 28 (9.3%), Klebsiella spp. 23 (7.6%) and Staphylococcus salprophyticus 14 (4.7%).  Escherichia coli 9 (3.0%), Pseudomonas fluorescens  7 (2.3%), Staphylocossus warneri 7 (2.3%) and Staphylococcus xylosus 6 (2.0%). *||||||SALAMI, Emmanuel Oluwagbemi. |M|A study of geomagnetic pulsations at the Ife obervatory. |||||| M.Sc. |S.O. Ogunade.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Physics|1992. |||OAU|||||viii, 104p. |||||||  English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Morphological features (occurence, amplitude and period) of Pc5 geomagnetic pulsations observed at IleIfe, an equatorial station south of the dip equator in Nigeria, from January 1986 to December 1989 are studied. Geomagnetic pulsations (also known as micropulsations) are among geomagnetic variations that is, variations in the main magnetic field of the earth which are of external origin.  Studies of these pulsations at equatorial region are few compared with high and midlatitude stations.  Hence, this study apart from providing the first set of analysed data of Pc5 geomagnetic pulsations south of the dip equator in Nigeria will provide an update knowledge of their morphological features.The data for this study were obtained using a groundbased EDA fluxqate magnetometer (model FM 100B) stationed off Road 20 in the senior staff quarters of Obafemi Awolowo University, Ilelfe.  In order to accurately determine the amplitudes, periods and duration of the Pc5 geomagnetic pulsations, records with best qualities were selected, enlarged and digitized using a photostat machine and a digitizer. In obtaining the amplitudes, the digitized data were then interpolated and converted into nanoTesla (nT) using a computer.Results show that both the amplitudes and occurrence characteristics show maximum around local noon 1200 hour local time (L.T.).  The amplitude of Pc5 geomagnetic pulsation at IleIfe is found to increase with the increase in kp index as reported for both high and midlatitude stations while the occurences maximizes at moderately high magnetic indices.  Pulsation activity of Pc5 showed maximum during the Equinexes and a minimum during June solstices (mayJuly).  The periods of Pc5 pulsations show semidiurnal variation and a negative but significant correlation with magnetic index kp.  Pc5 pulsations at IleIfe was linearly polarized in NorthSouth direction, that is, along magnetic meridian. These observational facts show that Pc5 magnetic pulsations at Ilelfe are of magnetospheric origin and propagation of these pulsations are in accordance with the theoretical field line resonance models which suggested that ultra low frequency (ULF) waves can be observed away from the resonance region (e.g. at the dip equator) as compressional evanescent (cutoff) modes. It is concluded that, in view of the limitations in this study, further basic study programmes are needed for both the regular (Pc) and irregular (Pi) geomagnetic pulsations in Nigeria.|Theses Collection|Morphological features/Geomagnetic pulsations/EDA fluxqate magnetometer/nanoTesla/Equinexes/magnetospheric.*||||||ADEYEMO, Adewumi Adefela.|M|The taxa composition, abundance and distribution patterns of zooplankton fauna of rivers and streams in Central Nigeria. ||||||M.Sc.  |I.F. Adeniyi.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Zoology |1992. |||OAU|||||xv, 156p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. The work was undertaken to characterize the taxa composition of zooplankton of the water bodies, to assess their abundance and distribution pattern and to show the relationships between the recorded species as well as their community structure. Fiftythree sampling stations were established. Sampling was carried out trice: October, 1987 to represent late rainy season, April through May 1988 to represent late dry season and May 1989 at the peak of dry season.  Sample collection was limited only to surface waters.A total of fiftysix species of zooplankton consisting of six species of Cladocera, eleven species of Copepoda and thirtynine species of Rotifera were recorded. Rotifers being the most abundant of the zooplankton in rivers and streams in Central Nigeria were dominated by members of the family Branchionidae.  Zooplankton were more abundant in the dry season than rainy season and in river impoundment/riverine lake stations than in other classes of stations. Indicator species of pollution recorded include Branchionus urceolaris Muller, Filinia opoliensis (Zacharias) Kellicottia longispina (Kellicott), Keratella cochlearis Gosse and it's suggestive of moderate to low pollution.  Association between zooplankton species seemed to be established mainly on family basis. Adeniyi.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Zoology |1992.|||OAU|||||xv, 234p. |||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This work was undertaken to obtain baseline information on the taxonomy abundance distribution and community structure of the zooplankton fauna of some rivers (mostly the major rivers) in Ondo State of Nigeria.  The relationship among the recorded zooplankton species as well as the rivers were also investigated.  It is the first work on the zooplankton of the Owena subbasin of the BeninOwena River Basin.  Zooplankton samples were collected during the two seasons of the annual cycle (March through July for rainy season and October through December for the dry season) from thirtyfive sampling stations established on fifteen river systems in the study area from 1981 through to 1983.  Sample collection was limited to littoral surface waters. A total of one hundred and eighteen species of zooplankton consisting of eighty-nine species of Rotifera, twenty-four species of Cladocera and five species of Copepoda were recorded. The following six species of rotifers (Dicranophorus claviger Koste & Shiel, Mytilina acanthophora Haver, Brachionus quadridentatus mirabilis Daday, Platyias quadricornis brevispinus Daday, Lecane unguitata africana Wisniewski, Lecane stenroosi Meissner) and one species of Cladocera (Macrothrix triserialis Brady) were recorded for the first time in Nigeria.Rotifers which were the most abundant of the zooplankton of rivers of Ondo State was dominated mainly by members of the family Brachionidae. Zooplankton were abundant in the dry season. Notable cosmopolitan species recorded are Lecane curvicornis curvicornis, Murray, Brachionus falcatus falcatus, Zacharias, Lecane bulla bulla Gosse, Lecane luna luna Muller, Platyias quadricornis quadricornis Ehrenberg, Beauchampiella eudactylota eudactylota, Gosse, Testudinella patina patina, Herman, Keratella tropica tropica, Apstein, Euchlanis sp I, Polyarthra sp. Bdelloid sp XII, Ceriodaphnia cornuta Sars, Moina micrura Kurz, Chydorus sp and Cryptocyclop bicolor Sars.The recorded indicator species that are suggestive of moderate to low water pollution include: Brachionus quadridentatus quadridentatus Herman, Brachionus angularis Gosse, Platyias quadricornis quadricornis Ehrenberg, Testudinella patina patina Herman, Keratella cochlearis Gosse, Keratella quadrata quadrata Muller, Hexarthra mira Hudson and Filinia longiseta longiseta Ehrenberg. Segun//G.A.O Arawomo.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Zoology |1992.|||OAU |||||xvii, 159p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Reproductive activities of three estrildine birds, Lonchura cucullata Swainson, 1837,  L. Poensis bicolor Fraser, 1842 and Estrilda melpoda melpoda Vieillot, I817 were monitored for a threeyear period from April 1987 to March 1990 with the aim of determining the influence of environmental factors and body condition on reproductive activities.  Mistnetted birds were chloroformed, weighed, moult noted and dissected to ascertain the reproductive state of both sexes.  The flight muscles were dissectedout and the lean dry weights were determined. Nest records were kept so as to determine details of site, plant species used, construction and dimension of nests, size and colour of eggs among other avian parameters.  Collected data were subjected to statistical analyses using Students Ttests and regression analysis where appropriate.It was found that the reproductive seasons coincided closely with the rainyseason, when grass seed and insect abundance were highest.  Over the seasons, reproduction in both species of Lonchura was bimodal whereas it was unimodal in Estrilda melpoda melpoda. Replacement of flight feathers started early in May in Lonchura cucullata, late May in L. poensis bicolor and early June in Estrilda melpoda melpoda. The estimated mean duration of moult in the three species seemed to be protracted in Lonchura cucullate (179  9 days), L. poensis bicolor (134  9 days) and Estrilda melpoda melpoda (142  6 days). It became apparent that reproduction and moult were not separated in time and therefore they were compatible.The most important internal factor governing reproduction was protein reserve in the flight muscles of the birds. It was found that the lean dry weights of proteins in the females were more influenced by reproduction and reproduction took place only when the female had large quantity of protein reserve to form eggs.  Both protein reserve (0.33g in Lonchura cucullata, 0.35g in L. poensis bicolor, 0.28g in Estrilda melpoda melpoda), and body weight (8.7g in Lonchura cucullata, 9.lg in L. poensis bicolor, 8.4g in Estrilda melpoda melpoda) of the three species were at their lowest towards the end of the reproductive season.  Testis activity was at its lowest in January and December and highest from April to August.  Lonchura cucullata showed early testes activity and had fully active testes in March.In the three species, domeshaped nests were constructed of grass inflorescences and both sexes exhibited cooperative behaviour during nest site selection and nest building activities. Eggs were laid on consecutive days until the cluth was completed.  The mean clutch sizes in Lonchura spp. and Estrilda melpoda melpoda were five and four eggs respectively.  The eggs were incubated for I1 to I5 days and the young were brooded for I3 to I5 days.  Predation on the nests was the greatest factor reducing reproductive success in these birds.|Theses Collection|estrildine birds, Lonchura cucullata Swainson, 1837,  L.
