Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The cichlid fish, Oreochromis niloticus (syn Tilapia nilotica) of different body weights, caught by beach seining and acclimatized for two weeks were allowed to starve for 10, 20, 30, 40, 50 and 60 days.  Unstarved specimens were used as controls. Samples from both starved and unstarved specimens were used to determine the effect of starvation on body weight, activity, promimate composition of the muscle, liver and brain of the fish. Similarly, the effects of starvation on the blood composition was determined by standard methods.The results revealed that starving the fish reduced its physical ability and body weight.  Judging from the values obtained for protein, lipid and glycogen, it became evident that the brain was less affected by starvation than the liver and muscle. During the first forty days of starvation, the bulk of the metabolic energy in the fish was provided by the lipid and glycogen of the muscle and liver.  However, with the prolongation of starvation (i.e. after 40 days) there was a reduction in the lipid and glycogen utilisation with a marked depletion in muscle protein.  Starvation also caused adverse haematological response in the fish. Factors found to affect these changes include length of starvation and the size of the fish.|Theses Collection|Oreochromis niloticus/lipid and glycogen/haematological.*||||||OMOJOLA, Ayobami Emmanuel.  |M|The effect of different preservation methods on the keeping quality of the fishes Sarotherodon galilaeus and Clarias lazera preserved by five different methods.||||||M.Sc.|E.A. Adesulu.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Zoology |1992.|||OAU|||||x, 90p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|A cichlid fish Sarotherodon galilaeus (Trewavas) and a Clarid fish Clarias lazera (Buchell) were preserved by five different methods, with the aim of assessing the effect of the various methods of preservation on the keeping qualities of the fishes.  The result obtained was expected to give the fish processors an insight into how best to preserve their fishes.  It will also show the best conditions for keeping lean fishes and fatty fishes for consumption.The fish specimens were divided into two groups. One group had their guts and gills removed before processing while the other group was left intact. The two groups of fish specimens were then subjected to different preservative methods namely ovendrying, smokedry, sundrying (with and without salt) and freezing at 14oC.  The keeping qualities were based on their iodine values, peroxide values and total volatile bases as indices of spoilage.  Chemical analyses were carried out fortnightly to determine the rate of chemical deterioration of processed specimens with time by standard methods. Microbiological examinations were carried out using standard techniques while the bacterial isolates were identified using standard biochemical charaeterization methods.Iodine values decreased with storage times while the peroxide values and the total volatile bases increased in the products of all the preservation methods indicating deterioration in quality in all the methods.  However, frozen specimens had relatively higher quality than the products of other preservative methods throughout the keeping period. The sundrying method gave products with poorest keeping quality. Specimens preserved without their guts and gills gave better products than the corresponding specimens preserved with these organs intact. Species of Pseudomonas, Flavobacterium and Micrococcus were found predominantly on frozen specimens while species of Bacillus, Citrobacter, Neisseria and Clostridium predominate on dried specimens.|Theses Collection|Sarotherodon galilaeus/Clarid fish Clarias lazera/Pseudomonas, Flavobacterium and Micrococcus were found predominantly on frozen specimens while species of Bacillus, Citrobacter, Neisseria and Clostridium.*||||||OWA, Stephen Olugbenga.  |M|Taxonomy and distribution of Nigerian earthworms of the family eudrilidae and their possible use as indicators of soils properties.||||||Ph.D.|Ademola O. Segun//Emmanuel Aduayi.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Zoology |1992|||OAU|||||xiv, 177p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Previous works on Nigerian earthworms have been mainly taxomomic in nature.  Much information is required about their ecology. The present study was aimed, therefore, at identifying and describing eudrilid earthworms from many parts of Nigeria, mapping out their distribution and determining whether or not they can be used as indicators of soil properties.Earthworms and soil samples were collected from 104 sampling locations that covered a combination of most ecological,  geographic, vegetational and edaphic zones throughout Nigeria.  The earthworms were identified using standard anatomical procedures and characters. The airdried soil samples were analysed for particle size grades and chemical composition by standard techniques. Computer software S.P.S.S. (Statistical Package for Social Sciences), was employed to perform simple and multiple linear correlation and regression analyses between earthworm abundance and the habitat factors of the earthworms.  Cluster analysis was performed to determine natural grouping among the sampling locations.Thirtyfour earthworm species were identified. Two additional new species were described namely, Keffia penetrabilis and Keffia  proxipora. The merger of Agrotoreutus Segun and Eutoreutus Michaelsen  with Buettneriodrilus Michaelsen and the distribution of Iridodrilus Beddard over Heliodrilus Beddard and the newly published genus Segunia Sims was not upheld.A few earthworms can be used as indicators of some soil types. The indicator species for the ferruginous tropical soils on crystalline acid rocks is Hyperiodrilus oshogboenisis, that for RedYellow ferralsols is Libyodrilus mekoensis while Keffia penetrabilis is for alluvial Boils. Considering soil textural types, Hyperiodrilus eurvaulus and Hyperiodrilus millsoni are suitable indicators of sandy loam soils while Hippopera ajokei, Hippopera ifensis, Hyperiodrilus oshogboensis and Keffia nigeriensis are indicators of sandy loam or loamy sand, i.e. of light loamy soils.  For the heavier sandy clay loam or clay, Keffia proxipora is the indicator. It is suggested that the distribution of earthworms could guide the demarcation of boundaries in the mapping of biotic, rather than purely vegetational zones.| Theses collection.|taxomomic/ecology/eudrilid earthworms/edaphic zones/anatomical procedures/airdried soil/Keffia penetrabilis and Keffia  proxipora//Agrotoreutus/Eutoreutus/Buettneriodrilus/Iridodrilus/Heliodrilus/Segunia/Hyperiodrilus oshogboenisis/Libyodrilus mekoensis/biotic.*||||||FAFORIJI, Richard Adebayo.|M|Federal financial transfers and State Government fiscal behaviour in Nigeria: 1978 - 1984. ||||||Ph.D.|S.A. Olanrenwaju.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Economics |1992.|||OAU||||| xii, 185p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The study examined the effect of Statutory Allocation and Loans on the internal revenue efforts of State Governments in Nigeria from 1978 to 1984. It also examined the extent to which the revenue sharing arrangement as operated within this period, provided adequate income to the State Governments, given their expenditure requirements. Furthermore, the study, which covered all the nineteen states in existence during the period, examined the extent to which State Governments utilized available  opportunities to exploit their internal sources of revenue.With the aid of secondary crosssectional data from relevant sources, a multiple regression analysis was adopted, the results of which were used to test the hypotheses of the study. The study postulated that Statutory Allocation had negative effect on the internal revenue efforts of State Governments during the period of study, but that Loans stir, iiulated their efforts.  It also postulated that given available tax handles, the states generated lower internal revenues than their capacity.The result of our analysis showed that during the period of study, many State Governrnents generated internal revenues much below their capacity, and that they were grossly underfunded under the revenue sharing arrangement. The result showed further that Statutory Allocation and Loans had no significant effect on the internal revenue efforts of the State Governments. Also, as a revenue equalisatiori scheme, the Statutory Allocation had no significant effect on the relative economic status of the states during the period. Thus, the study argued that, a centralized expenditure system, whereby state programmes are funded from the Federation Account on matching and conditional basis should be implemented in order to stimulate their internal revenue efforts, and that State Governments should be granted the power to vary the rates and coverage of their taxes. The study also argued further that the share of the Federal Government in the Federation Account should be reduced in favour of State Governments.|Theses Collection|Statutory Allocation/expenditure requirements/hypotheses/internal revenue/Loans stir/centralized expenditure system/Federation Account/revenue sharing/crosssectional data *||||||OGUNLEYE, Edward Oladipo.|M|Corporate growth determinants in some selected Nigerian manufacturing industries: 1974 - 1985||||||Ph.D.|J.A. Fabayo||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Economics |1992|||OAU |||||xiv, 266p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This study was undertaken with the primary objective of identifying those factors that relate to the growth of selected manufacturing industries in Nigeria during the 1974 85 period. Secondarily, it identified the major restraints to corporate growth in Nigeria, determined the average growth rate and the disparity in the growth rate of firms of different size classes, examined the extent to which economic and financial factors vis a vis sociopolitical factors affect corporate growth in Nigeria and investigated the extent to which the existing corporate growth theories are relevant in a typical less developed country  Nigeria.The methods of analyses were based on both parameter estimations and questionnaire survey approaches.  Using net assets and turnover as measures of size, the effects of such factors as size, profitability  and some other financial ratios on growth were examined. In examining the effect of size, some statistical and econometric methods which include mean growth rate and variance analysis, regression analysis and bivariate size distribution and variance analysis were made use of. In examining the effects of profitability and other financial ratios, only regression analysis was made use of. The questionnaire survey was with a view to identifying those factors which are not easily reflected in the Annual Reports and statements of Accounts of companies which formed thne basis for the data for parameters estimations.The study revealed that the importance of financial strength by both net assets and turnover in explaining higher profit rates and hence higher growth rates have only become relevant and well pronounced with the setting in of the worldwide recession of the early 1980's, and the consequential structural adjustment programme which was introduced.  As a corollary to this, the established relationship between corporate growth and profitability; that profitability is an important argument of the growth function, was confirmed. The important growth inducing and growth retarding factors identified in the questionnaire survey are nonfinancial and mostly exogenous to their operations. The growth inducing factors include competitive action to expand market in existing markets and overall expansion of existing markets, both of which are pursued through more intensive advertising.  Product  diversification, especially into agriculture was also identified as a growth inducing factor especially since the recessionary period when, as a result of increasing scarcity of foreign exchange, many companies have had to be sourcing their raw materials locally.  On the other hand, the growth retarding factors identified include unstable government policies, shortage of raw materials, foreign competition and general economic conditions.|Theses Collection|manufacturing industries/growth/sociopolitical factors/econometric methods/regression analysis/structural adjustment programme/exogenous/growth retarding factors/*||||||UNIAMIKOGBO, Samuel Ogbomeda|M|An economic analysis of the domestic resource cost and effective protection in selected Nigerian manufacturing industries: 1970-1984||||||Ph.D|J.A. Fabayo.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Economics|1992. |||OAU |||||xiv, 210p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The study set out to appraise the foreign exchange saving or earning of import substituting industrialization with particular reference to the Nigerian manufacturing industries; examine the extent to which the tariff structure has affected industrialization; and examine whether there was any bias in the manipulation of the tariff structure against or in favour of any group of industries and its implications. To achieve the above stated goals, two basic approaches were adopted in the area of methodology. The first dealt mainly with the evaluation of domestic resource cost and the various measures of,tariff protection in the Nigerian manufacturing industries for selected years.  The second approach formulated models to examine the relationship between tariff structure and industrial  development, and the extent to which the variations in industrial development have been affected by changes in the tariff structure (net effective rate of protection), employing the Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) regression technique.  The data used were obtained from the publications of the Federal Government of Nigeria, the Central Bank of Nigeria, the International Monetary Fund and the Federal Office of Statistics. The study revealed that activities in the capital goods sector with the lowest protective measures had the lowest domestic resource cost in terms of foreign exchange saving or earning while those activities in the consumer goods sector with the highest protective measures recorded the highest domestic Cost of foreign exchange.  Though the study also showed that the protection afforded, the capital goods sector was higher than that of intermediate goods sector in some of the yearst the bias of the tariff structure was clearly in favour of the consumer goods sector and against the intermediate and capital goods sectors.  In addition the discriminations against exports as expressed by negative net effective protection were more pronounced in the intermediate and capital goods sectors. These have retarded the pace of industrial development. The statistical methods employed in this study revealed that, there were statistically significant relationships between the measures of tariff protection and Import Substitution and Average Growth Rate of Domestic Production in some versions of the models. Furthermore, the unique number of years for adequate effectiveness of the measure of tariff could not be determined.For meaningful industrial development to be achieved, both the tariff rates on material inputs of some of the industries and the excise duties on some of the locally produced goods should either be reduced to the barest minimum or abolished. To avoid the discrimination against export industries usually arising from an over-valued domestic currency, there is the need for an appropriate exchange rate for the domestic currency.|Theses Collection|foreign exchange/tariff structure/Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)/International Monetary Fund/Federal Office of Statistics/capital goods sector/ intermediate goods sector/tariff/Import Substitution and Average Growth Rate/excise duties/over-valued domestic currency/exchange rate.*||||||AKPAN, Philip Abraham.|M|Analysis of patterns of development in South-Eastern Nigeria. ||||||Ph.D. |J.O. Abiodun.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Geography | 1992. |||OAU||||| xviii, 215p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This study set out to analyse the patterns of inequalities in socio-economic development among Local Government Areas (LGAs) in SouthEastern Nigeria and identify their causes. It also sought to classify the LGAs into development planning regions. Data on 26 variables including agriculture, manufacturing, social services, transport and communications were collected and analyzed. Statistical techniques used included factor analysis to identify patterns of  development multiple regression to determine causes of variation, and cluster analysis to group the LGAs.The results obtained from the analyses revealed a number of findings.  Six factors accounting for 73% of variation in the original 26 primary variables described the patterns of inequalities among the LGAs. These factors were postal communications, secondary school education, cooperatives, populationsize, cash crop and community development.  An analysis of the distribution of factor scores also confirmed the existence of inequalities among the 71 LGAs.  On the whole, some Local Government Areas loaded positively on factors of urbarnization, while others were positively associated with factors depicting socioeconomic setting. Thus, the existence of dualism in the space economy of the study area was revealed. In the analysis of the causes of variation in development, it was found that three independent variables explained about 70% of total variance. These variables were population of Local Government headquarters, population of Local Government Area and accessibility index of Local Government Area headquarters. Accessibility was, however, the most consistent explanatory variable in terms of its direction of influence on most of the factor.  A classification of the original 71 LGAs yielded ten disint planning regions. Four of these regions comprising 6 LGAs were described as developed, while the other 6 regions comprising 65 LGAs were found to be lagging. A number of recommendations were made to reduce the spatial inequalities identified.  Since the distribution of population and resources had been at the base of the inequalities, an important way out of the problem was to redistribute population and resources in the area.  To this ends, designation of more urban centres, improved accessibility, large scale farms, productionoriented cooperatives, and relevant communitybased programmes were recommended.|Theses Collection|cluster analysis/populationsize, cash crop and community development/urbarnization/dualism/space economy/large scale farms/communitybased programmes.*||||||ONI, Isaac Oluwatope|M|Military professionalism and military political rule in Nigeria since independence. ||||||Ph.D. |T.O. Odetola||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Sociology and Anthropology |1992.|||OAU |||||xiv, 466p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The study aimed at examining the various dimensions in which the involvement of the military in politics has affected the quality of professionalism in the Nigerian armed forces.  To pursue this objective, the impacts of military political involvement were examinied on six subthemes of professionalism, viz: cohesiveness, institutional autonomy, nationalism and patriotism, expertise, puritanism, and discipline. We also aimed at determining the present state of combat  readiness of the Nigerian military in the light of its political involvement, and the prospects of a stable civilmilitary relation in Nigeria.Our primary data derived from concrete historical events and activities of successive military administrations in Nigeria, with the intent of examining their implications for each subtheme of military professionalism. We also employed the interview method in the collection of data.  Two categories of respondents were interviewed viz: retired and serving military officers; and university lecturers and journalists. Other sources of data included  newspapers, magazines, books of historical accounts on the Nigerian military and its political role, and informal interactions with officers and men of the armed forces. The qualitative method was employed in interpreting our data.  The discussion of each subtheme was started by analysing relevant historical events and policies of successive military governments in Nigeria that relate to the particular dimension of professionalism under consideration. These were then set against the views of our interview respondents, and against findings from other sources of data. In our analysis, we undertook a logical interpretation of these data, supporting it with tabular presentations where appropriate.Our findings revealed that all the six aspects of military professionalism which we examined have, in varying degrees, been dysfunctionally affected by the involvement of the Nigerian military in politics, the most adversely affected being cohesiveness, puritanism and discipline. We found that as a result of the loss of the traditional military puritanist ethics, class reference group has become a more potent force in determining social action, which tends to reduce and dilute the force of professional reference group and values in the process of social action.  We discovered that the Nigerian military has sought to extend its political domination of the state to enforce a sociopsychological submissiveness of the civil society. The civilians' attempt to resist this has produced incessant civil  military clashes.Military political involvement was found to have highly dented the corporate image of the Nigerian armed forces. Indeed, the views of members of the civil society concerning the military apparatus appear negative, cynical and even contemptuous. There was also an easy consensus among our various sources of data that a prior step towards revamping the quality of professionalism in the Nigerian military must involve its lasting withdrawal from politics to face its primary calling of national defence.  Finally, we found that the prospect of a stable civil  military relation in Nigeria appears bleak and elusive unless the military accepts the principle of the supremacy,of civilian authority, and unless the social, structural and economic conditions that produce and nurture political instability are positively transformed. |Theses Collection|military in politics/Nigerian armed forces/institutional autonomy/nationalism/patriotism/puritanism/military professionalism/*||||||AINA, Olabisi Idowu.|F|Gender differences in work attitudes and behaviour among selected industrial workers in Lagos.||||||Ph.D.|Simi Afonja||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Sociology and Anthropology |1992.||| OAU |||||xvi, 518p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Current interest in gender issues is an attempt to correct, criticize and reconceptualize the epistemological basis of traditionally accepted knowledge which failed to fully incorporate women's activities.  Using the Nigerian industrial experience, this study challenges some of the basic assumptions of the traditional theories of sexual dimorphism in work organisations.  The study therefore examines gender differences in industrial employment looking at organisational opportunity structure at both objective and subjective levels. It also examines men and women's work attitudes and behaviour looking at personal attributes and ideological values about gender role relations. The unique experiences of men and women in sex-atypical jobs are also documented.  To achieve the objectives of the study, both micro and macro level analyses are made, as explicated in the "genderorganizationsystem' (GOS) schema adopted for the study.  The GOS approach is entrenched in the Weberian tradition of the social action theory and the Durkheimian objective social reality. Emanating from the theoretical framework, three major assumptions are made, resulting in nine operational hypotheses.Data for the study were collected from five multinational companies with fairly large female labour force, in Lagos.  On the whole, 281 respondents were included in the sample survey while 36 others were studied with qualitative methods. Other methods of enquiry include direct observation and a review of some official records.The data collected were analysed with nonparametric and inferential statistics. The results of the data analyses and the findings support an interlocking system of relationship between and among gender, work, and cultural factors.  Although gender sometimes has a preeminent influence on work roles, generally men and women in the same occupational group share the same work interests, hours, and employment status than men and women across occupations, signifying the influence of both individual attributes and structural factors. In a few cases, cultural barriers interact with discriminatory intent to produce forms of discrimination that is sometimes invisible yet perpetuating. All the operational hypotheses are confirmed except one, indicating the validity of the theoretical assumptions of the study. However, on the basis of the findings, the study argued that it is necessary to create employment equity, and improve men and women,s access to full employment opportunity and better working conditions, as these are important sources of maintaining an efficient workforce. Finally, implications of the findings which could help introduce feminist theoretical and methodological tools into organisational studies are presented.|Theses Collection|gender issues/epistemological/Nigerian industrial experience/sexual dimorphism/sex-atypical jobs/genderorganizationsystem' (GOS)/Weberian tradition/nonparametric and inferential statistics/operational hypotheses*||||||DAIRO, Olawale Usman|M|A study of the drying characteristics of benniseed||||||M.Sc|O.O. Ajibola||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Agricultural Engineering|1992|||OAU |||||xiv, 185p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Drying is an important process in the optimum utilization of agricultural crops. To carry out efficient drying operations, there is the need to determine important drying characteristics such as equilibrium moisture content, thinlayer drying behaviour and resistance to airflow. The objective of this study was therefore to determine equilibrium moisture content, thinlayer drying behaviour and airflow resistance of benniseed and the effect of various factors such as air temperature, air relative humidity, drying time, airflow rate, moisture content and bulk density on the drying characteristics.The desorption equilibrium relative humidity was studied at five  temperatures (40, 50, 60, 70 and 80oC) and moisture content values ranging from 4.9 to 25.5 per cent (dry basis) using the vapour pressure manometric method.  The thinlayer behaviour was studied in an oven at temperatures of 40, 50, 60, 70 and 80oC, initial moisture contents of 6.95 to 21.1 per cent (dry basis) and relative humidity values ranging from 12.5 to 58 per cent.  The resistance to airflow was studied at bed depths of 0.15, 0.30 and 0.45m, airflow rates of 0.234 to 0.369 m3/s.m2, bulk density ranging from 562.5 to 713.2 kg/m3 and moisture content values of 6.5, 10.4 and 15.4 per cent (wet basis).The equilibrium moisture content decreased with increased temperature at constant relative humidity.  The modified Henderson model gave the best fit out of the six commonly used models used to evaluate the data obtained. It had standard errors of 3.3 and 4.1 per cent when equilibrium relative humidity and equilibrium moisture content were taken as dependent variables respectively. The drying rate increased with increased air temperature, and initial moisture content, and decreased relative humidity of drying air.Airflow resistance described the experimental data better than the exponential model with lower residual mean square values at all levels of factors used.  Model parameters were related to the experimental variables.The resistance to airflow increased with increased airflow rate, bulk density, bed depth, per cent fine material and decreased moisture content. Airflow resistance was accurately described by Shedd's equation and an emperical equation comprising of the test variables with over 99 per cent of variance being accounted for by the variables|Theses Collection|agricultural crops/benniseed/manometric method/Henderson model/best fit/standard errors/Airflow resistance/Airflow resistance/residual mean square/moisture content/Shedd's equation/*||||||DINRIFO, Rotimi Rufus||Mathematical modelling of the force-deformation characteristics of cocoa pods.||||||M.Sc.|M.O. Faborode.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Agricultural Engineering|1992.|||OAU |||||xv, 131p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This study was undertaken to examine the breaking behaviour of cocoa pods and to model the forcedeformation characteristics of the pods under compressive loading in relation to the design of podprocessing machines. Parallel plate, quasistatic, uniaxial compression tests were carried out on two varieties of cocoa, viz: Amelonado and F3 Amazon. The data resulting from the test were analysed to determine some of the pods mechanical properties such as compressive breaking load, stiffness modulus and toughness.  The stiffness modulus values were compared with those calculated using relations adapted from Hertz's theory of contact stresses.The compression tests revealed that a cocoa pod features an approximately linear forcedeformation (fd) curve, cracks abruptly at the maximum sustainable load and shows a high degree of elasticity (about 85%). The average values of the compressive breaking load were 0.55 and 0.72kN for Amelonado and F3 Amazon pods respectively. The corresponding values of stiffness modulus were 92.8 and 94.0kN/m. When compared with the predictions of the Hertz theory a significant difference was recorded, using a two sample ttest.  This was found to be due to the pod's composite nature, complex geometry and rough surface as modifications incorporating these factors improved the predictions of theory. A rheological model was also developed to represent the behaviour of a pod during loading to breakage as in a podbreaking machine. The model consists of a linear spring, a telescoping element (to represent the irrecoverable deformation of about 15% the pod usually sustains when loaded and unloaded below failure load) and a fracture element (to simulate the sudden failure of the pod at the maximum load).  This model will require the addition of a Coulomb damper, a dashpot and a nonlinear spring in order to accurately simulate the more general conditions of creep and stress relaxation.|Theses Collection|cocoa pods/forcedeformation/Parallel plate, quasistatic, uniaxial compression tests/Amelonado/Hertz theory/ Coulomb damper/rheological model*||||||ADETONA, Oyebanji Suli|M|A study of heavy oil recovery by alkaline flooding at elevated temperatures||||||M.Sc|V.A. This process has a great potential for recovering acidic (heavy) oils.  Past studies of alkaline injection processes have been mostly at relatively low temperatures (< 50oC). The present study investigated the recovery of heavy oil by caustic flooding at elevated temperatures using both static and dynamic techniques.Static experiments were performed to investigate the phase behaviour and properties of the microemulsion systems formed when caustic solutions contact heavy oil at selected pH (1214) and temperature (2790oC) conditions. These initial experiments provided the necessary guidance for the dynamic flow tests in which caustic solutions at varying concentrations, temperatures and frow rates were propagated through 14.3o API oil bearing sand packs. Measurements of bed properties, oil recovery, and kinetic data were taken.Significant increases in the rate of oil production and overall oil recovery were achieved at higher pH levels (> 12.0) of the injected fluid. There was also an increase of up to 5% in the oil recovery at 50oC compared to 27oC. At 60oC and above, the cumulative oil recovery showed a decline.  In contrast, caustic injection rate appears to have minimal effect on oil production leading respectively to overall recoveries of 15.3, 13.7, and 14.2% at 70, 84, and 104ml/min. The kinetic data revealed a strong correlation of oil recovery with the rate constants for caustic reactivity in oil sand matrix.|Theses Collection|hydrocarbon formation/microemulsion/caustic reactivity/sand matrix*||||||EWEJE, Bolade Theresa. |F|A study of interfacial phenomena in alkaline silicate-bitumen systems. ||||||M.Sc.|V.A. Adewusi.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Chemical Engineering |1992.|||OAU|||||x, 152p.  |||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Alkaline silicate injection into oil sands is a chemical method for improving bitumen recovery.  The present experimental study   has been performed to investigate the interfacial phenomena occurring when the injected silicate contact bitumen. An initial characterization of the bitumen sample used was carried out to determine its API gravity and viscosity  temperature correlation.  Following this, static and dynamic experiments were conducted to investigate the effects of concentration of sodium ortho, meta-, and higherratio silicates, brine salinity, aliphatic alcohol additives and system temperature on the reaction of silicate solutions with bitumen and the phase behavior of the resultant multiphase systems.The API gravity of the bitumen was found to be 14.3 degrees while the viscosity was 13,20OmPa.S at 60oC.  The phase behavior data revealed an enhancement of bitumen mobilization at higher system temperature in all the alkaline silicate  bitumen systems studied. Similar behavior was also obtained with increased system pH at 28oC but only in cases where the ortho-, and metasilicates were used as the emulsifying agents.In the saline systems, increased NaCl concentration promotes the stability of upper phase microemulsion with a further indication   of higher microemulsion phase volume and increased oil mobilization at brine salinity greater than 1% NaCl than at lower concentrations.  Optimum salinity conditions corresponding to an oil  mobilization of 1.0, microemulsion oil solubilization of 0.5 and reduced phase equilibration time were attained at 2.5 and NaCl respectively for sodium ortho, meta and higherratio silicate cases.In contrast to the non-alcoholic systems, addition of butanol, hexanol and octanol to orthosilicate  bitumen system had an incremental effect on the transient behaviour of the microemulsion phase volume.  An acceleration of phase equilibration was also achieved at higher alcohol chain length, leading  to an optimum alcohol addition of less than 40% octanol. Explanation of  these results was proposed using information derived from the reaction kinetic data.  Also, the relevance of the various fidings for impoved silicate flood design was discussed.|Theses Collection|Alkaline silicate/interfacial phenomena/sodium ortho, meta-, and higherratio silicates, brine salinity, aliphatic/metasilicates/microemulsion/salinity/butanol, hexanol and octanol to orthosilicate.*||||||EKUWEM, Emmanuel Effiong. |M|Design and construction of a microcomputer-based automatic meteorological station.||||||Ph.D.|L.O. Kehinde.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,Electronic & Electrical Engineering  |1992.|||OAU|||||xxiv, 291p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The state of the troposphere as characterized by the prevailing levels of meteorological variables determines weather. Aviation and marine navigation activities, agricultural, environmental protection, urban and regional planning activities, among the many socio-economic activities of man, are subject to the vagaries of weather. The need to measure meteorological variables using appropriate instruments which form a sufficiently dense network of stations cannot, therefore, be overemphasized. This thesis presents novel as well as modified lowcost optoelectronic instrumentation techniques for routine measurement of wind speed, wind direction, atmospheric pressure, relative humidity, temperature, sunshine duration, rainfall amount and hydrostatic pressure.Using basically optoelectronic instrumentation, sunshine recorder, wind speed and wind direction transducer circuitries were designed.  Temperature was measured using a Philips electrical temperature sensor circuit. For atmospheric pressure and hydrobarometric measurement, a combination of a Light Dependent Resistor and a Light Emitting Diode with novel reflecting mirror assembly was employed. A Philips capacitive sensor and a frequency to voltage converter circuit was used for the measurement of relative humidity. For rainfall measurement the turbo-raingauge  principle in combination with optoelectronic circuits was used.  A specially designed stopper beam provided good accuracy.  The combined circuitry of all sensors were integrated and tested for online data acquisition using a data logger, a storage module, a peripheral interface module and an IBM PC  compatible logger support software package.  Each sensor was modularized and encased.  Calibration was then carried out using established standard instruments.From calibration results, good correlation coefficient of over 0.90 was obtained for most circuits. The programmed tipping resolution of the turbo raingauge was 0.25mm of rainfall amount.  For the sunshine recorder the threshold was 2.5V. In the measurement of hydrostatic pressure, 1cm of it was equivalent to 0.9807hp. An anemometer range of 020 Knots was obtained while the relative humidity range was 95% to 20%. Data acquired during the outdoor performance test of the automatic station were favourable when compared with those acquired by conventional instruments at the same site.  Local fabrication of meteorological sensors and solar floatcharged remote site power supplies have been recommended.|Theses Collection|troposphere/meteorological variables/optoelectronic instrumentation/transducer circuitries/hydrobarometric/Light Dependent Resistor/Light Emitting Diode/Calibration/hydrostatic.*||||||ODERINU, Adekunle Omotayo. |M|Development of a rural telecommunication network in Nigeria. ||||||M.Sc. |T.I. Ajayi.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Electronic & Electrical Engineering|1992|||OAU|||||xii, 128p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Until recent times, the development of rural telecommunication in Nigeria has not been given its due attention.  This is because rural areas in general are characterised by geophysical and economic problems that make provision of telecommunication service in such areas unattractive both financially and technologically. Efforts have however been made by different countries, developed as well as developing to provide telecommunication service for their rural communities.  As Nigeria is encouraging agroindustrialization of her rural areas, the provision of telecommunication service in these areas needs to be given due consideration along with other infrastructures in order to achieve an integrated rural development. The main objective of the project is therefore to design a telecommunication system suitable for rural parts of Nigeria.A digital telecommunication network has been designed for Atakumosa L.G.A. in Oyo State. The network uses a microprocessorbased "central" station located at Osu, and five "Subscriber" stations also microprocessor based which are located at OkeIbode, Isaobi, Iloba, Ibodi and Akeredolu.  Time Division Multiple Access (TDMA) is used by the central station to transmit information contained in thirty time slots; with each time slotdestined for a particular subscriber station. At the subscriber's level, Dynamic Time slot Assignment (DTA) is used to allocate time slots to subscribers requesting service.  Transmission is carried out at the CCITT primary multiplex rate of 2.048Mbps. The switching function of the central and "Subscriber" stations was simulated on a microcomputer. The results obtained shows that an increase in the number of subscribers on the switch or the traffic intensity per line (calling rate) without a corresponding increase in the number of time slots led to a performance deterioration of the switch, with more calls meeting congestion. These results are in reasonable agreement with expectations.  Some recommendations are made to accelerate the development of rural telecommunications in Nigeria.|Theses Collection|rural telecommunication/geophysical/agroindustrialization/microprocessorbased/Time Division Multiple.*||||||OLLEY, Joshua Ibikunle.  |M|Investigation of the effects of power system outages on network performance. ||||||M.Sc.|O.A. Komolafe.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Electronic & Electrical Engineering|1992.|||OAU|||||xiii, 152p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The desire of an Operating Engineer is to operate a power system in a secure state at all times.  However, due to continuous changes in electrical load demand, planned and unplanned outages of the system equipment, the operating condition of a power system changes continually.  The ability of the power system to continue to operate in a secure state irrespective of these changes determines, to a large extent, the security of the system. Since the occurrence of unplanned equipment outages is not predictable, the effects of such outages are simulated using digital computers.  If it is detected that the outage of some equipment will cause system insecurity, corrective actions are taken. In this work, a Fast Decoupled load flow algorithm which can be used to investigate the effects of outages of generators, transmission lines or transformers was developed.  Based on the algorithm, a Fortran programme was written and used to evaluate the security of the 121 bus, 200 transmission lines and transformers network of the National Electric Power Authority of Nigeria. It was detected that the outage of certain transmission lines and generators resulted in voltage and reactive power limit violations. The programme was able to correct the reactive power limit violations in most cases.  For example, a partial loss of generation at Kainji resulted in 10% reactive power violation and this was corrected by increasing the terminal voltage from 15.60kv to 15.64kv.  The Programme could not correct the reactive power  violations in some cases because the attempt at correcting them  resulted in voltage limit violation. This shows that if such line or generator is disconnected in practice, the operator will need to resort to load curtailment to maintain the security of the system. The programme developed was able to detect equipment limit violation and correct reactive power violations in most cases. The study has shown that to avoid incessant power outage in the national network, it is necessary to reinforce some of the 330kv lines by providing additional lines.|Theses Collection|Operating Engineer/Fast Decoupled load flow algorithm/Fortran programme/terminal voltage.*||||||AWOWADE, Olufunmilola Olaitan. |F|A comparative evaluation of thermo-physical properties of wheat and wheatless bread. ||||||M.Sc. |A. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Thermophysical properties are important in food processing and food equipment designs and construction. These are particularly invaluable for novel foods such as bread from composite and nonwheat flours in order to ensure products of reproducible quality.  This study furnishes data on some thermophysical properties of heat, cassava and maize flours as well as their combinations.Wheat, cassava  and maize flours were evaluated for particlesize, bulk density, colour, and amylograph pasting viscosity.  Rheological studies, using Haake rotational viscometer (RV3), were conducted on the dough and batter samples prepared from wheat, wheat-cassava, wheatmaize, cassava mixes and maize batter. Specific volume and specific heat capacity of the doughs were determined. Heat penetration during bread baking of the doughs was also compared.The mean particle size of wheat, cassava and maize flours were 154, 228 and 330 um respectively; while corresponding values obtained for bulk density were 498, 327 and 495 kg/m3.  Munsell colour notations showed cassava flour to be the whitest, followed by wheat and maize flours respectively.  Amylograph pasting temperature was found to range between 57.9o and 67.2oC. An increase in the level of substitution of wheat flour with nonwheat flours, produced an increase in peak viscosity while changes in the stability, setback value and amylograph consistency depended on the type and level of nonwheat flour.Rheological data showed that unyeasted doughs from wheat flour and composite of 50% substitution had comparable instantaneous elastic compliance (Jo) value of 0.95, 1.05 and 0.90 x 106Pa1  respectively for wheat, wheatcassava and wheatmaize doughs. For yeasted doughs, similar values of instantaneous elastic compliance, 1.20 x 106 Pa1  and shear modulus, 9.64 x 106 Pa, were recorded for wheat, wheatcassava composite (60% substitution) and wheatmaize composite (40% substitution) doughs; showing that they will likely yield breads comparable to wheat bread.At 40oC, substitutions with cassava gave higher values of specific volume (0.9321.025 x 103 m3/kg) compared to substitutions with maize (0.8661.019 x 103 m3/kg) while that of wheat was 0.966 x 103 m3/kg.  Specific heat capacity of cassava dough was higher than that of wheat dough. Peak values were observed for wheat and cassava bread doughs at 93oC and 83oC respectively. Adeyemi.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Food Science & Technology  |1992. |||OAU|||||xiii, 138p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. Abiose.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Food Science & Technology |1992|||OAU|||||xi, 142p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The occurrence of micro-organisms of public health significance in Nigerian processed foods is not well documented.  However, there are reports of sporadic outbreaks of foodborne infections and poisonings.  This work looked into the determination of the occurrence of micro-organisms of public health significance in some processed foods and investigated the source of contamination. Selected processed food samples, namely: chocolate drink, banana flavoured ice cream, chocolate flavoured ice cream, canned beans and canned fish were obtained from department stores, depots and retail outlets.  They were analysed for the presence of some micro-organisms of public health significance.  The enumeration of coliforms in the dairy samples was based on the most probable number technique; while the evaluation and characterisation of Listeria monocytogenes, Salmonella typhi and Clostridium botulinum was based on appropriate standard methods as obtainable in literature. The results obtained showed the occurrence of Salmonella species, Iisteria species and Coliform bacteria in the dairy samples.  The percentage occurrence of Escherichia coli in chocolate drink samples was 50% while in both chocolate flavoured ice cream and banana flavoured ice cream it was 47%. However, banana flavoured ice cream showed the highest percentage occurrence of Listeria monocytogenes (33%) and chocolate drink had the lowest   percentage of occurrence (23%); while 30% was recorded for chocolate flavoured ice cream.  The percentage occurrence of Salmonella typhi in chocolate drink, chocolate flavoured ice cream and banana flavoured ice cream were 7%, 10% and 7% respectively. Bacillus species were recovered from the canned food samples.  However, Clostridium botulinum, the causative agent of botulism, was not isolated.Recovery technique studies showed that Listeria monocytogenes proliferated at 7oC over a period of 10 days. The mean generation time of the organism in chocolate drink (10.32 h) was higher than in yoghurt (18.06 h).  It was observed that freezing stopped the proliferation of the organism. The occurrence of these pathogenic microorganisms in the dairy samples indicates that they do not meet internationally accepted safety standards.  The figures obtained are higher than the Food and Drug Administration standards.  Therefore, if such processed food products are consumed, they may cause diseases which might be fatal particularly in children.  There is the need, therefore, to improve on surveillance of Nigerian processed foods to ensure their microbiological safety.|Theses Collection| micro-organisms/public health/contamination/coliforms/Listeria monocytogenes/Salmonella typhi/Clostridium botulinum/Escherichia coli/Iisteria/monocytogenes/Bacillus/pathogenic microorganisms.*||||||OMOTOSO, Oladipo Emmanuel.|M|Effect of aluminium additions on the corrosion properties of tin-zinc base alloy electro-deposit on a steel substrate. ||||||M.Sc. |A. Ogunleye.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Metallurgical & Materials Engineering |1992.|||OAU|||||xv, 142p.|||||||OAU English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The corrosion resistance of aluminium in marine and industrial environment and the absence of galvanic coupling between aluminium and tin-zinc alloy, make aluminium a probable addition which might improve the corrosion resistance of the tinzinc base alloy electrodeposit. Since aluminium or aluminium alloys cannot be satisfactorily deposited from aqueous electrolytes, recourse was taken to developing an organic electrolyte that will permit the codeposition of aluminium, tin and zinc.  This project is therefore aimed at developing and optimizing a technique for the  electrodeposition of aluminiumtinzinc alloys and evaluating the corrosion resistance of the alloys.The study comprised a series of experiments in which coatings containing: 75% tin, 25% zinc; 10%; 20%; 30%; 40%; 50%; 60%; 70%; and 80% aluminium, balance tin:zinc in a ratio 3:1, were electrodeposited onto a steel cathode via an ethylbenzenetoluenealuminium bromide electrolyte. A potential of 26v was applied across the electrolyte cell to maintain a current density of 12.0  O.lmA/cm2.  The cell was constantly stirred and the specific conductance was kept at 35 x 103/cm by the addition of hydrogen bromide.  A deposition time of 100 minutes was required to deposit 1 mil thickness of the alloys at room temperature.  The cathode deposits were analysed for tin, zinc and aluminium by atomic absroption spectrophotometry. The cathode deposits were subjected to the copper chloride modified acetic acid accelerated corrosion (CASS) test to evaluate their corrosion properties.The tin, zinc and aluminium contents of each of the cathode deposits acquired a constant value after a period of electrodeposition time, ranging from 1000 minutes in the 80% aluminium alloy to 2500 minutes in the 10% aluminium alloy.  Agitation of the electrolyte was found to increase the efficiency of transfering the alloying elements from the anode to the cathode. Comparative results of the accelerated corrosion test showed that 20% aluminium offered the best corrosion resistance.  This was followed by the cathode deposits containing 75% tin; 25% zinc; 30% aluminium; and 40% aluminium.  The corrosion resistance then decreased in the following order; 50%, 60%, 10%, 70%, and 80% aluminium alloy deposits.  Thus, only the cathode deposit containing 20% aluminium, balance tin:zinc showed a marked superiority over the 75% tin, 25% zinc alloy coating.|Theses Collection|Corrosion/resistance/industrial environment/tinzinc base alloy/electrodeposit/*||||||ONYANGO, Leonard Odhiambo.|M|Computer simulation of the effect of operating parameters on the efficiency of the iron-making blast furnace. ||||||M.Sc. |G.O. Egundebi.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Metallurgical & Materials Engineering |1992.|||OAU|||||xiii, 146p. |||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Iron is very vital for the sustenance of modern technology. The ironmaking blast furnace remains the most efficient reactor for production of iron.  Efforts are continually made to make the process more efficient and less expensive in the face of mounting costs of raw materials. The blast furnace is like a black box. The  true state of the chemical and physical changes that occur in the furnace during iron making is little known.  Many studies and investigations have established that the overall process is amenable to external control of the input variables. However, documentation of the explicit relative effect of the control parameters is usually not readily available from steel plants to external investigators. In this work, a computer program simulating infurnace reactions has been developed. The simulation system is designed to model the effect of some process control parameters on the efficiency of an operating furnace. Several control parameters were tested.  These include blast air temperature, oxygen enrichment, coke ash content, and hydrocarbon fuel tuyere injectants. Statistical analysis was used to evaluate the working of the system. The system experiment output data were analysed and predictive mathematical models were established.The results revealed that, when changed singly and increasingly, oxygen enrichment produces the best positive response of the efficiency parameters of an operating blast furnace. Hot metal silicon content and blast moisture are very complementary to oxygen enrichment and blast temperature. The results obtained from this system show that it can be used as a process control tool by operators of the iron blast furnace.|Theses Collection|blast furnace/operating furnace/hydrocarbon fuel tuyere injectants/oxygen enrichment/predictive mathematical models*||||||IREFIN, Isaac Adeyemi.|M|Impact assessment of standardisation policies on selected food industries and consumers in Nigeria||||||M.Sc.|M.O. Ilori// S. Adjebeng-Asem||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Technology Policy & Planning|1992||| OAU||||| xiii, 165p||||||| English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The Federal Government of Nigeria has promulgated the food standardisation laws and regulations to protect the food industries and consumers against adulterated and misbranded products.  The powers for the enforcement are invested in the Food and Drugs Agency, Standard Organisation of Nigeria, Weight and Measures Administration and Pre-shipment Inspection Agency.  Despite these standardisation laws and regulations, substandard food products are still found in the Nigerian markets. This study was therefore designed to critically study food standardisation policies, the roles of the enforcement agents in the implementation of these policies, the food manufacturing industries and consumer awareness of these policies.Data were collected from the Standard organisations, selected industries and consumers in Ibadan and Lagos using structured and unstructured questionnaires and personal interviews, and thereafter analysed with descriptive and qualitative statistics. The law enforcement organisations have not been effective due to such operational constraints as lack of adequate trained manpower, infrastrutural facilities and overlapping functions of the organisations. Some of the selected food industries do not always conform to standards because they lack standard quality control laboratories.Majority of consumers (61%) prefer to return substandard food products to the sellers; 6% will report such cases to the organisations, 1% preferred to take court action indicating a low level of awareness of the food standardisation laws among the consumers. However, sex, income and education contributed significantly to the awareness of the food standardisation laws or actions taken against substandard products. Among the male consitmers. income and age contributed significantly to awareness while location and education contributed significantly to action taken against substandard products.  However, age, income and education contributed significantly to awareness and action against substandard products among the female population. The results emphasize the need to merge the various enforcement organisations to form one autonomous body and adequately financed in order that their functions can be streamlined for effectiveness and efficiency.|Theses Collection|food standardisation laws/adulterated and misbranded products/Pre-shipment Inspection Agency*||||||MAKINWA, Edward Olatonade|M|Engineering economic assessments of the use of sorghum for brewing beer||||||M.Sc| M.O. However, the Structural Adjustment Programme (SAP) introduced in the country in 1986 led to the use of sorghum and other locally available cereals for beer brewing.  This study investigated engineering problems such as plant replacement and adaptation encountered in some brew houses as a result of the use of sorghum for brewing. Interview and participation techniques were used for data collection.  This study also included investigative techniques on costs and policy implications.The technical problems were identified in milling, mashing and laundering processes.  However, the milling problem was solved by adapting the existing barley malt cleaner for sorghum grain at no cost. The use of external enzymes and installation of mash filter eliminated the mashing and laundering problems. However, the adoption of a special mashing technique which involves the use of endogenous enzymes of sorghum malt and either a manual or automatic siphon technique could solve these problems at reduced cost.  A brewery wishing to adopt this process should have a malting plant to guarantee the quality and steady supply of malt.  Such a malting plant of 6,000 tonnes annual capacity could generate an additional Internal Rate of Return (IRR) of 30% which is greater than the existing bank interest rate. The policy which emphasises the use of local raw materials is very effective in the brewing industry in Nigeria. However, government should pursue the policy on the production of steel products which are essential for the fabrication of malting plants and other food processing facilities to enhance the building of indigenous technological capability in the industry.|Theses Collection|malted barley/Structural Adjustment Programme (SAP)/milling/mashing/laundering processes/endogenous enzymes/ Internal Rate of Return (IRR)*||||||OHABA, Jacob Ata. |M|A study of the commercialisation of selected soy-maize products. |||||| M.Sc. |F.E. Ogbimi.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Metallurgical & Materials Engineering |1992. |||OAU |||||xii, 157p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The need to invest on research is often emphasised. However, it is research efficiency or the extent to which research expands knowledge and becomes into wealth that is more important than research per se. This is because a research system in which no knowledge gets converted into product can only exist for a short time. This study is, therefore, an attempt to systematically document the commercialisation experiences of two weaning foods, Soy-Ogi and Nutrend Infant Cereal, which are successful innovative products in Nigeria, so that the experiences may be used in commercialising other products.Data were mainly from secondary sources. These sources included the information bulletin of the organisations which produced the foods, conference proceedings and newsprint media.  Questionnaire survey and interviews were used to supplement the secondary data source. Both quantitative and qualitative approaches to data were used. Sketches, percentages and some other quantitative analyses, where applicable, were used to illustrate and characterize evidence. The study showed that the  commercialisation of the two weaning foods began with research. The research into SoyOgi by the Federal Institute of Industrial Research, Oshodi (FIIRO) sought to improve protein intake of Nigerian children weaned unto the traditional Ogi while that associated with Nutrend was mainly to surmount raw materials crisis for baby food production by Food Specialties Nigeria PLC (FSN). Both weaning foods contained soyabean. The study also revealed that it is not the high protein content of about 40% (w/w) which soyabean has, like other oil seeds, that especially commended it for baby food formulation, rather, it is the excellent nutritive quality and the supplementary value of its protein. The results also showed that the commercialisation of Soy-Ogi and Nutrend involved a co-ordinated sequence of factors and activities.  Eight phases were distinguished, namely, the existence within the organisation of motivated and knowledgeable individuals who developed interests in the tasks/problems to be solved; identification of the problem to be addressed through research; recognition of new ideas as a possible solution to the problem identified; actual efforts to solve the problem; experimental development of the ideas; the design and fabrication of production facilities; test marketing of products; and introduction of product into the market.  More importantly, the study showed that the interests of the motivated and knowledgeable individuals were sustained in all the stages of the commercialisation process to keep the activities on course.About one-third, 32% of the 601 respondents surveyed, weaned their babies unto Soy-Ogi as against about 24% who weaned children unto Nutrend Infant Cereal, while all other weaning foods were responsible for the balance of 44%.  The 32% who weaned children unto Soy-Ogi was made up of 2.8% who used FIIRO's Soy-Ogi and 29.2 who made their own Soy-Ogi at home.|Theses Collection|Soy-Ogi/Nutrend Infant Cereal/Federal Institute of Industrial Research/Ogi.*||||||OKEJIRI, Ephraim Chukwuma. |M|An examination of limiting factors to coal production in Nigeria. ||||||M.Sc.|J.B. In this study, the limiting factors to coal production were investigated. The purpose was to identify the causes of low production, as well as the ways to improve the production scenario. Data were collected  from both primary and secondary sources. These sources included the annual reports of the Nigerian Coal Corporation (NCC) and other relevant documents on the Nigerian coal industry.  Also, data were obtained from direct observation at the collieries, survey of miners using questionnaires, and interviews in the NCC and some industries using coal.It was discovered that there were no clear and specific productiondemand targets set for coal in Nigeria. The study also revealed that lack of technological capability and low investment rate in the industry have hindered the mechanization of mining operations. These findings show that coal is unlikely to play a major role in the Nigerian energy economy in the nearest future unless serious efforts are made to address them.  Nonethelsess, it is essential to encourage private sector investments in the Nigerian coal industry in order to improve the existing mining facilities and attract capital for new ventures. Adjebeng-Asem.||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Metallurgical & Materials Engineering |1992. |||OAU |||||xiii, 151p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Adequate training and effective utilization of scientific and technological manpower is essential for the technological development of a nation.  In recognition of this important fact, this study evaluated the training and employment prospects of science laboratory personnel in Nigeria.  The study aimed at assessing the National Policy on Science and Technology as it affects the training of science laboratory personnel.  It also sought to identify possible gaps in the demand and supply of these personnel and determine their training needs.  This was with a view to recommending ways of bridging the gaps between training and labour market requirement.Data for the study were collected from a sample of employers, trainers and trainee-technologists from industries, universities and accredited polytechnics across the country through structured questionnaires and personal interviews.  Content analysis of documents obtained from National Board for Technical Education and the Nigerian Institute of Science Technology was also employed to complement the primary data.  Techniques for data analysis included rating indices.At the close of the study, it was discovered that the degree of practical acquisition by the technicians and technologists was 27.7% lower than acquired theoretical technical knowledge, contrary to the expectation of S & T policy.  Equipment and materials for skill training were lacking to the extent that they were unsatisfactorily rated as 45% and 38% by trainers and trainees respectively. On the industrial working experience of graduated technicians, 17.69% of them were found not to have undergone the mandatory minimum one year working experience before being enrolled on the HND programme.  This finding points to the trivialisation of the stipulated admission requirement.  It also underscores the lack of importance attached to industrial working experience, so crucial to technical competence.With respect to the supply of science laboratory personnel, it was discovered that training institutions were producing science laboratory technologists and technicians in the ratio 1:1.35, which represents a rather high bias towards the training of technologists compared to technicians. On the demand side, the employment prospects were found unimpressive. As much as 36.5% of all employing industries did not employ a single science laboratory personnel throughout a two-year period and 53.8% of them also did not have any unfilled employment vacancy for the personnel.The identified training needs advanced by industries, bore relevance to the nature of the various industries, thus e-emphasising the necessity of making training relevant to labour market requirement. On the basis of the major findings, recommendations were made on the need to establish an Industrial Liaison Centre in each training institution as well as an Employment Agency in the Federal Ministry of Employment, Labour and Productivity for technicians.|Theses Collection|National Policy/trainee-technologists/National Board for Technical Education/Nigerian Institute of Science Technology/e-emphasising.*||||||Boboye, Bolatito Esther|F|Mutations of regulatory genes affecting the synthesis of pectate lyase in xanthomonas caropestris campestria||||||M.Sc. Microbiology|O.O. Shonukan||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Microbiology|1990|||OAU|||||xi,102p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Xanthomonas campestris campestris is a phytopathogenic bacterium responsible for many plant diseases, particularly soft-rot of fruits and vegetables. The pathogenicity of this organism is due mainly to the secretion of pectate lyase involved in the pectinolysis of plant cell walls.The objectives of this work were to study the production of pectate lyase associated with phytopathogenicity of Xanthomonas campestris campestris, to isolate and characterize the mutants in the regulatory systems controlling the production of pectate lyase and to examine the role of regulatory mutations in the synthesis of pectate lyase in Xanthomonas campestris campestris.Xanthomonas campestris campestris was grown and examined for pectate lyase activity in the presence of glucose and glycerol as energy sources and polygalacturonic acid and pectin as inducers. X. campestris campestris was subjected to ethylmethane sulfonate mutagenesis. Mutants were isolated and tested for the ability to produce pectate lyase in the presence of different energy sources and inducers. The mutants were grouped into different classes on the basis of their induction ratios with respect to induction by polygalacturonic acid. Effect of growth phase on pectate lyase production by each class of mutants was examined. Pectate lyase synthesized by the wild-type was purified. (ammonium sulphate precipitation) and some properties of the enzyme were examined.Production of pectate lyase in the mutants and the wild-type was inducible, constitutive, catabolite repression-sensitive and amenable to derepression. Pectate lyase synthesized by the wild-type had higher activity than pectate lyase formed by the mutants. However induction ratios of the mutants were higher than that of the wild-type strain. This indicates that the mutants were more strongly induced than the wild-type in the presence of polygalacturonic acid.Four classes of mutants were recognised with respect to their induction ratios. Effect of growth phase on pectate lyase synthesis by the mutants indicated that classes I and IIb and wild-type were partial - growth - phase - dependants (Pgpd). Classes IIa and III were total - growth - phase - dependants (Tgpd). The activity of the	partially purified pectate lease (ammonium sulphate fraction) was stimulated by Ca++, Mg++, Da++, Na+, K and NH+ but inhibited by iodoacetic acid, (EDTA) ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid and 2,4-dinitrophenol. Activity of the enzyme was optimal at pH 9.0 and at 40C.The results of this work offered some information about the regulation of pectate lyase synthesis in Xanthomonas campestris campestris. Such Information could be useful in designing genetical and physiological control measures against plant diseases caused by Xanthomonas campestris campestris and also in the production of pectate lyase for use in some local industries.|Theses Collection|Phytopathogenic bacterium/plant cell walls/pectate lyase/vegetables/polygalacturonic acid/mutants/enzyme/catabolite repression-sensitive/total - growth - phase - dependants (Tgpd) *||||||Bosede, Alfred Olufemi|M|Some results on Banach Algebra whose duals consist of multipliers||||||M.Sc. Mathematics|E.O. Oshobi||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Mathematics|1990|||OAU|||||vii,85p|||||||Englisg||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|In this thesis, some results on Banach algebra whose duals consist of multipliers were investigated. The case where the dual is a unital Banach algebra as in the style of Oshobi and Pym (1981) was considered in the sense that the Banach algebra has an identity element e whose norm e  is 1. With this and other certain conditions, it was shown that the dual of such an algebra is isometrically isomorphic to the algebra of continuous left multipliers on the Banach algebra.The case where the algebra is Aren's regular as in Oshobi and Pym (1984) that is, where the two Arens products in it coincide was also considered. Here, it was shown that under certain conditions the dual of such an algebra is a Banach algebra and that its multiplier algebra is the second dual.The case where the algebra has an approximate identity only Oshobi (1986) was investigated. That is, investigation started with a Banach algebra B with an approximate identity of norm I. With the assumption that its dual B' is a Banach algebra such that there exists an injective homomorphism B't B which maps B' onto an ideal in B and A defined to be the B'-closure of (B')2, it was shown that At is the multiplier algebra of A.|Theses Collection|Unital Banach algebra/isomorphic/Aren's regular/injective homomorphism  *||||||Ige, Iyunola Adunni|F|The development of an integrated medical information system||||||Ph.D. Computer Science|S.B.
