This delay results in an increased mortality rate. Many patients in Nigeria that could have been saved through prompt medical  attention are lost because of inadequate data processing methods. The methods adopted for gathering, processing, storing and retrieving information are not only inefficient but they also result in serious inaccuracies that fatally endanger the lives of patients. Hence the objective of this research was to develop an integrated computer-based medical information system. The integrated medical information system was developed using the Obafemi Awolowo University Teaching Hospitals Complex (OAUTHC) as a test case.The database schema design methodology, developed gave an algorithm that eliminates both transitive dependence and partial dependence from a relation. Thus the use of the algorithm on a relation gives a set of relation schemes that ensures there are no anomalies when the system goes into operation. The database schema design methodology developed in this thesis is applicable to general situations unlike the existing algorithms which are operative only within fixed constraints.This work has successfully applied database approach to medical information handling in a Nigerian hospital. It offered easy storage of data without duplication, quick retrieval of such data and easy exchange of information between the units of the hospital.|Theses Collection|Hospitals/health care delivery/mortality rate/patients/data processing methods/computer/information system/algorithm/database/Obafemi Awolowo University Teaching Hospitals Complex (OAUTHC)/Nigeria  *||||||Jaja, Ngowari|M|Comparative study of the efficiency of some extractants in assessing availability status of P, K, Mg, and Zn in igneous/metamorphic forest soils of South-Western Nigeria||||||M.Sc. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|A study was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of ten chemical extractants in determining P, K, Mg and Zn availability simultaneously. The study was conducted with soil samples collected from twenty different locations across the igneous/metamorphic rock zones of south western Nigeria. It involved laboratory and greenhouse experimentations. Soil-test values for available P and plant P-uptake was found to be poorly related to each other for all the extractants (P>0.05). The highest correlation (r = 0.329) was obtained with extractant 9(0.01M EDTA +0.5M CaCl2 + O.1M TEA, pH 7.3). The conventional Bray No. 1 extractant gave a very low correlation.	On the other hand, high correlations (P<0.05) were obtained between K-uptake and the following extractants;1:  Bray No. 1 (0.03N NH4 F + 0.025N HCl) 2:  (1N NH4 OAc pH7)3: (Modified NaHCO3 (0.05N NaHCO3+ O.O1M EDTA pH 8.5).4: (North Carolina Double acid (0.05N HCl + 0.025N H2 SO4 )  5: (New Mehlich (0.2N CH3 COOH + 0.0151 NH4 F + 	0.2N NH4 CI) 6: (1M NH4 HCO3 + O.O1M EDTA pH 7.6)  9: (O.O1M EDTA + 0.05M CaCl2 + O.1M TEA pH  7.3) 10: (O.O1M EDTA + O.O1M CaCl2+ O.1M TEA pH  7.3)and 0.01M EDTA + 0.05M CaCl2 + 0.1M TEA pH 6.0 as extractant B. The resulting correlation analyses with these new extractants did not improve over the earlier analyses. Extractants A and B gave high correlation with Mg uptake (M.05). K uptake correlated positively with extractant A (P<0.05) but not with extractant B (P>0.05).P and Zn had low correlations with both extractants A and B. Therefore, no single extractant had a high correlation for P, K, Mg and Zn simultaneously. However extractant 9 which had high correlations for K and Mg and the highest correlation for P could be used as a simultaneous extractant for P, K and Mg. Zn would then be extracted separately with extractant 7.A correlation analysis was carried out between soil test values and dry matter yield of maize. The result showed a higher correlation (e.g. for Mg r = 0.091-0.501) than that of uptake by maize (e.g. for Mg r=0.964-0.778). Applied Geology|A.A. Kayode//W.O. Emofurieta||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Geology|1990|||OAU|||||ix,88p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Geologic mapping, petrographic and geochemical studies of Liga Hills have been carried out to produce simple geologic maps, petrographic and geochemical data on the various rock types encountered in the area. The area was mapped on a scale of 1 : 10,000. Rock types identified include: dark grey cataclaslte, pink-coloured medium grained biotite granite, pink-coloured fine-medium grained granite, aplite and pegmatite and remnants of the surrounding rocks. The rocks and the alkali feldspars separated from them were analysed using Atomic Absorption Spectrophotometery (AAS), X-ray diffraction (XRD) and colourimetric methods. Major element analyses show that the rocks are granites and corundum normative. Trace element abundances B4 (444-826 ppm), Rb (288-358 ppm) and Sr (54-86 ppm) and element ratios Ba/Rb (1.20-3.47), K/Ba (53-1)3), K/Rb (140-183) and Rb/Sr (2.70-7.02) in the rocks taken together with the abundances and ratios in the alkali feldspars separated from them, Ba (200-710 ppm), Rip (461-1702 ppm), Sr (70-120 pre); Ba/Rb (0.12 - 1.54), K/Ba (148 - 658), K/Rb {72 - 222) and Rb/Sr (4.57-1420) suggest that the rocks are magmatic in origin and most likely of crustal parentage. Inter-element relationships, such as K-Rb, Ba - Rb and Rb - Ba -- Sr, in the whole rocks as well as in the alkali feldspar separates, established petrochemical trends which strongly suggest that the rocks were formed from magmas subjected to different degrees of fractionation. The trends show that the dark grey cetaclasite was formed from the least fractionated melt. The pink-coloured medium grained biotite granite and the pink-coloured fine-medium grained granite were formed from melts of intermediate fractionation while the apliteand pegmatites were formed from the most fractionated melts.  Based on the results of this study, it is suggested that the rocks of the Liga Hills are co-genetic and were formed from melts generated through anatexis of crustal materials. The maximum microcline structures (Triclinicity = 0.88 - 1.00) observed in the alkali feldspar separates reflect the long cooling history of the host rocks.|Theses Collection|Geologic mapping/rocks/Atomic Absorption Spectrophotometery (AAS)/X-ray diffraction (XRD)/fractionation/microcline structures/aplite/pegmatites *||||||Aluko, Patrick Ojo|M|Artificial insemination, genetic and cytogenetic studies in two cichlid fishes: Oreochromis Niloticus Linnaeus (Trewavas0 and Sarotherodon Galilaeus (Artedi).||||||P.hD. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Genetic similarities and differences were studied through embryological, chromosomal and biochemical investigations in two species of cichlid fishes - Oreochromis niloticus Linaeus (Trewavas) and Sarotherodon galilaeus (Artedi) to provide detailed information on the relationship between the two species.Ripe males and females of galilaeus and O. niloticus were injected with Tilapia pituitary extracts and Human Chroionic Gonadotropin (HCG) to induce spermination and spawning. Incubation of fertilized eggs was carried out in 500ml beakers. Chromosomes were studied from 12-hour and 40-hour post fertilization embryos. Lactate dehydrogenase and alcohol dehydrogenase isozyme patterns were determined by cellulose acetate electrophoresis of thirteen tissue homogenates. HOG was found to be effective in inducing spawning and spermination, while Tilapia pituitary extract was not. Intrageneric and intergeneric inseminations carried out showed that the pattern of embryonic and larval development in the two species and their hybrids were the same. A mean percentage hatchability of 60.1970 was obtained in all inseminations carried out. There were no significant (P > .01) differences in the growth rates of the two species and their hybrids at nine days post hatching.Behaviour of chromosmes in all mitotic stages in 12-hour and 40-hour old embryos of the two species and their hybrids indicated that all diploid species and the hybrids have 2n = 44 chromosomes of basically similar morphology. The gynogenetic hybrids between the two species have a haploid number of n = 22 chromosomes. No chromosomal markers identifying sex chromosmes were found.	Two forms of single nucleolus were observed in O. niloticus but only one form in S. galilaeus and in the hybrids, A low percentage (about 2% aberrations - ring chromosomes, polyploid cells, chromatin connections, dicentric bridges and laggards - were recorded in all stages of mitosis at the ages of 12 hours and 40-hours post - fertilization. The level of aberrations in meiosis of both species was high with clumping having the highest frequency of about 80. Cellulose acetate electrophoretic study or lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and alcohol dehydrogenase (AM) isozymes of some tissues showed striking similarity in the two species from three water bodies.The results suggest close phylogenetic affinity between the two species and that their hybrids could survive beyond the free swimming stage.|Theses Collection|Gene/ Human Chroionic Gonadotropin (HCG)/fertilization/lactate/Tilapia pituitary extract/inseminations/chromosmes/Cellulose acetate electrophoretic *||||||Ayanwale, Adeolu Babatunde|M|The economics of cassava production in Oyo North area of Oyo State, Nigeria ||||||Ph.D. Agric. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This thesis examined the resource-use efficiency in cassava production and processing in Oyo North Area of Oyo State. In carrying out the investigation, primary data were collected from cassava farmers and cassava processors selected through a stratified random sampling technique. Data collection involved the use of cost-route method to record detailed input-output ratios, price and other important information for the 1987/88 production season. The data were analysed with the use of budgetary techniques as well as production function approach. Also linear programming techniques were applied to determine the optimum combination of cassava with other farming enterprises in the study area.The result of the analysis revealed that cassava production and cassava processing were profitable enterprises in the study area. The observed levels of profitability were about N516.25 per hectare of cassava cultivated; N745.96 per tonne of cassava tuber processed into cassava flour (lafun); and N730.84 per tonne of cassava tuber processed into gari.The production function analysis revealed that land area, operating capital inputs and family labour were the most significant factors influencing cassava productivity. A further analysis revealed that resource-use efficiency in cassava production can be improved by increasing the area of land planted to cassava intercropped with maize, yam and cowpea and/or through a reduced rate of use of hired labour and operating capital in cassava production.The analysis carried out for cassava processing enterprises revealed increasing returns to scale both for gari and cassava flour (lafun) businesses. The above implied that further expansion of the existing processing scale can lead to better efficiency among cassava processors.The linear programming analysis revealed that the other crop enterprises being planted by the cassava farmers could generate an optimal farm plan which would result in an income of N836.91 per annum after taking care of subsistence as compared with an income of N925.60 per annum obtained from sole cassava cropping.|Theses Collection|Cassava/cultivation/cassava processors/cassava flour (lafun)/gari/cropping*||||||Ayoola, Lawunmi Molara|F|The modality for incorporating computer education into the curriculum of Federal Unity Secondary Schools in Oyo, Ogun, Ondo and Lagos States||||||M.A. Educational Technology|D.K. Oni//M.T. Ige||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Technology Policy and Planning|1990|||OAU|||||xvi,216p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|In Nigeria, the gap between this demand and supply of maize has increased from about 10,000 tonnes in 1976 to about 300,000 tonnes in 1985. This Rap can be reduced by using appropriate maize production technology. This work examines the impact of technology transfer on maize production in Ondo and Oyo States of Nigeria. The technology package examined includes improved maize varieties, chemical fertilizers agrochemical  and agricultural mechanization.Primary data were collected with the use of Questionnaires administered to two sets of  farmers. The first set consists of 100 randomly selected farmers participating in Oyo North Agricultural. Development Project (ONADEP) and the EkitiAkoko Agricultural Development Project (EAADP). The second set of farmers is made up of 100 selected maize farmers who do not participate in the Agricultural Development Projects (ADP) in Ondo and ONTO States. The data were analysed using Chisquare and multiple regression analyses.The result of the analysis revealed that about 32 per cent of maize farmers were not efficient in their use of resources. The ADP farmers used more improved seeds, fertilizers, herbicides,	pesticides and tractors than the non - ADP farmers. Thus the ADP farmers had higher maize productivity and higher returns. Also optimum farm sizes for ADP farmers were 8.05 ha. while that of non  ADP farmers were 2.45ha. It is significant that more than 80 per cent of the farmers operated below these optimum farm sizes. The marginal value productivities derived for all the technological	inputs indicate that their coefficients were higher than the marginal factor cost. This indicates that most of these inputs can still be more intensively utilized in an effort to improve on resource use efficiency. However, some major constraints	were identified as limiting the present use of technological inputs. These constraints include lack of adequate finance, high prices of inputs, poor infrastructures and lack of adequate technical knowledge on the part of the farmers.The policy recommendations advanced to improve the use of the technological inputs in maize production include the provision of credit to facilitate input archase and use, Expansion of extension education, provision of infrastructure by the government, and the need to increase the present farm holdings to attain economically optimal farm sizes.|Theses Collection|Maize/improved maize varieties/chemical fertilizers agrochemical/agricultural mechanization/Oyo North Agricultural. Computer Science|A.D. Akinde//L.O. Kehinde||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Computer Science|1990|||OAU|||||viii,88p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Computers are finding increasing use in diverse applications. As a result, their display systems are becoming increasingly sophisticated in an effort to meet with the requirements of the various applications. This has resulted in the extensive use of graphics display systems which place all kinds of facilities at the disposal of the user. This has however increased the workload of the main processor. This additional workload usually results in a marked degradation in the performance of the main processor. To avoid this degradation, graphics display systems are being designed in which the graphics functions are transferred to a dedicated processor in order to free the main processor for the main tasks of the system. This research effort is directed at designing a graphics display system that will maintain a specified image on the display by accepting as input the endpoint of the lines which define an image. It will cause the defined image to be displayed on the display device (raster-scan) and refresh regularly the displayed image and cause any modifications to be reflected on it. A study of display devices and line-drawing algorithms was carried out. A modular design was then adopted which made the system highly flexible and efficient. A dynamic and easily relocatable software system was designed for the Display Ring Processor and most of its facilities are software implemented which thus make them very easy to modify and at the same time ensures that the entire system can. be very easily upgraded. The designed software was loaded into the SDK-85 microprocessor and an IBM PC-XT connected as the host processor. The software was loaded and tested a module at a time because of the limitations of the processing environment of the SDK-85, specifically insufficient memory space. Special flags were included in the software to test that communication and transfer of data between the modules was taking place as required since the allthe software could not be loaded at once. A flag was also used to halt the microprocessor and inspect data meant for the Display Driver since one was not available for use in testing the system.The result showed that using the INTEL 8085 microprocessor as the heart of the Display Ring Processor the output of the main processor was enhanced. However, the use of a more powerful processor than the INTEL 8085 would increase the capabilities that could be buiIt into the Display Ring Processor system substantially. The ultimate aim would be to make the entire system compleletely invisible to the user, with negligible time between input of data and display of the appropriate image on the screen. A logical upgrade to this system would be the inclusion of a transformation module which would enable the system carry out transformations on the displayed image as directed by the user.|Theses Collection|Computers/graphics/algorithms/Display Ring Processor/software/SDK-85 microprocessor/IBM PC-XT/INTEL 8085 microprocessor/transformation module *||||||Ajele, Joshua Oluwafemi|M|Purification and characterization of glutathione S-Transferase from the Giant African snail. Archachatina marginata||||||M.Sc. Biochemistry|Adeyinka Afolahan||Ile - Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo University, Buiochemistry |1990|||OAU|||||xiii,129p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile - Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.| Schisto  soma heamatobium and Schistosoma mansoni are parasites that cause  schistosomiasis in Africa, and particularly in Nigeria. The intermediate hosts of these  parasites are the small water snails in the genus Bulinus. A way of eradicating the disease is by eradicating the intermediate hosts by the use of chemicals. Some of these snails, however, develop resistance to of these chemicals after a long exposure to the chemicals. It is plausible to assume that this resistance might be due to the activities of some detoxicating enzymes such as glutathione transferase. Choosing the giant African snail, Archachatina marginata, as a model snail, this work was undertaken in order to obtain some information about the structure and some kinetic properties of the purified glutathione transferase The basic glutathione transferase was purified, by a combination of ion exchange chromatography on diethylaminoethyl cellulose and carboxymethyl cellulose, adsorption chromatography and gel filtration, to homogeneity. The homogeneity of the purified enzyme was confirmed by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis in the absence and presence of sodium dodecyl sulphate. The subunit molecular weight was estimated be 22,500 - 23,500 daltons by sodium dodecyl sulphate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. The apparent molecular weight under non-denaturing condition was 44,000 daltons. The enzyme catalyzed the conjugation of glutathione with 1-chloro-2,4- activities of 47 pmol/min/mg and 38 pmol/min/mg respectively. The enzyme did not catalyze the conjugation of glutathione with 3,4-dichloro-lnitrobenzene and,1,2-epoxy-3-(p-nitrophenoxy) propane. The Michealis-Menten constant, Km, of the enzyme for glutathione and 1-chloro-2,4-dinitrobenzene were 0.23mM and 0.42mM respectively. The isoelectric point (pI) as determined by isoelectric focusing was 8.35. The amino acid composition showed that the enzyme had a relatively high content of the hydrophobic amino acid residues such as alanine, valine and leucine and a relatively high content of the acidic residues such as aspartic acid and glutamic acid. Inhibition studies on the enzyme with a number of chemical compounds showed that the enzyme was quite unique in its sensitivity to most of the inhibitors tested. Inhibition of the enzyme by N-ethylmaleimide showed that thiol group is essential for the enzyme activity and hence may be present at or near the active site. The enzyme was susceptible denaturation by denaturing agents and was able to regain some of its activity when the denaturing agent was removed. The result of the peptide mapping showed that the snail enzyme possesses at least four cysteine residues per molecule of the enzyme. The enzyme was stable at 25C and up to 40C when it was incubated at these temperatures over a period of 60 minutes. The enzyme was however rapidly deactivated at 50C and above.|Theses Collection|Schisto  soma heamatobium/snail/sodium dodecyl sulphate/polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis/glutathione transferase/enzyme*||||||Ajayi, Tayo Julius|M|L'AFRIQUE ET LA NOUVELLE CONTESTATION A TRVERS L'INCARCERE DE Y. E-mail: ul@Library.oauife.edu.ng|http://Library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise th Hezekal Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This study examines the picture of independent African states and their corrupt and tyrannical leaders, the maladministration and politics of repression in these states as presented by Yves-Emmanuel Dogbe in L'Incarcere  and Tierno Monenembo in LesGrapauds-brousse. Akingbohungbe||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Plant Science|1995|||OAU|||||xiv, 113|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Oedaleus nigeriensis Uvarov, is one of the two species of Qedaleys Fieber in Nigeria. It is widely distributed across Nigeria but it is a minor pest on crops. The second species, Oedaleus seneqalensis Krauss, is restricted to northern Nigeria where it is a serious pest of crops especially millet. It is interesting that Q. nigeriensis is not a serious pest and only adequate understanding of its biology can explain this minor pest status. This should be advantageous in planning to avoid a possible future outbreak of the insect. Accordingly, various aspects of the biology of the insect were studied. The seasonal breeding cycle and host plant associations were studied along a transect throughout different vegetation zones of Nigeria. The life history of the grasshopper was studied in the laboratory by rearing individuals singly, and several together as a population. The effects of four host plants on the development were also investigated. These included Axonopus compressus P. Beaux, Cynodon dactylon (L.) Pers., Eleusine indica (L.) Gaertn and Setaria gracilipes C.E. Hubbard; used singly, and as a mixture of all four to feed the insert. The influence of temperature and relative humidity on development was studied employing 23C, 26C, 29C, 32C and 35C constant temperatures, and 33%, 70%, 80% and 90% constant relative humidities. The field studies showed O. nigeriensis to be associated with 12 species of grasses distributed within 9 genera and 4 tribes. At Ogbomoso, llorin, Toro, Bauchi and Potiskum, two generations exist and they generally overlap. The exact time each generation commenced in the different areas varied in line with the advance of the rains. At lle-lfe, the population was scanty; and apparently one or two generations may be produced. Development was generally optimal when rearing was done on the mixed diet of four grasses. Hence, the developmental period was shorter (60 days compared with 106 - 127 days for single host plants); clutch size was also higher (26 eggs per pod compared to 18 - 20 eggs for single host plants). Polyphagy in the insect is therefore not just opportunistic; rather it is a necessary nutritional requirement for optimal development.Nymphal developmental period was 60 days and 56 days at 26C and 29C respectively, and 10% mortality was observed. It was elongated (81.5 days) at 23C, and mortality was 60%. At 32C, it was much reduced (47.2 days) and mortality was 30%. At 23C, adults laid one egg-pod, but laid three egg-pods at 29C and 32C. Thus, a temperature of 29C appears optimal for development. Nymphal mortality was 70% and 60% at 33% and 90% R.H. respectively. It was most pronounced in the first instar at 33% R.H. and in instars III - V at 90% R.H. It was 10-20% at 70% - 80% R. H. Similarly, adult mortality was 100% and 80% at 33% and 90% R.H. respectively compared to 20% at 70% - 80% R.H. Thus, optimal relative humidity for development is about 70% - 80%. |Theses Collection|Seasonal breeding cycle/grasshopper/Oedaleus nigeriensis Uvarov/Oedaleus Fieber/Oedaleus senegalensis Krauss/Nymphal developmental period/Polyphagy/insect.*||||||Njoku, Clifford Ikechukwu  |M|Computer Aided Design of Binary Batch Plate Distillation Process||||||M.Sc Chemical Engineering|A.N. Anozie||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Chemical Engineerng |1995|||OAU|||||xx, 335|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Batch distillation is one of the most widely used separation processes in the manufacuturing of specialty chemicals. The unsteady state nature of batch distillation process makes hand computation of design calculations tedious. Developing computer tools for design and simulation will not only eliminate this problem but also improve the accuracy of results. The computer design program for binary batch distillation proces developed in this work is based on two graphical design methods of binary batch distillation process: McCabe Thiele and Ponchon Savarit methods. The computer program is made up of two parts; design and simulation. The design part of the program estimates the number of stages required for a separation, distillate volume and time expected from such a distillation operation. Also included in the design program are the sizing of the rectifying column based on sieve tray design, and the heat transfer equipment (which includes a total condenser and kettle type reboiler). Constant reflux policy control method is adopted in the process design computations. The simulation part of the program simulates composition variations in the rectifying column with distillation time, considering constant reflux, variable reflux and step reflux control policies. Tabulated enthalpy, concentration data and vapour liquid equilibrium data are directly used in the program. Column liquid hold up was accounted for by an approximate method while actual numbers of distillation stages were estimated by considering tray efficiencies less than 100%.The computer program was run on a micro computer with ethanol, water mixture as distillation feed. The design results show an increase in the number of stages required for distillation with increase in expected distillate purity and decrease efficiency. The effect of column liquid hold-up was found to be stronger for very low initial charge volume, thus requiring more stages for separation. Ponchon Savarit method of design was found to be more sensitive than the McCabe Thiele method. For the simulation of a constant reflux policy operation, it was found that the distillate drawoff has a marked effect on distillation time, product purity, fraction of feed distilled and required number of stages for rectification. However for variable reflux policy operation, distillate drawoff was found to depend on the level of difficulty of separation; decreasing slowly at higher feed compositions and sharply at lower pot compositions. The overall average distillate purity obtainable by step reflux policy operation was found to depend on the cumulative contribution of the different reflux steps. However, it does not necessarily depend on the number of reflux steps but on choice of the reflux ratios and pot composition ranges for the different reflux steps. |Theses collection|Batch distillation/manufacturing of specialty chemicals/McCabe Thiele method/Ponchon Savarit method/reflux policy control/binary batch distillation*||||||Fawole, Ajibola Jelilat|F|Women and Community Bank Credit in Southwestern Nigeria||||||M.Sc Economics|R.O. Soetan||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Economics|1995|||OAU|||||xv, 158|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The study was informed by the increasingly significant role played by women in the Nigerian economy and because credit (access to loan facilities) has been a major factor limiting their contributions and productivity. This study therefore examines: the role of community banks in southwestern Nigeria in providing direct access to credit for women; constraints militating against female access to community bank's credit and the effects of community bank's credit on women's income, savings and employment. The data used for the study were derived from primary and secondary so~rces. The primary data were obtained with the aid of structured and semi-structured questionnaires administered to 273 successful loan applicants and 38 unsuccessful loan applicants of community bank's credit, from purposively selected occupations in Lagos and Ondo states. Secondary data were obtained from each community bank's credit records. Analytical techniques comprising descriptive statistics such as frequency tables and cross-tabulation were used. Chi-square (x2) test was used to test for significancies in the relationships of the cross-tabulations. Student T - test was used to test for significancies in the mean values of sales, profits and savings of successful and unsuccessful applicants. Information obtained from the twenty community banks in the sample for this study shows that on the average, the ratio of  females (1,188) patronising community banks were less than males (1,954) and women received 28.5% of the total loan disbursed. Results from the primary data indicates that, lack of access to suitable guarantors was the major constraint militating against female access to community bank's credit. other constraints were: irregular operation of account; lack of adequate collateral; dearth of economically viable projects; inability to operate a current account and non-membership of group/association, ~hrough which loans could be guaranteed. A large proportion of applicants used the community bank's credit for income generation purposes such as initiation and expansion of businesses, and majority (87.3%) of them took their loan obligations seriously by paying back their loans within the scheduled time. The community bank's credit had a positive effect on the income and savings of female loan recipients and, as respondents reported, their businesses were preserved (60.1%) while some jobs were created (35.5%). Also, Urban women had more access to community bank~credit than rural women because urban women had better access to information about formal credit. Based on these findings, suggestions were proffered to enhance: female patronage in community banks, access to community bank's credit and productivity of female loan recipients. These .I include: - Massive campaigns by community bank's officials to create awareness by women on community banking operations especially on the process of obtaining credit; - detailed disaggregation of data by sex; - counseling services by bank officials for loan applicants; - formation of women groups to guarantee loans for female loan applicants; and - granting of loans that are large enough to cover business expenses by community bank officials.|Theses collection|Women/Community bank's credit/Community banks/loan.*||||||Kolawole, Emmanuel Babafemi|M|Effectiveness of Chamer's Rule in Solving a 2 x 2 System  of  Linear Equations in Selected Secondary Schools in Ondo State||||||M.A. Mathematics Education|Sola Ehindero||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Mathematics Education|1995|||OAU|||||ix, 116|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The study was designed to compare the cognitive outcome of four methods in solving a system of Linear Equation among the Junior Secondary School three (JSS III) students in Ondo State in order to find out the best and most acceptable method. A total of eight hundred students were randomly selected from eight Local Government Headquarters of Ondo State. The four methods were randomly and evenly assigned to the eight secondary schools. There was one control group (Cramer' 8 Rule) and three experimental groups (Elimination method. Substitution Method end Equality Method). The data for the research were collected using ten item achievement tests on a 2 x 2 system of linear equation. The four treatment groups were subjected to Pre-tests/Post-tests and Retention test. The results of these tests were collected and analysed using student-t test statistic and Analysis of Variance (ANOVA). The result of this study showed that students assigned to Cramer's Rule performed better and retained more than those assigned to Elimination Rule, Substitution Rule and Equality Rule, despite the fact that they have never used Cramer's rule nor heard about it before the treatment. The implication of this study therefore is the need to introduce Matrices and Determinant as new topics in the Secondary School syllabus (JSS - SSS), in addition, there is a need for the inclusion of Cramer's Rule as a new method of teaching a 2 x 2 system of linear equation in Nigerian Secondary School Mathematics.|Theses collection|System of Linear equation/Cramer's rule/Elimination method/Substitution Method/Equality Method/Student-t statistic/Analysis of Variance(ANOVA)/Pre-tests Retention/Post-tests Retention.*||||||Kolawole, Olutoyin Dare|M|Factors Associated With The Discontinuance of  Some Agricultural Innovations Among Farmers In Ekiti North of Ondo State, Nigeria||||||M.Sc Agricultural Extention and Rural Sociology|J.A. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The focus of this study was to identify factors associated with the discontinuance of some agricultural innovations among farmers in Ekiti North of Ondo State, Nigeria. Special emphases were placed on the: identification of the agricultural innovations introduced to farmers in the study area; identification of the innovations which had been adopted and later discontinued by farmers; identification of social and personal factors which are responsible for the discontinuance of the use of innovations among farmers; and analyses of the characteristics of farmers who discontinued the use of the adopted innovations. The study was conducted in five rural communities which were randomly selected out of the thirty-one communities in the area. Structured interview schedule was used to obtain information from one hundred and fifty farmers in the project circle: Thirty farmers were selected in each of the five communities by simple random sampling. Descriptive statistical techniques such as frequency counts, percentages, means, standard deviation and weighted mean score were used to analyse the data. Correlation and regression analyses were used in determining the relationships between the variables investigated in the study. The investigation showed that about seventeen agricultural innovations were introduced into the area since the inception of the World Bank Assisted Agricultural Development Project in Ondo State. The results also showed that all the innovations were adopted except planting of yam minisett and alley farming. All the innovations introduced (except improved maize and homestead fish production) were at one time or the other discontinued by farmers. The investigation revealed that a great proportion of farmers discontinued the use of innovations as a result of lack of funds, lack of inputs and, natural circumstances and hazards. About 88.0% and 81.3% of the farmers were risk-aversive and financially constrained, respectively, hence influencing discontinuance. The study showed positive and significant correlations between discontinuance and sex (r = 0.1875), fatalism (r = 0.3405) and cost-profitability ratio of the innovation (r = 0.2050). Also, negative but significant relationship existed between discontinuance and cosmopoliteness (r = -0.1889), farm size (t= -2.211), relative advantage of the innovation (r = -0.2661), compatibility of the innovation (r = -0.2265) and, availability of the innovation (t = -2.255). |Theses collection|Agricultural innovation/Simple random sampling/Descriptive statistical techniques/World Bank Assisted Agricultural Development Project/yam minisett/alley farming/cosmopoliteness/fatalism/cost-profitability/farm size.*||||||Komolafe, Olaniyi Olusola|M|The Biology of The Fish Oreochromis niloticus in Opa Reservoir, Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile Ife, Nigeria.||||||Ph. D. Zoology|G. A. O. Arawomo||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Zoology|1995|||OAU|||||xx, 152|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Oreochromis niloticus (Linnaeus) had been reported as a major cichlid fish in Opa reservoir. A comprehensive study on the species was therefore designed to investigate the distribution, food and feeding habits, reproduction and fecundity, age and growth as well as its parasitic infestation Gill-netting and cast-netting methods were used to catch the fish samples. Specimens caught by cast-netting were only used for food and feeding and fish parasite studies while the two fishing methods were employed to study other aspects of the biology of the species. In the laboratory fish measurements were taken while scales were removed from specific locations for age and growth studies. Each fish sample was slit open ventrally from the anus to the pectoral fin and the sex and stage of gonad maturity determined. Mature gonads were weighed and preserved for fecundity studies. The stomach of each fish caught with cast-netting was dissected in the laboratory while the content was weighed and the volume determined and then preserved for food studies. Fresh fish samples were examined in the laboratory by conventional parasitological techniques for external and internal parasites. O. niloticus constituted 33.00% of all fish species caught in Opa reservoir during the period of study. The species was not spatially distributed in the reservoir. 90.5% of the specimens were caught near the reservoir bottom while 68.7% of the total catch was caught within the inshore area of the reservoir. O. niloticus was an omnivore in Opa reservoir. It fed on detritus, higher plant fragments, diatoms, algae and insect remains in a decreasing order of abundance. It was observed that the fish started feeding in the reservoir around 6.00a.m., reaching a peak around 3.00p.rn. and declined until 6.00p.m. O. niloticus of Opa reservoir bred throughout the period of study. The species was found to be a maternal mouth brooder with the female specimens carrying eggs and alevins in their mouths. The sex ratio of O. niloticus in Opa reservoir was 1:0.8. {Male/Female) The fecundity of O. niloticus ranged from 73 eggs to 1810 eggs with a mean of 815 eggs. Annulus formation on the scales of O. niloticus occurred between January and April annually. Male fish specimens grew faster in length than the females.  Growth in length in both sexes of O. niloticus decreased as the fish aged. Fish length and scale length relation- ship gave a statistically significant correlation (r = 0.835; P<0.001) while the fish length-weight relationship gave a statistically significant correlation (r = 0.969; P<0.001). 19.28% of the fish specimens examined were .infested with trematode parasites in the reservoir. Neascus sp, Clinostomum tilapiae and an acanthocephalan which infested O. niloticus specimens seemed not to have any serious adverse effect on them. Although gillnets with various mesh sizes could be used for catching O. niloticus specimens, a stretched mesh size of 10.2 cm was recommended for the proper exploitation of the fish species in Opa reservoir. |Theses collection|Oreochromis niloticus (Linnaeus)/the distribution, food and feeding habits, reproduction and fecundity/Gill - netting and Cast - netting methods used to catch Fish samples/Opa reservoir/annulus formation/Neascus sp, Clinostomum tilapiae/acanthocephalan*||||||Jemilugba, Margaret Olusolape|F|Effects of Advance Organisers in The Achievement and Retention of Student Nurses in Selected Concepts in Human Biology||||||M.A. Ed. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The study was designed to determine the effectiveness of Advance Organizers on achievement and retention of biological concepts among student nurses. The experimental design used in the study was a pre-test post-test control group type. A 50 item multiple choice test administered to both experimental and control groups was used in the study.Subjects for the study were 160 basic student nurses in the first half of their first year in three Schools of Nursing in Ondo and Osun States of Nigeria. Subjects ranged from 1830 years with the mean age of 21 years. The subjects were randomly assigned to two equivalent groups which were also stratified by gender. Each group contained 80 subjects The two groups were pretested and the experimental group was taught the introductory passage which served as the Advance Organizer., Both groups were next taught the selected concepts as contained in human biology textbook for nurses. The experimental and the control groups were later post tested immediately and two weeks after.The data collected was subjected to ttest analysis. All hypothesis were tested at 0.05 level of significance. The result showed that Advance Organizers facilitated achievement and retention more among the experimental group than the control group. The result of the study also showed that there was a statistically significant difference in the achievement and retention of mole and female student nurses in the organizing group. The male student nurses exhibited higher achievement and retention than the females. A significant difference in favour of student Nurses in Federal Schools of Nursing was also recorded.The result of this study showed that the effect of Advance Organizer on retention was statistically significant among the experimental group. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The thesis attempted a philosophical analysis, critique and justification of political violence. It also attempted to examine the place of violence, if any, in a democracy. The thesis also attempted to formulate a theory of political violence which is expected to provide an adequate basis for the moral justification of political violence. Finally, the thesis examined the realities of Nigerian politics, using as its basis the analysis of the concept of political violence.The methodology employed was the critical and conceptual analysis of existing philosophical literature on political violence and democracy. The thesis found that political violence is not only compatible with liberal democracy, but can also be justifiably used to transcend liberal democracy and therefore to establish a more fulfilling form of democracy. The thesis also found that at the base of political violence in Nigeria is the pluralist nature of the country and the inability of the ruling class to harness the value of pluralism to fashion out a unified Nigerian nation.The thesis concluded that political violence is sometimes justified under certain conditions of injustice and that political violence will remain in human societies until governments recognize and make the principle of justice a cornerstone in the act of governance.|Theses collection|Political Violence/Philosophical Analysis/Critique/Human Rights/Police Brutality/Robert Paul Wolff/Utilitarianism*||||||Bamidele, Timothy Bola|F|Financial Mobilisation Effort of The Federal Government of Nigeria,1970 -1988||||||Ph.D. Economics|A.O. Olaloye// S.I. Oladeji||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Economics|1995|||OAU|||||xiv, 237|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Economic Development has been widely accepted as a national objective of the developing economies. It has also been agreed among economists that inadequacy of funds has been the bane of growth and development of these economies. Most of them have resorted to stop gap measures which rely heavily on external financial resources to resolve the problem, disregarding the efficient exploitation of the available potential resources within their domestic frontiers. Prevailing international circumstances have however forced them to now look inwards and endorse endogenous supply of funds for development. The focus of this study is therefore to investigate the degree of mobilization of the available financial resources by the Federal Government of Nigeria within the period of 1970 to 1988. That is, to determine the taxable capacity and tax effort of the Federal Government for that period and to proffer suggestions to minimize revenue gap.Available studies were on cross - country and highly aggregated basis. This study provides a specific country approach which facilitates a less aggregative method of determining and analysing taxable capacity and tax effort by individual revenue source. Based on the fact that the GDP is the totality of all economic activities of a nation from where taxes could be obtained, and that the potential tax (or taxable capacity) is a function of potential GDP, the potential tax was estimated using three approaches viz, the constant growth rate, the targeted growth rate and the Okun's law equation approaches. Both taxable capacity and tax effort of the nation were estimated before being disaggregated by revenue source. Tax effort index was obtained by simple ratio of actual tax collection of the taxable capacity.The result of the potential GDP showed a permanent gap between actual and potential GDP, while reasons, linked with underdevelopment, aggregate supply shocks and demand side disturbances were adduced to account for the GDP gap. The results of the aggregate tax effort showed that the mean tax effort index of the Federal Government of Nigeria ranged between 0.28 and 0.51 during the study period. Oil boom periods however exhibited high tax effort indices. Individual revenue sources also exhibited the same traits and no revenue source exhibited any impressively high tax effort index except during the oil boom years. Evidences showed that there was a wide gap between actual and potential revenue of the Federal Government both aggregatively and by revenue source. This proves that large idle and unexploited resources were still left in the various revenue sources of the Federal Government during that period. The observed GDP gap and the consequent revenue gap is suggestive of an imminent revenue gap which should be pre-empted. Also, the low tax effort index observed implies the need for allocating more resources to the public sector through strategies which are capable of transferring economic surplus to the public sector.|Theses Collection|Economic Development/Developing Economics/Federal Government of Nigeria/Mobilisation/Financial Resources/Taxable Capacity/Potential GDP/Low Tax Effort Index.*||||||Balogun, Adeoye Lambe|M|Farmers Perception and Adoption of  Alley Farming Technology in Osun State||||||M.Sc Agricultural Extension and Rural Sociology|L.A. (Compositae) Against Callosobruchus Maculatus F.||||||M.Sc. Pharmacognosy|A.A. Gbolade//O.A. Onayade||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Pharmacognosy|1995|||OAU|||||xiii, 68|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Callosobruchus maculatus F. has been identified as major storage insect pest of cowpea (Vigna unquiculata s.sp. unguiculata) in Nigeria. It is effectively controlled using synthtic insecticides. Demerits such has high cost, toxicity (to handlers) and insect resistance associated with synthetic chemicals have led to the suggestion of using insecticides from of plant origin.By hydrodistillation, air-dried leaves of Ageratum Conyzoides L. yielded 0.9% of the volatile oil. The toxic effects of the oil on both sexes of the adult insects during 24hr was derermined. By fumigation experiment, it was observed that mortality increased gradually from an initial dose of 5ul/75ml container and reached a comparable level of 95% (LD50 22.9ul) and 97% (LD50 25.1ul) for the males and females respectively. The LD50 values suggested that male adults were more susceptible to the toxic effects of the oil than female adults.In the determination of the effect of the oil on oviposition and adult emergence on stored cowpea seeds, complete inhibition of oviposition (at 14 days after treatment) was not evident upon fumigation of infested cowpea seeds with different doses of the oil up to 60ul. On the other hand, complete inhibition of adult emergence (at 40 daysafter treatment) was obtained in seeds treated with a minimal dose of 20ul oil, A dose of 10 ul/9.5g swwds also produced marked decrease in ovipositon (compared with the number of eggs laid at this dosage).The effectiveness of the volatile oil as a fumigant was compared to that of a commercial fumigant (aluminium phosphide). The synthtic fumigant was found to reduce oviposition significantly at doses of 0.1 - 2.0mg/9.5g seeds in comparison with the untreated control, but ineffective in reducing emergence when compared with acetone-treated control. These effects were found to decrease with period of storage of cowpea after oil treatment.Precocene I (97.1mg/ml oil) and an unknown compound (50.9mg/ml oil) were isolated as the major constituents of the volatile oil. While precocene I inhibited both oviposition  (at 10ul) and adult emergence (at 2.5ul), the unknown compound exhibited no significant activities within the dose levels tested (0.5 - 10.0 ul).For complete protectoin of 100kg (one bag of cowpea, 105.3ml of the volatile oil would be required either as a fumigant or as seed protectant, while 26.4ml of precocene I would be needed using the latter method.The physical charateristics of the seed (percentage holed seed and percentage weight loss) were not adversely affected when compared with their respective controls.|Theses Collection|Callosobruchus maculatus F./insect pest of cowpea/Vigna unquiculata s.sp. unguiculata/hydrodistillation/air dried leaves of Ageratum conyzoides L./oviposition/adult insects.*||||||Akinyele, Olufunke Ibitola|F|Effects of Rational Emotive Therapy on the Superstitious Beliefs Among Secondary School Students in Osun State, Nigeria||||||M.A. Guidance and Counselling|K.A. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research| This study examined the effects of Rational Emotive Theraph (RET) on the superstitious beliefs of Secondary School Students in Osun State,  Nigeria. The main objectives of the study were to determine the efficacy of RET in treating superstitious beliefs and to find out whether variables such as sex, age, subject specialization and religion could significantly affect the effectiveness of the therapy. Subjects (N60) were drawn from a cluster of adolescents in a Secondary School in Osun State (age x = 16). The subjects' pre-test scores on Index of Superstitious Beliefs Scale developed by the researcher were used in determining their superstition levels. The same instrument was administered on the subjects after treatment for the purpose of collecting post-test data.Ellis' Rational Emotive Therapy (1962) principles were adopted as the treatment strategy in the experimental group. The treatment programme was made up of seven sessions. Each session lasted for one hour. The therapy spanned three and half weeks. Data were analysed using student t - test statistics and one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA). Five hypotheses were tested in the study. The first hypothesis was rejected (t = 7.67; P <.05) thereby showing that RET is efficacious in reducing the superstitious beliefs of treated subjects. The second hypothesis was upheld(t = 1.28; P <.05). This therefore gives the evidence that no gender difference was observable in the effect of RET on both male and female subjects in the experimental group.The third hypothesis was equally upheld (t = 0.74; P<.05). Thus showing that age did not affect the efficacy of RET. The fourth hypothesis was also confirmed (f = 2.48; P<.05). This attested to the fact that subjects of specialization did not affect the efficacy of RET in any way. The fifth hypothesis was also confirmed (t = 0.29; P<.05). This therefore provided the evidence that religion has no particular effect on the efficacy of RET in reducing the superstitious beliefs of the subjects treated.|Theses Collection|Rational Emotive Theraph (RET)/Superstitious beliefs of secondary school students/Osun State/Index of Superstitious beliefs scale/Ellis' Rational Emotive Therapy.*||||||Awa, Ayodele Victor|M|Organization of  African Unity (OAU) and The Challenges of Conflict Management in The 1990s||||||M.Sc. Internation Relations|A. Sesay||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, International Relations|1995|||OAU|||||x, 176|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|One of the greatest problems facing the international system in the recent times has been the extent to which crises, conflicts and wars have pillaged human society. Significantly, the search for peace and security in the international system has for long remained the major pre-occupation of statesmen and intellectuals alike. It has also found expression in the birth of various crises preventing multilateral regimes (ie. the concert of Europe, the League of Nations and the United Nations of our time.) The elusiveness of peace and security even within these contexts has equally led to the emergence of regional arrangements and organizations aimed at arresting the propensity for nation states to resort to war in a semi-primitive international system. This study critically evaluates the Organization of African Unity's (OAU) efforts in regional conflict resolution and the challenges of conflict management in the 1990s in the light of the emergence of new forms of intra and inter-state conflicts in Africa in the post cold war era.Data for the study were obtained from two main sources: primary source and secondary source. Our primary source includes official documents and reports from the OAU Secretariat and by the OAU Secretary General, speeches by Foreign Ministers of member states, the United Nation's charter, the OAU's charter, official gazettes as well as Reports commissioned by the OAU. They were complemented by secondary sources of information, such as books, articles in Journals, Magazines and Newspapers.The study finds that conflicts in the international system in general and, in Africa in particular, are complex and manifold, and that they form an integral part of social formations and interactions. Their causes are also multifaceted. Consequently, their management and resolution do not subscribe to any single stereotyped conflict management theory.The study suggests several strategies for effective regional conflict management by the OAU in the 1990s and beyond. It concludes that a revitalized and reinvigorated OAU, adequately funded and equiped, offers the best hope, especially within the context of 'try Africa first' approach, of effective regional conflict management and resolution in the 1990s and beyond.|Theses Collection|Multilateral regimes/Organisation of African Unity/conflict management/inter-state conflicts/international system/peace and security.*||||||Ajayi, Olajide Adedayo|M|A Study of The Distribution of Microorganisms In The Surface Water and Sediment of The Lagos Lagoon||||||M.Sc| K. A.  Ako  Nai||Ile-ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo University, Microbiology|1995|||OAU|||||x, 94|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The Lagos lagoon is an area of salt and brackish water separated from the adjacent sea by a low  lying shingle barrier. The specific objectives of the research are to isolate and identify microorganisms in the surface water and sediment samples collected from 24 stations, to relate the occurrence of the microbes to some physical and chemical properties of the surface water and to determine the in vitro antibiotic sensitivity profiles of the isolates recovered from these sites.	The physical and chemical properties of surface water were determined using standard techniques. PH and temperature of water collected from the sampling point were relatively stable. The salinity and conductivity of the water were high during the month of February. The chloride content determined by Mohr titration method was within permissible level of 250mg/l specified by WHO. The calcium content was high, the average recorded ranged from 138.68mg/l to 151.28mg/l for the periods of sampling collection.	Filter paper method was used for suspended solid (SS). (TOC) was estimated by UV absorbance at 254mm on filtered samples. The SS value ranged from 15,37mg/l to 45.98mg/l while the TOC value ranged from 15.31mg/l to 17.16mg/l for the months of February and June respectively.	Bacillus spp (31.21%) wee the predominant bacteria isolated from the lagoon. Other Bacillus isolates recovered were Bacilluss magaterium (16.76%) and Bacillus polymyxa (4.62%) Klebsiella sp. accounted for 9.25% and Enterobacter sp.9.25% while Escherichia coli constituted 8.99% of the total bacteria isolates. Veillonella sp. accounted for 2.89%. streptococcus sp. Proteus Vulgaris   and Pseudomonas sp constituted 1.73% each, of the total isolates. Other organisms encountered were Aeromonas Hydrophila subspecies anaerogenes (1.16%),Bifidobacterium adolescentis (0.57%) and Moraxella bovis (0.57%)	The results showed that low bacteria counts were recorded for the surface water compared with the sediment in which relatively high bacterial counts were recorded.	The in vitro antibiotic sensitivity tests revealed that 60% of the bacteria isolate showed multiple antibiotic resistances.  This is epidemiologically significant in that these resistant isolates may be difficult to control in the event of human infections. Since these organisms are also distributed in the surface water they are likely to contact minate marine organisms and if inadvertently consumed by this population, the resistant isolates may be difficult to treat. The study suggests routine monitoring of the lagoon water for sustainable economic and ecological development.|Theses Collection|Lagos Lagoon/Micro organism in The Surface Water/ in vitro antibiotic sensitivity Profiles/Salinity and conductivity/Suspended solid/ Bacilluis spp/Low bacteria count/Multiple antibiotic resistance/Marine Organism.*||||||Akinnawonu, Benson Monehin|M|Teleological Explanations, Causal Explanation and The Problem of  Reduction||||||M.A. Philosophy|Oladipo Fashina||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Philosophy |1995|||OAU||||||||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The aim of this thesis is to examine what teleological explanations are, and to determine whether explanations by reference to the future can be causal. The thesis attempts to clarify philosophers' debates on the nature of teleological explanations and to provide further arguments against the view that teleological explanations are reducible to causal explanations.The method of critical-conceptual analysis is employed. A review of existing literature on teleological explanations provides the background to the study. Several arguments for the reducibility of teleological explanations to non-teleological causal explanations are critically examined.The major finding of the thesis is that none of the attempts at reducing teleological explanations to ordinary causal explanations succeeds. The thesis concludes that teleological explanations are not causal explanations in the ordinary causal sense.|Theses Collection|Teleological Explanation/Philosopher's Debate/Causal Explanation/Critical Conceptual Analysis.*||||||Akinlo, Anthony Enisan|M|Impact of The Structural Adjustment Programme on Industrial Development in Nigeria||||||Ph.D. Economics|A.F. Odejide||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Economics|1995|||OAU|||||xi, 260|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This study aims at providing quantitative analysis of the effects of the various policies in the adjustment programme (interest, exchange and trade policies) on the performance of the industrial sector of the Nigerian economy. The study also verifies whether or not structural shift occurred in the industrial sector as a result of the introduction of structural adjustment programme in mid 1986.The analytical technique specifies the relationships between the major industrial variable such as output, employment, and profits and the quantifiable aspects of the structural adjustment programme. Primary data were collected from the manufacturing industries by the use of a questionnaire. The secondary data were obtained from the Central Bank of Nigeria and Federal Office of Statistics. Applying the least squares techniques parameter estimates was derived.The results of the interview show that the adjustment programme adversely affected profitability, output, productive capacity, employment and production costs of all categories of manufacturing industries. However, the effects were more intense in the producer good industries than in the consumer goods ones. The major shocks identified in the study include increased cost of capital, increased prices of domestic raw materials and changes in tariff system. Manufacturing industries became more cautious in decision making and adopted the following strategies to adapt to the shocks posed by the adjustment programme. These strategies include prudent financial management, reduction in labour force, increase in the unit price of output, improvement in the quality of their production and reduction in their stock of inventories.The results equally indicated that exchange and interest rates have adverse effects on the performance of the industrial sector through their effects on the costs of raw materials both imported and locally sourced which in turn adversely affects the level of prices, sales, capacity utilization, employment and profitability. The liberalisation policies instead of enhancing increased production precipitated high cost of production as well as unit price and thus decrease in capacity utilization.Finally, the structural shift tests show that structural shift occurred in the industrial sector with the introduction of the structural adjustments programme. In all, only few manufacturing industries especially the consumer good ones have benefitted marginally for the adjustment programme. Majority of the manufacturing industries were adversely affected by the programme.Based on these findings, there is there is need for government to intervene in the economy by moderating the exchange and interest rates. Likewise, industries with high local content particularly the consumer goods ones should be protected while local production of flat steel sheet, minerals among others should be increased to reduce the high import coefficienct of the capital goods sector in terns of raw materials.|Theses Collection|Structural Adjustment Programme/Nigerian Economy/Central Bank of Nigeria/Federal Office of StatisticsStructural Shift Tests/Capacity Utilisation/Employment/Profitability/Liberalisation Policy*||||||Akinlua, Akinsola Akin|M|Effectiveness of a Mathematics Correspondence Instruction On the Vocational Skills of Junior Secondary School Graduate Aprrentices in Ondo State, Nigeria||||||Ph.D. Corriculum Studies|S.M. The Subjects were randomly selected according to the type of their workshops, masters' formal educational background and numbers of apprentices in their workshops. The experimental groups were given a treatment which was the Mathematics correspondence instruction for industrial vocations (MIV). Four instruments were used to test the performances of the subjects. One of them was a 25-item multiple choice mathematics achievement test (MAT) which was developed and validated by the researcher. The other three were selected government trade test (GTT). Twelve research assistants were involved to see that the correspondence instructional material was used. Tests were administered the same day at all workshops.At P=0.05 significant level, analysis of the data showed that there were significant differences between the performances of the experimental and control groups in the Mathematics post test and the trade tests. Specifically, the apprentices who studied the Mathematics correspondence instruction performed significantly better in their trade tests and in the Mathematics post tests than those who did not. The null hypotheses which stated that there is no significant difference between the Mathematics main gain scores of the experimental and control groups" was rejected because the experimental group performed better than the control group. Also the hypotheses which state that "there is no significant relationship between subjects' performances on Mathematics and trade tests" was rejected because the result revealed a positive correlation between their performances in both tests. It was however upheld that there is no significant correlation between their performances in Mathematics' tests and trade tests and also between Junior Secondary School III Mathematics certificate grades and trade test grades.|Theses Collection|Effectiveness of Mathematics Correspondence Instruction/Trade Tests/Mathematics Achievement test/Governent Trade Test/*||||||Akinbola, Akinola Adeyi|M|Development of Some Dry Soup Mixes From Some Selected Local Soups||||||M.Sc. There are varieties of traditional local soups in Nigeria, and other African countries. The soups require much effort and time to prepare. The advantage of dry soup mixes is the convenience offered the customer. The study was therefore aimed at producing dry soup mixes based on selected local soups; and to study the keeping qualities and acceptabilities of the soup mixes.Four different local soups were developed as dry soup mixes. The soups were Vernonia leaf, Ribiscus esculentus, Vigna unguiculata and Arachis hypogea. They were produced as blends of ingredients dried at temperatures not exceeding 58oC.The reconstitution ratios of the soups were 1:6 for Hibiscus esculentus. 1:5 for Vernonia leaf and 1:4 for Vigna unguiculata and Arachia hypogea. Appearance, colour mouthfeel/thickness and taste of the reconstituted soups were acceptable to a sensory panel. Equilibrium water activities for safe storage of the soup mixes ranged from 0.08 to 0.31. The keeping qualities of the soup mixes determined by the free fatty acid and peroxide value changes for eight weeks showed the Arachia hypogea and Vigna unguiculata soup mixes were more stable than Vernonia leaf and Hibiscus esculentus soup mixes.The maximum free fatty acid values as percent oleic acid detected for the soup mixes were 1.10  0.02 for Arachia hypogea, 1.64  0.11 for Vigna unguiculata, 1.15  0.03 for Hibiscus esculentus and 1.14  0.04 for Vernonia leaf at 28  1oC ambient temperature. The maximum peroxide values as meg/peroxides per kg of fat detected for the soup mixes were 1.8  0.1 for Vigna unguiculata, 2.2  0.05 for Arachia hypogea, 5.6  0.00 for Vernonia leaf and 6.4  0.04 for Hibiscus esculentus at 28  1oC.|Theses Collection|Traditional Local Soup/Dry Soup Mixes/Reconstitution Ratio/Equilibrium Water Activities/Free Fatty Acid and Peroxide Value/*||||||Akande, Dorcas Mofoluwake|F|Reptition as a Major Linguistic-Stylystic Devicxe in the Poetry of Louis Macneice||||||M.A. English|C.O. A collection of the poems of MacNeice was first read through carefully, and then four poems considered to be representative of the use of repetition  in the poems were selected for in-depth study. The four poems were 'Prognosis', 'Apple Blossom' `The Gone-Tomorrow' and 'Prayer Before Birth'. This mination  involved the identification, classification and discussion of the different types of sentence, clause and group patterns manifested in each poem.It was found that it was the examples of syntactic parallelism that stood out prominently in each of the four poems. It was also these examples of syntactic parallelism that are thus foregrounded in the poems. The syntactic patterns repeated in the poems are of different types.
