L. Var. TZSRY)||||||M.Sc. Soil Science|E.A. Aduayi||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Soil Science|1995|||OAU|||||xiii, 104|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|A comparative study of the efficiency of Sokoto rock phosphate, (SRP, 35% P2O5) and water soluble single super phosphate (SSP, 18% P2O5) as P fertilizer sources for maize (Zea mays, (L) Var. TZSRY) was carried out on Iwo soil series (Oxic Tropudalf) in the field. The initial and residual effects of the two sources of P were assessed in 1989 and 1990 early cropping seasons respectively. The treatments consisted of the control, the two P sources applied at the rates of 25, 50, 100, 200 kg P2O5/ha and their mixtures in equal rations at the rates of 13.25 and 26.25 kg P2O5/ha.The available P was readily released from SSP while it was slowly released from SRP in the first year of trial. In the second year, however, the SRP supplied significantly higher P than SSP. The effectiveness of different rates of SRP in increasing maize grain yields followed the order of SRP25>SRP50.> SRP100 > SRP200 in the initial experiment while in the residual effects the trend was as follows:SRP50>SRP100 = SRP200> SRP25. The optimum grain yields of 5.9 and 5.1 tonnes/ha were obtained with SSP at the rates of 50 and 100 kg P2O5/ha in 1989 and 1990 respectively. The optimum grain yield could not be ascertained in the initial (1989) experiment for SRP, but in the residual (1990) effects, it was 4.9 tonnes/ha at the rate of 50 kg P2O5/ha.The relative agronomic efficiency values ranged from -500 to 0% and -150 to 100% in the initial and residual experiments respectively. This indicates that Sokoto rock phosphate was more effective in supplying P for maize growth in the second than in the first year of the experiment.|Theses Collection|Sokoto Rock Phosphate/Water Soluble Single Super Phosphate/Optimum Grain Yield/Relative Agronomic Efficiency Value*||||||Siyanbola, Adewale Tajudeen|M|Participation of Women in Agricultural and Rural Development Projects in Osun State of Nigeria||||||Ph.D. Agricultural Extension and Rural Sociology|A.A. Jibowu||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Agricultural Extension and Rural Sociology|1995|||OAU|||||xix, 266|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Women problems have received little attention in social research until recently when global attention is just being focused on them. Though women play significant and vital roles in social and economic development, many of these roles are not credited to them because of some socioeconomic, political, religious, attitudinal and other reasons. In agricultural and rural development, womens roles are invaluable. Women are active agricultural producers, processors and marketers. They are active in other non-agricultural rural development projects including the construction of roads and other public utility. The aim of this study, therefore, was to examine the participation of women in agricultural and rural development projects with a view to determining those factors that enhance or inhibit their participation. Data were collected from 282 randomly selected women participants in 238 agricultural and 205 non-agricultural in 24 communities in Osun State of Nigeria. Structured interview schedule duly pretested and validated was used to collect data between July and November, 1993. The study showed that women participated more in cooperative (34.08%) and group farming (31.93%) activities in agricultural development projects and environmental sanitation (29.27%) in non-agricultural rural development projects. Majority of the agricultural (52.94%) and non-agricultural (53.66%) projects were community-sponsored. Local and State governments contributed few projects. Federal and International agencies had little impact. The socioeconomic standard of the women who were mostly farmers (39%), traders (31.90%) and civil servants (12.11%) was low. The average year of schooling was about 5 and average annual income N1,442.52. Women farmers interviewed were not planting tree crops neither were they keeping much livestock. Majority took part in farm tasks such as harvesting, weeding, processing and marketing which are less strenuous than land preparation operations. Change agents introduced most (62.41%) of the projects studies. The more frequently used method of teaching the women was group meeting. Community attitude towards women was found to be largely neutral. Positive and significant relationships were found at 0.05 level of significance between women participation in agricultural and rural development projects and position of respondents among other wives (r = 0.258); number of children (r= 0.119); size of farmland (r= 0.299); years of schooling (r = 0.213), and social participation (r = 0.369). The more these factors were present, the more women participated in communal projects. Age (r = 0.106), income (r= 0.050) and cosmopoliteness (r = 0.041) were not significant. Community leadership (r= 0.314) and attitude towards women (r = 0.331) were also significantly associated with women participation. |Theses Collection|Women Problems/Social Research/Agriculture and Rural Development/Cooperative and Group farming/Environmental Sanitation/Socioeconomic Standard of Women/Land Preparation Operations.*||||||Torimiro, Dixon Olutade|M|Evaluation of Forms of Communication on the Adoption of Improved Agricultural Technologies by Farmers under Ogun State Agricultural Development Project in Nigeria ||||||M.Sc. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This thesis attempted a detailed examination of the libertarian and the welfarist arguments on equality and liberty in a just society. Attention is focused on the distinct conceptions of justice proposed by the welfarists, as expounded by John Rawls in the difference principle and the libertarians' attempt, represented by Robert Nozick's entitlement theory to refute the welfarist conception. Furthermore, this thesis examined, against Nozick's position that patterning considerations have no role to play in distributive, justice, the arguments for the distribution of social goods according to needs.  The methodology employed in this study was a combination of conceptual analysis and argumentation. The major arguments raised in John Rawls' A Theory of Justice, Robert Nozick's Anarchy, State and Utopia, as well as philosophy journals and commentaries, were examined. This thesis found that none of the theory of distributive justice standing by itself could constitute an adequate theory of justice. The entitlement principles have a role play in justifying the distribution of holdings. But the entitlement theory does not by itself, provide an adequate account of distributive justice; a theory that takes the consideration of needs into account is equally important. This thesis concludes that what is needed is a theory of distributive justice that takes both the entitlement principles and needs into consideration.|Theses Collection|Libertarian and Welfarist Arguement/Patterning Consideration/Anarchy State and Utopia/Theory of Justice/Entitlement Theory*||||||Aileme, Joanne Dada|F|The Effect of Light and Nutrient Stresson the Growth, Yield and Photosynthetic Apparatus of Cowpea||||||M.Sc. Botany|A.A. Adelusi||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Botany|1995|||OAU|||||xx, 134|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Cowpea (Vigna unguiculata), a legume, was subjected to light and nutrient stress to study the combined effect of these stress factors on its growth, yield and pigment accumulation. Cowpea seeds were grown in pretreated sand and watered with distilled water until the plants were established. A group of plants were nutrient- stressed by administering 100ml of complete nutrient solution once in four days while plants grown under shade were considered as light-stressed. The nutrient solution if administered once in two days was considered adequate for the plants and adequate light was obtained in the direct natural sunlight. In plants grown in full sunlight, there was enhanced biomass, root:shoot ratio, leaf area. duration, unit leaf rate, relative growth rate, photosynthetic pigment accumulation and seed yield. In the shade condition however all the above parameters except the leaf area ratio and leaf weight ratio were reduced. The plants in the shade also had altered plant habit, a delay in nodule formation while more leaves were produced. Nutrient-stress caused a reduction in all the above parameters except the root:shoot ratio. Under the shade and when nutrient was limiting, the photosynthetic pigments were not able to adapt to shade condition. A delay in the reproductive phase was noticed when both light and nutrients were limiting, but the cycle was of a shorter duration when nutrient alone was limiting. It can be concluded that cowpea respond to light and nutrient stress through altered plant habit, pigment accumulation and reduced seed yield. |Theses Collection|Light and Nutrient Strenght/ Pigment Accumulation/Root:Shoot Ratio/Leaf Area Duration*||||||Ajamu, Thomas Kayode|M|An Analysis of Denominationalism in the Deeper Christian Life Ministry and the House-To-House Prayer Ministries||||||M.A. Religious Studies|M.A. Ojo||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Religiuos Studies|1995|||OAU|||||viii, 97|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. It also identified the manifestations of denominational tendencies in the areas of doctrinal emphases, religious practices, membership and organizational structure, as well as the general outlook of these two Charismatic organizations.The study utilised the phenomenological and historical approaches for its methodology. The historical approach was based on the analysis and interpretation of primary sources, such as newsletters, Bible Study outlines, recorded sermons, etc. In addition, relevant secondary literature including books, journal and newspapers reports were consulted. The phenomenological approach involved the participation in and observation of some activities of the two organizations studied by the investigator.The study established that denominationalism is almost irresistible for Charismatic organizations that embark on evangelism and territorial expansion. This is because in the process of preserving their converts, denominational apparatuses, such as the institution of Sunday worship services, the employment of paid ministers, and structures to cater for the social needs of members, etc. will inevitably emerge. Ilesanmi||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Yoruba|1995|||OAU||||This study, set out to collect and analyse the lineage poetry, oriki orile of selected Crowned Obas in Ekiti: Arinjale, Ewi-Ado, Elekole and Onitaji, with a view to identifying the various allusions in each data and to interpreting the allusions in each data and to interpreting the allusions in each lineage poetry. Primary data were collected from poets and chanters in Ise-Ekiti, Ado-Ekiti, Ikole-Ekiti and Itaji_Ekiti. Many oral poets, chanters and singers in these towns were interviewed on the analysis and implications of allusions in their lineage poetry.The in-depth study of allusions in lineage poetry of the Ekiti-Yoruba is the focus of this study. The aim of the research is to open up a new area of research into Yoruba oral literature, especially poetry. Although, there have been studies on Oriki and/or oriki orile, not much attention seems to have been paid to the study of allusions and their analysis in such works.Library research was conducted with a view to cross-checking facts and/or claims made by informants. Relevant mimeographs, journals, theses and books relating to the research work were read and valuable information was deduced from them. The data collected were analysed in order to know the degree of allusions in the poetry of' each lineage, and selected allusions were analysed in order to know the meaning and the implication of each allusion.The study examined the concept of allus1on and its functions. It also examined its nature, its types, and structure, and its pattern of occurrence. The definitions of lineage poetry as given by some scholars were also examined. It is through the attempt made to analyse most of the allusions in each lineage poetry, that light was shed on the folklore of each lineage.The findings revealed that an in-depth study of oriki orile by way of analysing and interpreting the various allusions that the genre contains is highly essential to the over-all literary and semantic understanding of the genre. The findings also clearly revealed the nature of the historical, geographical, religions and sociological background of the Ise, Ado, Ikole and Itaji people in the Ekiti kingdoms. |xiv, 198|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. Mo se agbeyewo eda, eya ati ihun iyanrofeere, mo si se agbeyewo oriki ti awon onimo kan fun oriki orile. Nipa igbiyan ju ise yii ni sise itupale opolopo iyanrofeere ti o wa ninu oriki orile kookan ti mo gba jo, ni mo mo nipa fokiloo iran kookan.Ise yii fi han pe akojinle oriki orile nipa sise itupale ati titumo awon iyanrofeere inu re pon dandan ki a to le ni oye ise-ona eya litireso alohun naa ati itumo ti o ni lapapo.Ise iwadii yii tun fi eda eko-itan, ibudo, esin, ati ipile imo-ibara-eni-gbe-po awon eniyan ise, Ado, Ikole ati Itaji ni ile Ekiti han.|Theses Collection|Lineage Poetry/Oral Poets/Allusions/Oral Literature/Oriki Orile.*||||||Ajayi, Adedayo Olufemi|M|Identification of Training Needs of Women in Oyo State Nigeria||||||M.Sc. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The focus of this study was to identify the training needs 0f women farmers in Oyo state. Specifically, the study was designed to identify the women farmers' role in the production of selected crops and livestock; ascertain the present level of women farmers' knowledge and skill in the selected crops and livestock production, and identify the women farmers training needs in relation to their roles in selected crops and livestock production. The study was conducted in five selected Local Government Areas (LGAs) out of the 25 LGAs in Oyo state. Two percent of the communities in each selected LGA were randomly selected and one tenth of the households in each of the selected communities were also random1y selected. Structured interview schedule was developed and used to collect information from one hundred and seventy one women farmers. Descriptive statistical techniques like frequency counts, percentage, mean, standard deviation and weighted mean scores were used to analyse the data. In addition, correlation and regression analyses were used to determine the relationships between the independent and dependent variables investigated in the study.  The results showed that women farmers performed virtually all farm operations. Although they were highly involved in selection of cassava planting materials, planting of seeds, harvesting of grains and vegetables, they were less involved in chemical weeding, construction of poultry and livestock houses, slaughtering and dressing of animals and marketing of livestock products. The weighted mean scores in knowledge and skill of women farmers were low in chemical treatment of seeds, chemical weeding, storage of grains in modern maize cribs and silos, chemical and indigenous method of pest control and marketing of produce at cooperatives. The construction of modern houses for poultry, and pens for livestocks, compounding of livestock feeds, livestock breeding, identification and diagnosis of sick animals, selection and administration of drugs also had low weighted mean scores on knowledge and skill. The felt training needs of women farmers included construction of modern poultry house, livestock pen, diagnosis of sickness in, livestock and selection and administration of drugs. The study showed positive and significant correlation between felt training income from farming (r = 0.1569). However, there was a negative but significant correlation between felt training needs and years of farming experience (r = -0.1667). |Theses Collection|Crops/Livestock/Women Farmers/Chemical Treatment/Diagnosis/Sick Animals.*||||||Ajetomobi, Joshua Olusegun|M|Factors Affecting the Economic Efficiency of Womewn Farmers Within Ondo State Agricultural Development Programme||||||M.Sc. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This study examined the factors affecting the economic efficiency of women farmers within the Ondo State Agricultural Development Programme (ODSADP). 100 each of participants and non-participants were randomly selected from the 5 zones into which ODSADP was divided. Structured questionnaires were administered on the respondents to collect data on salient variables of interest. The analysis of the data revealed some structural differences between participants and non-participants in their use of production resource for maize and cassava but not maize, though both groups were not economically efficient. Results indicate increasing returns, to scale for maize production with sum of elasticities being 1.04 and 1.13 for participants and non-participants respectively. For cassava, results indicate decreasing returns to scale for non-participants with sum of elasticities being 0.71 and 1,13 for participants and non-participants. These result also imply that the participants were more efficient than the non-participants in their use of resources for cassava production.The t-test and X2 test analysis of the socio-economic character of the participants and non-participants showed that age, family size, farming experience and membership of farmers group influenced the respondents willingness to participate in the Women in Agriculture (WIA) programme. It was also observed that the use of fertilizer by participants was significantly affected by their farming experience, record keeping and time devoted to farming. However, only the time devoted to farming significantly affected the use of fertilizer by non-participants. Age and education significantly affected the participants use of credit while the use of credit by non-participant was affected only by farming experience. (Meliaceae)]||||||Ph.D. Pharmacognosy|A.A. Elujoba||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Pharmacognosy|1995|||OAU|||||xiii, 180 |||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Khaya qrandifoliola (Welw) C.D.C. family Meliaceae is used in form of decoction by traditional healers in the Western part of Nigeria for the treatment of malaria and other febrile conditions.  The research was aimed at investigating the antimalarial efficacy of the stem bark extracts and to evaluate the various phytochemical fractions of the extract for antimalarial properties. Also, to isolate and characterize the constituents of the crude drug extract and evaluate these chemical constituents for in vivo (in mice) and in vitro antimalarial properties. In line with these objectives the powdered stem-bark of K. grandifoliola was extracted with water using Soxh1et apparatus. The aqueous extract was successively partitioned with n-hexane, chloroform, and ethyl acetate. The aqueous extract and the organic solvent fractions were evaluated for schizonticidal (in vivo) and plasmocidal (in vitro) activities against Plasmodium berghei berghei in mice and P. falciparum respectively.The aqueous extract gave about 87% average chemosuppression at 500 mg/kg/day, while the reference chloroquine gave 91 % chemosuppression at 5 mg/kg/day. The n-hexane, chloroform, ethyl acetate and water fractions gave 91 %, 45%, 48% and 60% chemosuppression respectively at 200 mg/kg/day. The n-hexane fraction (NH) was further purified and the subfractions therefrom NH-1, NH-2, and NH-3 at 100 mg/kg/day gave 57% and 12% chemosuppression respectively. By in vitro experiment, using P. falciparum, extract and fractions gave 1.C50 value range of 0.84 to 20.41 g/ml for the Nigerian P. falciparum isolates and 1.40 to 21.11 g/ml for the multi-drug resistant clone W2 strain of P. falciparum. Chloroquine and Mefloquine were used as standards which gave 1.C50 values of 0.045 g/ml and 0.002 g/ml, respectively. The NH-2 subfraction gave the highest plasmocidal activity in vitro against P. falciparum (1.44 g/ml for the multi-drug resistant clone W2 strain). Two compounds isolated from the NH-2 subfraction, were characterized as pseudrelone X (NH22e) and methyl 6-acetoxy angolensate (NH23b). Compound C5-IV, obtained from the chloroform fraction, was characterized as methyl-6-hydroxy angolensate while compound KE34-F from the ethyl acetate fraction was suggested to be an isomer of methyl 6-hydroxy angolensate (compound C5-1V). The results have thus provided some scientific support for the use of Khaya grandifoliola as an antimalarial agent by traditional healers in Nigeria. Although the observed activity was lower than that of the standard antimalarial drugs tested, the high level of schizonticidal and plasmocidal activities against multi-drug resistant strain of P. falciparum is interesting and should justify further studies. |Theses Collection|Khaya grandifoliola (Welw) C.D.C. family/Meliaceae/decoction/traditional healers/treatment of  malaria/febrile conditions/antimalaria efficacy/phytochemical fractions/crude drug extract/stem bark/multi-drug resistant*||||||Afolayan, Kayode Raphael|M|Physicochemical properties of lysozome from fruit bat ( Eidolon helvum, kerr) kidney||||||M.Sc, Biochemistry|Ogunbiyi, O.A||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Biochemistry|1995|||OAU|||||x, 79p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Lysozyme or mucopeptide N-acetylmuramyl hydrolase (EC 3.2.1.17) is an enzyme which hydrolyses the glycosidic bond between C-1 of N-acetylmuramic acid and C-4 of N- acetylglucosamine in the peptidoglycan of the cell walls of bacteria, thus killing the bacteria and protecting the host cells from infection. The enzyme has been extracted, purified  and characterized from various sources including avian egg-white, insects, reptiles, man, monkey and dog. This study was undertaken to extract and purify the lysozyme from the kidney of the fruit-eating bat, Eidolon helvum (Kerr), with a view to establishing its general and special characteristics in comparison to the liver lysozymes of the same animal and lysozymes from other mammalian as well as non-mammalian sources. A homogenate of fruit bat kidney was prepared and lysozyme purified from it by heat treatment at 60C for 10 minutes followed by cation exchange chromatography and re-chromatography on Carboxymethyl Sephadex C-2S. A partial purification was achieved as the preparation gave two bands on polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. The molecular weight of the enzyme determined by gel filtration on Sephadex G-100 was 13,490 daltons. The enzyme has an optimum pH of between 8.0 and 9.0. Histidine and imidazole inhibit the enzyme competitively with inhibition constants of 20 and 24mM respectively. Substrate saturation of the enzyme occurs in the range 200 to 210g/ml, while substrate inhibition occurs at a substrate concentration above 210g/ml. The Vmax for the enzyme was found to be 13.5 absorbance (450nm) change/g protein while a K of 57.3g/ml was also obtained. The enzyme preparation was relatively stable to heat, retaining about 51% of its activity when incubated for 45 minutes at 60oC and pH 7.0. When heated at 100oC for 20 minutes at a pH value of 5.0, 7.0 or 9.0, the enzyme retained 36.5-43.5% of its activity. Fruit bat kidney lysozyme resembles fruit bat liver lysozyme and hen egg-white lysozyme in many of the properties studied and may be another chicken or c type lysozyme. |Theses collection|enzyme/bacteria/kidney/fruit-eating bat/mammalian/egg-white lysozyme/hen.*||||||Ogunyomi, George Olushola Ayobami|M|`The scale of justice and the judicial process in nigeria||||||PhD,  Law|Ijalaye, D.A.// Bopari,S.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Law|1995|||OAU|||||xix,365p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The avowed goal of our Constitution is to promote the good government and welfare of all persons in this country on the principles of Freedom, Equality and Justice and to consolidate our national unity. Towards these ends, the entire superstructure of our legal system and judicial process are erected and continue to be erected for the main purpose of justice-dispensation and the auxiliary goal of securing public order. There is, however, a constant need to appraise and improve upon the process because of its apparent shortcomings, so as to make it more beneficial, even if the desired social goals cannot be attained absolutely. Ironically, the level of success and efficiency or effectiveness of the machinery of justice can only be determined by realistically evaluating the judicial/legal process on the scale of justice based upon an understanding of the relevant concept of as well as the approaches to the administration of justice in Nigeria. The aims and objectives of this thesis are to explore and critically evaluate the Nigerian juridical construct and judicial process on the scale of justice in order to determine whether justice can result there from despite all the emphasis placed on the process as the last hope of man. The work defines our scale of justice as consisting of those beliefs, principles, processes and the institutions which we build up as well as our actions and reaction to them. It reviews and examines theories of justice such as absolute justice, discusses and identifies jurisprudential and sociol-political backgrounds of the Nigerian of Justice and isolates the peculiar or features of law in the solution of human conflicts in Nigeria. In addition, the work also examines and discusses administration of Justice under the modern Nigerian machinery of in the light of public reactions thereto as well as the impact of military administration thereon. The methodology of the analytical and sociological of jurisprudence are employed. Primary and secondary sources, data and literatures are re- viewed and analyzed in the subject of this work. In addition, use is made of practical observation made, and derived in the course of my legal practice. The work finds, on the One hand, that some of the merits of our present day machinery of justice are fair hearing in dispute resolution as well as the proscription of the barbaric modes o right assertion legal process. On the other hand, it that judicial justice, not, only lies beyond the reach of the common man but that the end-product the judicial process could often be unrewarding and illusory if the cost is properly counted. The work maintains that true or real justice cannot be attained through the instrumentality of the judicial process whether in this country or elsewhere because of the many limitations and short-comings of the system which often makes the pursuit of justice practically illusory. Nevertheless, the work, out of expediency, advocates that attention be paid to the serious defects of our adjudicatory system and offers suggestions for its improvement. |Theses collection|Constitution/government and welfare/national unity/legal system/judicial process/jurisprudential/jurisprudence/barbaric modes/sociol-political backgrounds.*||||||Elubamipe, Yunusa Kehinde|F|Towards a marxist epistemology||||||PhD, Philosophy|Fashina, O||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Philosophy|1995|||OAU|||||xii,281p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The main objective of the thesis was to formulate a Marxist epistemology, taking account of some achievements and defects of contemporary non-Marxist epistemology. The thesis examined some major philosophical challenges to traditional foundationalist epistemology by some influential contemporary non-Marxist philosophers such as Wittgenstein, Foucault, Macintyre, Quine, and Rorty. Furthermore, the thesis identified and assessed some influential interpretations and criticisms of epistemology in Marx's philosophical writings. Finally, the thesis attempted to determine in what ways Marxism could make a distinct contribution to epistemology. The methodology employed was textual interpretation and conceptual analysis of existing texts both in Marxist and non-Marxist philosophy. The thesis analyzed primary texts such as Karl Marx's The German Ideology, Economic and Philosophical Manuscripts, Grundrisse. The Poverty of Philosophy, Preface to a Critique of Political Economy, and Capital. In addition, up-to-date primary and secondary texts from Marxist and non-Marxist scholars were extensively used. These included journals, monographs, and edited collections. The thesis found that Marx did not offer a systematic epistemology. Nevertheless, Marx made substantive contributions to epistemology, both through his general conception of epistemology and his answers to specific issues in the discipline. In particular, it was found that there are Marxist answers to the problems of Truth, Perception, Knowledge, and justification. Although Marxist epistemology as it was identified in this thesis did not present a settled core set of answers to these traditional issues, this does not detract from Marx's contributions. The thesis concluded that a viable and intellectually rewarding Marxist epistemology will emerge from the development and expansion of the current state of Marxist philosophical scholarship, through constant revisions and rigorous critical appraisal. |Theses collection|Marxist epistemology/non-Marxist epistemology/philosophers/foundationalist/philosophical.*||||||Brown, Adedayo Alfred|M|Evalation of peppers (capsicum spp) as enhances of egg production and quality in layers||||||PhD, Animal Science|Sonaiya, E.B.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Animal Science|1995|||OAU|||||xiv, 116p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Peppers (Capsicum spp.) are the only pigmenting agents which have been reported to increase yolk size in addition to coloring the yolks. This research was carried out to study the chemical composition of local peppers (Capsicum spp.), and to determine the extent to which inclusion of various levels of peppers in layers diets could affect productive performance and quality of eggs. Four varieties of peppers were tested: Capsicum annuum ('Tatase'-TT), Capsicum annuum ('Atarodo'-RD), Capsicum frutescens ('Shombo'-SH), Capsicum frutescens ('Atawewe'- WW). Proximate components, total carotenoids, ascorbic acid, pH and crude piperine were determined in pepper varieties subjected to two processing procedures: Parboiling-Drying-Grinding; or Drying-Grinding. Voluntary intake of peppers and water, and bioavailability of pepper carotenoids were determined in layers. Studies on productive performance for two 28-day periods were carried out using diets containing 0.0, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, or 2.0% of SR, or RD in the diets. Eggs produced by birds feeding on these diets were evaluated for their quality characteristics. All the peppers contained more Gross Energy (GE), Crude Protein (CP), Crude Fibre (CF), Ether Extract (EE) and ash than maize which had more Nitrogen - Free Extract (NFE). Among the peppers, WW consistently contained the highest CF, EE and GE; TT was highest in CP, ash and NFE; SH and RD were marginal in their CF, CP, EE, GE, ash and NFE contents. Parboiling prior to drying and grinding led to a general reduction in the vitamin C, total carotenoid, CP, EE, GE, CF and OM contents of the peppers.Voluntary intake of peppers and water was in the order: RD = SH = WW = TT (P<0.05). The percent bioavailability of the carotenoids was not significantly (P>0.05) different among the various peppers. Body weights and rectal temperatures were not significantly affected by pepper intake, 'and no mortality was recorded. Vitamin C content of the peppers was positively correlated (P<0.05) with pepper and water intake (r=0.73 and r=O.90, respectively). Bioavailability of carotenoids was negatively correlated (P<0.05) with total carotenoid content of peppers (r=- 0.71). There were no significant differences (P>0.05) among the various diets for hen-day production, mean egg weight, rate of lay, egg mass and feed consumed/g egg at the end of the 56-day study. Egg weights and feed intake were significantly higher in the second period (P<0.05). The 2.0% RD diet had the highest (P>O.O5) egg weights, yolk weight, yolk color, and shell surface area among the ~ annuum diets. Overall, the 2.0% RD diet was not different from the 0.5% SH for most of the parameters measured (P>O.O5). There was a significant correlation (P<O.Ol) between the yolk weight and egg weight for the Capsicum - containing diets. The study shows that Atarodo (C. annuum) or Shombo (C. frutescens) did not significantly enhance productive performance, while 1.5-2.0% Atarodo (C. annuum), or 0.5% Shombo (C. frutescens) could enhance yolk pigmentation, yolk weight, shell thickness, and egg weight in layers. The ascorbic acid and carotenoid contents of peppers may be the major active compounds responsible for enhancement of quality of the eggs. |Theses collection|Peppers/yolks/eggs/Parboiling-Drying-Grinding/Drying-Grinding/yolk pigmentation.*||||||Bodunrin, Henry Olatokunbo|M|Attitude of adolescent towards abortion in Lagos Mainland Local Government Area||||||M.Sc, Sociology and Anthropology|Odebiyi, A.I||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Sociology and Anthropology|1995|||OAU|||||ix, 86p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Adolescent sexuality is fast becoming one of the priority areas of research in recent times, with particular attention given to attitude of adolescents towards abortion. Pre-marital sex is now the norm among adolescents hence unwanted pregnancies are on the increase. Against this background, unsafe abortions often resulting in mortality among adolescents is often rampant or unavoidable. This explains the need for a study of this nature so as to prevent this human wastage. This study examined the attitude of adolescents towards the issue of abortion and towards its legalization. It examined adolescents preferences for safe sex, and also identified the methods of abortion known to adolescents. Finally, the study highlighted the need for education on safe sex. The study was carried out among secondary school pupils in Lagos State between mid May and June ending 1994, using a multi-stage sampling technique, 240 secondary school pupils were selected from senior secondary school III within Lagos Mainland Local Government Area. Primary data were collected through questionnaires while the review of previous studies formed secondary data. The data collected were tabulated, interpreted and buttressed with discussions. Furthermore Chi-square analysis was adopted for testing the hypotheses. The most interesting aspect of the finding is that there were differences between the male and female responses. More female adolescents preferred abortion to marriage as a solution for unwanted pregnancy than the male adolescents. Again more females than males stated that they would depend more on peers than parents on issues of abortion. Adolescents in the study were not favourably disposed towards the use of condoms. Moreover, adolescents tend to support the introduction of sex education in secondary schools. Some of the recommendations that emanated from the study are that government should legalize abortion and guarantee all women access to contraceptive choices and safe abortions. Also obstetric wards should be supplied with adequate facilities for effective management of complicated abortion cases. Sex education should be introduced into secondary schools and adolescents should be encouraged to practise safe sex through the use of condoms. Moreover, parents should counsel their adolescent children on issues of sexuality and contraceptives so as to prevent unwanted pregnancies. |Theses collection|Adolescent sexuality/abortion/Pre-marital sex/adolescents/unwanted pregnancies/human wastage/safe sex/marriage/condoms/contraceptive/obstetric ward/children.*||||||Adedui, Aderemi |M|Sediment yield from erosion plot on ultisols, ife area, south western nigeria||||||M.Sc, Geography|Ogunkoya, O.O||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Geography|1995|||OAU|||||ix, 85p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Sediment yield was studied from nine erosion plots cultivated with early maize in 1985. These nine plots are sited in three different locations around Tonkere on slopes of 10%, 8% and 14%, with three contiguous plots (A, B, C) in each of the locations.The study aims at determining the magnitude of soil loss from the maize plots; the relationship between soil loss and factors such as rainfall erosivity, soil erodibility, slope and crop management and using the data obtained to evaluate the parameters of Universal Soil Loss Equation (USLE) as well as to test the goodness of fit of the USLE derived for the study area.Rainfall erosivity parameters and other components of USLE were determined and analysed following the methods outlined by Morgan (1979). Multivariate statistical methods were used in data analysis.Soil loss was highest in Tonkore 3 (309 Kg/ha/yr), followed closely by Tonkero 1 (219 Kg/ha/yr) and the least (73Kg/ha/yr) from Tonkere 2. Soil loss correlated most significantly with runoff, followed closely by rainfall amount and antecedent precipitation index (A.P.I.) with r = 0.69, 0.58 and 0.57 respectively (significant at a = 0.05).Other erosivity parameters such as peak intensity, Al15, El15, KE>25 and El30 indices were also significantly related to soil loss but average rainfall intensity did not.Runoff, rainfall amount, A.P.I; peak intensity, EI15, KE>25, EI3O indices and average intensity respectively explain about 48%, 34%, 32%, 18%, 14%, 13%, 10%, 8% and 1% of the soil loss variance.Of all the Universal Soil Loss Equation (USLE) components considered in the present study, rainfall erosivity factor (R) correlate most significantly with the observed soil loss (r= 0.88, at a = 0.05) followed closely byslope factor (LS). However, crop/cover factor (C), credibility factor (K) and management practice (P) exhibited poor or no relationships with soil loss, Rainfall erosivity and slope factor together account for 89% of the variance in the soil loss observed with the former alone accounting for 78% of the soil loss variance in the nine stations. The stepwise regression equation derived from the result of the USLE components determined from nine stations is expressed asLog A = -0.0054 + 0.68 Log R + 0.28 Log LS.The result of the X2 - analysis used to test the goodness of fit of the derived USLE for the study area revealed that the difference between predicted soil loss and observed soil loss is not significant.|Theses collection|Sediment yield/early maize/Universal Soil Loss Equation (USLE)/Rainfall erosivity.*||||||Adebisi, Samuel Sunday|M|Teratogenic of ethanol on the inta-uterine development of bones in rat||||||M.Sc. Pharmacitics|Akala, E.O//Onawunmi, G.O.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Phamacitics|1995|||OAU|||||xviii, 173p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Amodiaquine is superior to chloroquine in the treatment of chloroquine resistant Plasmodium falciparum malaria. Its hepatic biotransformation, however, allows only a small fraction of the orally administered drug to reach the systemic circulation unchanged. The alternative route via slow rate-controlled infusion is difficult for ambulatory patients. The current effort is directed towards the formulation of a suppository of amodiaquine hydrochloride (AMQHCL), since it has been shown that rectally absorbed drugs bypass the liver to enter the systemic circulation.The in vitro release of AMQHC1 from naturally occurring and locally available fatty bases such as theobroma oil and shea butter has been reported to be poor when compared to the semi-synthetic fatty bases and the hydrophilic bases, In the present study, non-ionic surfactants were therefore incorporated in the suppositories and their effects at enhancing in vitro release of AMQHC1 determined. The amount of drug release from the prepared suppositories in the in vitro test for drug release was estimated spectrophotometrically. The effects of the types and concentrations of surfactants on the extent of drug release, melting range and softening point were assessed by complete analysis of variance and the Newman-Keul's test.Tween 80 at 4% w/w produced the best release enhancement from theobroma oil suppositories. Tween 20 was optimal at 8% w/w while Brij 35 inhibited drug release. All the surfactants enhanced AMQHCL release from shea butter suppositories. The melting ranges of all the suppositories of the two bases were adequate and there was correlation between softening point and  the extent of drug release. From the kinetics studies on theobroma oil and shea butter suppositories, the zero-order kinetics was found to be the best fitting model. However, at 10% w/w AMQHCL in shea butter suppositories, diffusion controlled release was observed which changed to zero-order kinetics at 20% w/w AMQHCL.The best formulation of AMQHCL suppositories with adequate drug release and physico-chemical properties can be produced with 4% w/w Tween 80 in theobroma oil and shea butter. Softening point may serve as an index of drug release and the zero-order kinetics will be very beneficial if sustained in vivo. This will provide a constant drug blood-level that will be independent of the drug concentration at the site of absorption.|Theses collection|Amodiaquine/chloroquine/Plasmodium falciparum malaria/ambulatory patients/theobroma oil/shea butter/drug blood-level /biotransformation/drug.*||||||Adebayo, Adetokunbo Adedayo|M|Electrical resistivity investigation of the ground water potential of the okitipupa/ agbabu tar sand area of ondo state||||||M.Sc. Applied Geophysics|Ako,B.G.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Geology|1995|||OAU|||||xiiii, 135p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The study of electrical resistivity and borehole data for groundwater development in the Okitipupa/Agbabu tar sand area of Ondo State has been carried out. This is with a view to identifying the different aquifer units and their characteristics, the subsurface structures/tectonics and their influence on the general hydrogeological conditions in the area. The electrical resistivity data were made up of 48 Schlumberger Vertical Electrical Soundings (VES). The resulting VES curves were interpreted by curve matching and computer based direct and indirect interpretation techniques.The results revealed that simple type curves (e.g. H, HA, KH,QH types) are characteristic of the areas where the depth to the Basement Complex rock is shallow, while complex type curves (e.g. KHK,KHAK,HKHK and QHKQ types) are indicative of the areas where the depth to the Basemcnt Complex rocks are rather deep. From the quantitative interpretation of the sounding curves and available geological data, a maximum of fOur geoelectrical layers were identified North of the area close to the Basement Complex while further South, between five and six geoelectrical layers were identified. These layers include the topsoil/lateritic horizons (l= 200-3840?-m), sandy clay/clay (l= 10-500?-m), saturated sand/conglomerate (l= 300-900?-m) and weathered basement/fresh bedrock (l>1300?-m). The results also revealed evidence of faulting by the uneven nature of the basement topography, downwarping and rock boundary displacement. Dar Zarrouk parameters (T = Transverse unit resistance, in Ohm-m2 and S = Longitudinal layer conductance in Siemens) were computed from surface measured resistivity values; and from therein aquifer transmissivity estimated. A good relationship exists between the transmissivity values calculated from pumping test analysis and those computed from VES results. In the Abeokuta Formation, transmissivity from pumping test analysis was 10368 m2/day while the transmissivity calcu1ated from VES results were found to range from 10164 m2/day} to l0500m2/day. In the Benin Formation, the transmissivity from pumping test analysis was between 103.68 m2/day and 146.88 m2/day for OK BH 3 respectively; Whi1e the transmissivity calculated from VES results ranges between 101.38 rn2/day to 152.00m2 /day respectively. The Abeokuta aquifer seems more pro1ific than the Benin Formation aquifer.The most promising aquifer unit with resistivity values of between 200-900?-m in the study area was found, to consist of fine-sands to coarse grained sand-stones and conglomerate which are at depths of about 50m to the North and about 95m to the South respectively. The resistivity values of the tar sand/clayey horizons and saturated alluvium were found to be quite low (l = 10-100?-m). The average thickness of the aquifer was estimated at about 25m in Abeokuta Formation and 36m in Benin Formation. The results permitted fair to excellent correlation between the geoelectrical and stratigraphic data, particularly the delineation of lithological boundaries, bitumen saturation. New subsurface structural sections for the study area have also been evolved. |Theses collection|Electrical resistivity/borehole/groundwater/subsurface structures/tectonics/hydrogeological/Basement Complex/pumping test.*||||||Abiona, Olatunde Olusesan|M|Design and simulation of a microprocessor based hazard detector device for an industrial environment||||||M.Sc. Computer Science|Akinde, A.D.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Computer Science|1995|||OAU|||||xi, 101p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|For a medium or large size industry to attain higher productivity, safety has to be given higher premium than had been the case, if losses especially from human resources and financial implications are to be minimized, the conventional methods of sensing hazard are presently inadequate. The application of a microprocessor for hazard detection and control will be of great benefit to an industrial environment from the point of flexibility, reliability, versatility and cost reduction.In this research the software aspects of a microprocessor-based hazard detector device was designed. The hazards monitored include: fire, flooding, unauthorized entry and burglary. Various sensors were used to monitor and detect these hazards. Specifically, smoke detector for fire outbreak, liquid level switch for flooding, a combination of switches and clock for unauthorized entry and finally a combination switches, clock and crystal microphone to sense burglary. To drive the hardware, a suite of flexible softwares utilizing the Round-Robin polling technique over interrupt technique was designed and implemented using assembly language. Simulation of the design was implemented using the microprocessor application trainer (MAT 385).The performance evaluation of the designed software simulation gave independent acquisition of each sensor input signal for each hazard. The processor ends an average of 2 to 3secs processing each sensor input signal and activating the respective actuators to forestall the part icular hazard. The software designed eliminates the use of multiple circuits, to detect, monitor and control the various hazards. It also offers flexibility such that if the environment changes, the only change needed will be reprogramming of the ROM. |Theses collection|Human resources/hazards/industrial environment/microprocessor/flooding/software/programming/ROM/microprocessor application trainer (MAT 385)/sense burglary/crystal microphone/liquid level switch/sensor .*||||||Abayomi, Olatokunbo Solomon|M|The biology of the fish genius claria in opa reservoir, obafemi awolowo university, ile-ife, nigeria||||||Ph.D. Zoology|Arawomo, G.A.O.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Zoology|1995|||OAU|||||xx, 142p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|A study on the identification, distribution, food and feeding habits, pattern of reproduction and fecundity, age and growth and types of parasites affecting the fish genus Clarias was carried out in Opa reservoir between 1989 and 1992.The fishing methods effectively employed in this study were hook and line fishing, gill netting, cast netting, and traps. The longline was the best gear for the exploitation of this fish species in the reservoir.A total number of 1253 fish specimens identified as Clarias gariepinus (Burchell, 1822) were caught as the only fish species of the genus Clarias in the reservoir. More of the fish specimens were caught during the dry seasons than the wet season. They were mostly caught at might and the specimens were not evenly distributed in the reservoir. The majority of C. gariepinus caught were concentrated at the shallow vegetated inshore area.The study revealed that C. gariepinus was an omnivore. The food items were plant detritus, whole insects and insects remains, mud, diatoms, algae, rotifers, molluscs, crustaceans, fish, protozoans, earthworm, plant seeds and palm fruits. Detritus and diatoms were predominant during the rainy season. The food consumed by the fish varied with sizes. It fed throughout day and night.The sex ratio of C. gariepinus in Opa reservoir was 2:1 (male to female). The fish species bred throughout the year during the period of study. The peak of breeding was observed in the months of June to August. The fecundity of C. gariepinus in Opa reservoir ranged between 1,567 and 650,625 eggs with a mean of 57.81 eggs. The eggs had bimodal distribution with modes at 0.4mm  1.0mm  1.8mm.The fish vertebrae were found to be most suitable to age C. gariepinus. The annular rings were laid on the vertebrae between December and February when there was a temperature drop due to the harmattan period followed by high temperatures of the dry season. The females grew faster in length than the males in the first two years while the males grew more rapidly than the females in the successive years of life. The growth in length in both sexes of C. gariepinus decreased as the fish aged. The weight of the fish species in both sexes increased with age.C. gariepinus thrived well in Opa reservoir an the mean condition factor for the fish species was 0.72. C. gariepinus was found to be infected by only one parasite which was a trematode, Orientocreadium sp. It was concentrated only in the adult and more were found in the male specimens. The level of parasitic infection was observed to be very low and therefore never affected the vitality of the fish species.|Theses collection|Fecundity/gill netting/hook and line fishing/Clarias gariepinus/vertebrae.*||||||Adeyemi, Adenike|F|Haemagglutinins from the seeds of Dioclea reflexa (Hook,F) (Papilionacae)||||||Ph.D. Biochemistry|Aboderin, A.//Ogunbiyi, O.A.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Biochemistry|1995|||OAU|||||xvi, 141p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|As part of the interest in the occurrence of lectins in plant species native to the tropical West African Subregion, the nature of the molecules responsible for the haemagglutinating activity in the extracts of the seeds of Dioclea reflexa (Hook, F.) was investigated in this study.Two agglutinins namely Dioclea reflexa agglutinins I and II (DRA-I and DRA-II) were isolated from PBS extracts of the seeds of Dioclea reflexa and purified to homogeneity by chromatography on columns of Sephadex G-150.The purified agglutinins were characterised by determining the molecular weight by gel filtration and electrophoresis; analysing the amino acid content by pre-column derivatization technique, PAS staining for covalently attached carbohydrate residues, aswell as investigations for possible lectin - carbohydrate interaction.PBS extracts of the seeds of Dioclea reflexa agglutinate, non-specifically, human red cells of A, B and 0 groups, the agglutination is inhibited by D-glucose, D-mannose, o-methyl-D-glucoside, a-methyl-D-mannoside, NAcetyl-glucosamine and D-fucose. The extract however showed no lectin-carbohydrate interaction in double-diffusion experiments in agarose gels with starch, guargum, glycogen, Dextran T-500 and hemocyanin.DRA-I is a monomeric protein, Mw 34000 daltons which is inhibited by N-Acetyl-glucosamine. DRA-II on the other hand, is a homomeric dieter with Mw (subunit) of 16000 daltons. It is inhibited by D-glucose and D-mannose and their a-methyl derivatives. DRA-I and DRA-II are not glycoproteins. The amino acid compositions of DRA-I and DRA-II, although different, may be compared with those of many other legume lectins documented in the literature. DRA-I is clearly a larger molecule with 343 residues as against 153 for DRA-II. DRA-I lacks methionine residue and is completely devoid of sulphur-containing amino acids while DRA-II has a single methionine residue per subunit.The data so far established suggest that DRA-I and DRA-II are different molecular entities from the same source considering their physical and biological properties. They however share many characteristics with other documented agglutinins.The two agglutinins are probably products of two separate genetic determinants although the possibility that both are products of a large precursor molecule cannot be definitely excluded.|Theses collection|lectins/plant species/haemagglutinating activity/electrophoresis/monomeric protein/glycoproteins.*||||||Adekomi, Ademola Abimbola|M|Effect of peer interactive video taped microteaching on performance in teaching pratice among teachers tainees in selected subjects of the adeyemi college of education in ondo||||||PhD. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This study investigated the effect of Peer Interactive Videotaped Microteaching on performance in field teaching practice amongst teacher-trainees in selected subject areas of pure science, arts, and social studies. A total of sixty randomly selected first year NCE students were used for the Study. Twenty students, each from Physics, Yoruba, and Geography respectively were chosen to represent the broad areas of pure science, arts, and social sciences. Data were collected using the five instruments named Practical Teaching Assessment Scale (PTAS), Rater's Perception Inventory (RPI), Modified Interaction Scale (MIS), Teacher Competency Pre-knowledge Test (TCPT), and Teacher Trainee Evaluation of Microteaching (TEM). The data collected were analyzed using mean score, correlation coefficients, t-test, Wilcoxon test of gain and E-ratio at the relevant stages.The analysis of data revealed that every teacher-trainee involved in the microteaching exercise performed significantly better in the field teaching practice than their control counterparts. In essence, the mean score (X) of the field teaching groups are 63%, 62%, and 68% compared with the control groups' mean score of 44%, 50% and 48% respectively in Physics, Yoruba, and Geography. There was also a significantly higher and non-uniform interaction in rnicroteaching than in field teaching for the three subject groups. The study further revealed that Raters perception of microteaching has no significant effect on Rater's assessment of teaching practice. The correlation coefficients between Rater's perception and their ratings of either microteaching or field teaching are low and non significant, ranging between 0.007 and 0.07. There was also no significant difference between the performance of male and female teacher-trainees in either micro-teaching or field teaching.Further more, the study revealed that microteaching was effective for training both male and female teachers in all the subject areas investigated. It was also found that there is a positive correlation between performances in field teaching and microteaching; hence microteaching has a high degree of predictive validity for field teaching. The use of interaction ana1ysis for evaluating teaching practice was found more probing and more objective than the conventional Practical Teaching Assessment Scale (PTAS). |Theses collection|Peer Interactive Videotaped Microteaching/field teaching practice/teacher-trainees/Practical Teaching Assessment Scale (PTAS)/Rater's Perception Inventory (RPI)/Modified Interaction Scale (MIS)/Teacher Competency Pre-knowledge Test (TCPT)/Teacher Trainee Evaluation of Microteaching (TEM)/microteaching.*||||||Aboderin, Oluwakemi Adebisi|F|Ona iseda gbolohun ibeere ninu ede yoruba||||||M.Sc. Yoruba Language and Literature|Adewole, L.O.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, African Laguages and Literature|1995|||OAU||||The objective of this work is to examine the applicability of Government and Binding theory on wh-questions evident in the day to day speech. Government and Binding theory explained sentence structures through some constraints, conditions and rules. It also explained reasons for movement in Yoruba wh-question sentences. X-bar theory, which is a tool of Government and Binding, was used to explain constituents' precedence and dominance, antecedent government, C -command and M-command. Government and Binding theory was used to explain the empty Category Principle, Surface Structure constraint, bounding and subjacency as they affect  Yoruba question sentences. It is  expected that the extent of the applicability of Government and  Binding theory onYoruba wh-questions will be exposed by this work. The bases of this work were relevant books on this theory, sentences extracted from native speakers' speeches and the researcher's competence too helped a great deal  especially to explain movements and their grammaticality  or deviances. This work showed that as there are various wh-questions, so are there various types of movement. It also showed that many of the constraints, conditions and rules evident in Government and Binding theory were useful for the explanation of Yoruba wh-question though there are some exceptions. The effectiveness of government and binding theory is not debatable but its universality needs to be revisited. Government and Binding theory could also be a basis for the explanation of sentence structures in the Language. |ix,135p|||||||Yoruba||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Ite ise yii ni lati se afihan bi ti ori ba ijoba ati adipo se sise si lori alaye ihun gbolohun ibeere oni-ni ti a n seda ninu iprde ojoojumo l'ede yoruba.Tiori ijoba ati idapo yii ni awon ote,ilana ati ofin kan ti o gbe kale fun  atupale ihun gbolohun.Iru agbekale yii n'salaye ofin to de agbefo  bii:idi ti o fi wale tabi  ti ko fi le waye ninu ihun.Ni ona keji;a lo tiori onmipele ti o je elo fun tiori ijoba ati adipo,lati salaye ifarakinra oro nipase ikanmupo ati igapa,ide iso itokasi,ijoba,ase omo-inu,ase ipekun ati bee bee lo.A lo ti ori yii lati salaye ote isori ofo,ote ihun oke,aala agbefo girama ijoba ati adipo sise de lori gbolohun ibeere  ede yoruba lenu iwadii yii, a se akojo awon iwe to se koko lori tiori yii gege bii ipile fun ise wa. A tun lo awon ibeere ti a gbo lenu awon wlede ninu alaye ise naa. Imo oluwaa\dii gege n\bi omo yoruba naa tun ran wa lowo, paapaa lati salaye ibofinmu ati aibofinmu awon gblolhun ibeere oni-ni.Ise yii fi han oe, bi ihun gbolohun ibeere oni-ni se po naa ni agbefo pe orisiirisii. Engineering Physics|Oluwole, E.F.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Physics|1995|||OAU|||||xiv, 140p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Both total suspended particulate matter (TSP) concentration (g/m3) and atmospheric dust deposition rates (Tonnes/km2. .month) were sampled within the factory and outside the neighbourhoods of Ashaka cement works. The gross TSP concentration ranged from 139 g/m3 to 9368 g/m3 with an average of 3000 g/m3 for dry season within the factory. In wet season, the range was from 159 to 2304 g/m3 with an average of 750 g/m3. The range of TSP concentration in the neighbourhoods for both dry and wet seasons are 164 - 1720 g/m3 and 100 - 325 g/m3 respectively. In major shopfloors such as cement mill, raw mill and packing plant, dust concentration as high as 3 x 104 g/m3 was recorded. Similar trend was observed in the deposition rates within the factory. High deposition rate was recorded at the site close to the process area. The deposition rate within the factory ranged from 187 - 1681 Tonnes/km2.month, with maximum deposition rate observed in wet season. In the neighbourhoods, dust deposition range is from 6 to 266 Tonnes/km2.month. Comparing dust concentrations within the factory premises and even in the neighbourhoods with limit set by FEPA for industrial environment (250 g/m3 daily average), values observed exceeded the limit by 3 times to about an order of magnitude in most cases. The deposition rates exceeded the USEPA limit of 11.8 Tonnes/km2. month by about two orders of magnitude. Elemental characterization of both samples was done by Energy dispersive X-ray Fluorescence (EDXRF) technique. The analysis revealed the presence of the following elements in most of the samples: Na, AI, Si, K, Ca, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, ln, S, Cu, and Pb. Enrichment factors calculated for these elements showed Ca, S, ln, Cu, and Pb to be highly enriched. Range of enrichment factor values obtained for these elements are: 30 - 350, 75 - 200, 100 - 14700 and 20 - 700 (dimensionless) respectively. The implication is that the activities of the factory enhanced the presence of these elements in the ambient air. AI, Fe, Mn, Na, V, and Cr were moderately enriched while Si and K were not enriched compared to the crustal source. Source apportionment by Factor analysis (FA) and Chemical Mass Balance (CMB) receptor models were carried out. Cement and soil mainly in the form of re-entrained dust were identified as the major sources of these pollutants. The methods revealed 60 - 82 % cement contribution within the factory while 10 - 30 % were attributed to cement in the neighbourhoods. The dispersion characteristic of the factory using Gaussian based dispersion model showed the predicted TSP concentrations to peak at 18145 g/m3 and 11100 g/m3 for 8-hours and 24-hours averaging periods respectively. These values agree with observed concentrations within a factor of two. From isopleth plot of the model run, the TSP concentrations and Atmospheric deposition rates, sanitary zone of between 5 km or greater has been found to be an ideal safe distance from the factory because the TSP concentrations predicted by the model and measured values were below the FEPA limits. In order to assess the possible health impact of cement dust on the workers, 327 randomly selected workers were subjected to lung function test. The Forced Expiratory Volume in one second (FEVJ and the Forced Vital Capacity (FVC) of the lungs of the workers were measured using Vitalograph bellows Spirometer. Hence, the average ratio of FEV1/FVC for the selected workers was 81.1 % compared with 84 % for the control (120 healthy non-industrially exposed population). This study has revealed that cement workers have relatively lower lung function when compared to non-exposed controls. This could lead to chronic obstructive lung disease later in life. Toxicity potential (TP) which shows the degree of contamination of the environment by pollutants was determined. The TP value greater than 1 could be regarded as dangerous to man's health. A highest TP of 34.2 was obtained in the shopfloors with 1.9 recorded in the neighbourhoods. This study has shown the need to control environmental pollutants emanating from this factory both for compliance with limits by FEPA and the health of the communities purposes. Also, the adequacy of EDXRF technique in the analysis of particulate pollutants has been corroborated by this study. |Theses collection|total suspended particulate matter (TSP)/atmospheric dust deposition rates (Tonnes/km2. .month)/shopfloors/Chemical Mass Balance (CMB)/Forced Expiratory Volume/pollutants.*||||||Nwankpa, Alexander Chinyere|F|Determination of elemental composition of nigerian coals by fast neutron activation analysis||||||M.Sc. Physics|Balogun, F.A.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Physics|1995|||OAU|||||x, 103p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Elemental composition of Nigerian coals was determined using the fast neutron activation analysis (FNAA) technique. Representative coal samples were collected from Okpara, Okaba, Lafia Obi and Owukpa mines. The NBS Standard Reference Material, Coal SRM 1632a was also analyzed, for the purpose of verifying the accuracy of the method. Neutron flux at the centre of the vial in the irradiation position of the neutron generator has been measured to be (2.610.04) x 108 ncm2s-1 and the spatial distribution established.Thirty four elements were detected and their concentrations determined using the high purity Germanium detector. Essential corrections due to interfering reactions associated with each nuclear reaction were made.The Rare Earth Elements REE, La, Ce, Sm and Eu were found to be common in Nigerian coals. The concentrations of the major/minor elements determined for the Nigerian coals were found to be much tower than the mean values of those reported for coal samples from other parts of the world. Also the concentrations of the toxic elements As, Cr, Cu and Sb in Nigerian coals are very low compared with China and U.S.A. coals. Good agreement was observed within one standard deviation when the results were compared with the work of others that used the INAA method in analyzing Nigerian coals. The results conclusively showed that Nigerian coals are of low ash content and would cause less environmental pollution when used for domestic or industrial purposes.|Theses collection|Elemental composition/coals/Neutron flux/Germanium detector/Rare Earth Elements REE.*||||||Salawu, Busari Murufu|M|Effect of behaviour rehearsal therapy on test anxiety among selected secondary school students in osogbo, osun state||||||M.A. Education (Guidance and Councelling)|Alao, K.A.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Educational Foundation and Counselling|1995|||OAU|||||viii, 193|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This study was designed to find the relative effects of Behaviour Rehearsal Therapy (BRT) on test anxiety of secondary' school students. It was also designed to determine whether the level of test anxiety, sex and religious beliefs of subjects would influence the relative efficacy of BRT in reducing test anxiety. The study made use of random pre-test, post-test control group design. The forty eight subjects were drawn from 124 senior secondary two students of Anglican commercial Grammar School, Osogbo who completed Test Anxiety Scale (TAS). Through stratified random sampling, the subjects were categorised into control and experimental groups. Both TAS and General Anxiety Scale (GAS) (Sarason, 1972), were used in determining the pre-treatment test anxiety level of subjects. The treatment package was adapted from Goldrieds blueprint on cognitive restructuring therapy which consisted of 8 sessions of 40 minutes each, spanning four weeks. Both TAS and GAS were readministered for post test. T-test analysis and analysis of variances (ANOVA) were used in data analysis.Results of statistical analysis revealed that test anxiety of secondary school students could be significantly reduced by BRT (P <0.05). However, it was moderately test-anxious subjects whose test anxiety were most considerably reduced (P<0.05). It was further established that there was no differential effect of BRT on subjects' sex, academic class and religious beliefs. The therapy could thus be applied irrespective of sex, academia class and religious beliefs of the subjects. The study therefore showed that BRT could effectively reduce the test anxiety of subjects and that its efficacy was not impaired by subjects' sex, academic class and religious beliefs. |Theses collection|Behaviour Rehearsal Therapy (BRT)/Test Anxiety Scale (TAS)/General Anxiety Scale (GAS)/religious beliefs.*||||||Salami, Ayobami T.|M|Structural changes in vegetal cover in ife and ede regions of south western nigeria between 1963 and 1993||||||Ph.D. Geography|Ekanade, O.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Geography|1995|||OAU|||||xix, 186p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This research focuses on spatial and temporal analysis of vegetation with remotely sensed data in a part of Southwestern Nigeria. Emphasis was placed on the identification of structural changes of the vegetation although, some baseline data on the floristic characterisation of the area were also generated from the study. For comparative purpose, two study sites were chosen - one from the forest reserve area, which is closer to the mature forest, and one in Ede area which is close to the forest fringe. Data were also collected from a tract of mature Tropical Rain Forest to serve as control for the study sites. Data were generated from aerial photographs (1963 and 1973), SPOT XS (1986), LANDSAT TM (1991) and intensive fieldwork (1993). The satellite imageries were digitally analysied using MUL TISCOPE software package while aerial photographs were subjected to analogue procedure. After the barycentric classification, the outputs of cover statistics, confusion matrix and classification were obtained and related to the results of photo interpretation. It was found that agro-forestry is as much a threat to mature Rain Forest in Ife Area as mixed grassland is to secondary forest in Ede Area. In Ede Area, the secondary forest is receding at an average annual rate of 1.90% \vhile mixed grassland is increasing at an average annual rate of 16.11 %. In Ife Area, the areal coverage of forest reserve is reducing at an average annual rate of 1.01% while agro-forestry is increasi,ng at an average annual rate of 16.42%. The introduction of exotic trees as it is currently being practised by the government was found to have aggravated the intensity of floristic degradation in Ife Region while the activities of peasant farmers have resulted in higher degradation of structural complexity of vegetation in Ede Region. The study shows that vegetation structure is the most affected parameter, when mature Tropical Rain Forest is subjected to human interference. For instance, percentage overstorey cover has been degraded by 95.87% and 73.45% in Ede and Ife Regions respectively. The floristic' analysis shows that areas where tree crops are now predominant in Ife Region were once occupied by the typical species of the mature Rain Forest while ecotone communities are found in Ede Region. Furthermore, agricultural practices have led to regressive succession in Ede Region. The digital image analysis shows that precise classification which is easily obtained from the automated procedure in the dev-eloped countries was hampered by the heterogeneous nature of the landscape. However, the level of error associated with each classification was obtained from the analysis. This study highlights the problems and prospects of using remote sensing techniques in surveying Africa's rural landscape with its bewildering complexities. The findings of the study suggest that paucity of data which has been the bane of rural planning and indeed, environmental management in Nigeria, could be easily overcome if the potentialities of aerospace data are fully exploited.|Theses collection|Remote sensing/Vegetation/floristic/forest reserve area/Tropical Rain Forest/environmental management.*||||||Sanni, Ayodele Adedayo|M|Development of a microproceesor based electronic rotary display board||||||M.Sc.
