O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Outdoor advertising is increasingly becoming a common media (channel) through which the populace are informed of available products and services for their common good. This project presents a novel technique of utilizing a single display,structure to convey, one at a time, numerous large, 'life-sized' aesthetic, attention - catching and impacting picture adverts each conveying different and distinct advertising messages that will lead to the satisfaction of their diverse needs. In this design, microprocessor - controlled stepper motors were employed to effect bidirectional movement of the screen (on which the adverts can either be drawn, pasted or printed). The hardware designed includes transistor driver/buffer circuitries to power and control each individual motor for independent functioning; position detector circuitry comprising of an LED/LDR pair; and a lighting control circuit consisting of four a.c switching reed relays for powering any three combinations out of the total of four different coloured 240V a.c bulbs. A modular - structured software application control program to implement the various sequential control operations of the display system was developed and tested using the software development aids on the Microprocessor Application Trainer MAT 385 which also acts as the controller for the system. The MAT under program control implemented: the powering of one of the motors at a time by generating its respective step drive sequence effecting bidirectional movement of the screen; independent viewing of each of the adverts; setting and execution of the viewing-time of each advert (frame); and the beautification of any viewed advert by appropriately activating the coloured lamps. The average viewing time of the designed display board is 8 secs with an average screen speed of 0.15 cm/secs (each motor being driven at a stepping rate of 200 steps/secs). These values though, can be varied to suite a variety of purposes requiring different viewing times as well as screen speeds. This design has great potentials as a commercial tool because of its versatility and relative cheapness. |Theses collection|Outdoor advertising/microprocessor - controlled stepper motors/Microprocessor Application Trainer MAT 385.*||||||Ugwu, Elizabeth Ndidi|F|The study of terpenoid constituents of euphobia||||||M.Sc. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Euphorbiaceae plants are of great importance for instance in drug making. The biological activities of these plants are associated with the diterpenoid constituents present in them. This work was therefore designed to isolate the diterpenoids constituents of the Nigerian species of Euphorbia tirucalli Linn. and Euphorbia poisonii Pax. and to carry out spectroscopic studies and chemical transformations on the isolated compounds with a view to elucidating their structures. The latex of Euphorbia tirucalli was collected by tapping the stems of the plant along old lfe-lbadan road, lle-lfe for a period of three days, while the latex of Euphorbia poisonii was collected from Adelu village in Kwara state. The latices were extracted with methylated spirit and the extract partitioned into petroleum spirit and ether fractions. These fractions were then subjected to extensive chromatographic separations, mainly column and a series of multiple preparative thin layer chromatography. The pure compounds isolated were analysed using infra red spectroscopy and proton and carbon-13 nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. The petroleum spirit extract of Euphorbia tirucalli gave compound ETP20, a triterpenoid. The ether extract afforded pure solids, ETE30B and ETE40C. The ETE30B was found to be identical with Euphorianin, an ingol-hemiacetalacetate diterpenoid ester, while ETE40 was shown to be a phorbol ester. Three pure closely related compounds euphorianin and compound L (which had earlier been isolated) and a new euphorianin derivative compound K were isolated from Euphorbia poisonii.The diterpenoid compounds isolated from these plants could possess some of the biological activities associated with the diterpenoids as has been reported in some other Euphorbia species. These compounds may also be responsible for some of the reported medicinal activities of the plant. |Theses collection|Euphorbiaceae plants/drug/diterpenoid/spectroscopic studies/methylated spirit/chromatography/petroleum spirit.*||||||Popoola, Bayode Isaiah|M|Effect of a self management training model on study behaviour of secondary school students in akure, ondo state||||||M.A. Educaion (Guidance and Counselling)|Adeyoju,J.A.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Educational Foundation and Councelling|1995|||OAU|||||x, 159p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. The study sample consisted of forty-eight students  of St Peter's Secondary School, Akure in Ondo State. The subjects were classified into three academic ability groups and assigned to one experimental and one control group. Two instruments, the Study Behaviour Measurement Scale (SBMS) and the Adolescent Self-Control Scale (ASCS) were administered before and after the training programme to collect data on subjects' study behaviour and self-control skills. Data collected from the administration of the research instruments were analysed using the t-test and analysis or variance (ANOVA). The significance of the results were considered at 0.05 level or probability. Microbiology|Kolawole, D.O.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Microbiology|1995|||OAU|||||ix, 88p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Wound sepsis has continued to constitute a significant problem to physicians despite the development of antibiotics, improved surgical and aseptic techniques. The discovery of penicillin and its clinical practice in the 1940s changed the direction of medical practice in which it became possible to cure serious and progressive infections caused by common bacterial pathogens including those due to Staphvlococcus aureus. However, the widespread use of penicillin led to a phenomenon in which patients and hospital personnel had become colonized with penicillin resistant staphvlococcus aureus. This study was conducted to characterize staphylococci obtained from septic wounds and to screen them for the production of penicillinase. The study population consisted of two hundred patients undergoing wound dressing at the Obafemi Awolowo University Teaching Hospitals Complex, and the Health Centre, both in Ile-Ife. Smears were obtained from the wound site of each patient using sterile cotton-tipped applicators and were cultured on blood, nutrient and mannitol salt agar. Bacterial isolates were identified based on their cultural, morphological and biochemical characteristics. Phage typing of the staphylococcal isolates was performed using the international set of typing phages and the antibiotic sensitivity patterns of these strains, were determined using the agar diffusion method. All the isolates were screened for the production of beta-lactamase enzyme using the acidometric agar plate method and the iodometric method. Ninety-eight staphylococcal isolates were recovered from the two hundred patients with wound sepsis. Eighty of the isolates were staphylococcus aureus, twelve were staphylococcus sciuri and six isolates were staphylococcus qallinarium. Phage typing of the S. aureus strains revealed that group III and non-typable strains were predominant. All the coagulase negative staphylococci were non-typable. Tests of the antibiotic sensitivity patterns revealed that all the S. aureus strains were resistant to penicillin and streptomycin while 89% were resistant to ampicillin. In addition, 26% were resistant to tetracycline, 15% to chloramphenicol, 6% and 9% were resistant to gentamycin and erythromycin. Twenty-two multiple antibiotic resistance forms of S.  aureus were recovered, representing 28% of the isolates. All the coagulase negative staphylococcal isolates were resistant to penicillin and trimethoprim, while 89% were resistant to streptomycin and fusidic acid, 67% resistant to neomycin and kanamycin while 44% were resistant to chloramphenicol. All the S. aureus isolates produced beta-lactamase as detected by the acidometric agar plate method while 94% tested positive using the iodometric agar method. None of the coagulase negative staphylococci produced beta-lactamase detectable by either of these methods. The study revealed S. aureus as the predominant organism associated with septic wounds in the two hospitals and that penicillin G may not be effective in treating wound sepsis. It is suggested that sensitivity tests be done to identify the infective agent before treatment. There is also the need to control the use and sale of antibiotics in our community. |Theses collection|Wound sepsis/physicians/antibiotics/penicillin/aseptic techniques/medical practice/staphylococci/ampicillin/clinical practice.*||||||Taiwo, Olurotimi Olorunfemi|M|An eamination of selected witten test of senior secondary school learners in nigeria||||||M.Sc. It also aimed at suggesting some approaches to the teaching of writing that will equip the students to write cohesively and. coherently. The methodology used involved the collection of data from some secondary schools in Osun, Ogun and Oyo States of Nigeria. The data were written texts representing four major genres of English written texts - Narrative, Explanatory, and Argumentative texts. The analysis focused on text-forming relations and consistency in register. In this respect, we made analysis of Reference, Lexical Cohesion, Conjunction, Theme, Ideational Meanings, and Schematic Structure The study discovered that the linguistic environment, the teacher and the students themselves play a great role in the kind  of texts produced by the students. Most of the writings of ESL writers do not reflect the distance between them and their reader, therefore, the texts were characterised by improper identification of participants, redundant references,  illogical connection of information and excessive use of simple additives. The study concluded by suggesting that ESL teachers in the teaching of writing should concentrate on Register which students learn implicitly. To achieve this, it was suggested that classroom teachers should focus on and define the writing tasks of the students. To do this, teachers should concentrate on the content of writing (Field), the channel of communication (mode), the audience of communication (Personal Tenor) and the purpose of communication (functional Tenor). O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|It has been made clear theoretically that spread and backwash effects of growth centres are spatial-temporal processes (Casetti, et al, 1971;Weinand,1972; Gaile. 1979; Richardson, 1976) and that 2 time (distance) points are needed to generate the time (spatial) paths of spread- backwash processes. Unfortunately all studies conducted on growth centre's impact have centred on one time (place) pattern (Olajuyin, 1982; Abiodusn, 1981; Moseley. 1973a,1973b; Weinand, 1973) for absence of appropriate time series data for such studies. It is thus the object of this study to present a procedure for the testing of time pattern of spread/backwash effects and the application of this to Osogbo Sub-region of Nigeria using time series data to test the hypotheses of time pattern of spread and backwash and hence spillover effects.  The methodology adopted for the study focused on the review of   literatures, direct personal observation on the field and the examination of existing condition by use of questionnaires.The study finds out that the establishment of Osogbo steeI Rolling Company and Nigerian Machine Tools Limited has led to increased income and employment of migrants, natives and commuters. Heavy public and private capital has flown to  Osogbo, while significant capital goods movement and expenditure into and outside Osogbo sub-region have resulted in the establishment of the industries. Heavy effect has been felt through expenditure on housing, transport, food stuff and dependant relatives by industrial employees. Referred adult cases treated by specialised health services at Osogbo have also increased.  To test the hypotheses of time pattern of development the logistic function and marginal utility function were adopted to measure spread and backwash effects respectively. The high explanatory power of time for the spread and backwash effects in each of the areas shows that time is a very important explanatory variable of dependant variables (spread and backwash).The regression equations also confirm that spread and backwash and hence spillovers follow time path as spread and backwash effects increase with time. The time series analysis shows that time represents a good predictor of predictand variables of spread and backwash. Seasonal variation values adequately represent the actual spread and backwash values as the regression of actual values on trend and projected seasonal variation values produces R2- values of between 58% and 97%. The study confirms the hypotheses of time pattern of impact of growth centres. However the actual and full shapes of the curves are not I fitted because time is unripe for such differentiated structure. The study shows time path of impact in periphery and other places follow different patterns. The time pattern of spread, backwash and spillovers in the periphery shows that time is unripe for maximum benefits and disbenefits. This is the argument that initiated this study and on this basis it is suggested that policy makers should not abandon growth centre policy as a long time horizon is needed before it can really achieve positive spillovers (net spread). The study suggests policies to bring about maximum polarisation and rising spread in the periphery . |Theses collection|spread-backwash processes/osogbo steel rolling company/*||||||Ibitoye, Simeon Ademola|M|Development and adaptation of porters clay for use by local foundaries||||||M.Sc. M.Phil Met and Maths|Afonja, A.A.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Metalogical and Materials Engineering|1995|||OAU|||||xx, 188p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|In this study, the possibility of using potter's clay as binder in foundry moulding and coresand mixes was examined. For the moulding sand, mixes of the sample of Ipetumodu potter's clay deposit and silica sand were produced and AFS cylindrical specimens were made. The green compression, dry compression, green shear, dry shear and hot strength and permeability of the mixes were then determined. Two out of nine mixes produced were selected as base sands and further treated with powdered charcoal and wood flour as additives. The effect of the additives on the tested properties was established and the results were later compared with those of moulding sand currently in use in local foundry. Five different mixes were prepared for the coresand, each containing potter's clay, silica sand, 2% wood flour, 5% water and different starch content. AFS standard cylindrical specimens were also prepared from each mix and the dry compression, dry shear, hot and baked strength, mould hardness, baked permeability and collapsibility were determined. The results obtained were compared with properties of coresand currently in use at local foundries. It was observed that with the addition of powdered charcoal and wood flour in amounts of 2.40 to 2.70% and 3.00 to 7.20% respectively to the prepared potter's clay - bound sand mixes, desirable moulding sands are obtainable. It was also noted that potter's clay - bound coresand mixes containing 2.10% wood flour and starch in the range of 1.50 to 1.95% exhibit desirable properties. Not only did the prepared sands compared favourably with the sand used in local foundries but exhibited in certain respects superior properties applicable in both iron and non-ferrous foundries. It was also established that the use of potter's clay in foundry core and moulding sands is feasible and economical and could be a potential substitute for imported bentonite in local foundries. |Theses collection|Potter's clay as binder in foundry moulding/coresand mixes/Ipetumodu potter's clay deposit/silica sand/AFS cylindrical specimen/foundry/wood flour.*||||||Onanuga, Kehinde Onakemi|F|Delimitation of hydrocarbon reservoir size from seismic velocity depth profiles over agigo oil field, niger delta||||||M.Sc. Applied Geophysics|Olorunniwo, M.A.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Geology|1995|||OAU|||||xv, 163p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Twelve seismic sections and a suite of borehole logs comprising Spontaneous Potential (SP), GammaRay (GR), Resistivity (ER) and Sonic Logs from six wells in AGHIGHO oil field in the Niger Delta have been interpreted for subsurface geological structures, possible hydrocarbon potential and the delineation of lateral extent of hydrocarbon reservoirs. Three regional faults and three horizons were picked at depths of 1400m, 1900m and 2800m respectively. The horizons divided the area into four layers: - Layer 1 belongs to the Benin Formation; Layers 2 and 3 fall within the Agbada Formation while Layer 4 belongs to the basal Akata Formation. The isochron maps of the tops of layers 2, 3 and 4 showed anticlinal structures faulted close to the fold axis. The presence of closures on these maps possible hydrocarbon bearing zones within the layers. Layer-l has an average thickness of 1320m and an average velocity ranging between 2000m/sec and 2111m/sec. Layer-2 has an interval velocity ranging between 2400m/sec and 2850m/sec while the sediment thickness varies between 460m and 560m. Layer-3 has an interval velocity varying from 2490m/sec to 3380m/sec while the sediment thickness ranges between 430m and 150m. The depth to the top of Layer-4 is between 2100m and 2900m. Areas with low interval velocities on the isovelocity maps indicate possible hydrocarbon bearing zones within the layers. Two hydrocarbon reservoirs were identified by the correlation of interpreted seismic sections with borehole logs from the AGHIGHO oil field. Reservoir 1 is located within layer-2 and spans the interval 1569m and 1712m while Reservoir 2 is located within layer-3 and span the interval 2034m and 2270m. Both reservoir sands contain intercalations of shale which seal the hierarchical hydrocarbon columns in the reservoirs. From the study of seismic velocity depth profiles across AGHIGHO field, a structural index based on velocity ratio was established. structural index maps were constructed to study the lateral extent of the hydrocarbon bearing areas within the reservoirs. The of horizon 1 indicated index values varying between 0.72 unit and 0.83 unit while the index values within reservoir 1 varied between 0.66 unit and 0.92 unit. The index map of horizon 2 showed variation of index values unit and 0.89 unit, while the index map of reservoir 2 showed variation of index values between 0.71 unit and 0.90 unit within the reservoir. Results of the delimitation in reservoir 1 indicated areas with index values greater than 0.83 unit as hydrocarbon bearing while areas with index values less than 0.83 unit as non-hydrocarbon bearing. Results of the delimitation in reservoir 2 indicated areas with index values greater than 0.80 unit as hydrocarbon bearing while areas with index values less than 0.80 unit as non-hydrocarbon bearing. Comparison of the results of the index maps with waveslowness maps showed good agreement. Reserve estimates were calculated for the volume of in place based on the results of the delimitation studies. In reservoir 1 it was calculated to be 1.48 x 108m3 and in reservoir 2 it was calculated to be 7.5 x 108m3. |Theses collection|Seismic sections/borehole logs/AGHIGHO oil field/isochron maps/hydrocarbon bearing. *||||||Omoregbee, Friday Egbena Abuwa|M|Communication of improved farm practices to rural women contract farmers in benue state, Nigeria||||||M.Sc. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The primary purpose of this study is to describe the communication process through which the extension workers of Benue Agricultural and Rural Development Authority (BNARDA) disseminate improved farm practices to rural women contact farmers. Specifically, the study was conducted to investigate the improved agricultural technologies disseminated to rural women contact farmers; the methods of communication between the extension workers and the rural women contact farmers; the channels used for getting feedback from rural women contact farmers by the extension workers as well as analyze the socio-economic factors which have influence on the frequency of contacts between extension workers and rural women contact farmers. Twenty-five wards were randomly selected. A total of two hundred and fifty rural women contact farmers were randomly selected. One hundred and fifty out of four hundred and forty-eight extension workers of BNARDA were randomly selected from the three zones. Guidance and Councelling|Alao, K.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Educational Foundation and Councelling|1995|||OAU|||||vi, 67p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Developing societies such as Nigeria are confronted with a series of problems which militate against their national development processes. Women are seen by pioneers of comparative education as crucial factors in the process of national development. The controversial issue of which socializing model, (parents or peers) exert greater influence on the adolescents' choice of careers has remained unsolved. Some problems which teenagers encounter in choosing unrealistic careers such as the inability to cope with courses in their fields and ultimate lack of satisfaction in the world of work has persisted. The study investigated the relative influences of peers and parents on Nigerian adolescent choices. Four hypotheses were proposed and tested. One of the hypotheses confirmed that there was no significant difference between male and female adolescents in their orientation towards their peers in the choice of careers. Another indicated that there was no difference between urban and rural adolescents in their orientation towards their parents in their choice of career. The remaining two hypotheses showed that there is no significant difference between male and female adolescents in their orientation towards peers in their choice of career while the last one stated that there is no significant difference between rural and urban adolescents in their orientation towards peers in their choice of career. These two hypotheses were rejected. The study strongly recommends that since the adolescent is under the influence of both parents at home and peers in the school, the adolescents orientation will be a function of the interaction of both the parents and the peer group influences. The study recommends that counsellors, parents, teachers, and educationists should give the students thorough counselling on their choice of career. They should also improve the social relationship with adolescents so as to be able to provide more effective and realistic direction on adolescent career. |Theses collection|peers/national development/pioneers/careers/hypotheses/orientation/counselling  *||||||Ojolo, Bosede Olukemi|F|The organisation and management of rural women cooperative in osun state of nigeria||||||M.Sc. Agric Extention and Rural Sociology|Laogun, E.A.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Agricultural and Rural Sociology|1995|||OAU|||||xv, 155p|||||||Englsih||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The study investigated some aspects of the organization and management of rural women cooperatives in Osun state of Nigeria. Specifically, the study was designed to determine: members level of satisfaction with the derived organizational benefits, the organizational structure and decision-making pattern of the groups, the activities of the groups, the level of organizational participation of members, the acquisition and use of productive resources available to the cooperative groups and the nature and types of linkages existing between the cooperatives and the union, other cooperative societies, and relevant government agencies. Six Local Government Areas (LGAs) were randomly selected from the twenty-three LGAs in the state. Four women cooperative societies were randomly selected from each of the selected LGAs. A total of twenty-four women cooperatives were therefore used for the study. Twenty-five percent of the members were randomly selected from each cooperative, while four leaders of each cooperative were purposively selected and interviewed. A total of 306 respondents consisting of 210 members and 96 leaders constituted the subjects of the study. Two sets of interview schedules were used for data collection; one set was used for the leaders while the other was used for other members. Data analysis was undertaken by the use of frequency distribution, percentages, mean and Pearson's product moment correlation. Results showed that majority (59%) of the cooperative members were averagely satisfied with the derived organizational benefits; thirty-nine percent of the cooperative members and 58% of the leaders had formal education. Leadership training was not common to majority of the members. The organizational structure of the societies did not vary significantly. The management of each of the societies was vested on the management committee who reports back to the general body from time to time and decision-making pattern was mainly assembly decision-making. All the groups engaged in thrift and credit while some groups added other activities like trading, food crop production and food processing. Level of organizational participation by cooperative members was average for majority (82%) while 56% had good opinion about their groups. Access to land and labour was difficult. About 50% of the cooperative groups had no land to cultivate. The most frequent source of land acquisition was community land (29%) and used mainly for farming and processing. Most of the cooperative groups depended on group and hired labour for their farming operations. Capital acquisition was a great problem to most of the groups. The cooperative groups hardly had access to credit from the lending institutions due to high interest rate and lack of collateral. The cooperative union however provided loan for about 43% of the groups for members' use. Linkage existed between most of the groups and the union (87%), other cooperatives (84.4%) at the village level and the Ministry of Commerce and Industry (85.5%). Problems facing cooperative groups were largely lack of adequate government assistance and difficulty in securing loan. Positive and significant relationships were found at 0.05 levels between members' level of satisfaction with the derived organizational benefits and annual income (r = 0.216), level of education (r = 0.215) and individual opinion about the organization (r = 0.457). Similarly, level of organizational participation was positively and significantly associated with level of education (r = 0.169) and annual income (r = 0.264). |Theses collection|Rural women/management/cooperative/organizational benefits/decision-making/organizational structure/cooperative structure/collateral.*||||||Ojo, Joshua Olufemi|M|Application of nuclear analytical technique to studies of elemental models in health and some diseases in man||||||Ph.D. Engineering Physics|Oluwole, A.F.// Durosimi, M.A.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Physics|1995|||OAU|||||xvi, 233p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The present work has examined the use of the nuclear analytical techniques Instrumental Neutron Activation Analysis (INAA) and Proton-Induced X-ray Emission (PIXE) in studying levels of trace elements in the hair, whole blood, erythrocytes and plasma of human subjects both in health and those suffering from some diseases viz Sickle Cell Anaemia (SCA) , Haematological malignancies and Affective disorders. Various factors that could lead to an optimum application of the two techniques for the biological matrices studied were also investigated. Results of the trace element levels in healthy humans provide, for the first time, baseline levels of these elements in hair, whole blood, erythrocytes and plasma of Nigerians. An epidemiological comparison of Nigerians with other populations from various parts of the world indicates that there are no serious differences in the trace elements contents of hair and blood of Nigerian subjects. The capability of the two analytical techniques in detecting various elements was also compared. Comparison of trace elements in the blood and hair of healthy and diseased Nigerians has clearly implicated trace elements in the three diseases studied. In SCA, the levels of the elements Cl, Cu, Fe, K, Na, P, Rb and Zn are significantly altered (p<0.005) both in erythrocytes and whole blood, while Zn is also significantly depressed in the plasma. Likewise, the elements Br, K, Zn and Cu (erythrocytes) and Br, Fe, Zn, Cu, and S (Plasma) are deranged in subjects with haematological malignancies; while P, S, Fe, Cu, Zn (erythrocytes) and K, Cu and Zn (plasma) are altered in those with affective disorders. Trace elements interaction and compartmentalization have also been further elucidated. Significant correlations were sought and found between pairs of elements in both hair and blood. In particular, the zinc and chlorine concentration in hair was found to be significantly correlated with the levels of the same elements in erythrocytes. Alterations in correlations between pairs of elements in patients suffering from the three diseases of interest were also rigorously sought and noted. Using Cluster analysis technique, a very fair discrimination between control subjects and those suffering from haematological malignancies and affective disorders, based strictly on the trace element milieu in their blood was obtained. From all these results, it is clear that more accurate prediction of the response of various trace elements pools in the body following derangements or perturbations in some elements in any of the interacting pools is now possible. Based on the various alterations attributable to sickle cell anaemia, haematological malignancies, and affective disorders, directions for future studies on these diseases that is more likely to result in concrete clinical gains have been indicated. It has been demonstrated that without recourse to complicated analytical regimes of irradiation, waiting and counting, or radionuclide separations, most elements of biological importance can be conveniently detected through their intermediate-lived isotopes (with half-lives of roughly several hours), while the others such as Ca, S, P, Pb could be assayed using PIXE as a complimentary technique. Several protocols including data analysis have been tested out and automated. This work is therefore open-ended and other diseases would be investigated as soon as the biological bases are established. |Theses collection|Nuclear analytical techniques/Instrumental Neutron Activation Analysis (INAA)/Proton-Induced X-ray Emission (PIXE)/erythrocytes/plasma /Sickle Cell Anaemia (SCA)/Haematological malignancies/epidemiological/radionuclide separations.*||||||Omowe, Atime Daniel|M|The role of shell petroleum development company and the state in the underdevelopment of the niger delta of nigeria. 1937-1987||||||Ph.D. International Relations|Soremekun, K.// Sesay, A.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Internationalo Relations|1995|||OAU|||||xix, 322p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This study was concerned with the role of Shell Petroleum Development Company and the Nigerian state in the underdevelopment of the Niger Delta. It examined the process and nature of the underdevelopment of the area beginning from 1937 when Shell started operations there, to 1987 when most of the contradictions associated with oil production had fully unfolded. The data used in this study were obtained from library, archives and interviews. The method of extracting data from library and archival sources which were mainly books, journals and monographs, was that of analysis; for interviews, it was the open-ended questions. The study revealed that the Delta area for the period under review was underdeveloped. The activities of both Shell and the state deepened the incapacities of its inhabitants to meet most of their basic human needs such as food, shelter, pipe-borne water. It was also demonstrated in the study that the absence of a mining policy in the country accounted for their pollution of the environment of the area and the destruction of its economic State capitalism in the upstream sector of the petroleum industry as the study showed, placed great emphasis on the collection of oil rents. Consequently, it was unable to develop the local capability to find and win crude oil independent of Shell. Inspite of the Indigenization Decree, it was clear from the study that Shell Petroleum Development Company still remained wholly owned by its parent body in Europe: Royal Dutch/Shell Group. Although Shell had adequate environmental and labour policies which it implemented in Europe and the United States of America, the study found that they were not enforced in the country. The domestic bourgeoisie as demonstrated in the work was not involved in oil production. However, it played the role of a go-between for the state, Shell and the host oil communities mainly to satisfy its selfish economic and political interests.To be able to reverse the underdevelopment of the area particularly the effective control of the pollution of its environment, the state should cease concerning itself essentially with the collection of rents. The countrys indigenous technological base should be developed in order to reduce its (state) heavy reliance on the company so that it can control its operations.|Theses collection|Shell Petroleum Development Company/Niger Delta/petroleum industry/Indigenization Decree/environmental and labour policies/underdevelopment.*||||||Ojewale, Stephen Ayotunde|M|Effect of cognitve restructuring therapy on the self concept of physically disabled students in oyo state||||||M.A. Education (Guidance and Councelling)|Afolabi, E.R.I.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Educational Foundation and Councelling|1995|||OAU|||||viii, 84p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. The main  objectives of the study were to determine the efficacy of CRT in improving the self-concept of physically disabled students and to find out whether students variables such as sex and age would significantly influence' the effectiveness of the therapy. The sample for the study consisted of twenty-four physically disabled students selected from Cheshire High School, Ijokodo, Ibadan. The subjects were randomly assigned into experimental and control I groups. The control group received no treatment. An instrument, the adolescent self-Concept Scale, developed by Burns (1977), was administered on the subjects both before and after treatment to determine the levels of their self-concept. The treatment programme was carried out for seven weeks consisting of seven sessions of one hour per session. Data obtained both prior to and after the administration of the therapy were analysed using t-test. The significance of the results was determined at 0.05 level of probability. Results of the data analyses showed that Cognitive Restructuring Therapy (CRT) was effective in improving the self-concept of physically disabled students. The therapy did not show any significant difference in improving the self-concept of subjects due to sex or age. These results suggest that CRT could be used to enhance the self-concept of a wide range of physically disabled students in Nigeria. |Theses collection|Cognitive Restructuring Therapy (CRT)/physically disabled students.*||||||Oni, Thimothy Olakunle|M|Factors affecting agricaltural credit utilization in selected banks in osun state||||||M.Sc. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The access to and uses of credit facilities in banks by smallholder farmers have been very limited while co-operatives, friends, relatives moneylenders and social organisation such as 'Esusu' groups cannot provide adequate quantities of all the credit requirements of the farmers. The objectives of the study are to examine factors influencing agricultural credit use in the operation of smallholder agricultural credit scheme in the Nigerian Agricultural and Co-operative bank and the United Bank for Africa in achieving the goal of establishment coupled with reactivation and expansion of agricultural projects in Osun State. The Primary data were provided by 150 farmers randomly selected from credit beneficiaries of NACB and UBA in ten local government areas of Osun State. Structured questionnaires were used to collect data on personal and farming characteristics of beneficiaries. Other sources of data are the bank employees. The factors influencing credit use and repayment were determined by means of statistical and econometric analysis. The amount of loan obtained, amount of investment on farm, amount of interest repaid, extent of contact between the farmers and the banks, disbursement lag, farm size and farming experience serve as explanatory variables. The results obtained from regression analysis showed that the critical determinants of credit use and repayment are amount of loan obtained, disbursement lag and extent of contact between the farmers and the banks. The amount of loan obtained and extent of contact are positively related to amount repaid while disbursement lag is negatively Loan repayment rates showed 39 percent for NACB and 41 percent for UBA. Constraints on credit use and ability for repayment were found to include bureaucracy in lending policy and procedure, coupled with inadequate logistics and misconception among farmers to credit repayment. The study indicated that efforts directed at reducing these bottlenecks will enhance the use and repayment of credit. Based on the results obtained from the study the following policy recommendations were made. The banks' operational management should decentralise the implementation strategy in the smallholder agricultural credit scheme. In addition, the time interval between the period when application is submitted and when loan is disbursed to smallholder farmers should not be more than two months. A specialised department for loan monitoring and supervision should exist in bank's operation management that will direct loan to smallholder farmers. Also, the smallholder farmers should insure their crop enterprises against risks of loss due to pests, diseases and bad weather. The major contribution of this study to knowledge was that the results obtained from the study revealed that the amount of loan collected, the disbursement lag and the extent of farmers' contact with bank were the variables that significantly influenced the use and repayment of credit facilities. Expenses on hired labour were not significant. |Theses collection|credit facilities/smallholder farmers/co-operatives/moneylenders/'Esusu' groups/econometric analysis/Loan repayment rates/disbursement lag.*||||||Oniah, Victoria Ozoemezinem|F|Planning implications of environmental degradation in some oil producing community of delta state||||||M.Sc. Urban and Regional Planning|Olajin, M.O.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Urban and Regional Planning|1995|||OAU|||||xvi, 209p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Environmental degradation has assumed a global dimension and has taken the forefront in most debate current in current world issues. Based on the current world awareness on environmental problems, this study has become imperative, with a view to evaluating the effect of oil activities on the environment. The specific objectives of the study include: examining the genesis and nature of environmental degradation and its contributing factors; investigate the origin and geographic extent of oil drilling in the study area and effect on the inhabitants of these areas. To achieve these objectives, primary and secondary data were collected from relevant authorities including oil companies, planning offices, lands and survey divisions among others. The simple random sampling technique was applied to administer questionnaires to a total of 313 respondents out of which 198 respondents were indigenes of the oil producing areas and 115 respondents were the oil company staff. Findings were analysed empirically and statistically using correlation, cross tabulation and multivariate techniques. Results were also shown on table. Plates were used for illustrations. The study reveals that loss of farmlands and fishing ponds either through direct acquisition or environmental degradation from oil activities has led to increased pressure on available land and subsequently reduced farm size, fallow periods and crop\ catch yield. The study also shows that exploration and exploitation of oil has left the rural areas in a perpetual poor state as most of these localities are in remote, and impenetrable areas. The state of their environment has made it unhabitable hence the massive rural-urban migration. To check these problems the Oil Mineral Producing Areas Development Commission (OMPADEC) was established. Based on these findings policy recommendations have been tailored to reflect these findings. The recommendations are of three categories namely the oil companies, the Federal Government and its agencies and the indigenes of the oil producing areas. It is therefore suggested that Environmental planning and management is needed in all settlement to ensure healthy environment. There is need for community development, which can be achieved via dual effort through 40% contribution from the oil companies and 60% contribution from OMPADEC. This commission should also endeavour to convert the flared gas into generating electricity. There is need also for the integration of environment into economic development planning and decision making at all levels of government and private sector. Government should also create a friendly environment for both the operators and indigenes. The findings and recommendations, meant to ameliorate the problems identified will, no doubt, be of immense use in environmental planning and management and other related matters in other areas of oil exploration and exploitation in Nigeria. |Theses collection|Environmental degradation/global dimension/oil drilling/rural-urban migration/flared gas/Oil Mineral Producing Areas Development Commission (OMPADEC)/oil exploration/oil exploitation.*||||||Ohiosimuan, Oiseomaye Ohifeme|M|Production characteristics of rabbit breeds in the humid tropics||||||M.Sc. The experimental groups were randomly assigned to treatment levels which were Group-Merit, Group-Competition, Individual-Merit and Individual-Competition instructional techniques. The instrument used, Biology Achievement Test (BAT), was designed and validated by the researcher. Higher Educational Administration|Bamishaye, E.A.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Educational Administration and Planning|1995|||OAU|||||viii, 128p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research| The study was designed to identify the causes of brain drain and to examine the extent and impact of brain drain on the development of Nigerian Universities.A study sample of two-hundred and ten (210) academic staff was selected from three Nigerian Universities through stratified and random sampling techniques. Questionnaires and interview guides were administered to thirty-nine (39) Heads of Departments in the selected universities to obtain information on the extent and impacts of brain drain in their departments. Findings from the analysis of data showed that brain drain from the selected Nigerian Universities occurred because academic staff in Nigerian Universities were not adequately paid for the services rendered and that teaching equipment and facilities were iradequately provided. Consequently, the morale of  University lecturers was dampened. As a result, lecturers left the University system for the developed countries and private organisations in Nigeria and abroad. At  Obafemi Awolowo University, 11e-Ife twenty-seven percent (27%) of its lecturers left the institution in the last four years. A total percentage of thirteen percent (13%) left University of Ibadan, Ibadan and another thirteen percent (13%) left University of Lagos, Lagos. Some academic programmes were adversely affected and the quality of instruction was eroded. The University of Lagos required additional twenty-five percent (25%) to its established positions in the Faculties of Administration, Social Science and Engineering while the University of Ibadan required additional twenty-one percent (21%) to its established positions in the Faculties of Arts, Science and Law. Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife required additional thirty-five percent (35%) of its staff in the Faculties of Education, Agriculture and Dentistry. Some departments had to use experts in related disciplines to teach some courses. |Theses collection|Brain drain/University lecturers/academic staff.*||||||Onileowo, Olufunmilayo Titilayo|F|Morphogenetic charaterization studies of upland soils in ife area of osun state||||||M.Sc. All the soils have been identified to belong to two Association and have been  classified differently as Uitisols and Inceptisols. The first transect (TS-I) is located on an isolated landscape while the second transect (TS-2) ran from an lnselberg down to the stream channel. The parent materials of the upland soils of TS-l are basically residual as deduced from their morphological feature and physical properties. Quartz \/eins are the main sources of the of the gravelly horizon of soil identified as two. Series on TS-1 especially those located on the middle and shoulder positions landscape. Parent materials of TS-2 had undergone erosional /depositional cycles evidenced by multilayer parent rnaterials of colluvium on residuum. Moreover, In addition to abrupt and clear soil horizon boundaries within the profiles, stone lines within the pedons at the foot of the inselberg could further exp1ain their developments. The break in soil stratification is expressed by abrupt shifts of medium and fine sand subtractions on clay free base for TS-1 pedons while continuity of their parent materials is expressed by increase of these sand subtractions with an increasing depth. The multigenetic nature of TS-2 pedons is expressed by the regular and uniform to random distribution of sand subtraction on clay free base. The concavity of particles size curves of TS-1 upland pedons shows that they are well graded. This suggest probable preservation of soil parent materials. These parent mateials are subsequently transformed to soil regolith during pedo-genesis. Colluvial nature is expressed by steep multifaceted curves. This is an indication of poor sorting, and / or loss of certain soil fractions in pedons of TS-2.On TS-1, organic content of pedons decrease from surface horizons to subsurface while on TS-2 there is no define pattern of organic carbon distribution. The soil are generally not deficient in Ca2+ and Mg2+, but are low in Na+ and K+. Generally, breaks in horizon continuity in upland pedons especially on a rolling landscape like TS-1 do not necessarily indicate colluvial interruption of residuum but could be due to eluviation  illuviation processes and gravel addition from parent material or rock. The soil on the crestal position of TS-1 is described as basically sedentary and may be formed from any of these processes couple with mass wasting at the shoulder.|Theses collection|Soil/Uitisols/Inceptisols/parent material/Quartz \/eins/colluvium on residuum/pendons*||||||Oyedepo, Emiola, Adunni Ruth|F|A study of the efficacy of some wound dressing anticeptics against organisms isolated from sceptic wounds in two hospitals in ile-ife||||||M.Sc. Microbiology|Kolawole, D.O.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Microbiology|1995|||OAU|||||xi, 147p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The antimicrobial efficacy of four wound dressing antiseptics; Eusol, Acriflavine, Hydrogen peroxide and Savlon was tested against organisms isolated from septic wounds in Obafemi Awolowo University Teaching Hospitals Complex and Obafemi Awolowo University Health Centre. The study was directed at assessing the current resistance pattern of the organisms to these antiseptics and some of the antibiotics currently in use. The prevalent organisms implicated in the production of sepsis were also noted. One hundred and two wounds were studied; 94 yielded 162 organisms and 8 yielded no organisms on culturing. Swabs of the wounds were streaked on blood agar and mannitol salt agar. Bacteriological techniques were employed to identify the primary isolates which were then tested for antibiotic sensitivity using standard procedures. The efficacy of the antiseptics was tested by means of the disc-diffusion technique and the determination of the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC).The predominant organism isolated from the wounds was Staphylococcus aureus constituting 24% of the total isolates. The enteric gram negative rods, altogether accounted for 49.7% of the isolates, with Escherichia coli contributing 13% and Pseudomonas aeruginosa 10%. The remaining 26.7% was contributed by 10 different species belonging to the family enterobacteriaceae. Trauma wounds which were predominant accounted for about 25% of the wounds. They were mostly located on the extremitites.Generally, the organisms were sensitive to chloramphenicol, streptomycin and gentamicin and resistant to ampicillin, penicillin, tetracycline and erythromycin. About 50% of the gram positive organisms were sensitive to cloxacillin while the gram negative organisms were resistant. The disc diffusion and minimum inhibitory concentration procedures showed the following to be the order of efficacy of the antiseptics with a few variations, Hp > Sv > Ac > Eu. By the two methods eusol was ineffective in inhibiting or killing any of the organisms. Acriflavine was only partially effective, as the undiluted solution did not inhibit Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Proteus vulgaris and Proteus mirabilis. The 1:10 and 1:20 dilutions of savlon were only partially effective, they produced between 12 and 20mm zones of inhibition for all the organisms. Hydrogen peroxide was effective against all the organisms with diameters of zones of inhibition being 40mm and above. It exhibited a lower MIC than the other antiseptics with the gram negative organisms, except with E.coli and Ps.aeruginosa. Among the gram positive organisms the MIC of savlon was generally lower. The organisms most susceptible to savlon were Staphylococcus aureus , S. epidermidis, Staphylococcus sp. and Streptococcus feacalis. The organism most susceptible to hydrogen peroxide was Streptococcus feacalis. Acriflavine was most effective against . epidermidis and Streptococcus feacalis. In this study Pseudomonas aeruginosa was the single most resistant organism and this may not be unconnected with its possession of inherent resistance and lipopolysaccharide complex. Eusol was found to be the most ineffective antiseptic, probably as a result of wrong handling of the antiseptic coupled with the development of resistance by the organisms themselves. It was recommended that use of the partially effective or ineffective antibiotics and antiseptics be strictly monitored.|Theses collection|disc-diffusion technique/minimum inhibitory concentration(MIC)/Pseudomonas aeruginosa/lipopolysaccharide/*||||||Osilana, Adebola Olutosin|M|Cloroquine disposition flowing reptile administration in man||||||M.Sc. Pharmaceutical Chemistry|Ogunbona, F.A.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo Univeristy, Pharmaceutical Chemistry|1995|||OAU|||||xii, 96p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. Estate management|Igalo, J.I.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo Univeristy, Estate Management|1995|||OAU|||||xvii, 171p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|There have been a few known studies linking urban residential location and accessibi1ity to workplace in traditional African cities. Yet, there is a strong and compelling need for urban resource managers and investors to understand the functioning of the socio-economic structure of urban environment so as to efficiently allocate, manage and exploit these resources. Following the dearth of reliable information on the residential and work-place location activities and the intra-urban movement of urban dwellers, real estate market participants have continuously had difficulties obtaining necessary information about the pattern of residential location requirements of households vis-a-vis the effect of their (the households) concern for proximity to workplace. This study therefore examined the variables of urban residential location decision, the elements of measuring accessibility, the role and degree of the collective and individual impact of these accessibility elements in house selection process and the link between the level of income of households and their analysis of accessibility to workplace in residential location decision-making.194 tenant households, 67 landlords, 9 caretakers and 7 firms of Estate Agents, Surveyor's and Valuers were examined in a stratified sampling survey conducted in April 1994 in Benin City, Edo State capital. Descriptive and inferential statistical models, including correlation and regression analysis were applied in the examination of the empirical evidence. The result showed a strong relationship between accessibility to workplace, income levels of  households and residential location decision-making in a traditional African urban area. Also established is that the socio- cultural affiliation of households to particular neighbourhood was a significant factor in residential location selection. This study thus recommended prudent and judicious measures for urban resource allocation, management and exploitation so as to promote urban structural and socio-economic efficiency and harmony. |Theses collection|urban residential location/traditional African cities/socio-economic structure/households.*||||||Obioh, Imoh Bassey|M|Inventorisation and modellinf of the emission of greenhouse pollutants in nigeria||||||Ph.D. Physics|Oluwole, A.F.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Physics|1995|||OAU|||||xxiii, 275|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The determination of the emission rates and pathways for the emission of greenhouse gases and other toxic air pollutants is carried out with a view to determining the sources and source strengths. This will enable the prognosis of emission pathways for the emission relevant processes as well as the modelling of the various impacts on the atmospheric environment in Nigeria. Results provide an initial input to an expected National Emissions Data Systems (NEDS) being proposed. NEDS will be required as a modelling warehouse for emission, dispersion/deposition, atmospheric physico-chemical reactions, global warming and cost-effectiveness analysis of the control measures for these pollutants. Current emission estimates cover the whole federation as well as the states as minimum spatial grids where data is available. The emissions are also determined over a temporal range which allows emission trends to be evaluated. Source distribution comprises all the known combustion, industrial processes, biogenic and natural processes. Emission factors are partly measured by techniques of photometry, chemiluminescence, flame ionization detection for gaseous pollutants. Oxygen (02) measurement was based on the paramagnetic properties of oxygen molecule, and particulate matter by gravimetric techniques. Additional emissions factors were modelled from process analysis as well as from literature review. Emission spread sheet with about 150 processes was used to determine the gross emissions from all sources in Nigeria for the year 1988. Trend analysis of emission over the past 50 years was carried in major economic sectors. The use of impact prediction indices to determine probable implications of these emissions was carried out in respect of global warming phenomenon. Using a scale analysis of emissions in sectors, an emission reduction model based on four emission reduction scenarios was developed. Results show that the particulate emission for cement production in Nigeria is higher than US EPA figures by factors of between 2 and 3. Upstream oil and gas sectors show significant emission from gas flares which are higher than emission in gas fired utilities and public power generation. Annual emissions show that Nigeria is not a major source of the studied air pollutants on the global scale. Local sources conglomerate around Lagos, the Niger delta and the north central part of Nigeria. Annual emission rates in thousand tonnes are S02(87), NOx(926), CO(6700), PM(22360), VOC(6746), CH4(1050), Pb(2.8) and N20(8.7). Trends show annual growth rates of approximately 72% between 1960 and 1989 compared to 7.6% between 1940 and 1960. Annual emission rates have increased by 1 to 2 orders of magnitude during the period. Global warming monitored for Lagos, Calabar and Kano indicate increase of between 0.3 and 0.5C per decade. This is comparable to the global average reported as 0.3C. A reduction model based on a 4-scenario energy management and efficiency improvements options accordingly show that reduction in the flaring of natural gas holds the key to large scale reduction in all the plausible scenarios in the short term. |Theses collection|emission rates/greenhouse gases/National Emissions Data Systems (NEDS)/atmospheric environment/physico-chemical reactions/gravimetric techniques.*||||||Obasohan, Edward Eremwanrue|M|Development and simulation of a modified fourth-stage runge-kutta algorithm for sloving ordinary differential equations||||||M.Sc. Computer Science|Ogwu, F.J.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Computer Science and Engineering|1995|||OAU|||||viii, 133p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The mathematical formulation of physical phenomena in almost every sphere of human endeavour, be it engineering, control theory or Economics often leads to one or a set of differential equations. Although great advances have been made in numerical methods to obtain solutions to initial value problems in ordinary differential equations, there are many problems which seriously tax them. One such class of problems is stiff equations for which most existing explicit methods do not give a stable and reliable result. The need to improve on this lapse motivated the development of a new modified classical fourth-stage Runge-Kutta formula. Using, the conventional classical fourth-stage Runge-Kutta formula as a basis, a modified numerical method with rational incremental and stability function was developed. A computer program was designed to implement the proposed method in solving some initial-value problems in ordinary differential equations. Results obtained for the stability function indicate that the proposed formula has a stability interval (-3.875,0) compared to (-2.78,0) for the classical fourth order Runge-Kutta formula. The numerical solution obtained using various meshsizes further support the classical Runge Kutta formula as still the best one- step formula for handling simple nonstiff problems. However for a mildly stiff problem,  the result obtained for botl1 the proposed formula and the well known classical Runge-Kutta formula with a fixed meshsize (h) = 0.2 establishes the stability advantage of the proposed formula. |Theses collection|mathematical formulation/physical phenomena/differential equations/Runge-Kutta formula.*||||||Obembe, Olawole Odun|M|Vegetative propagation of cola nitida (vent.) schott and endlicher by plant tissue culture||||||M.Sc. In this study, the micropropagation of C. nitida by means of tissue culture was investigated to provide baseline information on the responses of the explants to some growth media. Explant materials from young leaves and nodal segments of C. nitida seedings were cultured on modified Murashige and Skoog (MS) medium supplemented with different auxins and cytokininso. The implanted materials were incubated at 27+/-1oC under continuous light. Calluses were induced successfully from young leaf cultures on the medium supplemented with 1-naphthaleneacetic acid (NAA) 0.5-5.0mg/l and 6-benzylaminopurine (BAP) 1.0n and with BAP 1.0-5.0m and NAA 1.0 mg/l. The best callus growth was obtained with NAA 1.0gm/l. Callus induction was also successful with nodal segments cultured on the medium supplemented with NAA 0.5-2.0mg/l and BAP 10.0m. Callus growth from nodal segments was best maintained on NAA 1.0mg/l. It was observed that the callus derived from the nodal segments showed the tendency of cell differentiation. The different morphological parts of these species are traditionally used in Nigeria in the treatment of stomachial diseases. The MeOH extracts of these plants were screened phytochemically and also analysed chromatographically using standard techniques. Phytochemical tests showed that these plants contain flavonoids in all morphological parts while alkaloids were found mostly in their roots. Other constituents such as cardiac glycosides, tannins and saponins were of varied distribution in the different parts of each plant Antimicrobial tests of extracts of the different morphological parts showed weak activity against most of the test organisms indicating that its ethnomedicinal activity is not due to a activity against microorganisms. This suggests an activity due to physiological or pharmacological effects of the chemical constituents.Large scale fractionation of N. leavis rootbark led to the isolation of several compounds from samples collected both during the dry and raining seasons. Of these compounds, four alkaloids were characterised and identified as pyrazole alkaloids, which, are rare in nature. A completely randomized design was used to allocate the birds to six -treatment groups with four replicates per treatment as follows: Treatment 1, Bilateral Castrates(48) with both testicles removed; Treatment 2, Left Castrates (48) with the left testicle removed; Treatment 3, Right Castrates (48) with the right testicle removed; Treatment 4, Sham Operated (48) with cockerels incised and both testiclcs examined but left intact; Treatment 5, Intact Males (48) serving as a control and Treatment 6, Intact Females (48) serving as a control. The Bilateral Castrates attaincd a mean body weight ,that was  significantly (p < 0.05) higher than that of  the Left Castrates, Intact Males and Intact Females at sixteen weeks of age. The mean red blood cell counts and white blood cell counts were lowered by caponization in all the treatments. The sample for the study consisted of fourteen companies that were systematically selected from eight manufacturing- service and service industries in and around Lagos. Three research instruments were utilized to collect data from the companies selected for the study. The data collected were analysed using statistical models such as Fisher's Exact Test, Regression Analyses, and Pearson's Product Moment Correlation Coefficient. Data were also analysed by describing the phenomenon observed. All the hypotheses were tested at 0.05 level of significance. The results of the study indicated that a higher service companies (80%) expended money that was classified as high on training. When the amount expended on training was adjusted for the total workforce of the companies, the result showed that the expenditure on training per worker was dependent on whether the company was a manufacturing-service or service company. With an exact probability of larger value of .021, service companies came clear as being more committed to training than their manufacturing-service counterparts. Sixty six percent of large companies had high commitment rating as against 56% for giant companies. The results also revealed that the companies drew trainers from all the available sources for sourcing trainers - "in - house" and "out - of - house" and the companies had their own, or had access to the basic minimum physical facilities for training. The results showed that although the percentage of workers trained was not dependent on the nature and size of the companies, a higher percentage of service (60%) and large companies (66%) had high involvement in training. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This thesis investigated some discourse feature of selected interviews in English of some Nigerian politicians by journalist. Specifically, it did three things: describing the structure and organisation of the content of conversational interaction between journalists and politicians in the interviews, observing the communication strategies and motivations of the participants in negotiating the interactions, and also observing the orientation of participants towards each other and towards the subject matter of the interviews.The methodology used involved the collection of data from interviews conducted in both the electronic and the print media. The data were used to illustrate the various features of interactions in the interviews- including the structure, transactions, exchanges, moves and acts - and the strategies used by participants in the negotiation of meaning. The findings of the study revealed (1) that the Initiation-Response (IR) structure was the predominant exchange  structure in the interactions, with the response (R) move having, more potentials of extension than the rest of the moves;  (2) that the journalist initiated exchanges, used frames, introduced topics and controlled the interaction, while the politician could not; (3) that politicians replied cooperatively when questions helped to further their cause and evaded questions that did not promote their interests; (4) that journalists asked sensitive questions sometimes with the intention to ridicule, expose, indict or implicate the, politicians or other people, whose behaviour were anti-social. The conclusion of the thesis summarised the features of discourse structure, orqanisation and participation observed In addition, it suggested the need for further studies on the negotiation of meaning in journalist  politician interviews, particularly on the role of intonation in interviews. It also suggested the need to relate the above findings from interviews to other types of discourse. |Theses collection|Initiation-Response (IR)/print media/politicians/journalist.*||||||Fatuase, Alfred Adeniyi|M|Application of ausubelian advance organiser theory as a strategy for enhancing reading comprehensin among junior secondary schools in ondo state||||||M.A.Ed. Pretest and post-test in comprehension were administered. The group taught with AOT model performed significantly better in comprehension than their counterparts. They also performed significantly better in vocabulary acquisition. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The study examined the relationship between the personality correlates of self concept, risk-taking, need achievement, anxiety, extraversion, locus of control and impulsiveness and guessing behaviour in three forms of multiple-choice tests, namely the multiple-choice test with three, four and five options. The subjects of the study were one hundred and twenty undergraduate students (comprising of 72 females and 48 males) randomly selected in the Faculty of Education, Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife. The instruments of the study consisted of standardised self report inventories and a battery of achievement tests which were adequately validated. Both tests were administered on the subjects over a period of time. The resulting data were analysed using relevant correlational analysis procedures and the analysis of variance at 0.05 level of significance. Results of the analyses indicated that there exists a positive and I statistically significant relationship between extraversion, risk-taking, I state anxiety and guessing behaviour. Negative and statistically significant correlations were obtained between guessing behaviour and self concept (SC) in all the MC formats, and also between guessing behaviour and in achievement (NA) in both 4-MC and 5-MC formats. The result also revealed that guessing behaviour is significantly related to academic ability with the tendency to guess increasing with ability. It was also found that guessing behaviour is significantly affected by test item format, with most guessing taking place in the 5-MC format. Thus, students who are extraverted, are text anxious and are high risk takers, are likely to guess in multiple-choice tests while those who have a favourable concept of themselves and those who are well motivated to achieve are less likely to guess in multiple-choice tests. |Theses collection|self concept/risk-taking/need achievement/anxiety/extraversion/locus of control/impulsiveness/multiple-choice tests.*||||||Fasoro, Joseph Oluotimi|M|Justification in ethics||||||Ph.D. Philosophy|Fasina, O.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Philosophy|1995|||OAU|||||xii, 364p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This thesis attempted to defend the objectivity of moral judgements and ethical statements. It critically examined some meta-ethical theories. In addition, it attempted to establish that proper justification of moral judgements or ethical statements need not be an infallible set of propositions, and that moral justification should be assessed by some criteria of adequacy. The methodology used in this work included library research. Books and journals on current debates on meta-ethical theories were consulted. The method of critical and conceptual analysis was also employed. The thesis found that an excessively abstract approach to justification has been an obstruction to the resolution of disputes in meta-ethics. It also found that the adequacy of moral justification was not to be determined by the philosopher's ability to satisfy the sceptic's demand for an indisputable moral purpose. The thesis concluded that the contractarian rational choice theory is the most plausible philosophical basis for the adequacy of objective justification. But to adequately deal with the complexity of moral issues, this theory too required some bridge principles. |Theses collection|moral judgements/ethical statements/meta-ethical theories.*||||||Farinde, Akinloye Jimoh|M|Factors associted with the effectiveness of the training and visit extension system of the lagos state agricultural development programme, nigeria||||||Ph.D. Agric Extension and Sociology|Jibowo, A.A.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Agic Extension and Rural Sociology|1995|||OAU|||||xix, 313p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. The study specifically determined the effectiveness of the Training and Visit extension system; identified the organization extension worker and farmer-related factors that are associated with the effectiveness. The study was conducted in five purposively selected rural local government areas, namely: Agege, IbeJu-Lekki, Epe, Ikorodu and Badagry in Lagos State. Structured interview schedule was used to elicit information from two hundred and fourteen full-time farmers. Seventy-three copies of Questionnaires were completed by LSADP extension workers. Frequency and percentage distributions, means, standard deviation and lorenz curve were used the data. Correlation analysis was used to test the hypotheses formulated; Factor and component analyses were used to isolate the crucial factors with the effectiveness of the Training and Visit extension system. The results showed that the effectiveness score was average. Only two organizational factors namely; number of superior/Village Extension Worker (VEW) (r = 0.233) and number of participants at Fortnightly Training (FNT) session (r = 0.335) were significantly associated with effectiveness. While only seven Extension worker-related factors were significantly related to effectiveness, fourteen farmer-related factors were significantly associated with the effectiveness the Training and Visit extension system. Extension worker-related factors were age (r = -0.2981); number of extension contacts with farmers (r = O. 3624); number of training sessions given to farmers (r=0.2697); number of visits paid to farmers (r=0.5717); number of demonstrations given to farmers (r=0.6618), number of advice given to farmers (r=O. 5549), and number of SPAT plots established (r=0.5854). Groups of factors isolated in association with the effectiveness were: research-extension-farmer linkage, regular and continuous training, motivation of extension workers, maturity of extension workers, length of knowledge philosophy of extension, definition, teaching methods, frequency of use of SPAT, unity of command, intensi1y of FNT session, role performance, family size, supervision, degree of advisory number of innovations disseminated, extension-farmer ratio and contact farmers.
