E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The main objective of this study was to determine the influence of family structure on the incidence of juvenile delinquency. Specifically, the study examined the relationship between family structure and juvenile delinquency and the implications of delinquency for the society. Data for the analysis were obtained primarily from the questionnaire designed to elicit information from respondents in respect of their family background. The questionnaire contained items which were mostly close-ended while some were open-ended in nature. Respondents were divided into two groups: the delinquent experimental group and the non-delinquent control group. The descriptive technique with the use of frequency tables and cross tabulations were used to analyse the data collected. Our study reveals that 56.25% of the delinquents said they came from broken homes against 75.00% of the non-delinquents who said they came from intact homes. Thus, our findings reveal that family breakdown is a contributory factor to delinquency causation. Also, our study reveals that 62.50% of the delinquents said they were rniddle born children while 37.50% of the delinquents said they were first and second born children. Hence, our findings reveal that sibling order of children is a contributory factor to delinquency causation. Our study also reveals that 67.08% of the delinquents claimed that their peer groups had influence on why they became delinquents while 22.92% of the delinquents said their peer groups had weak or no influence on their delinquent acts. Thus, our findings peer groups is a contributory factor to delinquency causation. Based on the findings of the study, we recommend that a family Counselling Unit counsel troubled the negative implications of divorce while parents should try to closely monitor the activities of their children and the kind of friends they move with. |Theses collection|family structure/juvenile delinquency/non-delinquent control group/delinquent experimental group/broken homes/peer groups/family Counselling Unit/divorce.*||||||Eyeh, Stephen Obrthe|M|Images of space and objects in ayi kwei armah's fiction||||||M.A. Literature in English|Kolawole, M.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, English|1995|||OAU|||||viii, 133p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This thesis examined the images of space and objects in five novels of Ayi Kwei Armah in order to show their relevance to the author's themes. The study aimed at showing that this stylistic device is utilised not only to show art for arts sake, but for arts to arouse a social consciousness and ideological vision.The methodology used involved the identification of various spatial images and objects in Armah's The Beautiful Ones Are Not Yet Born. Fragments, Why Are we so Blest? Two Thousand Season and The Healers. Images of similar nature were classified so as to determine their functions and their symbolic implications to social reality. The recurrent images in all the novels were studied in order to reveal their intra and inter-textual relationship. This helps to determine the consistency of Armah as an Artist in his use of images to form his ideological stance or vision. In addition, spatial objects like buildings, harbour and other objects such as money and cars were analysed as symbols that contributed to the expression of Armah's ideological stance and vision.The study showed that characters were deployed as individuals that occupy spatial and moral space and whose interactions and movements from one place to the other have symbolic implications. Among them are the highly individualistic characters that constitute the manipulative and the higher group oppressors. But the ordinary characters connote humanity and communality. It also showed that Armah built on these two categories of characters to reveal class conflict and establish a universal ideology of the peasants versus the bourgeoisie. The study also showed that Armah's five novels are a manifestation of profound intellectual and scholarly efforts to promote human existence devoid of avarice and decadence. It was concluded that Armah's imagery are worth studying because he has used them to present a chronology of events from the period of traditional society, to the modern post-indpendence periods. He has sifted the good of collective living, 'the way', from the traditional African society as a way forward in the present time instead of the individualism of African leaders. |Theses collection|social consciousness/ideological vision/inter-textual relationship/bourgeoisie/peasants.*||||||Esu, Dada Gabriel|M|The effects of an eight-weed physical activity training programme on the physical fitness status of deaf children in Ondo State||||||M.A. Physical Education|Okurotifa, E.G.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Physical Education|1995|||OAU|||||x,93p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. Animal Science|Olobunmi, E.A.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Animal Science|1995|||OAU|||||xix,78p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Various diseases are known to affect pigs including ectoparasitic infestations; and sarcoptic mange is one of the most important. This disease is largely treated with organophosphorus and chlorinated hydrocarbons which, in Nigeria, are mainly imported hence scarce and expensive. Experiments were then carried out to investigate the prevalence of this disease; and also the effects of a locally available herb as an alternative remedy for the disease.A survey of 12 pig farms was carried out to determine the prevalence of sarcoptic mange in lbadan, Ile-lfe and llesa areas of South-Western Nigeria. Identification and phytochemical analysis of the local herb (Heliotropium indicum Linn. ) was also carried out. Crude water extract (W.E). petroleum ether extract (P.E.E) and fresh juice of the herb (F.H.J) were tested for acaricidal activity against sarcoptes mites in vitro. Mortalities of Mites were recorded after 1 hour, 2 and 8 hours; and compared with mortality in ivomectin (a conventional drug) treatment. Clinical trial of the herb extracts was carried out. by topical application to mange infested pigs on days 0, 8, and 16. Parasitological assessments were by microscopic examination of skin scrapings obtained 3 days after each application, and then 21 days after the last herbal treatment. Effects of the herb extracts were compared with a single injection of the recommended dose of ivomectin.Results of the survey showed that about 92% of the farms had pigs infested with mange. Fifty percent of the 842 pigs in the farms were infested, and 205 pigs of these were not treated. Phytochemical analysis of the herb showed that H. indicum contains alkaloids, saponins and tannins. The mean percentage mortalities of mites in the herb extracts were 84.13%. 95.56% and 99.08% respectively for W.E., F.H.J. and P.E.E. while ivomectin treatment had 100 percent. There was no significant difference between ivomectin and the herb extracts; but the four treatments differed significantly from the control (treatment with distilled water). In the clinical trial, W.E.. P.E.E. and F.H.J. had 43.51%. 82.17%, and 84.99% mean reductions of mites respectively, while ivomectin had 37.46 percent. However, there was no significant difference between ivomectin, P.E.E. and F.H.J., but the 3 treatments differed significantly (P < 0.05) from W.E. treatment. Three applications of fresh herb juice of H. indicum are effective for mange treatment in pigs.|Theses collection|pigs/ectoparasitic infestations/sarcoptic mange/organophosphorus/chlorinated hydrocarbons/herb/Heliotropium indicum Linn/skin scrapings/Parasitological assessments/microscopic examination.*||||||Eso-Olawale, Sunday Davies|M|Effect of testwiseness training in objective test performance among secondary school students in osun state.||||||M.A.Ed. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The purpose of the study was to investigate the effect of testwiseness training in objective test performance among secondary school students and whether the efficacy of the testwiseness training will he influenced by academic ability. The study was also designed to examine if students' subject specialisation(s) will significantly influence their profit from testwiseness training.The study made use of pretest-posttest control group design with 120 senior secondary school III non-testwise students selected by stratified random sampling. They were randomly assigned to experimental and control groups. The study made use of a self constructed Student Testwiseness Scale (STS) using Bishop and Ebel (1965) testwiseness principles. A TestwisenessTraining Package (TTP) was also developed using the same principles. Furthermore, an Achievement Test Battery (ATB) consisting of test items in English Language, Biology and Economics written three different objective test formats (multiple choice, True-false, and completion) was also developed. All the instruments were adequately tested for reliability and validity. Pre-treatment scores of the STS were used to identify non-testwise students. The latter were thereafter randomly assigned to experimental and control groups consisting of 60 students per group. The experimental group was given a six-week testwiseness training of five sessions. The control group was given placebo treatment. The two groups were presented the student testwiseness scale after the treatment. One-way analysis of variance, t-test and multiple comparisons (T - method) were used in data analysis.Results of data analyses indicate that testwiseness training significantly improved students' academic performance. Further, the effect of testwiseness training on the performance of students with different levels of academic ability was not significant. Furthermore, all subjects, irrespective of subject specialisations, had improved academic scores.Thus, the study tends to suggest that testwiseness training can be profitable for students of different academic abilities and subject backgrounds.|Theses collection|testwiseness training/academic ability/TestwisenessTraining Package (TTP)/Student Testwiseness Scale (STS)/placebo treatment.*||||||Falade, Johnson Oluremi|M|La creativite stylistique de birago diop dans les contes d'amadou koumba||||||M.A. Foreign Languages|Nweze, E.C.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Foreign Languages|1995|||OAU||||This theses examined the style of African folktales after their transcription, taken as an example, the literary work of Birago Diop, Les Contes dAmadou Koumba .It also examined how Birage Diop evoked the oral style in the translation and transcription of African folktales in the period immediately preceeding and after their transcription in the French languge.The methodology employed included the analysis of relevant literature on literary and stylistic approaches to African folktales as well as a critical study of Birago Diops Les Contes dAmadou Koumba.The thesis found that Birago Diop succeeded in evoking oral style in the translation and transcription of Les Contes dAmadou Koumba. Political Science|Durotoye,Y||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Political Science|1995|||OAU|||||x, 201p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This study examined and sought to explain the determinants of voter behaviour in Akwa Ibom State, particularly in the gubernatorial election of 1991. It began by looking at findings in the literature on determinants of political behaviour particularly voting. From there the study went on to discuss the evolution of electoral participation in Nigeria and then placing it within the political economic context of Nigeria. This was followed by discussion and analysis of findings of the field research conducted in Akwa Ibom State to identify the determinants of voter behaviour in the state. The methodology employed in the study was both quantitative and qualitative. On the one hand, questionnaires and structured interviews were used to collect data from a sample of voters selected from purposively sampled areas. The investigation centred on demographic characteristics of respondents as well as the role of money and group solidarity on voters choice. Later on, the variables so collated were correlated with patterns of voter behaviour. On the other hand, the qualitative method relied on the political economy approach to explain the findings revealed by the survey research. A few of the findings met expectations. For example, the majority of voters were in the 30 to 49 age bracket. This is as the literature predict. However the relatively high voting rate of 18 and 29 age bracket contradicts expectations. Similarly, against all expectations, the open ballot system adopted during the elections did not significantly disenfranchise voters. In the same vein, the study cannot establish that education and occupation influence voter turn- out significantly. However, the most interesting finding, in our judgement, concerns the role of money and group solidarity in the determination of voter choice and behaviour. In this area, we found that voters in the lower socio economic status were more disposed toward accepting bribes during election than the upper socio-economic status voters. In contrast, the upper socio-economic status voters were more interested in ensuring group solidarity than in material gratification during election. They appear to be willing to defer their rewards. They probably know that material benefit will follow in the form of appointments and contracts when the election is won. Using the political economy approach, therefore, the study explained this incident as a function of the rentier and patrimonial nature of the Nigerian state.  A few of the findings met expectations. For exampe, the majority of voters were in the 30 to 49 age bracket. This is as the literature predict. However the relatively high voting  rate of 18 and 29 age bracket contradicts, expectations. Similarly, against all expectations, the open ballot system the elections did not significantly disenfranchise voters. In the same vein, the study cannot establish that education and occupation influence voter turn-out significantly. However, the most interesting finding, in our judgement, concerns the role of money and group solidarity in the determination of voter choice and behaviour. In this area, we found that voters in the lower socio economic status were more disposed toward accepting bribes during election than the upper socio-economic status voters. In contrast, the upper socio-economic status voters were more interested in ensuring group solidarity than in material gratification during election. They appear to be willing to defer their rewards. They probably know that material benefit will follow in the form of appointments and contracts when the election is won. Using the political economy approach, therefore, the study explained this incident as a function of the rentier and patrimonial nature of the Nigerian state. |Theses collection|political behaviour/electoral participation/voters/*||||||Fagbohunka, Bamidele Sanya|M|Characterization of cellulase from the haemolymph of giant african snail archachatina marginata||||||M.Sc. Biochemistry|Afolayan, A.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Biochemistry|1995|||OAU|||||x, 99p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The giant African snails (Archachatina marginata) are herbivorous tropical gastropods. They are commonly located in areas littered with decaying vegetable matters which they feed on. When the haemolymph of this organism was passed through Sephadex G-200, the resin was digested. The ability of snail to digest vegetable matters and the digestion of sephadex G-200 resin by the haemolymph led to the suspicion of the presence of cellulase in snail haemolymph. Cellulase from the haemolymph of the giant African snail (Archachatina marginata) was purified to homogeneity by a combination of Gel filtration on BioGel P-300 and ion exchange chromatography on DEAE - Sephadex A-SO. The homogeneity of the pure enzyme was confirmed by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis in the absence and presence of sodium dodecyl sulphate. The sub-unit molecular weight was 16,875+/- 1,556 daltons and the apparent molecular weight as determined by gel filtration was 52,000 daltons. Thus the enzyme is at least a dimer. The enzyme had a specific activity of 1359.09 units/mg of protein. The Michaelis-Menten constant Km for CM-cellulose was 5.17+/- 0.74 mg/ml and the Vmax was 1067+/- 195 units/ml. The enzyme did not degrade salicin, cellobiose and O-nitrophenyl -D-glucopyranoside. Its activities towards filter paper and cotton wool were insignificant compared with its activity towards CM-cellulose. Linamarin was found to inhibit the action of the enzyme to about 18%. The high specificity for CM-cellulose and the rapid decrease in the viscosity of CM-cellulose suggests that the enzyme is likely an endoglucanase. |Theses collection|giant African snails (Archachatina marginata)/herbivorous tropical gastropods/vegetable matters/haemolymph/Gel filtration/chromatography/Michaelis-Menten constant/electrophoresis.*||||||Gbadebo, Adewole Michael|M|Biostratigraphy and paleoecology of meren-a and meren-b wells niger delta, nigeria||||||M.Sc. Applied Geology|Salami, M||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Geology|1995|||OAU|||||xvii, 221p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|A total of one hundred and eighty-two (182) ditch cutting samples from Meren-A and Meren-B wells have been studied for microfauna and microflora. Additionally, the lithologic sequences in the wells have been studied and analysed. The main objective of this study has been to establish the age(s) of the sediments, zone them biostratigraphically, determine the environment in which the sediments were deposited and finally attempt gross correlation of the two wells that have been studied. Lithostratigraphic interpretation of the two wells resulted in the delineation of two informal units referred to as Unit X and unit Y. These units exhibit lithologic characters similar to the Lower and Upper Agbada Formation. Based on palynomorph contents, three zones have been erected for the two wells. These are Nymphaea lotus (Late Miocene age), Gemmamonoporites sp. (Late Miocene age) and Echiperiporites cf estelae (Early Pliocene age); foraminiferal biostratigraphical zones ranging through Late Miocene/Early Pliocene age include: Globorotalia dutertrei (Late Miocene) and Globigerina nepenthes (Early Pliocene) for the planktonic foraminifera of the two studied wells. Similarly, the inferred benthonic foraminiferal zones of Meren-A from base to top are: Uvigerina peregrina/Quinqueloculina seminulum, Lenticulina vortex/Triloculina sp., Florilus costiferum/Lagena sulcata and Marginulina raphanus. Those of Meren-B in ascending order are Uvigerina sparsicostata/Sigmolina schlumbergeri,  Quinqueloculina microcostata/Lenticulina vortex and Lenticulina Formosa/Lagena sulcata zones. On the basis of the occurrence of the following land derived microfloral assemblages: Zonocostites ramonae, Pachydermites diederixi, Verrutricolporites rotundiporus Psilatricolporites crassus, Verrucatosporites usmensis, Nymphaea lotus, Pediastrum as well as the following benthonic foraminiferal assemblages: Uvigerina peregrine, Sigmolina schlumbergeri, Bulimina sp., Alveolophragmiun sp. Quinqueloculina sp., Lenticulina sp., Nonion sp., Cyclammina minima, Florilus sp., Lagena sp. Etc., dinoflagellates and foraminifera inner linings, the paleoenvironments of deposition deduced for the study areas are : Middle Neritic to Bathyal, Inner Neritic, Inner to Middle Neritic, Fluviomarine to Inner Neritic and Fluviomarine environments.Meren-A and Meren-B wells have been found to be grossly correlative in terms of their lithogic units, microfauna and microfloral similarities. |Theses collection|microfloral/microfauna/lithogic units/Lithostratigraphic interpretation/biostratigraphically/palynomorph/benthonic foraminiferal zones/assemblages/paleoenvironments/Fluviomarine environments.*||||||Odejobi, Cecilia Omobola|F|Ihun Orin Eebu Ni Ife||||||M.A. Yoruba|Akinyemi, A.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,  African Languages and Literature|1995|||OAU||||This thesis is a study of vituperative songs among the Ife; a dialect group in Yorubaland. The work identified vituperative songs as a genre of Yoruba orature and described its structure as found in Ife dialect. It also examined its various uses as observed among these people. Vituperative songs were collected in Ile-Ife as well as in towns where the dialect is spoken. These towns include Ife, Ifeetedo, Oke-Igbo and Ifewara. The structuralist theory provided the theoretical framework for the analysis of the structure and uses of the vituperative songs collected. The structure of the songs showed that each song datum was rendered in very short stanzas of not more than four or five poetic sentences. Where a vituperative song was more than five sentences, the exponent would repeat part or whole of the five sentences. Also, it was found that repetition is an important stylistic feature of vituperative songs and that this accounted for the rhythmic structure of the songs. The rhythms of vituperative songs were often symbiotically complemented with kinesics which enabled the creator exponent introduced linguistic devices of aesthethic significance into the songs. All these combined make the songs functional. Another finding is that the exponent of the songs were mostly females of varying ages. The audiences of the songs were usually the target of the vituperative songs. The exponent usually sang to express their personal emotions al though the songs could also be used to correct social ills of the society. Such ills are many and varied. Two examples will suffice here viz:One, a man planning to seduce a young girl, Two, the consequences of laziness in the society. They could also be means of finding lasting solutions to quarrels in the society. |x, 183p|||||||Yoruba||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Ise yii se atupale orin eebu ni aarin awon Ife, ti o je isori eka-ede kan ni ile Yoruba. Tiori Ifoju ihun-wo-ise ni a lo lati fi se atupale ihun ati ilo awon orin eebu ti a ko jo.Ihun orin eebu fi han pe orin kuukuukuu ti ki I ju ewi oni-gbolohun merin tabi marun-un lo ni. Nibi ti a ba ti ri orin ti o ju ewi onigbolohun marun-un akoko ni. Bakan naa ni a tun ri I pe awitunwi je abuda Pataki fun orin eebu; eyi si n je ki eto iwohun orin dogba. Sociology and Anthropology|Odebiyi, A.I.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Sociology and Anthropology|1995|||OAU|||||ix, 107p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Guinea worm disease has been recognized as a major public health problem in Nigeria. The government has been concerned with its eradication. But before an effective eradication can be achieved, there is need for information on people's perception, beliefs and practices about the disease, The study examined the knowledge, attitude and practices relevant to guinea worm disease and its socio-economic costs in The rural areas of Aramoko, Ekiti.The study was undertaken between mid March to April ending 1995. Using multistage sampling technique, a total of 220 respondents were selected. Only 162 cooperated and completed the questionnaires. Thirteen patients were also interviewed to determine the socio-economic costs of the disease. Two traditional and two western orthodox health service providers were interviewed on the mode of management. The research instruments were semi-structured questionnaires, and in-depth interview schedules. Data obtained were mainly qualitative. The quantitative data from the semi-structure questionnaires were analysed using simple percentages. The qualitative data were analysed using sample categorization of responses and some interesting responses were quoted in the tent.The study showed that the people in the community tended to perceive guinea worm disease within the preternatural and supernatural realms and consequently the traditional healers were preferred for its management than the western orthodox practitioners. Also it was observed that the socio-economic cost of the disease tended to vary with the types of jobs that patients engaged in. It was particularly high among the farmers as they could not go to the farm at all during the illness episodes. Another major finding was that people in these rural areas rely mainly on water from streams and wells since the taps were not functioning.Recommendations emanating from the findings are: (i) the need for health education and (ii) the need to provide portable water to the rural areas.|Theses collection|Guinea worm disease/public health problem/orthodox health service.*||||||Omobuwajo, Olarenwaju rita-marie|F|Heartwood constituents of pcynanthus anglolensis welw and baphia nitida lodd||||||Ph.D. Pharmacognosy|Adesanya, S.A.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Pharmacognosy|1995|||OAU|||||xii, 125p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The resistance to insect attack, microbial degradation and other inherent tensile strength has made woods of principal interest to artisans. These tropical woods are fast disappearing due to indiscriminate cropping. This poses a potential danger in forestry and to those heartwoods known to have ethnomedicinal uses. One of the uses of certain types of wood is as chewing sticks. Earlier investigations have shown that such sticks possess antimicrobial properties. This work extends such investigation to the woods of Baphia nitida Lodd and Pcynanthus angolensis Welw. used locally as chewing sticks. These woods were extracted with organic solvents and, after establishing antimicrobial, activity in the extracts, were fractionated using column chromatography respectively. The fractions were purified using a combination of chromatographic techniques to give pure compounds some of which were identified and characterised on the basis of their mass, nmr and uv spectroscopic data. Out of eleven compounds isolated from P.angolensis, three were characterised as - sitosterol, 2'-hydroxyformononetin and a novel isoflavone 7, 4'-dimethoxy 2'- hydroxyisoflavone. Fourteen compounds were isolated from B. nitida out of which three were identified as -sitosterol, sativan, medicarpin and a fourth partially characterised as an isoflavene. Antimicrobial assay of some of the isolated compounds showed no appreciable activity for -sitosterol and other compounds from P angolensis except 2'-hydroxyformononetin and 7, 4'-dimethoxy 2'-hydroxyisoflavone. The former was active against Escherichia coli (NCTC I 0418) and Aspergillus niger at 360g/ml respectively while the latter was active against the same organisms at 360 and 350 g/ml respectively. In conclusion, further work will be required to isolate other active compounds that are present in minute quantities in both plants. |Theses collection|insect attack/microbial degradation/tensile strength/artisans/heartwoods/ethnomedicinal/chewing sticks/antimicrobial/chromatography/spectroscopic data/novel isoflavone.*||||||Olufajo, Arinpe Gbekelolu|M|Isefe ninu asayan ere-onitan apileko yoruba||||||Ph.D. Yoruba|Ilesanmi, T.N.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Afican Languages and literature|1995|||OAU|||||xii, 231p|||||||Yoruba||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This thesis examined the forms of satire (Efe) in Yoruba society. It analysed the forms of satire in some selected Yoruba written plays relating to eligious leaders and followers and the evils perpetrated religious ome families and political leaders.The methodology employed for the study included oral interviews on the definition and functions of the concept of satire. A review of relevant literature on satire and humor in general was carried out. Finally, the theoretical framework for analysis of the texts was a blend of the cultural and Marxist approaches to the study of literature.Taking cognizance of the forms of satire, the thesis discovered that Yoruba written plays could be generally classified into two: one , pure Satirical plays (ere-onitan plays that make mere allusion to satirical sketches in their  oncepts.The thesis also discovered that the term Efe (satire) is interchargeably used in place of other of humor like par (jokes), Awada forms Awada (jest) and (Ridicule). Thus, the thesis observed that though a sharp distinction could not be made between these forms, the aim of satire distinguished it from the others. Its aim is to bring a positive change to the society by ridiculing the fools and the  vices in a deviant. It was also discovered that satire failed to achieve its surpossed aim in modern Yoruba society due to misplaced priorities in the societal value.The thesis concluded that the major source of the satire found in the analysed texts is 'oppression" which permiates the society at large. It occurred at all level of human interaction and this is to an abuse of the political, religious or domestic position occupied by the victims of satire|Theses collection|Satire (Efe)/Yoruba society/literature/cultural/plays.*||||||Olowere, Modupe Fisayo|F|Plasma thyrotropin, thyroxine and tri-jodothyronine levels in hypertensive pregnant nigerian women||||||M.Sc. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Plasma thyrotropin (TSH) and tetra-iodothyronine (T4) levels were detertmined by enzyme-linked Immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and plasma tri-iodothyronine (T3) levels by radioimmuno assay (RIA) in ten (10) randomly selected hypertensive pregnant Nigerian women in the second and third respectively and in five (5) hypertensive Nigerian women 5 days post partum. All the subjects were between 20 and 30 years of age. Ten (10) healthy normotensive pregnant Nigerian women and five (5) normotensive partum matched for age, parity and stage of pregnancy served as controls. The mean plasma T4 levels for hypertensive pregnant Women in the second and third trimesters and 5 days post partum of 127  66.35, 181  62.27 and 148.7  71.45 nmol/litre respectively were each significantly (P<0.05) higher than 104  30.6, 120  29.12 and 99.2  7.29  nmol/litre for their normotensive counterparts. The third trimester result for plasma T4 levels in each category of women was Significantly higher than that of the second trimester.  The ANOVA results confirm that with respect to plasma T4 levels the pregnancy whether hypertensive or normotensive is stage dependent. The second trimester plasma T3 levels of 2.7  0.26 nmol/Litre for hypertensive women was significantly higher than 2.10  0.25 nmol/Litre for their normotensive counterparts. No other significant difference was observed. Plasma TSH values were within normal range throughout this study, but the third trimester value of 3.4  0.51 mU/l for normotensive women was lower than the post partum result of 3.68  0.75 mU/l but the difference lacked significance. It is concluded that the plasma T4 levels are stage dependent in both categories of pregnancy. There seems to be an association between raised T4 levels and hypertension in pregnancy. More work needs to be done to ascertain the cause of the significant rise in plasma T4 in hypertensive pregnancy particularly from the point of view of a cause and effect relationship. |Theses collection|Plasma thyrotropin (TSH)/tetra-iodothyronine (T4)/Immunosorbent assay (ELISA)/plasma tri-iodothyronine (T3)/radioimmuno assay (RIA)/trimesters/ANOVA/normotensive/hypertension*||||||Olowe, Joshua Hanson Oluadare|M|Language and ideology in nigerian newspapers in the mesium of english||||||Ph.D. English|Aremo, B.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, English|1995|||OAU|||||x, 264p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This thesis examined the interplay of language and ideology in Nigerian English-medium newspapers. It investigated how various English structures and lexical items are used by these newspapers in projecting various socio-politically determined shades of opinions and beliefs within the society. The study focused specifically on editorials as the areas where the various ideologies are most clearly established and the stances the newspapers take towards issues and events most readily discernible. The data for the study were selected editorial texts from the Daily Times, The Guardian the Nigerian Tribune and the New Nigerian. The subjects of the selected editorials were on the nationally important issues of religion, labour relations and politics. As a result, the various ideologies that threw up the editorials were such that cut across diverse interests and institutions within the Nigerian polity. The thesis employed the methods of critical linguistics. Thus, it involved identifying the significant structures and lexical items in the editorials and examining their use and functions against the background of relevant ideologies. The analysis involved examining the editorial texts sentence by sentence in order to give the imbrication of language and ideology adequate attention.  From the analysis, it was clear that in projecting their various ideological viewpoints, Nigerian English-medium newspapers employ various linguistic devices all of which involve careful and methodical manipulation of structures and items within the English Language. It was found that among the most widely used of these linguistic devices are thematization, passivisation and nominalization. The choice of intensive/extensive constructions and varying arrangements of the main and subordinate clauses within the complex sentence structure were found to be among the very potent mean of showing ideological learning. The analysis revealed the pervasive use of lexical items (often emotively charged) as textual nodes for contriving ideological insinuations. |Theses collection|Nigerian English-medium newspapers/language and ideology/thematization, passivisation and nominalization. *||||||Olatubara, Charles Olufisayo|M|Activity patterns and urban residential location decision in ibadan, oyo state||||||Ph.D. Geography|Ogunjumo, E.A.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Geography|1995|||OAU|||||xvi, 161p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|One of the problems confronting the urban residents relates to how to operate in the face of the complexities of the urban environment. The search for an optimum residential location has been a source of chronic problem to the urban dwellers. Transportation problems of workers and other residents in lbadan including traffic congestion, reduction in the number of public transport vehicles and increasing commuting cost, further tend to increase the difficulty of getting easy access to activity nodes patronized by households. Sub-optimal residential locations of households in relation to the distribution of urban activity nodes tend to increase the cost and time budgets of households in addition to other socio-psychological problems. Some households, however, have constrained choice in which households simply occupy existing vacancies. The research approaches the issue from the standpoint of activity distribution of households and how such distributions affect their residential location decisions. Ibadan has been used as the study area for this work. Seven hundred and thirty six (736) household heads provided the basic data for this study. A network of grids was superimposed on an updated map of Ibadan and a systematic sampling of a residential building in every other grid intersection was carried out across the city. Several simple and multivariate techniques were used to analyse the data. The study revealed some departures from existing propositions of earlier research efforts. It was discovered that households did not necessarily choose their residential locations in relation to the city centre used in this study. Households appeared to show a tendency towards proximity to their activity centres. This is reflected across the urban space irrespective of such locations in relation to the city centre. Some households also showed a tendency to change residential locations when the activity centres patronized by such households appeared to be inconvenient. Others, however, failed to change their residential locations even when some factors should ordinarily make them change residences. Based on these findings, it is recommended that household units and their activity patterns be adopted in a neighbourhood approach to facility planning and location. A modification is also proposed in the use of this concept for urban landuse planning.|Theses collection|Urban residents/traffic congestion/public transport vehicles/socio-psychological problems.*||||||Olaluwoye, Olaniyi Olakanye|M|Ferminist aesthetics in selected works of buchi emecheta||||||M.A. Literature in English|Kolawole, M.E.M||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,  English|1995|||OAU|||||vii, 96p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|A number of accomplished writers mainly women who are feminist inclined find it difficult to accept openly that they are feminists. Among such writers is Buchi Emecheta. Therefore, the thesis aimed at studying and analysing the works of Buchi Emecheta within the concept of feminism to determine how much she portrayed feminist consciousness. It also aimed at assessing the unique feminine perspective, themes and images of women in her works and evaluating them within the framework of a woman as a spokesperson for her gender vis-a-vis the existing male depictions of womanhood. The methodology used involved a theoretical approach, which examined the concept of feminism and then related it to the works of Buchi Emecheta. To achieve this, a critical examination of four selected novels from her works was undertaken. The feminist characteristics in the works were identified with specific reference to the themes, characters, characterization and ideological tools. In addition, references were made to Emechetas claim by citing critical comments and interviews on her works. The work concluded that literature by women provide insight into female experiences and also challenged male chauvinism. It established Buchi Emecheta as a feminist writer whose works proved that, contrary to the complacent image of women presented by some African male writers, women are fulfilled human beings who know what they want and how to get it. She is a feminist who successfully probed deeply into the female psyche in a patriarchal society where women are expected to be seen but not heard. Buchi Emecheta achieved the above image of women through her multi-dimensional characterization, decked with irony. |Theses collection|Writers/feminist/Buchi Emecheta/womanhood/chauvinism.*||||||Oladunni, Olufemi Ajayi|M|Analysis of resourse-use effiiency in tobacco-food crops farming system of oyo state, nigeria||||||Ph.D. Agricultural Economics|Oni, S.A. // Fabiyi, Y.L.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,  Agricultural Economics|1995|||OAU|||||xvii, 166p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This study examines the efficiency of resource-use in a Tobacco-Foodcrop farming system of Oyo State. To do this, the primary data for the study were collected from tobacco and non-tobacco farmers through a multi-stage stratified random sampling technique based on farm size and the farming system. Cross-sectional data were collected to include the input and output rat and other socio- economic variables that affect directly or indirectly the output of the agricultural enterprise. The data were analyzed using the production function and budgetary analysis techniques. The Corrected Ordinary Least Square (COLS) method was used to determine the closeness of the to the production frontier zone. The result revealed that a typical tobacco farmer devoted an average of 4.47 hectares to tobacco and 4.62 hectares to foodcrops. This shows that while the tobacco farmers pursue the goal of satisfying their cash requirements in the cultivation of tobacco, the goal of food self sufficiency was not left behind. The food-crops produced include yam, cassava, maize, sorghum and vegetable crops. The result also revealed that the returns to management by the non-tobacco farmers was =N=1107.38 per hectare of farmland cultivated while tobacco farmers made =N=5412.82 as returns to management. This shows that it is more profitable to combine a cashcrop, in this case tobacco, with other foodcrops than to cultivate only foodcrops. Also, a small scale farmer had as much as =N=5,815.25 per hectare as returns to management compared with a large-scale farmer of =N=4833.34 per hectare of cultivated farmland. In terms of efficiency of resource-use, it was observed that most of the resources were over-utilised since their marginal value products (MVP) were less than their respective factor costs. The extent of this was more among non-tobacco farmers and the large-scale farmers. Therefore, profits can be enhanced by making necessary adjustments in the present levels of resource-use given the prevailing price conditions and the levels of the stock of the resources. The technical efficiency ratios revealed that the non- tobacco farmers had an average of 49 percent while the tobacco farmers had 58 percent. It was found out that the technical efficiency of the tobacco farmers was significantly greater than that of the non-tobacco farmers. Also, the technical efficiency ratios show that small- scale farmers were more technically efficient in resource utilisation than the large-scale farmers. |Theses collection|Tabacco-foodcrop farming system/cashcrop/small scale farmer.*||||||Olajide, Yetunde Folashade|F|Effects of the seepage of some agrochemicals on cichid and clarid fishes inhabiting the obafemi awolowo university teaching hospital and research farm behaviour||||||M.Sc. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The influence of some agrochemicals on the abundance and fillet composition of the cichlid and clariid fishes inhabiting the Obafemi Awolowo University Teaching and Research farm reservoir were monitored between October, 1993 and March, 1994. During the period of study, structured questionnaires were administered to the head of the various units in the Teaching and Research farm to obtain information on the type of agrochemicals in use on the farm.Water and fish samples were also collected fortnightly from the reservoir. Physico-chemical parameters of water monitored during the-period include the pH, dissolved oxygen, biochemical oxygen demand, alkalinity and total hardness. The ionic component of water samples and fish fillet collected during the period was also monitored. The proximate composition of the fish fillet as well as that of the stomach content samples were also analysed during the period.Investigation revealed that during the last five years, twenty-one agrochemicals broadly classified into four groups had been in use in the various units on the Teaching and Research farm. The agrochemicals included two fungicides, eleven herbicides, four insecticides and four fertilizers. The questionnaires however showed that the potential for pollution is minimal due to the minimal and irregular usage of these agrochemicals on the farm.Analyses of the physico-chemical parameters of the water samples showed that the water collected from the two sampling sites were more or less homogenous and very poor in nutrient. Sodium, potassium, calcium and magnesium were the major cations in the water body while ammonium, sulphate, nitrate, chloride and silicate were the major anions. (Trewavas Orechomis), niloticus (Trewavas) and Tilapia zillii (Gervais) were the members of the family Cichlidae caught, in the reservoir during the period of study. Only one member of the family Clariid (Burchell) was caught during the same period. The study revealed the preponderance Sarotherodon galilaeus specimens over all the other fish species in the reservoir.The abundance of fry observed during the period of study showed that fish species were thriving in the reservoir. This indicates that the prevailing chemical composition of the reservoir could apparently tolerated by the fishes inhabiting the water body.|Theses collection|Agrochemicals/dissolved oxygen/biochemical oxygen demand/pollution/farm/homogenous/fertilizer/reservoir/fish/waterbody*||||||Okunlola, Isaiah Adebayo|M|Interpretation of seismic reflection data over upomami oilfield, Niger Delta||||||M.Sc. Applied Geophysics|Oloruninwo, M.A.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Geology|1995|||OAU|||||xiv, 142|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Eleven seismic sections and a suite of borehole logs from Upomami oil field, Niger Delta, Nigeria have been studied for the delineation of the general subsurface geological structures and possible hydrocarbon accumulation in the area.  Four faults and four seismic horizons at depths of 1300m, 1800m, 2200m and 2900m were picked. The seismic horizons divide the study area into five layers. Layer -1 is Benin formation. Layers - 2, -3 and -4 fall within Agbada Formation while layer -5 corresponds to the Akata Formation. Layer -1 has a thickness of 1300m and interval velocity ranging from 1965m/s to 2090m/s. Layer -2 has a thickness range of 400m to 610m and an interval velocity ranging from 2365m/s to 2748m/s. Layer -3 posseses a thickness of between 320m to 570m with an interval velocity of 2503m/s to 3232m/s. This layer constitutes the hydrocarbon reservoir in the study area. The thickness of layer -4 varies from 375m to-750m and its interval velocity ranges from 2567m/s to 3348m/s. Layer-5 extends from a depth of about 2900m downwards. Qualitative interpretation of the induction electrical logs revealed the presence of hydrocarbon in eight separate sands intercalating with shales within the reservoir. Quantitative interpretation of the reservoir zone showed that shale content varies from 1% to 47%, porosity ranges from 17% to 21% while the hydrocarbon saturation ranges from 70% to 95%. The hydrocarbon moveability index ranges from 0.14 to 0.68 implying that the reservoir contain movable hydrocarbon. Seismic velocity - porosity - shale content mathematical relations were generated and used to predict the porosity and shale content distribution of the reservoir. The produced porosity and shale content maps revealed that porosity varies from 15% to 21% while shale content by volume ranges from 3% to 31% in the reservoir.The Isochron map of the reservoir revealed a rollover anticlinal structure while the isopach map revealed a southwestern dip of the reservoir respectively. The interval velocity, wave slowness and fluid velocity maps were used to describe the reservoir variability and to delimit the hydrocarbon bearing zones in the area. On the basis of this study, zones with interval  shaleanging from 2750m/s to 2900m/s, wave slowness of between 350s/m and 370s/m and fluid velocity ranging from 1300m/s to 1600m/s have been designated as hydrocarbon bearing zones. The results of the interval velocity, wave slowness and fluid velocity maps have good agreement. The hydrocarbon reserve estimate in the area was found to be 3.93x108m3. Two wells have been recommended for drilling in the delineated hydrocarbon bearing zones in the study area. |Theses collection| seismic sections/borehole logs/ hydrocarbon/reservoir/shale/*||||||Yesufu, Thomas Kokumo|M|Development of a novel technique in the implementation of cryptographic systems||||||M.Sc. Electronic and Electrical Engineering|Ajayi, G.O.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Electronic and Electrical Engineering|1994 |||OAU|||||xiii, 79p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng|||| I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Cryptography, which is the privacy transformation of data while in transit to ensure its proper use, requires chaotic keys to be ideal. This work presents a new technique which employs the knowledge of chaos in generating the key used in the implementation of an unconditionally and provably secure cryptographic system.A known analog chaotic circuit from the Chua's Circuit Family (CCF) was chosen and its digital hardware implementation carried out to serve as a cryptographic key generator. A secure transmission of a 16kbps data using the cryptographic system was carried out. In addition, a computer simulation of the system was carried out.It was found that only two out of the four devices in the analog chaotic circuit used are necessary for the key generation. The digital hardware implementation of the system shows that the key, which is both transportable and reproducible, can be readily deleted or changed as the need arises. The timing diagram of the system shows that, at a clock rate of 128kHz, the bit rate of the key is 16kbps. The performance evaluation of the system shows that there is a marked difference between the encrypted data and the original data due to the chaotic nature of the Lissajous figure obtained from both. Moreover, the statistical tests on the cryptographic key stream shows that it is uniformly distributed and chaotic. It is, therefore envisaged that this technique will bring about the easy application of chaos in the implementation of cryptographic systems for a modern communications environment.|Theses Collection|analog chaotic circuit/digital hardware implementation/timing diagram/ modern communications environment*||||||Evoh, Chijioke Josiah|M|International politics of environmental protection||||||M.Sc., International relations|Oyesola, O.P.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, International Relations|1994 |||OAU|||||vii, 225p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. In specific terms therefore, this study focuses on the dynamics of the contemporary international economic order and its effect on the global environment.The findings of this work reveal that there is indeed a lobal awareness of the inherent linkages between the economic status of a nation and environmental contradictions. However, the countries of the North who perpetuate and dominate the global ystem lack the political will to adopt requisite economic trategies to Corroborates the fact that a fundamental restructuring of the existing, imbalances in the international economic frameworks which, currently places considerable environmental burden on the developing countries, is a prerequisite for the security of the earth's environment. Law|Oretuyi, S.A.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Law|1994|||OAU|||||lvi, 835p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng|||| I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This study aimed at examining the role of the courts in the governance of Nigeria in historical perspective identifying the underlying theoretical and philosophical underpinnings, analysing the trends and perspectives in the courts' interpretative attitude and evaluating the emerging trend towards a truly Nigerian Constitutional jurisprudence.The primary information for the study were derived from reported and unreported judicial decisions and statutory and constitutional provisions in the select n of judicial decisions, the study adopted a holistic approach. while emphasis was placed on decisions of the Supreme Court as the highest court of the land, attention was also focussed on the lower courts since judicial law-making is an activity in which these courts can also lay claim to have participated, This gives a comprehensive picture of the role of the courts in governance. The judicial decisions were examined in the context of the relevant constitutional and statutory provisions. Books and articles on the courts and general comments on judicial performance constitute the secondary source of information.The study revealed that although in pre-colonial "Nigeria", there was no judicial review of governmental action, as we understand it today, there was some form of constitutionalism. with the advent of the colonial power, English-type legal system was imported into Nigeria, as a potent instrument of consolidating and legitimising colonial rule. As was to be expected,it was difficult under the new dispensation to question the exercise of governmental power in court. The courts, were, however, occasionally assertive in the exercise of their power against the executive.Judicial review is now well established in the country. However, there is as yet no coherent theory of evaluation of the judicial role. The study argued that judicial decision-making is a judicial and a political act and that the Constitution is a legal as well as a political document. These facts were apparently not lost on the Nigerian courts as their liberal approach to constitutional interpretation clearly demonstrates. The same liberalism permeates their attitude to the procedural and factual elements of constitutional adjudication. As shown in chapter seven, they have not allowed technicalities of law to defeat the end of justice, A similar streak of liberalism is discernible in their application of the law of remedies.Under the military administrations while some judges have meekly succumbed to ouster clauses in some decrees, others have insisted that they can inquire into whetherthere had been compliance by executive acts with the provisions of enabling decrees, especially where the liberty of the individual is concernedThe conclusion showed that the supreme Court is gradually but steadily charting the course of a truly Nigerian Constitutional jurisprudence, This is evident in the court's disposition to decide 'hard cases' debito justiciae and interpret the constitution in the light of the peculiar realities of the Nigerian situation The need to consolidate this trend and make the legal process serve the interest of the common man were seen as the greatest challenge now facing the judiciary of constitutionalism. with the advent of the colonial power, English-type legal system was imported into Nigeria, as a potent instrument of consolidating and legitimising colonial rule. As was to be expected, it was difficult under the new dispensation to question the exercise of governmental power in court. The courts, were, however, occasionally assertive in the exercise of their power against the executive. Judicial review is now well established in the country. However, there is as yet no coherent theory of evaluation of the judicial role. The study argued that judicial decision-making is a judicial and a political act and that the Constitution is a legal as well as a political document. These facts were apparently not lost on the Nigerian courts as their liberal approach to constitutional interpretation clearly demonstrates. The same liberalism permeates their attitude to the procedural and factual elements of constitutional adjudication. As shown in chapter seven, they have not allowed technicalities of law to defeat the end of justice, A similar streak of liberalism is discernible in their application of the law of remedies. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng|||| I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Protein energy malnutrition of infants is one of the major nutritional problems in the developing world, this is mostly attributed to diets which have low levels of protein and energy. Plant protein sources have been found attractive both in cost and availability. The process of germination has been shown to improve the nutrient characteristics of grains, consequently, it was applied in this study to develop a weaning food with low water holding capacity, low viscosity and increased nutrient density.Experiments were conducted to formulate a weaning food from germinated grains. Germination of period of 72 and 48 hours were applied for the cereals and legume respectively. The germinated grains were dried at a temperature not exceeding 45C, milled and formulated as follows - corn (60%), rice (20%), soybean (15%) and defatted sesame (5%). Defatted sesame flour was added to supply methionine and cystein. The product was evaluated for proximate composition, physico-chemical properties, animal feeding trials and amino acid analysis. The data obtained were compared with those of cerelac and nutrend as control diets.The protein, fat, ash and carbohydrate contents of the germinated diet were 17.00%%, 8.45%, 1.63% and 66.81% respectively. The diet was not significantly different (P>7 0.05) from the controls in terms of physico-chemical properties, such as water holding capacity, swelling capacity and viscosity but significantly different (P<0.05) from the ungerminated diet. The bioassay parameters; protein efficiency ratio (PER) and net protein ratio (NPR) were not significantly different (P > 0.05) from those of the control diets. However, the essential amino acid level of the germinated diet was found to be superior to that of the ungerminated diet.The results from this study have shown that germination of grains offer a good potential in the formulation of weaning foods and will go a long way in helping towards the eradication of protein energy malnutrition in infants.|Theses Collection|germination/malnutrition/methionine/nutrients/protein efficiency ratio (PER)  *||||||Olojo, Oluwarotimi Odunayo|M|Studies on aquation of some haklopentacy anocobaltate (III) complexes and their reductons by titanium(III) in acidic aqueous media.||||||M.Sc., Chemistry|Ojo, J.F.// Olubuyide,O.A.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Chemistry|1994|||OAU|||||xv, 111p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng|||| I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|There is a conceptual relationship between squatter settlements and the regional development policies of the Third World countries. The concentration of these nations' economic activities anti infrastructure amenities in few cities resulted in the rapid urbanisation and unprecedented immigration of these areas with the attendant social ills such as lack of housing for the migrants.The Nigerian government. respond to arrest the housing crisis by implementing several housing programmes but without at the same time tackling rural poverty and neglect which are the causes of migrations. These strategies have failed to curb housing shortages because of their comprehensive "top-downsupply-driven nature.But, while the official responses failed dismally, the urban poor have attempted to resolve the housing problems by establishing their own shelter and.settlements on the fringes of the burgeoning cities, The housing conditions of these areas, like the, slums, are deplorable due to the fear of eviction and the temporary nature of tenure. Against: this backdrop, what is needed is to examine carefully this resourcefulness and the problems inhibiting the improvement of these areas and improve on this housing initiative. This will improve the welfare of the residents end national housing stock at minimum costs.Mkpologwu, a squatter settlement in Enugu, has been carefully chosen for this case study, which is based on the author's original data, The objectives of the study are to access the pausing needs and the housing and environmental. conditions of the residents and to suggest policy recommendation  to improve its conditions among others. To achieve these, secondary data were collected from some relevant authorities like Town Planning, survery and Lands Divisions among others. For ease of analysis, the coded systematic random sampling was applied to administer questionaires  to 353 household heads out of the estimated 521 households.The findings were analysed  and second, statistically using bivariate and multivariate techniques. Results are also shown on tables, graphs and plates.The findings of the study are typical of the case than general, but there is,every reason to suggest that the issues involved are more national than Local. Amongst the findings ere that immigation is caused by rural neglect and poverty; national housing policies have been to the disfavour of the urban poor;  squatter settlements are the outcome of housing shortages for the urban migrants; and poor housing conditions of squatter areas areamenable to upgrading programmes.Policy recommendations have been tailored to reflect these observations. These are two sets - micro and macro. The first set deals with the strategies to ameliorate the housing conditions of Mkpologwu while the second are meant to effect institutional changes in the national development and housing strategies. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng|||| I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The study investigated the methods by which the people of Ife (in South Western Nigeria) convey sympathy to the bereaved and the most effective period for doing so.From a pilot study undertaken, 17 modes of conveying sympathy were obtained and these were incorporated into the final questionnaire used for the Research. A total of 220 subjects consisting of widows, widowers, divorced and remarried people from the six quarters in Ile-Ife constituted the subjects for the study. They were selected by stratified random sampling. Data was collected for the study using a questionnaire incorporating the outcome of the pilot study and an interview schedule administered over a period of two weeks. The collected data was analysed using percentages.The result of the analyses showed that the most effective sympathy modes are: the giving of relief materials such as food (61.2), staying with and attending to the needs of the bereaved (57.0%), taking care of the children left behind by the deceased (57.0), and visitation to give words of encouragement (54.5%)While the least effective are: Weeping and wailing (12.7%), dressing in black (14.5%) and reciting the elegy of the deceased (20.0%). Further, it was found that the first seven days was the most effective period for conveying sympathy after bereavement. In addition, women were found to encounter more excruciating cultural and social constraints than men in the expression of grief. From the findings of the study, it appears that the establishment of helping centres in the difference communities would be helpful.|Theses Collection|Widows/widowers/divorced/bereaved/elegy/  *||||||Buhari, Jimoh Owolabi|M|Conguence of Holland's typology theory with six selected occupational groups in Nigeria||||||M.A.Ed., Guidance and Counselling|Afolabi, E.R.I.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Educaional Foundations and Counselling|1994|||OAU|||||xii, 89p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng|||| I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Large reserves of naturally occuring petroleum liquid condensate exist in Nigeria's oil fields. This work attempts to separate benzene, toluene, xylene (BTX), which are important feedstocks of the petrochemical industry, present in these condensates. Petroleum liquid condensate from Mobil's Inim 8B well, light naphtha, heavy naphtha and fluid catalytic cracking unit (F.C.C.U) effluent were fractionated in a sieve plate column into four fractions. The cuts were in the temperature ranges of 0C-60C, 60C-80C, 80C-120C and >120C (bottoms). The fractions were then subjected to the Fluorescent Indicator Adsorption (F.I.A) analysis to determine the relative percent aromatics in each of the cuts. The F.I.A analysis result for the 80C-120C cut, which constitute the BTX 'heartcut' gave percent aromatics of 9.45, 9.05, 23.37 and 52.05 for the liquid. condensate, light naphtha, heavy naphtha and F.C.C.0 effluent respectively.The only fraction (80C-120C) of the liquid condensate containing all the required components, benzene, toluene and xylene, was used in the separation of BTX by the adsorption-desorption process. Two adsorbent types - silica gel and activated magnesium silicate, and three groups of solvents - alkyl halides, alcohols and a nitrile compound, were employed as desorbents. The combination of silica gel -trichloromethane was found to be effective for BTX separation in the 80C - 120C cut of the liquid condensate. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng|||| I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Twenty eight seismic sections and a suite of geophysical well logs from Ekokor field of Niger delta have been interpreted to delineate the subsurface geology and structures associated with hydrocarbon accumulation in the study area. A total of five faults and four seismic horizons at depth of 1700m, 2650m, 3200m and 3500m respectively were picked.These horizons divide the study area into five different layers.The isodepth maps of layers 1,2,3 and 4 show a general increase in thickness from North to South in the study area. The isodepth and isochron maps show Monoclinal structure in the upper part of the study area to a depth of 2700m. Below this depth a hanging wall structure which traps hydrocarbon was delineated. The isovelocity maps were used to describe the velocity distribution and also to delimit the hydrocarbon zone in the area.The qualitative interpretation of the lithologic logs (Gamma-Ray and SP) and the electrical resistivity logs (short normal and induction) revealed five broad zones designated as zones A,B,C,D and E for the two wells (well 1 and well 1-S). A sixth additional zone designated F occurs in well 1 - S. It has been noted that the corresponding zones in both wells have the same characteristics. Zone A lies between 1750m and 2050m in well 1, and 1640m and 2060m in well 1-S. It consists of an intercalation of shale and sand and is water bearing. Zone B lies between 2120m and 2480m in well 1, and 2100m and 2500m in well 1 - S. Zone B is sand. The sands contain water. Zone C is between 2750m and 3050m in well 1, and 2550m and 3000m in well 1 - S.The zone is Shaly sand. It is water bearing. Zone D lies between a depth of 3120m and 3450m in well 1, and 310Om and 336Om in well 1 - S. The  zone is shale. It acts as cap for zone E. Zone E is between 35OOm and 3690m in well 1, and 354Om and 36OOm in well 1 - S. The Zone is sandy shale. The sand is hydrocarbon-bearing. Zone F is between 3625m3690m and exists in well 1 - S only. The Zone is an interbed of sand and shale. The sand contains hydrocarbon.Furthermore, the results of compaction studies showed that action varies with mean depth in the area. The wave slowness of the ineated reservoir showed that low values wave slowness between 240- 290 us/m can be interpreted as representing non-porous and therefore compacted zones while zones with high value wave slowness between 300 and 340 us/m represent porous and therefore non-compacted .The trend obtained from compaction curves provided information e overpressure zones in the area. Correlation of the zones wereanalysed to produce a map of the ten of the overpressure zone in Ekokor .This map can be used to monitor the drilling blowout in the area structure recognised in the study area is a hanging wall closure is representative of the main trapping mechanism for hydrocarbon Niger delta and the basis of the results of  this study of Ekokor field, two appraisal wells has been recommended to be drilled in the western part the area. This will greatly enhance the hydrocarbon reservoir development of Ekokor field.|Theses Collection|Geophysical well log/hydrocarbon accumulation/isodepth/isovelocity/lithologic logs/electrical resistivity logs/  *||||||Olaniyan, Adeniyi Oluwasegun|M|Quality of groundwater in the basement complex area in Oyo and Afijio local government areas of Oyo state.||||||M.Sc., Applied Geology|Adediran, S.A.// Adeniyi, I.F.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,Applied Geology|1994|||OAU|||||xii,131p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng|||| I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The study was carried out to provide a baseline information on the physico-chemical quality of groundwater in Oyo and Afijio Local Government Areas of Oyo State in relation to the underlying bedrocks. Geological mapping of the study area was undertaken in order to determine the main rock types. Water samples were collected from hand dug wells, boreholes and surface waters in seven localities and were analysed in the laboratory for their chemical constituents. The results obtained from the determination of the physico-chemical parameters were subjected to various statistical tests and plots. This was to test and attempt to explain the spatia-temporal variations in water quality parameters in relation to the bedrock types.The results of ANOVA among groundwater quality samples on the different bedrock units showed that most of the values were not significantly different among the parameters considered for the two seasons investigated. Except for the physical parameters of wells, colour, chloride and silica, all the other parameters were not significantly different. The differences between some of the groundwater quality and surface water quality samples were found to be significant using the student `t' test. The following parameters shows significant differences between the two types of water considered: colour, dissolved solids, total solids, total hardness, calcium, sodium, silica, nitrate and iron at P< 0.001 confidence level while the other parameters were not significant. The same test on the two sets of samples during rain and dry seasons shows that only manganese is significantly different at 0.01 confidence level while the other parameters show no significant difference. The overall mean nitrate level of (0.42  0.46) mg/1 and mean sulphate and chloride level (21.7  16.2) mg/l, (56.2  41.6) mg/1 respectively indicate that the groundwater in the area of study to be wholesome and potable due to the relatively low concentrations of chlorides, sulphates, and nitrates in almost all the entire groundwater samples. The correlation coefficients revealed a positive relationship between most of the ions analysed for. The highest `r' value of 0.8211 was between magnesium and conductivity while the lowest `r' value of 0.0331 was between sodium and nitrate.The study reflects a fairly distinct pattern between water quality and the bedrock geology. However, the statistical tests seem to provide better correlation between groundwater quality and bedrock types than chemical plots irrespective of anthropogenic influences. It is thus recommended that geochemical analysis of the overburden could be carried out to obtain a better correlation between water quality and the underlying bedrock geology.|Theses Collection|physico-chemical quality/Geological mapping / ANOVA*||||||Imasogie, Benjamin Iyalekhuosa|M|Development and cahracterisation of isothermally heat-trreated nodular cast irons||||||PhD., Met. and Matls. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng|||| I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|An investigation has been carried out to determine the suitability, nodulizing potency and optimum concentration requirements, of calcium, Ca/Mg-based masteralloy, CaSi-CaF2, and magnesium, respectively, as nodulizers in irons produced under the same casting conditions and base materials. An attempt was made to establish optimum heat-treatment parameters for the improvement in mechanical properties of the irons produced.Different numerical indicators have been used to assess the graphite spheroidization rating of these alloys, and to aid a visual perception of the graphite morphologies, SEM studies on deep-etched specimens were carried out. The microstructural and mechanical properties of ferritic, ferritic-pearlitic, pearlitic and bainitic grades of these irons were characterized and compared.The results obtained indicate that up to 92% nodularity could be obtained by using calcium based compounds, compared with 95% for Ca-Mg mixture and 97% using magnesium-ferrosilicon. Their as-cast mechanical properties were also comparable. It was established that, compared to magnesium, calcium-treated nodular irons show little or no susceptibility to chilling and formation of secondary phases such as phosphide eutectic and lediburite. The irons produced displayed good  response to the different applied heat-treatment schedules, asevidenced from their microstructures and mechanical properties, resulting thereof.
