O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng|||| I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The study presents an empirical evaluation of the performance of United Bank for Africa Credit Scheme For Rural Women in Ondo, Osun and Oyo States of Nigeria. The objectives of the study includes a determination of the loans given in terms of geographical spread, group and individual; an assessment of the impact of the scheme on income, savings and expenditure of rural women; and a comparison of the rates of loan repayment among beneficiaries in the three states. Others objectives include analysis of factors influencing loan repayment under the scheme, and the identification of the constraints facing the scheme in order to provide the framework for its improvement.The data used for this study were derived from primary and secondary sources. The primary data were obtained with the aid of structured questionnaire administered on 200 loan beneficiaries selected from Nine UBA branches in the states. (These include Akure, Oke-Igbo, Ilara-Mokin,; Ibadan Central, Molete, Oyo; Oyan Osu and Imesi-Ile). The respondents were chosen through a stratified random sampling technique in which loan types and Bank Branches were used as strata. The secondary data obtained from the bank's records contained information on Loans issued, repaid and interest charges. Analytical techniques employed include descriptive statistics and ordinary least squares regression method. A multiple regression model of varying polynomial degrees were used in estimating the determinants of loan repayment among beneficiaries. The analysis of credit granted under the scheme in the states showed that a total of 880 loans valued at N3.45m were received by beneficiaries for the period of 1988-1991. The scheme covered 72 Local Government Areas (LGAs) in the three states. Variations were observed in the determination of loan repayment in the surveyed states. The net income after credit use and number of years of formal education are major determinants of loan repayment in Ondo state. In Osun state the number of years of formal education, age of respondents and years of enterprise experience were entified as the major determinants of loan repayment whereas in Oyo state, net income after credit use and years of project experience were the major determinants of loan repayment. On the aggregate therefore the major loan repayment determinants identified were net income after credit use and age of beneficiaries. The empirical results of the loan repayment analysis showed that the scheme has not performed very well. The average rate of loan repayment was about 46% although there were slight variations among the states.The impact of the scheme on the living standards of beneficiaries was assessed by considering their savings, income and expenditure levels before and after loan acquisition. The results showed that the beneficiaries had substantial increase in the parameters examined. The most critical constraints confronting the scheme were high interest rates charged on loans and the rising cost of inputs. Remedial measures to mitigate the shortcomings of the scheme include interest rate reduction and provision of facilities to enhance loan recovery.|Theses Collection|empirical evaluation/ UBA/ Local Government Areas (LGAs) *||||||Oyedele, Victoria Iyabode|F|An analysis of investigative and confirmatory laboratory approaches to biology instruction in senior secondary schools.||||||M.A.Ed., Curriculum studies|Ehindero, O.J.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Curriculum Studies|1994|||OAU|||||xi,86p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng|||| I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|High incidences of bacterial resistance to commonly used antibiotics including ampicillin and tetracycline have been reported for organisms isolated in Ile-Ife and other Nigerian towns. Among factors that have been blamed for the selection of resistant strains are subinhibitory blood levels and significant amounts of antibiotic left unabsorbed in the gut. These factors may arise when products of poor bioavailability are used in the treatment of infections.Six samples of tetracycline and five of ampicillin capsules, all with a 250mg label claim, were purchased from hospitals, community pharmacies, patent medicine shops and road-side stalls in Ile-Ife. The capsules were subjected to tests for weight uniformity, microbiological assay, breakdown products and dissolution characteristics. Comparative bioavailability studies employing healthy male volunteer subjects were carried out in which samples obtained from manufacturers and, in the case of ampicillin, a solution served as reference standards. Bioavailability was estimated from urinary excretion data and statistical analysis of  bioavailability parameters was carried out by means of Wilcoxon's signed rank test and analysis of variance.All the tetracycline and four of the ampicillin capsule samples purchased in Ile-Ife were found to be of of sub-standard quality. This poor quality resulted in bioavailability problems in four of the eight products used in the comparative bioavailabillity study. There was significant correlation between data obtained in the bioavailability and dissolution tests for both antibiotics. Inter-individual variation was high with both drugs and statistically significant with tetracycline. The extent of absorption of tetracycline from capsules in four of the five test subjects was higher than that documented by-previous workers.The study revealed that ampicillin and tetracycline bioavailability problems are being routinely dispensed in Ile-Ife. The results show that there is urgent -need to enforce the regulatory control of drugs, especially antibiotics, in this environment.|Theses Collection|bacterial resistance/ weight uniformity/ microbiological assay/ breakdown products/ dissolution characteristics*||||||Olaogun, Kayode Abiola|M|An investigation of physico-chemical properties of some underexploited Nigerians Oilseeds||||||M.Sc. The study was aimed at providing basic information to establish their potentials for both nutritional and industrial uses in Nigeria.Most of the seeds were collected from the botanical gardens of Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife, while others (Cyperus esculentus and Carcinia kola) were purchased locally in the market. The cracked, dehulled and ground seeds were determined for proximate composition: moisture, ash, crude fibre, crude protein, oil and carbohydrate. Mineral levels (Na, K, Ca, Mg. Zn & Cu), fatty acid profiles and viscosities at various temperatures (30 - 80C) were also determined. Other properties investigated included saponification and iodine values, refractive indices, specific gravities and infra-red spectra. These properties were compared with those of the commercial and conventional oilseeds.The analytical techniques used were mainly as described by the Association of Official Analytical Chemists (AOAC). The moisture and ash contents of the seeds ranged from 3.85% in C. puicherrima to 9.87% in C. escuientus, and from 4.30% in H. barteri to 10.32% in C. pulcherrima respectively. Oil content ranged between 14.69 and 30.86%. G, kola gave the lowest protein content of 0.21%. The legumes (C.	pulcherrima, B. monandra &  B, rufescens) were fairer sources, with values in the range of 21.72 and 26.63%. Crude fibre determination gave values between 9.52 and 18.81%. Only H. barteri gave a detectable myristic add (C14.0) content of 2,93%. Only C. escuentus cand be considered very rich in oleic acid - C18:1 (63.72%). Other values ranged between 10.143 and 22.89%. Except C. escuientus, (10.82%), all the other oils were good sources of linoleic acid - C18:2 (30.45 - 58.59%). only H. barteri contained linolenic acid - C 18:3 (17.75%). Viscosity measurements ranged between 13,18 and 27,54 existed in the sodium potassium and calcium contents of the species while there was a close similarity in the magnesium and Zinc contents. Except for G. kola, the infra-red spectra of all the oils showed only the bands expected for normal triglycerides. Saponification values were generally high and ranged between 165.8 and 240,8. Iodine values were in the range of 82.4 and 123:0, The	obtained for the refractive indices and specific gravities were comparable to those of the conventional oils.The study revealed that the oilseeds have good prospects as substitutes and supplements to the conventional ones in both the food and non food industries.|Theses Collection|conventional/ analytical techniques/ Association of Official Analytical Chemists (AOAC)*||||||Olaogun, Kayode Abiola|M|An investigation of physico-chemical properties of some underexploited Nigerian oilseeds||||||M.Sc., Chemistry|Omode, A.A.//Fatoki, O.S.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Chemistry|1994||| OAU|||||xii, 110p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. Total. starch of breadfruit was determined by enzymic method while toxicants were analysed by phytochemical screening and colorimetric methods. The physicochemical properties of starch, the total free sugar components and total reducing sugars were evaluated using centrifuge, paper chromatography and colorimetric methods. The rate of decomposition of breadfruit was determined by analysing the pulp for total. free sugars produced at specific time intervals using Anthrone method.The chemical composition of breadfruit showed that the core had the highest values of moisture (83.8 - 88.3%), ash (5.7 - 8.1%), protein (7.7 - 14.7%), fat (2.9 - 3.6%), crude fibre (16.4 - 19.2%), total free sugars (5.0%), total reducing sugars (2.4%) and the least for total carbohydrate, starch and vitamin C. The proximate composition of breadfruit showed no significant differences between trees nor with location at P< 0.01 . The mineral components Ca, Mg, Zn, Cu, Fe, Cd, Na, K and P were relatively high compared to some of the conventional carbohydrate sources. Potassium values were higher than other minerals is in all the three parts with the core value (3.64%) being other highest. The fruits stored in water and aaucous fo:rmaldehyd~ solution were better preserved than those kept in the refrigerator and room temperature. Tannin level was highest in peel (0,07%) and lowest in core (0.02%). The swelling and solubility of the isolated starch at the maximum pasting temperature (95C), were 3,827% and 24.2% respectively. Intinsic viscosity was 2.95 cS. Amylose content was highest in starch isolated from freeze those dried samples (24.8%) and least in starch from those dried at 80oC (22.6%). The use of such flours increased after the ban, but information on the quality characteristics and baking properties of maize-banana mix as composite has not been investigated. Therefore the use of maize--banana. mix as composite flour in breadmaking as investigated with a view to formulating an acceptable baked product. flour mixes obtained by substituting maize cake with ripe banana pulp at different percentage levels (10-50) ,ere evaluated for proximate composition, amylograph pasting viscosity, syneresis, water holding capacity, reducing and non-reducing sugars, and Moisture uptake (sorpti o isotherm). Bread from the flour mixes were subjected to sensory evaluation for external characteristics (crust colour, symmetry), internal. characteristics (crumb _colour, crumb texture and grain), taste, aroma and overall acceptability, and the results analysed statistically.The proximate compositions for the flour samples were 5.5-6.8%, 5.57-6.4; 2.87 -4.25%; 0.03-2.42%; and 82.3- 83.6%, for moisture, crude protein, crude fat, ash and carbohydrate.by difference, respectively. The peak viscosity of maize flour was the highest while that of 50% substituted sample was the least with values of 1080 B.U. and 330 B.U. respectively.|Theses Collection|non-wheat flours/breadmaking/proximate composition/*||||||Abari, Ayodeji Olasunkanmi|M|Communication practices and organisational climates of secondary school in Lagos state.||||||Ph.D., Educational Administration|Akinola, J.A.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Educational Administration|1994||| OAU|||||xiv, 198p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. Two structured questionnaires were designed to collect pertinent data. One was the Organizational Climate Description Questionnaire (OCDQ) designed to measure organizational climate and classify the sample schools into climate types. The other was the Communication Practices Questionnaire (CPQ,) designed to measure the communication practices that go on in the schools. The Teachers in the sample schools were randomly selected as the subjects to respond to the questionnaires. The Pearson's Product- Moment correlation Analysis was employed to find out the relationship between the variables of organizational climate and communication practices in their aggregate and separate forms. Results obtained from data analysis revealed that the aggregate and separate forms of organizational climate and communication practices are related in various degrees, both positively and negatively. With the resulting relationships, each of the identified climate types was separately described based on the projected communication features. The latter were rated low, average and high. Thus the results further revealed that an open school climate is characterized by such practices that constitute low communication channels, high communication feedback, low communication with the transactional environment and low communication barriers.A controlled school climate is separately characterized by such practices that constitute average communication channels and feedback, low communication with the transactional environment and high communication barriers. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng|||| I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Two hundred and twenty five ditch-cutting samples of sediments from the Miocene section of the Agbada Formation in four main boreholes: Obeakpu-6, Korokoro-10, Ete-1 and Utapate South-1 situated in the eastern Niger Delta as well as three ancillary boreholes: Etelebou-1, Edasuo-1 and Kugbo West-I located in the central Niger Delta were studied for their lithostratigraphic characteristics, depositional environments, transport history and provenance. In addition, twenty-seven recent river sediment samples from Imo, Kwa Ibo, Cross and Calabar rivers were also examined using standard sedimentological and stratigraphical methods which included systematic sample description as well as geophysical log, grain size, heavy mineral and clay mineral analyses.The study was ultimately aimed at contributing to the existing knowledge of the stratigraphy and sedimentology of the Niger Delta and thus facilitating more fruitful exploration for hydrocarbons in the delta. Based on Iithologic characteristics, two informal lithostratigraphic units, A and B, which respectively correspond to the lower and upper units of the Agbada Formation, were distinguished in the four main boreholes.Geophysical log, clay mineral, grain size and sand percentage analyses show that in the four main boreholes, sediments were deposited in environments that vary from the fluviomarine lower coastal plain to the marine.  Textural characteristics suggest that the sediments of Obeakpu-6 and Korokoro-10 boreholes were transported over a longer distance than those of Etc-1 and Utapate South-1. Heavy mineral analysis permitted the recognition of a factor (the hvanite-Staurolite factor) for distinguishing the two ancient river systems contributing sediments to the Niger Delta during most of the Tertiary, the Cross and the Niger-Benue River syvstems. Heavy mineral and clay mineral analyses show that the sediments of Obeakpu-6 and Korokoro-10 boreholes were derived largely from the Abakaliki Fold Belt as well as the Adamawa-Sarduana Massif and/or the Oban Massif, while those of Ete-1 and Utapate South-1 boreholes were largely sourced from the Oban Massif and the Calabar Flank. The preponderance of kaolinite in their clay mineral suites indicates that the sediments in the four main boreholes were generated under a warm and humid tropical climate in an environment of steep slopes and high topographic relief.|Theses Collection|lithostratigraphic characteristics/ depositional environments/ transport history/ provenance*||||||Ajelabi, Olufunmilola Bola|F|Removal of heavy metals from industrial wastewaters using natural adsorbents||||||M.Sc., Chemistry|Asubiojo, F.O.I||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Chemistry|1994||| OAU|||||xvi,120p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng|||| I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Heavy metals as a group are one of the major pollutants in industrial wastewaters, and conventional techniques of removing them before discharge of the wastewaters into public waterways are generally very expensive. In this study, the effectiveness of cheap, readily available natural materials as adsorbents of heavy metals from industrial wastewaters was investigated. Natural materials investigated include bagasse, paddy husk, corn cob, wheat bran, peanut skin and human hair.Two modes of removal were carried out. In one set of experiments, mixed standard solutions of some heavy metals and also effluents from different industries were run through columns packed with natural adsorbents. In the other set, the mixed standard solutions and the effluents were, simply agitated with known weights of the natural adsorbents. Heavy metal concentrations of the mixed standard solutions and the industrial effluents were determined before and after contact with the natural adsorbents using Atomic Absorption Spectrophotometry (AAS). Parameters such as column height, substrate weight, particle size of the substrate and the pH of the substrate in solution were varied to obtain optimum conditions for heavy metal removal. Virtually all the materials were found to be good scavengers of heavy metals, as good if not better than some of the conventional, expensive commercial materials such as ion-exchange resin currently in use for wastewater treatment. The mechanism of removal is proposed to be similar to ion-exchange resins and adsorption. The adsorption capacities of the natural adsorbents vary from one heavy metal to another. Based on the overall mean percentage removal of heavy metals (87.6 to 92.2%), the heavy metal adsorbing capacity of the natural adsorbents is of the following order: Corn cob > paddy husk > peanut skin > human hair > wheat bran > bagasse. in terms of weight of heavy metal adsorbed per unit weight of adsorbent, the efficiency of heavy metal scavenging is of the following order: Bagasse and human hair > corn cob and peanut skin > wheat bran > paddy husk. Efficiency of heavy metal removal by the natural adsorbents increases with column height and decreases with particle size of adsorbent and residual heavy metal concentration in the effluent. Development of this method is recommended as an efficient and cost-effective method for wastewater treatment.|Theses Collection|Pollutants/public waterways/Atomic Absorption Spectrophotometry (AAS)/ion-exchange resin/natural adsorbents/heavy metal  *||||||Adeyemi, Kehinde Oluseye|M|Interpretation of seismic reflection data over moonstone-3, offshore Niger Delta||||||M.Sc., Geophysics|Olorunniwo,M.A.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Geophysics|1994||| OAU|||||xiii, 249p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng|||| I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Ten seismic sections and a suite of borehole logs from Moonstone-3 oilfield, offshore, Niger delta have been analysed and interpreted for possible hydrocarbon prospects in the study area.Five major faults, in addition to a structure-building fault and four seismic horizons were mapped. These seismic horizons divide the study area into five layers. The Dix technique of interval velocity and depth inversion was used in computing the interval velocities and depths to each horizon. The computed interval velocities in horizon one range from 1944 - 2131 m/s, while the depth values range from 1320 - 1556 m.In horizon two interval velocities range from 2279-2955 m/s while the depth values range from 1492 - 1761 m. In horizon three interval velocities range from 2363 - 3174 m/s while the depth values range from 1787 - 2107 m and in horizon four interval velocities range from 2340 - 3489 m/s while depth values range from 2243 - 2733 in. Results show a general increase of interval velocity with depth as well as lateral velocity inhomogeneity . This may be due to the pattern of faulting in the area and to some extent on facies changes.Seismic structural maps such as isochrons, isovelocities and isopachs were prepared from the parameters of each layer. The isochron isopach maps have revealed roll- over anticlinal structures in the area. The isovelocity maps were used to describe the velocity distribution over the study area.In addition to the growth-fault-generated anticlinal structures revealed by the structural maps, stratigraphic traps such as Facies-change trap and crestal accumulations below mature erosional surfaces were also recognized on the seismic sections. These crestal accumulations represent the main trapping mechanism for hydrocarbon in the study area and are presented as strong reflection events on the seismic sections.The qualitative and quantitative interpretation of the borehole data have revealed four broad zones represented by zones A, C and D respectively. The borehole data was correlated with the surface seismic sections and the four zones were recognized. Zone A is made up of fresh water/minor oil and gas. Zone B is made up of shale acting as a cap rock over zone C which is hydrocarbon bearing. Zone D is dominantly salt water bearing.Waveslowness and sand ratio analysis of the sand-shale columns revealed that waveslowness/sand ratio were higher within the amplitude map of the sand body and lower outside of it.|Theses Collection|Hydrocarbon/inhomogeneity/seismic structural maps/isochron/isopach/isovelocities/anticlinal structures/waveslowness/crestal accumulations*||||||Obi, Olutayo Olumide|M|The effect of nutrition and health interventions in rural poultry production in Osun state.||||||M.Sc., Animal science|Sonaiya, E.B.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Animal Science|1994||| OAU|||||x, 76p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng|||| I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Two main studies were conducted. The first was a survey to obtain information on profitability of rural chicken production in Osun state. Average flock size was 17 birds. Ninety-eight percent of the respondents offered grain supplements and average feed supplementation cost per bird per month was N 7.70. Basket coops were the common type of overnight housing provided and the depreciated cost was about N 0.103 per bird per month. The average price of a mature cock was N 79, while hens and growers cost N 58 and N 29, respectively. The farmers were willing to pay N 4.30 per bird for vaccination against Newcastle disease and N 6.70 per Kilogram of compounded feed. Gross margin estimation shows that the farmers realize a positive margin of N 4.50 from the sale of growers at 3 months of age and N9.00 and N 30.00 on hens and cocks, respectively, when sold at 6 months of age.The second study was conducted on-farm to study the effect of offering supplements (commercial growers mash) and vaccination against Newcastle disease on the productivity of scavenging village chickens. The treatments were villages in. which supplementation, vaccination, a combination of supplementation and vaccination were offered. The control was the village in which no experimental supplement or vaccination was offered to the scavenging birds. Data were collected on body weight changes, apparent average supplemental feed intake, flock size, number of eggs laid, number of chicks hatched, and number of chicks surviving at 2 , 4 , 6 and 8 weeks. The data collected was analyzed for means, standard deviations and percentages. The means were compared and separated using one-way analysis of variance and Duncans New multiple range test.The results indicate a drop in average apparent daily intake (g/bird) of the experimental supplements after the first period for the different groups except the cocks whose consumption fluctuated down the periods. The average daily weight gain (g/bird/day) fluctuated over time for birds in all treatments. The vaccination treatment had the highest average daily gain of 2.78 g/bird/day but this was not significantly different from other treatments. The average clutch sizes of hens in both supplementation and supplementation + vaccination treatments (9.26 and 8.78 eggs) were significantly higher than those in the vaccination and control treatments (6.70 and 6.33 eggs). The overall average clutch size was 8.36 eggs while the average number of chicks hatched was 6.08 a hatchability of 72.7%. Mortality was highest in the control treatment (65.0%).Supplementing 50% of the calculated requirements of scavenging chickens with commercial growers mash and timely vaccination against Newcastle disease improved the productivity and the gross margins obtainable from rural chicken production system.|Theses Collection|commercial growers mash/vaccination against Newcastle disease*||||||Oladimeji, Hakeem Olawale|M|Bioactivity-guided fractionation of acalyphia wilkesiana.||||||M.Sc., Pharmaceutical Chemistry|Olugbade, T.A.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Pharmaceutical chemistry|1996||| OAU|||||xi, 90p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng|||| I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The genus, Acalypha (Family, Euphorbiaceae) consists of about 570 species and varieties including weeds and ornamental shrubs. Members of this genus are used extensively in traditional medicine in various cultures (African, Oriental, Indian, European and Oceanian) to treat a number of infections including skin fungal infections, respiratory disorders and gastrointestinal infections.In this work, six Acalypha species namely A.,ciliata, A. indica, A. hispida and A,. wilkesiana varieties (Red, Golden-yellow and Lace varieties) were screened for antimicrobial properties and brine shrimp toxicity. Only A. ciliata, a weed, demonstrated LD50  200ppm in the brine shrimp assay. The ornamental plants, A. hispida and the three varieties of A. wilkesiana demonstrated significant antibacterial activities against E. coli, S. aurens, B. subtilis and Ps. aeruginosa. Only A. hispida and the red Acalypha showed significant anticandidal (C. pseudotropicalis) activity as well. Hence, one of these two, the red Acalypha was selected for detailed studies. The red Acalypha has been specifically reported to he used extensively in the treatment of bacterial and skin fungal infections like Pityriasis versicolor, Impetigo contagiosa and Tinea versicolor in traditional herbal medicine in Nigeria.Studies involving solvent-partitioning of the aqueous ethanolic extract located antimicrobial activity in the butanol fraction.Subsequent bioactivity directed this fraction successively on sephadex LH-20 and polyamide 6S column revealed the antibacterial principles as a mixture of two polyphenols. Minimum effort liquid chromatography of' the mixture on silica resolved the mixture into two compounds which were identified using spectroscopic methods, one as cofilagin and the other tentatively identified as geraniin. Both compounds isolated demonstrated antimicrobial activities against the five test organisms.While corilagin and geraniin have been previously reported from other sources, the antimicrobial properties of these ellagitannins have not been hitherto reported. Although corilagin is well known to be an artefact resulting from in-process hydrolysis of geraniin, the natural occurrence of this tannin in red Acalypha was confirmed, in the present study, by its thin-layer chromatographic detection in fresh leaves.|Theses Collection|species /weeds and ornamental shrubs/gastrointestinal infections/A.,ciliata, A. indica, A. hispida and A,. wilkesiana/*||||||Agaie, Shuaibu Sulaiman|M|Relationship between learning styles and academic performance of nursing students in schools of nursing in Osun state||||||M.Sc. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng|||| I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This thesis examines the bases and impact of internationalisation on the Eritrean national question in Ethiopia.It traces the origins of the Eritrean problem, the major phases of Eritrean Nationalism as well as Ethiopia's responses tothe national question. Besides, it identifies the external dimensions of both the Eritrean nationalist movement and Ethiopia's responses to the insurgency.Primary data was obtained from interviews, personal communications with Eritrean and Ethiopian official representatives; and official reports and publications of the liberation fronts. The secondary sources include books and journal articles by academics, diplomats, journalists and reports of international news media. The study shows that, the Eritrean problem is rooted in material contradictions arising from the mutually opposing forces of Eritrean and imperial Ethiopian nationalism.lt however, shows that geo-political consideration played a great part in nurturing the seeds of the conflict. Moreover, internationalisation inheres In the logic of the national question once it assumes the dimension of a full-fledged national 1st conflict.Internationalisation occurs at two levels: (i) at the level of the warring parties, and (ii) at the level of the international society. Both parties to the conflict have to solicit external support while foreign states, regional and global actors are drawn into the conflict for varying objectives but mainly because of their vested interest in safeguarding those norms and principles of international relations which serve the end of regime and state security. Thus, while the Eritrean cause was generally isolated, Ethiopia attracted tremendous political, diplomatic and military support from the international community.The enquiry, however, reveals that the incidence of internationalisation is not unilinear as it responds to changes, in the conditions of the warring parties and developments in the external environment: Because of the persistence and explosiveness of the fighting, as well as the momentous changes in the international system, the Eritreans succeeded in breaking out of isolation, gaining, in the process, a considerable measure of recognition and support for their cause. As the position of the international community changed- from one of prolonged isolation to reconciliation, and, lately, to tacit encouragement, the Eritreans consummated their independence, thus overcoming the resilient normative and structural constraints which impede the creation of new states.|Theses Collection|internationalisation/warring parties/independence/Nationalism/diplomacy/foreign relations*||||||Nfah, Mary Baba|M|Design and implementation of recursive descent parser generator||||||M.Sc. Computer Science|Ekong,V.J.U.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Computer science|1994||| OAU|||||ix,142p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng|||| I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Programming languages provide a means of communication between the computer user and the computer. They are characterized by highlevel languages which cannot be directly executed by the computer. There was the need to translate such languages into machine executable instructions hence compilers became paramount. A compiler operates in phases each of which transforms the source program from one representation to another.This work is concerned with the syntax analysis phase, based on the recursive descent parsing technique. Table implementations of recursive descent parsers are common. The need to eliminate the use of a parsing table has been recognised, hence a solution approach to design and implement a directly executable parser from a grammar specification was provided by this work. A recursive grammar was and this formed the input to LL(1) grammar was specified the parser generator. The parser generator- was implemented using a set of recursive procedures with semantic actions embedded into the parsing procedures to automate the generation of output. A lexical analyzer was incorporated to extract tokens from the input source language. The output of the parser generator consist of the recognized constructs of the source language together with an intermediate representation in postfix polish notation. The number of times each nonterminal in the source language was called during the execution of program was also determined.Parsing procedures once built into a compiler are not easy to change because they are normally augmented with code that perform semantic analysis and code generation. Also grammars are sometimes updated to accommodate new or modified constructs. It is therefore desirable to have a way of updating a parser without affecting other compiler components. Rather than using the LL(1) table to build parsing procedures, the result of this work has been to automate the translation of a grammar into an intermediate form which can then serve as input to a code generator. The parser generated, is also flexible and efficient in its utilisation of time and memory space. It is easier to implement and excutes faster than a table driven parser.|Theses Collection|Programming languages/communication/syntax analysis phase/*||||||Ebune, Lydia Ntube|F|Evaluation and simulation of memory allocation schemes||||||M.Sc. Computer Science|Ogwu, F.J.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Computer science|1994||| OAU|||||xi, 144p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng|||| I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The importance of memory management in operating systems has only been recently recognized and accepted. The recognition of this fact has led to a series of advancements in producing various memory management schemes to improve on operating systems.The various memory management techniques are used in managing the main memory of the computer, so that it can efficiently accommodate all the requested processes. Selection of a memory management schemes for a specific system depends upon the hardware design. Some of these factors have been used in the evaluation model to determine the efficiency of some schemes.These schemes were evaluated using an emulation of the memory environment of a computer system, with special attention to the components involved with memory management such as the Tasker, which simulates task execution by generating deallocation requests for random memory blocks, the Viewer that displays memory, the Memory which is structured into contiguous blocks of memory space and the freelist Manager which provides functions such as deallocation, block remapping and allocation of free space. The schemes were then simulated using these four components to determine their efficiency. the main program is called Memsim written in Pascal programming language.The results obtained indicated that no particular scheme is actually the best in satisfying all memory management requirements of proper utilization of memory, proper handling of internal and external fragmentation. The results show that, while some schemes are good in memory utilization, others are good in handling internal and external fragmentation. Optimal memory utilization with 56 processes running was 417792 bytes. When compared to the overall available memory of 524288 bytes of memory size, it was observed that only a memory space of 106496 bytes was left unused. The two schemes that had this amount of memory utilization were, dynamic allocation with relocation block unit-1024 and dynamic allocation without relocation block unit-1024. The lowest level of internal fragmentation was with the partition allocation with relocation and dynamic allocation with and without relocation block unit-1, with no internal fragmentation. The lowest level of external fragmentation with 56 running processes was indicated by dynamic-allocation with relocation block unit - 1024. From our results it was observed that having an hybrid memory allocation scheme (i.e. combining two allocation schemes, one that reduces internal fragmentation and one that properly utilizes memory space) will maximally utilize memory.|Theses Collection|operating systems/ memory management/ Pascal programming language*||||||Amujoyegbe, Bamidele Julius|M|Preliminary studies of yield system analysis in some selected cultivars of cowpea ( Vigna unguiculata , (L) Walp.)||||||M.Sc. Low yielders, apart from showing inferior phenotypic performance, were late maturing. The alternative pathways through which cowpea achieve yield are: number of pods per plant, 100 SDW, The %. SGR, YGR, BM and BGR. The most important trait for indirect selection is the YGR because of its highest direct effect on yield. Prolonged growth duration is not favourable to cowpea grain yield unlike prolonged DSF.|Theses Collection|emergence (E)/ emergence percentage (E%)/ emergence index (El)/ emergence rate index (ERI)/ vigour index (VGX)/ Seed weight {100 SOW)/ number of pods per plant (NPP)/ harvest index (HI)/ threshing percentage (Thr.%)*||||||Coker, Akinwale Oladotun|M|The effects of high velocity gradients in water coagulation||||||M.Sc. Civiil Engineering|Ogedengbe, O.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Civil Engineering|1991|||OAU|||||xiii, 104p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|An overview of the trend of the nation's economy within the past one decade leaves no doubt as to the desirability of any effort aimed at minimising the spending of not only the hard-earned foreign currencies but also the local one.Purchase of aluminium sulphate (alum) - commonly used in the nation's waterworks is gulping colossal amounts of money yearly. Any effort to substantially reduce this therefore becomes meaningful, laudable and one in the right direction. It is against this background that this study was under-taken to investigate the effects of high velocity gradient, G (intense rapid mixing) in water coagulation, with and without addition of coagulant.The typical raw water used for the study was obtained by damming a portion of the stream in front of the Civil Engineering Building at Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife. A 32-litre sample of the raw water was positioned ready for the run in a tank and using a calibrated high-shear stirrer, the water was subjected to selected levels of G-200, 500 and 800 per second for 2, 8, 16, 24 and 32 minutes. In cases where coagulant was used to supplement G, it was added immediately the rapid mixing was begun. The results were analysed using turbidity removal, pH and level of finished water alkalinity as yardsticks.It was found that turbidity removal generally continued to improve with increasing G with or without coagulant, with more substantial improvement obtained when coagulant was applied. However optimum coagulant dosage was 20, mg/1 alum or 30 mg/1 ferric chloride for all levels of G applied.Application of velocity gradients without coagulant generally had no significant effect on the pH and level, of finished water alkalinity. On the other hand, depressions in the pH values and levels of finished water alkalinity resulted when G was supplemented with coagulants, with greater depressions given by the ferric chloride than alum.Conclusively, high velocity gradients with and without addition of chemical coagulants have substantial effects on water coagulation. On the basis of the three yardsticks of turbidity removal, pH and level of finished water alkalinity, application of G with alum gave the best results.|Theses Collection|turbidity removal/coagulant/ferric chloride/G/alum/water alkalinity/*||||||Olaleye, Adedayo Olushola|M|A study of the development and performance of the civil service in western Nigeria, 1954-1976||||||Ph.D. Public Administration|||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Public Administration|1991|||OAU|||||xi, 284p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. Generally, civil service systems in the third world have performed below these expectations with only a few exceptions.A body of literature in this field acknowledged and claimed that the Western Nigeria Civil Service has been on the whole successful in its effort to promote social and economic development in its milieu. This study documented and analysed the various dimensions of this acclaimed success of the Western Nigeria Civil Service between 1954 and 1976 with a view to ascertaining those factors responsible for the achievements of the service and examine those factors that hindered success. It thus sets out to evaluate the Civil Service through the use of some objective criteria for the measurement of the organisations performance. An input-output method was used to evaluate performance having considered the influence of the environment and the importance of availability of resources, personnel, funds and materials could play on organisational goal achievement.Furthermore, the historical method was adopted in this study in order to enable us collate and evaluate critically available evidence to buttress the conclusions reached. Archival survey and examination of literature were undertaken. Furthermore, samples of 120 past political and administrative actors were interviewed to validate or refute some of the views expressed in the literature.There was evidence of concrete achievement recorded throughout the period under study. Though the resources generated during the civilian era (1954 t0 1966) were lower than that generated during the military era (1966 to 1976), there were greater physical achievements  evidence of better performance.Also, there was an indication from the study that commitment to goals was greater during the early civilian era than during the period of military rule. The evidence showed that civil service performance was greatly enhanced by the nature of the environment, high degree of motivation and the successful cooperation between the administrative and political class.For the Civil Service to be able to meet the expectations of the future, it must be prepared to adapt to changes in the environment. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The gap between food production and requirement grows wider in Nigeria. Current efforts to bridge this gap focus on integrating the numerous small scale farmers into the modern farming systems through the Agricultural Development Project situated in all states of the federation. One crop that is fast gaining popularity and which can reduce the twin problems of food shortage and malnutrition is soyabean. This study examined the socio-economic factors influencing the adoption of the crop's farming practices at the EAADP coverage area.The study involved 296 farmers randomly selected from the project's enclave. Structured questionnaires were used to collect data on the personal and farming characteristics of the farmers. Other sources of data include the EAADP Offices and Federal Agricultural coordinating Unit (FACU).Using correlation analysis, regression techniques, the Linear Probability Model and Production functions, the study revealed that the socio-economic factors influencing adoption scores of soyabean farmers positively include size of farm, farmers   proneness to innovation and farmers level of education. Household size, social-status and cost of variable factors affected adoption score negatively. On the other hand, the Linear Probability Model result showed that any farmer picked at random in the enclave had 36% probability of being an adopter.Adoption score elasticity showed that the most important variable that influenced changes in adoption score was the cost of variable inputs hence policy must focus on reducing the cost of variable inputs to farmers.The production functions confirmed that adopters were more efficient than non-adopters in the use of inputs. They also showed that the most important variable inputs in the production of soyabeans at the enclave were insecticides and herbicides.Constraints on adoption of soyabean practices were found to include high cost of inputs and lack of credit facilities to farmers. Even if credit were available the cost, that is, interest rate, was too high for the, average farmer. From the project's perspective, constraints include inadequacy of extension correlates, like roads, farming inputs and finance.The study concluded that efforts directed at reducing these bottlenecks would increase the adoption of soyabean practices and hence its output.|Theses Collection Theses Collection|food production in nigeria/EAADP/malnutrition/*||||||Osatuyi, Oluremi|F|Synthesis and acute toxicity tests of estragole and its derivatives||||||M.Sc. The objectives include synthesis of estragole and its derivatives from cheap materials using simple methods and to test its potency against the insect pest Zonocerus variegatus. The study also aimed at using structure activity relationship to obtain relevant parameter needed for biological activity of the synthesized compounds and its derivatives.Allylation of phenol and claisen re-arrangement of the resulting allyl ethers to allyl phenols was carried out. This was followed by alkylation of the allyl phenol with dialkylsulphate. Purification was done by column chromatography/thin layer chromatography. Z. variegatus was collected from Teaching and Research Farm, Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife. The toxicity of the synthetic compounds to the insects was determined and LD50 and KD50 were computed.Topical application of 1.5l of the pure synthetic compounds to variegated grasshopper Z. variegates showed toxic effect on the 3rd  and 4th nymphal instars.Mortality occurred without any kicking or jerking of legs. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This study undertook an analysis of the socio-economic and risk characteristics that might be influencing the adoption of improved high-yielding and disease-resistant varieties of maize seeds, chemical and mechanical technologies and related cultural practices by farmers with the use of quantitative techniques. A multi-stage sampling of 218 farmers across six local government areas of Oyo State constituted the primary data source.An adoption-intensity index was constructed to show one categorisation of farmers in the technological continuum. Simultaneous exploration of the data` set for the maximum likelihood estimation showed the optimum cut-off value for the index to be 35%. Subsequently, 57.34% of the farmers were classified as adopters, and the remaining) 42.66% non-adopters.In view of the dichotomous nature of this exercise, its formulation constituted a binary-choice model, and the probit specification had been employed.Based on the magnitudes of the coefficients, the results of the probit analysis indicated that the stimulus index of adoption was influenced more by the availability of storage facility, cropping pattern, membership of cooperatives, contacts with extension agents and land tenure. However, only  the coefficients of storage facility and extension contacts were significant at 5% level.The value of the extimated risk-aversion parameter was found to range between 0.87 (for lowest degree) and 1.72 (highest). Individual farmer's risk-aversion parameter was incorporated into the probit modal sand this was found to be significant at 5% level.The regression of the risk-aversion parameter with the personal characteristics of the farmers revealed an adjusted R2 of 0.37. Membership of cooperative societies, contact with extension agents and education were found to be significantly related to risk-bearing abilities of the farmers.The probit analysis of the effects of different policy alternative on adoption revealed that liberal credit had the greatest impact of increasing number of prospective adopters by 10.97%. This was followed by increased extension contacts (9.63%), and provision of storage facilities (4.59%).Based on these analyses, principal reasons for non-adoption fall into six broad areas. These in descending order, are non-availability of inputs, smallness of farms, inadequate knowledge, conservatism/traditional beliefs, financial constraints and unprofitability of the inputs.|Theses Collection|adoption-intesity index/probit analysis/cropping pattern/risk aversion parameters/*||||||Amoran, John Ayodele.|M|Financial Management Accountability in the National Youth Service Corps (19731989).||||||Ph.D.|Olu Omopariola||Ile-Ife,Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University, Management Accounting |1991.|||OAU|||||xiv, 4 31p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This thesis examined the relationship between ViceChancellors and the performance of selected SouthWestern  Nigerian Universities.  The selected Universities were: Obafemi Awolowo University, IleIfe; University of Lagos, Lagos; University of Benin, BeninCity; University of Ilorin, Ilorin;  Bendel State University, Ekpoma; and the Federal University of Technology Akure.   The study covered the years between 1960 and 1986.The methodology employed was theoretical, descriptive and statistical. Primary data were collected through questionnaire and interview methods. Secondary data were collected from the National Universities Commission (NUC) Office in Lagos, and the central administration offices in each of the Universities.   Other relevant information was obtained from reports of visitation panels, reports of commissions of inquiry, official gazettes, the calendars of each of the Universities, addresses and speeches of the ViceChancellors, newspapers and magazines, and other published and unpublished works on Nigerian Universities.The study found out that while there exists a relationship between leadership styles and performance in SouthWestern Nigerian Universities, the nature of the relationship did not suggest a one best leadership style. Moreover, various factors were found to be mediators between leadership styles and performance.These include: the quality of the leader, the nature of politics in Nigeria, politics within the University, the impact of culture, the peculiarities of the academic enterprise and the role of the state in the management of Universities.In all, sixteen ViceChancellors were assessed with regard to their contributions to the performance of their institutions.   Six of them were perceived to be high achievers, five were scored as moderate achievers, while five were seen as low achievers.In conclusion, the study made some policy recommendations which could assist in the selection of Nigerian ViceChancellors as well as improving the performance of Nigerian Universities. It was recommended that the selection of ViceChancellors should be further democratized thereby making them more accountable to their constituents. It was further recommended that the Government should avoid as much as possible, the tendency to treat Universities as just another agency of government.  A further recommendation was that Nigerian Universities need to be better funded while the Universities should find ways of limiting their dependence on government funds. On a final note, it was recommended that at the end of every decade, there should be a mandatory and comprehensive review of the philosophy, goals and objectives as well as the performance of Nigerian Universities.|Theses collection.|ViceChancellors/SouthWestern  Nigerian Universities./ policy recommendations/Nigerian Universities/ performance of Nigerian Universities.*||||||Ojo, Adenike.|F| Impact of Government Policies on RuralDevelopment in Ondo State of Nigeria, 1976-1986||||||Ph.D.|Dele Olowu.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,Public Administration|1991|||OAU|||||xiv, 384p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Analysis of the impact of Governments' agricultural and industrial policies on the performance of smallscale industries (SSI) located in the rural areas of Ondo State, including the influence of such policies on the industrial promotion functions of local associations is the focus of this study.Bringing together relevant elements of economic theories and approaches, the study takes as point of departure, the mass participatory approach to rural SSI development within the framework of an integrated rural development model.A combination of the analysis of documentary records, participant observation, and interviews that were conducted during field surveys between 1987 and 1988 were the three main research techniques utilised. A total of 178 rural industrial establishments (processing, manufacturing and servicing concerns) were contacted, out of which 150 participated in the study, giving a response rate of 84%. Interviews were also conducted with selected members of local associations and officials of relevant governmental agencies. Descriptive statistical tools and relevant computer programmes were used for data analysis.The study found that the Federal and State Governments policies aimed at assisting industrialisation in the State mainly favoured largescale enterprises.  The few policies directed at the SSI sector were urbanfocussed, thus such policies tended to tilt the balance of competition against the ruralbased SSI. The upsurge observed in local associations business  motion activities in the form of joint ventures and some hips reflect collective response aimed at overcoming policies which tended to hinder SSI growth. Also within the conceptual scheme proposed, the study appraises the capacity of the rural SSI sector for meeting the basic needs of the agricultural and the entire rural population for goods and service at affordable cost, using  Ondo State as a case study.  It is also significant that rural SSI created employment for both sexes and especially for women as the latter constituted 53% of the proprietors and 48% of the total workforce.The study proceeds to assess and document the contributions of ruralbased SSI in the State to local rawmaterials sourcing, technology procurement, adaptation and utilisation, and utilisation. and integrated, rural enterprise development. It found that rural SSI face several external and internal constraints. Separating these critical factors, and instituting the key reforms proposed, would facilitate appreciation of the essence of the rural SSI sector and also improve its performance.The study thus recommends that Ondo State should adopt a policy of integrated rural development, through a vigorous strategy of rural economic diversification, with rural-based SSI as one of the crucial vehicles for a dynamic, competitive and economically integrated State. It stresses that neither bureaucratic centralism, paternalism nor the magic of market forces per se can bring about the needed sustainable rural transformation. It advocates lowcost, highimpact, massparticipatory strategies.  These are of primary relevance in encouraging an entrepreneurial  environment, promoting productivity, meeting the needs of the agricultural sector and of the rural population; while connecting the heights of the political and economic system with the lower stratum of the production structure, on which the former should rest.|Theses collection.|agricultural and industrial policies /smallscale industries (SSI) / rural industrial establishments/largescale enterprises*||||||Olaleye, Adedayo Olusola.|M| A Study of the Development and Performance of the Civil Service in Western Nigeria (1954-1976)||||||Ph.D.| A.O. Generally, Civil Service systems in the Third World performed below these expectations, with only a few exceptions. A body of literature in this field acknowledged and claimed that the Western Nigeria Civil Service has been on the whole successful in its effort to promote social and development in its milieu.  This study documented and analysed the various  dimensions of this acclaimed success of the Western Nigeria Civil Service between 1954 and 1976 with a view to ascertaining those factors responsible for the achievements of the service and examine those factors that hindered success. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The angraecoid orchids constitute a difficult assemblage of plants whose main line of classification has generated much controversy among taxonomists.  Authorities differ in their interpretation of subtribal groups of this complex. Eightysix morphological characters as well as epidermal and pollinaria features were extracted from 100 angraecoid orchid species occurring in Nigeria and Cameroun. Four basic data matrices (BDM) comprising 18 (vegetative), 37 (vegetative and floral), 63 (floral) and 86 (vegetative, floral and ecological) characters by 100 operational taxonomic units (OTU's) were made.  A quantitative comparison of each BDM was then made by employing three computer-based classification techniques, Centroid Sorting (CS), Detrended Correspondence Analysis (DCA) and Principal Component Analysis (PCA).  The groupings from PCA and DCA were similar but both differed from the CS which misplaced several taxa.  The result based on 63 characters consistently deviated from those based on 18, 37 and 86 characters respectively.  The generic composition of the groups seem to be less influenced by the number than by the nature of the characters employed.On the basis of these results and additional evidence from the study of the epidermal and pollinaria systems, the angraecoid genera are divided into three groups, of which the leafless, comprising Microcoelia and Chaulidon is new. Investigations carried out on the vegetative morphology, leaf epidermis and pollinaria system revealed characters of taxonomic significance which helped to reinforce the results  of automated classification by computer.  The groupings resulting from both morphological and epidermal studies bear close correspondence to the groupings from the DCA and PCA.Evidences support the earlier moves of merger of Barombia with Aerangis, Rhipodoglossum with Diaphananthe and Encheridion with Microcoelia.  Further findings revealed that Tridactyle,  Solenangis and Dinklageella fit better in the Angraecinae than Aerangidinae.  For now, Solenangis and Dinklageella should continue to be maintained as distinct taxa while Listrostachys is better included in the Aerangidinae rather than Angraecinae.An indented, computer-aided key was prepared for the 100 OTU's which included 14 new records for West Africa.  The 37 characters used for the key-construction were coded according to the DELTA (Descriptive Language for TAxonomy) format to run the Key Constructing Program (KCONP), on an IBM Compatible Microcomputer System. The resulting automated key was stored in a floppy disc which is kept in the herbarium of the Department of Botany, Obafemi Awolowo University.  The automated key was tested on herbarium specimens and found adequate.|Theses Collection|angraecoid orchids/taxonomists/epidermal and pollinaria features/vegetative morphology/epidermis and pollinaria system /herbarium/Department of Botany, Obafemi Awolowo University*||||||Olanipekun, Samson Oloyede|M|A Study of the Rural Development Programmes of the Ogun-Oshun River Basin Development Authority (O-ORBDA). ||||||Ph.D.|Akinade Olumuyiwa Sanda.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, public Administration|1991.|||OAU|||||xx, 238p. |||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This work appraised the impact of State intervention in the management of rural development programmes through the institution of River Basin Development Authorities with particular reference to OgunOshun River Basin Development Authority (OORBDA) which covers Lagos, Oyo and Ogun States.  The work examined the extent to which the Authority was able to improve the socioeconomic environment of the rural communities through its programmes and services.  Such programmes included agriculture improvement schemes and water resources development activities. Furthermore, in view of the transfer of its agricultural production activities to other agencies like the Directorate of Foods, Roads and Rural Infrastructure (DFRRI), this study explored the range of functions left for O-ORBDA.In contrast to the high level of success associated with the River Basin Strategy in some countries such as the famous Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) in the United States of America (USA), the achievements recorded by the O-ORBDA fell below expectation.  This low performance level could be explained in terms of the peculiar problems confronting the River Basin Authority.  The problems included government policy reversal and those of inadequacy of funds and technological expertise which the River Basin Authority would require for effective performance.The methodology adopted is impact study with a focus on an appraisal of the stated goals of the organisation. Preliminary data on the Authority's activities were gathered from its headquarters.  This provided background information which stimulated further investigations.  A questionnaire was administered on management and project staff of the Authority.  They were also interviewed on issues relating to the successes and failures of the programmes of the Authority.  Another questionnaire was used to ferret out information from 2,850 inhabitants of project area.  This figure included 1,040 or 62% of the 1,653 participating farmers and 1,810 other beneficiaries of the Authority's programmes.The study discovered that the Federal government had reviewed its involvement in the sustenance of high  cost irrigation projects.  This resulted in the existing array of uncompleted projects in OORBDA's jurisdiction.  Furthermore, the study showed that the Authority could not provide rural infrastructures to any significant extent as it was not fully equipped to perform that role. OORBDA recorded greater success in its agricultural production activities (now expunged from its schedule) more than it did in the provision of good roads, housing, electricity or health care delivery.  This was due to the inadequacy of resources available to it. A major implication of the findings is that O-ORBDA cannot be totally relieved of participating in agricultural production activities as it now provides irrigation water.  Besides, it is important that the Authority relates with the farmers to enable the latter accept its role and consequently patronise it. This patronage would in fact make the OORBDA viable and be less dependent on the Federal government's financial support.|Theses collection.|State intervention/rural development programmes/River Basin Development Authorities/Directorate of Foods, Roads and Rural Infrastructure (DFRRI)/high  cost irrigation projects/ rural infrastructures/agricultural production*||||||Bamire, Simeon Adebayo|M| Risk and Farm Investment among Farmers in OdoOtin Local Government Area of Oyo State, Nigeria.||||||M. Phil. Agricultural Economics|O.L. Oludimu||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Agricultural Economics| 1991.|||OAU|||||xi, 99p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The major objective was to estimate quantitatively the Interrelationship between risk, investment decisions and household socioeconomic characteristics.  Data were collected from 160 farmers randomly selected from eight villages in Odo Otin LGA of Oyo state making use of structured questionnaire. These were then analysed through the use of safetyfirst model, Linear programming technique and discriminant analysis.Results from the safetyfirst model showed that farmers in the study area can be categorised into two namely: Risk Averse and Risk Preferring. It also indicated that about 81 percent of the farmers exhibit risk aversion.  The Linear Programming technique showed the effect of risk on the profitability of farmers' investments. Risk preferring farmers were found to be compensated by a higher return on their investment compared to those who exhibit risk averse behaviour. The discriminant Analysis technique however revealed that socioeconomic characteristics such as Land area,  level of schooling, offfarm income and membership of farming groups are positively associated with risk bearing.  It also supports the results obtained from the safetyfirst rule.
