Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.| The objectives of the study were to: analyse the price behaviour of Nigeria's palm produce economy over the period 19731987; evaluate the performance of the regression and timeseries models using historical simulation of price data; and forecast future values of the price series using regression and combined regressiontime series models.The time series data used for this study were obtained from the publications of the Central Bank of Nigeria, and  Federal Office of Statistics. A regression model was selected for each of the palm produce price data (palm oil price series and palm kernel price series) and then time series models were constructed for each regression residual series.The results of the regression analysis lend credence to the claim that statistical elegance of an econometric model is not directly related to its ability to forecast well. The RootMean-Square (RMS) simulation error, RMS forecast error and Theil coefficient (U2) of the linear models (having lower fit) were 95.97, 183.53 and 0.985 respectively for palm oil and 43.19, 52.76 and 1.05 respectively for palm kernel, whilst those of the double log models (having better fit) were 97.6, 201.17 and 1.08 respectively for palm oil and 43.84, 61.08 and 1.21 respectively for palm kernel.The combined regression  time series models (obtained by combining each residual time series model with respective regression model) out performed the regression models (though not appreciably particularly for palm oil price series). The RMS simulation error, RMS forecast error and U2 of (palm kernel) combined model were 85.27, 44.22 and  .878 respectively, whilst those of regression model were 93.73, 52.76 and 1.05 respectively.  For the (palm oil) combined models the values were 221.8l, 318.98 and 1.71 respectively  whilst those of the regression model were 230.52, 183.53 and 0.985 respectively.  In addition, the combined models provide better forecast of trends in prices of palm produce than the regression models.The results of the supply analysis indicated that the equations estimated using predicted palm produce prices obtained from the combined models provide better approximation (in terms of goodnessoffit and exhibited relationships) to the actual models than those estimated using predicted palm produce prices obtained from the regression models.|Theses collection.|Nigeria's palm produce/Central Bank of Nigeria/Federal Office of Statistics/conometric model/RootMean-Square (RMS) simulation error/RMS forecast error / Theil coefficient (U2)*||||||Osunade, James Adewale|M| Studies on the Suitability of Laterized Concrete for Grain Storage Silo|||||| Ph.D| Fola Lasisi||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University, Agricultural  Engineering| 1991|||OAU|||||xv, 216p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|In  the tropics, there are considerable losses of farm produce before, during and after harvest as well as during storage. Therefore, postharvest storage protections are essential in  order to reduce loses in agricultural produce particularly in  grains.  The complete absence or inadequate storage facilities on the farm seriously contribute to unaccountable loss of quality in grains for processing and consumption. In an attempt to produce an adequate storage structure having local material content, this project looks into the suitability of laterized concrete as a material for the construction of storage silos. Tests for workability, strength characteristics, physical and thermal properties including coefficient of friction of grain on wall materials, angle of internal friction, specific heat and thermal conductivity were carried out on the laterized concrete used in designing the silos.  Indices such as grain moisture variation, level of mould development, insects infestation, viability and changes in nutrient content of grains were used to evaluate the effectiveness of the laterized concrete silos.  The temperatures inside laterized concrete and metal silos were observed in response to changes in the external temperatures.  Mathematical expressions were developed for predicting temperature and moisture distribution  within the stored grains.  The expressions were tested.A slump value of 37.7mm and an average strength of 16.27N/mm2 were obtained for laterized concrete.  Of the three materials of construction tested, galvanized sheet metal gave the lowest coefficient of friction of 0.16 followed by plywood 0.33, and laterized concrete 0.35. Changes in the measured and simulated temperatures and moisture content for laterized concrete were smaller than those for the metal silos.  There were also lower levels of insect infestation, mould development and moisture content (below 14.5 per cent) in the laterized concrete.The results suggest that the design pressure for laterized concrete silo should be based not only on the load imposed on the wall by the grains but also on the frictional property of laterized concrete wall. The results further suggest that laterized concrete silos are better than metal silos for storing maize grains.|Theses collection.| tropics/farm produce/storage/ postharvest storage protections /grains/ local material content/ laterized concrete /coefficient of friction of grain/ grain moisture variation/mould development/insects infestation/changes in nutrient content/ metal silos*||||||Farinde, Akinloye Jimoh|M|Effectiveness of Extension Methods used in Disseminating Improved Agricultural 	Technologies in Lagos State|||||| M. Phil| A. A. Jobowo||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University, Agricultural Extension and Rural Sociology|1991|||OAU|||||xvi, 282p|||||||Eglish||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The  focus of this study was to determine the effectiveness of extension methods used in disseminating improved agricultural technologies in Lagos state. Emphases were placed on identification of the various extension methods used by the Lagos state Agricultural Development Projects (LSADP) extension workers and how the methods were selected; identification of the improved agricultural technologies disseminated to the farmers with the extension method(s), identification of the teaching aids used with the extension method(s) in disseminating each improved agricultural technology, and determination of the impact of the extension methods used on the level of adoption of improved agricultural technologies by the farmers.The study was conducted in five rural local government areas in Lagos state, out of the twelve local government areas in the State.  Structured interview schedule was used to collect information from one hundred and twelve fulltime male farmers in the project enclave, while structured questionnaire was completed by all the Lagos state ADP's extension workers. Fourteen circles under the five extension area units, two villages under each circle and four farmers from each village were  selected using the simple random sampling technique.  Descriptive statistical techniques like frequency counts, percentages, mean standard deviation and weighted mean score were used to analyse the data.  Correlation and regression analyses were used to determine the relationships between the variables investigated in the study. The results showed that all the extension workers found method and result demonstrations and farm visit as the  most appropriate and effective  methods  for disseminating all the improved agricultural technologies to the farmers.   About 87% of the extension workers selected their extension teaching methods based on the number of farmers to be reached and nature of practices to teach farmers. Inventory of the agricultural technologies showed that about fifteen improved agricultural technologies had been disseminated to farmers in Lagos state since the inception of LSADP in 1987. Specimen and record books were found most frequently used teaching aids with all the methods identified.  Eightyeight  percent of the farmers had adopted more than ten of the  improved agricultural technologies hence farmer's level of adoption was high.The study showed positive  and significant correlations between adoption of recommended practices and complexity of method (r = 0.042),  organization  of method (r = 0.334), extension workers' attitude towards self (r = 0.594), extension workers' years of formal training received (r = 0.395), size of the farm (r = 0.230) and cosmopoliteness (r = 0.206). Also, it shows negative but significant correlations between adoption of improved agricultural technologies and farmers' age (r = 1.814) and extension workers' knowledge of improved agricultural technologies (r = 0.339). To enhance methods' effectiveness, reliance must be placed on the use of the individual and group contact methods and obstacles such as cost, such as cost, complexity and difficulty in the organization of mass media methods should be removed for their effective uses.|Theses collection.| agricultural technologies/Lagos state Agricultural Development Projects (LSADP)/ farm visit/ extension workers/years of formal training*||||||Mwaseba, Dismas|M|Popular Participation in Rural Development Projects in Morogoro District of Tanzania||||||M.Phil| Joseph Adebanji Alao||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University  , Agricultural  Extensions and Rural Sociology| 1991||| OAU|||||xv, 174p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|.The study sought to determine the level of participation in selected rural development projects and identify  characteristics associated with it. The population was stratified by sex and the simple random sampling technique was used to draw 15 men and 15 women from each of the four study villages.  Consequently, the total sample size was 120.Interview schedule was used in eliciting relevant responses from the respondents.  Informal interviews were also conducted to supplement the data obtained through the interview schedule.  Data collection took place from July 15 to August 31, 1990.  The data collected were analysed through the use of such statistical methods as simple frequency counts, percentages, chisquare (X2) and contingency coefficient (C).The study found that the level of participation in the selected rural development projects undertaken communally was generally low.  It also found that 79.2% and 57.5% of the respondents participated in the implementation of the projects and election of village leaders respectively.  The study further found that 19.2%, 18.3%, 10.8% and 8.2% of the respondents respectively participated in decisionmaking, problem identification, planning and evaluation.  Despite the low level of participation in the projects, an overwhelming majority (94.4%) of the respondents assessed the projects as successful. The study also revealed that participation of the people in communal projects was hindered by individual and leadershiprelated problems.  The major problems related to the individuals that hindered participation in communal projects were personal commitments and poor health.  The major problems related to the leadership that hindered participation were lack of leadership accountability, poor organisation, favouritism and nepotism and lack of regular communication between the leaders and their followers about project progress.Statistically significant relationships were found between level of participation in communal projects and sex (X2 = 13.14), age (X2 = 7.03), membership in organisations (X2 = 10.18) and the mode of joining the projects (X2 = 17.59) at 0.05 level of significance.  Specifically, the data showed that a great number of men, members of organisations and respondents who joined the projects voluntarily and through persuasion participated in the projects more than women, nonmembers and those who joined the projects through coercion respectively.  The data also showed that a great number of respondents in the age group of 3655 years participated in the projects more than those in the other two age groups, namely below 35 years and above 55 years. No statistically significant relationships were found between the level of participation and the selected community characteristics, that is, level of village development (X2= .05), average number of ethnic groups (X2 .77) and village size (X2 .50) at 0.05 level of significance.   To promote popular participation in development, efforts should be made to encourage village leaders to make effective use of participatory structures such as the village assembly and embark on programmes aimed at overcoming the aforementioned problems.|Theses collection.|rural development projects/communal projects/leadershiprelated problems/ poor health/leadership accountability/poor organisation/favouritism and nepotism/ communal projects and sex*||||||Siyanbola, Adewale Tajudeen|M| Characteristics of Local Leaders and Adoption of some Agricultural Innovations in Ede North Rural Development Project Area||||||M. Phil| Adegboyega A. Jibowo||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University  /Agricultural Extension and Rural Sociology|1991||| OAU|||||xix, 265p||||||| English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The main aim of this study was to determine the effects of the characteristics of local leaders on the adoption of agricultural innovations in the Ede North Rural Development Project Area.  Attention was focused on the personal, socio-economic and leadership characteristics of the respondents and adoption of the agricultural innovations introduced by the Department of Agricultural Extension and Rural Sociology, Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife.Data were collected from one-hundred and two leaders and seventy-eight non-leaders in three villages in the project area during the months of January and February, 1991.  Structured interview schedules containing open and closed ended questions duly pretested were used to collect the data.  Leadership identification was done by positional and reputational techniques. The non-leaders interviewed were selected through simple random sampling.The study showed that leaders emerged more from the older male (84.3%), indigenous members of the community who had large families and more economic resources than others.  The identified leaders were also fairly educated with 5.70 years as the mean period of schooling.  The major criterion for recognising people as community leaders were: ability and willingness to contribute to community development which was mentioned by 60.8% of the leaders; economic base, 51.4%; and official position, 45.1%.The innovations studied had wide-spread adoption among leaders and non-leaders who were aware of them.  These included hybrid maize which was adopted by 92.2% and 86.3% of leaders and non-leaders respectively; improved cassava variety, 69.7% and 77.6%; fertilizers, 66.7% and 49%; improved sheep management, 95.0% and 97.6%; improved goat management, 83.6% and 73.1%; pre-emergent herbicides, 68.0% and 80.6%; crib, 48.6% and 57.1% and post- emergent herbicides, 94.1% and 73.3%.Cribs for grain storage and application of post-emergent herbicides were the only innovations of which the respondents were not widely aware.  Only 36.3% and 17.9% of leaders and non-leaders respectively indicated awareness of the crib as an innovation and 33.3% and 29.5% respectively of leaders and non-leaders were aware of post-emergent herbicides.Positive and significant relationships were found between adoption of innovation by leaders and age (r = 0.213); years of schooling (r = 0.197); years of residence (r = 0.312); cheerfulness (r = 0.296), and consideration (r = 0.514).  These mean that the greater the degree of these characteristics possessed by leaders, the greater the extent of their adoption of the agricultural innovations.Consideration was found to be positively and significantly associated with cheerfulness among leaders (r = 0.319) and non-leaders (r = 0.260).  This means that consideration increased with cheerfulness among both categories of respondents. Future leadership training programme should be organised in such a way to help leaders imbibe the culture of consideration and cheerfulness in dealing with their followers|Theses collection.|agricultural innovations /indigenous members/economic resources/hybrid maize/.improved cassava variety/pre-emergent herbicides/ grain storage*||||||Odubote, Idowu Kolawole|M|Genetic and non-genetic sources of variation in litter size, kidding interval and body weight at various ages in West African dwarf goats||||||Ph.D| J.O. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Records on eight hundred and forty-eight West African Dwarf Goat kids sired by eleven bucks mated to a total of one hundred and thirty does were used for this study. The records were obtained from the Nigerian-Dutch Research Project "Management of the West African Dwarf Goats in the humid tropics" sited at the goat unit of the Obafemi Awolowo University Teaching and Research Farm, Ile-Ife, Nigeria.The mean kidding interval and litter size at birth were 283.15 6.79 days and 1.70 0.04 kids respectively.  Parity, season and year of birth effects were significant (P < 0.01) for kidding interval.  Parity also had significant (P < 0.01) effect on litter size at birth.  The average litter size at weaning was 1.22 0.08 kids.Mean body weight at birth, 13 weeks, weaning, 26, 39 and 52 weeks of age were 1.280.01kg, 5.390.05kg, 6.260.05kg, 7.810.07kg, 9.960.09kg and 12.340.12kg respectively. The genetic correlations among body weights at the various ages were positive and significant (P < 0.01).An Annual Reproductive Rate of 2.19 kids and Productivity Index of 9.88Kg at weaning were obtained.  Litter weaning weight appears to be the best criterion for selection to improve body weights. A. Akinyemiju||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University ,Plant Science |1991|||  OAU |||||xii, 91p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Effect of methods of establishment, planting date and population density on grain amaranth production were investigated.  Field studies were carried out to evaluate the influence of methods of establishment, planting date and population on the agronomic performance of three Ameranthus species:  Amaranthus cruentus L., A. hybridus L., and A. hypochondriacus L.  Also investigated in the screenhouse were the appropriate herbicides for controlling weeds in grain Amaranths. The results showed that the Amaranthus species performed better in the early season than in the late season.  Generally, seeds planted with sawdust emerged earlier than in the other methods of establishment.  Drilled, hillplanted and transplanted plants grew taller, had more inflorescences and produced higher grain yield than sawdust-treated plants.Generally, the Amaranth species performed better in the May and June planting dates than in the August or September planting dates.  Plants were taller with more branches longer inflorescences, larger leaf area and better grain yields in May and June than in August and September plantings.  Grain yield per plant was highest at 40,000 plants/ha. However, the highest grain yield/ha irrespective of the species and date of planting was obtained at the highest population density of 160,000 plants per ha.  A. hypochondriacus produced the highest grain yield of 917 and 886 kg/ha in May and June, respectively at 160.000 plants/ha.In the screenhouse, the Amaranthus species responded similarly to the herbicide treatments; alachlor, diuron, metolachlor, and metribuzin were phytotoxic to the amaranth plants when applied preemergence, irrespective of the time of application, while imazaquin was lethal to the plants.  Alachlor, diuron, metolachlor and metribuzin applied postemergence were slightly toxic to the plants.  However, the toxicity symptoms disappeared later and subsequent growth and grain yield per plant were not adversely affected.  Bentazon was slightly toxic to the plants irrespective of the time of application and this toxicity was also overcome at the later stage of growth.  At the two times of application, fluazifopbutyland sethoxydim were nonphytotoxic to the plants irrespective of the species.  The plants treated with bentazon, fluazifopbutyl and sethoxydim, irrespective of the time of application, had similar length and dry weight of inflorescence and grain yield per plant with the control, indicating that these herbicides can be used selectively weed control in grain amaranth.|Theses collection.|planting date/ population density/ grain amaranth production/Ameranthus species/herbicides/ inflorescences/sawdust-treated plants/Grain yield per plant/screenhouse*||||||Bewaji, Francis Akinlabi|M|A Survey and Herbicidal Control of Water Hyacinth and Associated Aquatic Weeds found in Ilaje/EseOdo Local Government Area of Ondo State, Nigeria||||||M. Phil|O.A. Akinyemiju||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University , Plant Science|1991|||OAU||||| xiv, 135p.||||||| English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Studies were conducted at the Ilaje/EseOdo Local Government Area (LGA) of Ondo State in 1988 and 1989 to provide data on the abundance of water hyacinth (Eiehhornia crassipes (Mart.) Solms) and associated aquatic weeds found in the water ways of the LGA.  Information was also obtained on the phytotoxicity of herbicides on the predominant weeds, the persistence of the herbicides in water, and water quality changes following a herbicidal control of the weeds in the screen house.     In the aquatic weed surveys, density of the weeds was determined from 1m2 floatable quadrats. Measurements were also made on some growth parameters of selected flowering water hyacinth plants.  The phytotoxicity of asulam (Methyl [(4aminopheny1) sulfony1] carbamate), 2,4D  [(2,4dichlorophenoxy) acetic acid], Actril DS, a formulated mixture of Ioxynil (4hydroxy3,5diiodobenzonitrile) + 2,4D, diquat [6,7dihydrodipyrido (1,2(x :2, 1-C) pyrazine diium ion], paraquat (1,1dimethyl4, 4-bipyridinium ion), glyphosate [N(Phosphonomethyl) glycine)] and terbutryn [N(1,1dimethylethyl)N ethyl6(methylthio)1,3,5triazine2,4diamine] each foliarly applied at two rates on water hyacinth and water lettuce (Pistia stratiotes Linn.) was monitored for 28 days after application in the screen house.  The persistence of 2,4D, diquat, paraquat, and terbutryn was also monitored in water for 12 weeks following their application on water hyacinth and water lettuce. Residues of herbicides in water samples were extracted by standard procedures and analysed using a UVSpectrophotometer.  The physicochemical parameters of water quality were determined by standard methods.Water hyacinth was the most predominant aquatic weed (72% abundance) followed by water lettuce (17%).  Eleven other    identified weeds were low in abundance (11%).  Three forms of water hyacinth (small, medium and giant forms) wore identified.  The smallest form has a mean height of 11cm and nonbulbous leaf petioles; the medium form has a mean height of 19cm and is characterised by bulbous leaf petioles while the giant form has a mean height of 89 cm and nonbulbous leaf petioles. Both water hyacinth and water lettuce were susceptible to a single spray application of 2,4D, diquat and paraquat each at 2.0 kg a.i./ha, ioxynil + 2,4D at 3.0 kg a.i./ha and terbutryn at 1.0 kg a.i./ha. Glyphosate at 1.5 and 3.0 kg a.i./ha was not effective on water hyacinth although found effective on water lettuce, while asulam at 2.0 and 4.0 kg a.i./ha was not effective on any of the two weeds.Herbicide residues increased from an initial low level (0.001  0.25 ppm) immediately following application to a peak value of 0.52 ppm at 2 weeks after treatment (WAT) in water lettuce, and 0.66 ppm at 4 WAT in water hyacinthculture tanks.  By 6 and 10 WAT no residue was detected in water lettuce and water hyacinthculture tanks, respectively, irrespective of herbicide treatments.Water temperature, pH, and some major nutrients which were low under the cover of water hyacinth and water lettuce increased due to mineralisation of the dead and decaying weeds following herbicide application. Dissolved oxygen was however low due to the presence of weeds and its utilization by microorganisms responsible for the decaying of dead weeds. The results of this study show that herbicides when carefully selected and applied have potentials for the control of water hyacinth and water lettuce in Nigeria.|Theses collection.|abundance of water hyacinth/ aquatic weeds/phytotoxicity of herbicides/screen house/bulbous leaf petioles/ spray application/Water temperature/ pH/Dissolved oxygen*||||||Amusan, Alani adeagbo|M|Pedogenesis in granitic gneiss of humid tropical Southwestern Nigeria|||||| Ph.D|T.I. Ashaye||Ile Ife, Nigeria Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University, Soil Science|1991||| OAU|||||xiii, 205p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The genesis of granitic gneiss derived soils in the upland areas of humid tropical Southwestern Nigeria was studied.  Four modal deep soil profiles representing the dominant soil series of Iwo and Ondo formed from coarse and medium-grained granitic gneiss were selected.  Morphological, physical, chemical and mineralogical changes resulting from rock-saprolite-soil transformations were studied.The solum depth for both soil types ranges from 180-273 cm and the saprolite extends beyonds 3m.  The surface 0-20cm horizon is slightly gravelly (2-16%), coarse sandy loam, and dark bronw (7.5 YR 4/2 YR 3/3).  The sub-soil at 20-75cm is uniformly yellowish red (5 YR 4/6) in Iwo series and strong brown (7.5 YR 5/6) to red (2.5 YR 4/6) in Ondo series and gravelly (27-42%) sandy clay loam to sandy clay.  The subsequent underlying horizons are mottled.A consideration loss of the basic cations and silica occurs during rock-saprolite-soil weathering with residual accumulation of Fe and Al oxides.  Experimental leaching of the rock-sample sufficiently confirms these observations, and also suggests hydrolytic weathering.  Factors suggested to have encouraged hydrolytic weathering in Southwestern Nigeria are high rainfall, continuously high soil temperature, acidic precipitation and siliceous parent rock.  The cation exchange capacity by summation method (CEC-sum) ranges from 12.46 - 26.06 and 13.68 - 22.54 me/100g soil in Iwo and Ondo series respectively.  Percentage base surface is less than 35% for both series.  The relatively high amount of pH-dependent charges (PDC) and DCB-Fe2O3 indicate that the soils are intensively weathered.The fine sand of Iwo series contains predominantly quartz (50-80%) and hydrous mica (5-30%), while quartz (85-95%) dominates with traces of kaolinite in Ondo series.  Feldspar, hydroxy-Al-interlayered vermiculite, maghemite and kaolonite occur in small amounts in Iwo series.  Quartz (45-60%), kaolinite (5-10%) and hydrous mica (5-10%) dominate the silt fraction in Iwo series but mainly kaolinite (20-60%) and quartz (20-60%) in Ondo series.  Gibbsite, goethite, metahalloysite and hydrous mica also occur in the silt fraction in small amounts.  The clay fraction in Iwo series contains kaolinite (50-60%), hydrous mica (8-10%), metahalloysite (8-10%), gibbsite (8-10%) and quartz (4-8%).  In Ondo series, the clay fraction is predominantly kaolinite (> 80%) with about 10% metahalloysite.Ferrallitic pedogenesis is proposed for the soils.  Lessivation, induration and braunification are recognised as other dominant pedogenetic processes.  The study indicates that Ondo series are more developed than Iwo and that the occurrence of gibbsite is not necessarily an indication of advanced weathering stage in soils of Iwo series in SW-Nigeria.|Theses collection.| granitic gneiss /humid tropical Southwestern Nigeria/mineralogical changes/solum depth/ basic cations/silica/ rock-saprolite-soil weathering/ hydrolytic weathering/ quartz/Ferrallitic pedogenesis*||||||Afolayan, Stephen  Funsho|M|External and Socio-Political Transformation in Pre-Colonial Igbomina||||||Ph.D|I.A. Akinjogbin||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University    History|1991||| OAU |||||xi, 461p||||||| English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This thesis examined the impact of external relation on state formation among the pre-colonial Igbomina, a distinct Yoruba dialectal and frontier cultural group who occupy central Nigeria.  It evaluated the nature of autochthonous existence and the level of sociopolitical development in Igbomina before the emergence of the dynastic states.  It then assessed the relations of the Igbomina with their neighbours, namely, the Edo, Ijesa, Ekiti, Oyo, Nupe, Ibadan and Fulani.  The trends and patterns of external domination, the responses of the Igbomina to these external contacts, and their impact on the Igbomina were discussed.The methodology employed consisted of the analysis of primary and secondary sources, on the Yoruba, Nupe and Fulani, the three ethnic groups with dominant imperial interests in the area.  An extensive and intensive oral investigation was carried out in the study area.  Various categories of oral sources, archival and official records, and existing ethnographic, linguistic  and archaeological data were collected, corroboratively and critically examined.The thesis found that, contrary to popular traditions, the advent of the Ife-Oyo migrant groups in Igbomina area was not the beginning of the peopling of the region. It also discovered, that there is no credence in the generally accepted tradition of a common origin, common migration and similar antiquity for the various Igbomina groups. The thesis showed that the various Igbomina groups came to their different locations from  different places, for various reasons and at different times.  The study further found that the location of Igbomina in the middle belt of Nigeria, and on the frontiers of the Nupe, Oyo and Fulani, made it an area of plural cultural interactions and a focal point in the struggle for power and supremacy among these more powerful neighbours.The thesis concluded that the forces of external pressure were the most dominant factors in the development of Igbomina society.  External contacts resulted not only in ruins and desolation but in a profound lasting social, economic, demographic, political and military transformation of the society.  The Igbomina became prone and vulnerable to external dominion because of their internal decentralisation; conversely, external domination resulted in internal socio-political transformation which paved the way for unification and the emergence of the Igbomina as a district sub-group of the Yoruba.|Theses collection.|pre-colonial Igbomina/frontier cultural group/central Nigeria/ autochthonous existence/sociopolitical development/dynastic states/external domination/imperial interests/internal decentralisation*||||||Ashe, Muesiri Oberorakpovioma|F| The Evolution and Impact of local Government Administration in Eastern Urhobo Area of Bendel State, 1952 - 1983||||||M.A|A.A. Adediran // A. Aborisade||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University, History| 1991|||OAU|||||xi, 132p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This work attempts to contribute to our understanding of the operation of the local government system in Nigeria.  It focuses on  the Eastern Urhobo area of Bendel State.  The research methodology employed includes the collection and systematic evaluation of documentary evidence, oral information and archival materials.  These are supplemented by published works.  The analysis indicates that by 1983 the Eastern Urhobo were yet to find a satisfactory local government institution to replace the one that was abolished by the British in 1900.  It is also clear that starting with the Native Courts proclamation of 1900 and Native Authority ordinance of 1916, Eastern Urhoboland witnessed various changes in the search for a viable local government system up to 1983.  In addition, it is found that the local authority system did not have much significant impact on the area during the period under consideration. This is because the Eastern Urhobo local government authority was faced with two sets of problems.  The first set was the internal weaknesses within the local government council.  The other was the general shortcoming of the local government system in Nigeria. Finally, the study shows  that the already existing macrostudies in the field have created some problems of generalisation that can hardly be resolved without researches at a microlevel.|Theses collection.|local government system in Nigeria/Eastern Urhobo area / Bendel State/British/ Native Courts proclamation of 1900/ Native Authority ordinance of 1916*||||||Aregbesola,Michael Oluwole|M|A Critical Examination of the Nature of Perception and Knowledge in Plato's Theaetetus|||||| M.A|J.T.Bedu-Addo||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University     Philosophy|1991|||OAU||||| xii, 171p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This thesis attempted a detailed examination of the nature of perception and knowledge in Platot's dialogues.  Attention was thus focussed on the first definition of knowledge offered in the dialogue  Theaetetus, namely, that knowledge its perception (151E186E).  This consideration necessitated a comprehensive elucidation of the analysis of perception contained in that section of the dialogue.  Furthermore, this study examined Plato's argument against the thesis that knowledge is perception.  It also evaluated the veracity of Plato's view of the role of sense- perception in the process of acquiring knowledge.The methodology employed in this study was a combination of critical analysis and argumentation.  Specifically, Plato's major dialogues such as the The Theaetetus, the Phaedo, the Timaeus and the Republic, and other relevant texts and commentaries were assessed.The thesis established that contrary to the assumption of some scholars that Plato's Theaetetus contains one continuous theory of perception, there are two different accounts of the nature of perception in the relevant section of the dialogue  the explicit and the implicit theories of perception.  It was also established that while Plato cannot be said to subscribe to the explicit theory, the implicit theory truly represented his view on perception as evident in the Timaeus, the Phaedo and the Republic.  The thesis concluded that in Plato's theory, the role of sense perception as a theory of knowledge is limited.|Theses collection.|Platot's dialogues/dialogueTheaetetus/critical analysis/argumentation/ Phaedo/Timaeus/the Republic/explicit theory/*||||||Ebijuwa, Temisanren|F|Women's Autonomy and the Problem of Abortion||||||M.A. Philosophy|M. Oke||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo University, Philosophy|1991||| OAU|||||vi, 117p||||||| English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This thesis studied the problem of abortion in the context of moral .  It examined the arguments for the case that abortion is immoral, and considered the relevance of various third-party interests in the fetus to the debate about the morality of abortion. The methodology employed was critical philosophical analysis of journal articles and standard texts published within the last twenty-five years in the area of moral philosophy and applied ethics.  In addition, some decided court cases on abortion and related matters were critically analysed.The thesis found that most of the discussions on the subject of abortion in moral philosophy have been based upon the mistaken assumption that in order to show that abortion is morally impermissible, all arguments must proceed from the status and the rights of the fetus, or from a third-party's interest in the fetus.  It was found that woman, as autonomous and rational agents, have the right to determine their role in procreation and have sovereignty over what is immediately affecting their lives.The thesis concluded that once we recognise that unwanted pregnancy is a threat to the health of the woman, and the state as acknowledges it as its duty to protect each of its citizens from even the minimum amount of threat, the state has a primafacie duty to provide abortion services to pregnant women seeking abortion.  To deny, withhold or curtail women's right to such services is to act immorally.|Theses collection.|abortion /third-party interests/fetus/critical philosophical analysis/unwanted pregnancy*||||||Oladoyin, Anthony Mayowa|M| A Comparative Study of Strawson and Aristotle on Particulars and Universals||||||M.A| J.T. Finally, the thesis examined the logicalontological status of particulars and universals.The methodology employed in this study was a combination of comparative, conceptual and critical analyses.  Major concepts such as universals and quality, essence and attribute, form and accident, were comprehensively analysed and examined. Olupona// J.O. Arulefela.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University   Religious Studies|1991||| OAU |||||x, 110p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Life in Ife traditional society is permeated by religion so much that there is hardly any aspect of life of the people which is not influenced by religious beliefs.  This study was therefore conducted to describe, from the perspectives of the lfe people themselves, the central ceremonies, myths and rituals in IleIfe religious life and to show the social and religious significance of these myths and rituals especially in the integration of Ife community.  It also examined the claim in the study of religions that myths precede rituals in religious world views of traditional peoples.A total of nineteen eminent traditional chiefs, herbalists, farmers, and traders of Ilelfe origin whose ages ranged between 50 years and 80 years were visited and interviewed orally. Personal observations were also made of some physical structures which had relevant significance to the study.  In addition secondary materials from libraries and museums were used. The data collected were subjected to a phenomenological analysis.The result of the study showed that myths and rituals are central to Ife religious world view.  It was revealed that the popular Ife religious myths relate to the lives of some heroes such as Ogun, Obatala, Moremi and heroines in lleIfe who have become deified as a result of their activities in the service of mankind.  It further showed  that myths and rituals in the traditional religion of Ife people are intricately related and intertwined so much so that it is difficult to know which one precedes the other.In addition it was revealed that the deeds and activities of the gods which constituted the central focus of the myths and rituals were in connection with the acquisition of power and medicine for the maintenance of the society and the kingdom.Finally, it was shown that a scholarly focus on myths and rituals would yield new and better perspectives on the nature and study of Yoruba traditional religious communities.|Theses collection.|Ife traditional society/ religious beliefs/rituals/ traditional chiefs/herbalists/ Ogun/Obatala/ Moremi/myths*||||||Adebajo, Olusola Oladipo|M|Agbeyewo Ise Awon Asiwaju Onkowe Yoruba lati Odun 1848 si Odun 1938||||||Ph.D|Akinwumi Isola||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University ,Yoruba Language & Literature| 1991||| OAU||||| xv, 394p|||||||Yoruba||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Our main concern in this work is a critical examination of the works of early Yoruba Writers from 1848 to 1938.  In realisation of this broad topic, this work is not hampered by the compartmentalisation always associated with literature viz categorisation under prose, poetry and drama, We examined Yoruba publications of the period in totality.  But because of our limited knowledge in the fields of linguistics and Yoruba Language, we excluded books on Yoruba language and the Dictionaries produced during the period under reference.  The specific objectives of this research are twofold.(a) This work critically examined the works of earliest Yoruba authors from 1848, when the first publication in Yoruba was produced, to 1938 when the late D.O. Fagunwa started the popularisation of the Yoruba novel, (b) It also examined in greater details the structural pattern and peculiar literary devices employed by each author.In order to successfully accomplish our task the following were our research methodology: (a)  The National Archives in Ibadan and Lagos and archival materials elsewhere were used. (b) Relevant materials in the State and Local Government libraries in Ibadan, Abeokuta, Akure, ljebuOde etc, were consulted. University Libraries especially the ones that stock old materials were made use of.  Examples of these are: the Africana Library of the University of Ibadan, the Institute of African Studies of the same University, the Gandhi Library of Lagos University and etc.  Besides, Corporate and personal libraries were made use of.  Examples are the S.S. Peter and Paul Library Ibadan, the libraries of Bishop Seith lrunsewe Kale and the late Reverend D.O. Epega.  (c)Elderly Yoruba men and women who themselves were editors of Yoruba Newspapers and authors of relevant books were interviewed.  Some of them are Paa Adegboyega Sobande who was editor of the popular Akede Eko and Chief T.T. Solaru, a retired Methodist Bishop. (d) Our findings and materials were then collated and critically examined.Chapter one of the thesis traces the activities of Christian. missionaries, the reduction of Yoruba Language to writing and the life history of some of the authors at the time and what prompted them to write Yoruba books.  Chapter two is devoted to the structure of the books.  Chapters three and four treat in details the content of the books under literature and NonLiterature books respectively. The  fifth chapter is devoted to the critical examination of the particular literary devices employed by the authors. The concluding part gathers the threads of thoughts together highlighting our findings viz: (a)  that no formal attempt has been made so far for the collection and critical examination of a mixedgrill kind of work as we now present, (b) that nonLiterature books have their own intrinsic values for the literary critic, and attention is being drawn to this area for further studies.  |Theses collection.|early Yoruba Writers/Yoruba publications/linguistics/National Archives/Christian. missionaries/Akede Eko/NonLiterature books*||||||Akinyemi, Akintunde|M|Ilo Oriki Lawujo Ilu Oyo|||||| Ph.D|Akinwumi Isola||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University ,Yoruba Language and Literature|1991||| OAU|||||xvii, 530p|||||||Yoruba||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|From available literature on oriki n Yoruba, it seems that no detailed study has been undertaken on the uses of oriki in Oyo town.  This thesis is therefore an attempt to cover part of the vacuum.  This thesis aimed at examining the Oyo town example of the uses of oriki in Yoruba societies. It aimed at identifying, describing and reappraising the various forms of Yoruba oriki. It also aimed at examining and describing the ubiguitous but changing nature of oriki in some selected oral literature in Oyo town. The sociopolitical and economic contexts of the creation and function of oriki in Oyo town were also examined.The methodology employed consisted of the analysts of data collected from the field on oriki.  An extensive and intensive oral investigation was carried out in the study area.  Various categories of archival and library records, and existing historical and literary data were collected and critically examined. For the purpose of our analysis, we adopted a Marxist sociology of literature approach in its broadest sense.The thesis found that the popular convention that oriki is the essence and the most dominant element of the content of most of the Yoruba oral literature is also true of the oral genres in town. In addition, the thesis found out that rara, a popular variety of Oyo chant, was a chanted variety of oriki, in which various types of personal names, personal oriki, nickname, appellation, individual oriki and orile play a prominent part.  The thesis also discovered that oriki forms the basis of all the Oyo traditional religious chants used in the worship of their Orisa. The thesis discovered, however, that contrary to popular convention, the role played by oriki in the creation of oral literature in Oyo town varies from one genre to the other.  The thesis further found that, the content of oriki, as used in Oyo traditional society is meant to defend project and protect the ideological views of the ruling class. The thesis also observed that the present economic changes and their attendant  social values had affected the uses and role of oriki in the creation of oral literature in the present-day Oyo town. The thesis concluded that the term is more elastic in Oyo town than a mere 'praise', 'descriptive" or 'lineage' poetry when compared with the ones in other Yoruba towns.  Oriki is equivalent to names  names which can indicate undesirable as well as desirable qualities and which are seen as being in some way the key to a subject's essential nature. In short, oriki situates a person or thing within his or its society.  In a society like the Oyo town, where poetry is the main vehicle of expression for ideological views and also the main source of information about historical social structures, oriki is very important.|Theses collection.|oriki/Oyo town/Yoruba societies/popular convention/oral literature /Marxist sociology/rara*||||||Ayanwole, Samson Adeyeye|M|An Appraisal of the Effectiveness of the Workers' Education Programe of Osogbo Steel Rolling Company in Nigeria||||||M.A|T.O. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The study was designed to investigate the degree of effectiveness of some factors affecting workers' education programme in the Osogbo Steel Rolling Company (O.S.R.C.) in Nigeria.  It also aimed at examining whether there was a significant relationship between the objectives of workers' education as stated by management and the outcome as seen by both management and the workers of Osogbo Steel Rolling Company.  The study was undertaken with the belief that workers continuing education, which is an aspect of adult education, could promote efficiency and productivity in industries, as well as the development of human potentials, if such programmes were effectively executed.  The study also examined the scope, objectives, mode of practice, provisions of incentives and availability of facilities for the execution of workers' education in the O.S.R.C.The sample comprised 70 management staff and 70 workers making a total of 140 subjects randomly selected from the various departments of the company.  The instrument used to collect relevant data for the study was designated (AWEP0) 'Appraisal of  Workers' Education Programme Questionnaire'.  The data collected were then analysed by using the appropriate statistical methods like Spearman rank order correlation, t-test analysis.  Each hypothesis was tested at 0.01 level of significance.  Percentages were also used to identify the level of performance for each of the factors considered in the issue.The results of the study revealed that there was no significant difference between the objectives of workers' education as stated by management and the outcome as seen by the management and the workers of O.S.R.C. The study, however, found that the percentage effectiveness in terms of outcome of workers' education was found to be very high.  Similarly, the practice of different types of workers' education programmes at O.S.R.C. was found to have fallen below average (31.2%), and thd the commonly practised types were inservice training, onthejob training, and seminar. Again, the provision of workers' education facilities at O.S.R.C. has not been very encouraging (53.8%). The study revealed that, library   facilities were inadequate, while the provision of incentives for workers to participate in workers' education programmes in the company was also found to have fallen below average (47.2%). Fasokun.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University  , Continuing   Education|1991|||OAU||||| xxiv, 370p||||||| English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|.The study investigated the efficiency and effectiveness of resource allocation system in the implementation of adult education programmes in selected Nigerian Universities. The study investigated the level of interest in adult education, the popularity of adult education and the contributions of adult education to the final assessment (G.P.A.) of education students. The study too examined the criteria used for allocating resources in Nigerian Universities as well as the efficiency, adequacy or otherwise of such existing criteria.  The study also made an attempt to assess how effectively and efficiently the resources allocated are utilized by the departments of interest within the universities considered.The sample for the study consisted of three out of six universities commonly referred to as "first generation universities".  The universities were selected through random sampling procedure.  Two research instruments, 'The Resource Utilization Growth/Departmental Output Rating (RUG/DOR) Efficiency Index", and 'The Financial Resource Assessment Questionnaire, FRAQ' were developed and utilized to collect data from the sample population.  The data collected were analysed using various statistical instruments and models such as the ttest, chisquare, oneway ANOVA, twoway ANOVA, Spearman's Rank Correlation, the Turkey Test, the Bartlett test, the Kruskal-Wallis Test and the Randomised Complete Block Design (RCBD).  All hypotheses were tested at 0.05 level of significance.The results of the study indicated that there was a generally high interest in and popularity of adult education courses with sampled students having taken a mean load of 8 units of adult education courses for graduation, and above 96% of the sample having taken at least one adult education course for graduation.The results revealed that adult education courses were found to have contributed positively to the final assessment (G.P.A.) of the students, as illustrated by the fact that the average value of adult education (VAE) for the 147 sampled students was as high as +0.0119. The results also revealed that the Departments of Adult Education in the selected universities were consistently underfinanced in relation to other comparable departments throughout the period under investigation.  An indication of this is the fact that the growth rates in votes were found to be generally higher for Physical Education than for Adult Education in all the universities sampled.Finally, despite lower and dwindling financial resources, the results established the fact that Departments of Adult Education showed greater cost efficiency than the Departments of Physical Education, as indicated by their DOR values which were consistently higher on the average than that for Physical Education.|Theses collection.| resource allocation system/adult education programmes/Nigerian Universities /financial resources/The Resource Utilization Growth/Departmental Output Rating (RUG/DOR) Efficiency Index/ 'The Financial Resource Assessment Questionnaire, FRAQ*||||||Osuji, Basil Ebube|M|The  Relationship between Developmental Tasks and SocioDemographic Variables among Adult Learners in Ife Central Local Government Area of Oyo State.||||||M.A.|J.A. The study was undertaken with the belief that adult education could enhance the achievement of the developmental tasks if such adult education programmes are well organised. The study also examined the relative importance of the sociodemographic variables to adult learners' achievement of the developmental tasks.The study population comprised  1,000 adult learners enrolled in adult education classes from which stratified random sample of 300 was selected. Bases for stratification were gender, age, income  and occupational level groups.  The instrument used for the study was the 'Adulthood Developmental Tasks Questionnaire' (ADTQ) adapted from the list of Havighurst's developmental tasks. The research was designed to determine whether the sex, age and the focus or the training which was used on school setting could influence the effectiveness of assertive therapy.Subjects for the study were selected from Urban-Day Grammar School, lleIfe, through a stratified sampling procedure.  The sample, numbering fortyeight were equally divided and assigned to experimental and control groups with adequate consideration given to their ages and sexes. Two research instruments designated School Setting Questionnaire Measure of Assertiveness (SSQMA) and Out of Schoolenvironment Questionnaire Measure of Assertiveness (OSQMA) were administered on all subjects before and after the training to collect information on their level of assertiveness.  The data obtained were analysed using  appropriate statistical procedure namely mean standard deviation and ttest. The level  of significance was fixed at 0.05.The results of the data analysis revealed that assertiveness training had positive significant effect on low self esteem students in secondary schools.  A significant difference was also observed in the effects of assertiveness training on the two sexes. Furthermore, the result showed that there is a significant difference in the effect of assertiveness training on different age groups of early adolescence (1114 years) and late adolescence (1518 years). It was also discovered that assertiveness training based on school setting had an effect in solving other interpersonal problems encountered by the subjects outside the school.The findings of this study showed that assertive training should be given to students in secondary schools especially when they are entering secondary schools in order to place them on equal starting point with others who are good asserters.|Theses collection.| low self esteem /students/secondary schools/assertive therapy/sex/age*||||||Alao, Kayode Ayodeji|M|Demographic Variables and Vocational SelfConcept as Correlates of Career Decision-Making Among Students in some Nigerian Universities.||||||Ph.D. | Olu Makinde||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University, Education Foundation and Couselling|1991|||OAU||||| xviii, 320p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.| This study examined the relationship between students' vocational selfconcept  and demographic at background on the one hand and students' career decisionmaking skills on the other.  The demographic variables whose correlations with career decision making were investigated included under age, gender, birth position, religious background, parents' literacy status,  students' ethnic and faculty affiliations.  The study also investigated the effects of University setting on students' career  decision-making skills of planning, exploration and information processing.  The  subjects of the study were 678 undergraduate students selected through stratified random  sampling technique from Obafemi Awolowo University, llelfe; Ahmadu Bello University,  Zaria; University of Nigeria, Nsukka; Bendel State University, Ekpoma and Cross Rivers State University, Uyo.  Four test batteries namely, Demographic Data Inventory (DDI), the Vocational Self Concept Rating Scale (VSCRS), the Assessment of Career DecisionMaking (ACDM) and Career Development Inventory (CDI) were used to collect data.  Data gathered were analysed using chisquare, contingency coefficients, Pearson Product Moment Correlation, OneWay Analysis of Variances and Duncan's Multiple Comparison Test. All hypotheses were tested at 0.05 level of significance.The results of the study indicated that students' demographic background generally bears no significant relationship with students' career decisionmaking. About  82% of the students exhibiting high decisionmaking competence were from the major ethnic groups, while only 18% of the students from ethnic minorities exhibited high career decisionmaking competence despite the fact that ethnic minorities accounted for 37.7% of the subjects sampled.  Faculties of Education and Science accounted for the majority of subjects with high career decision making competence. These two faculties accounted for 62.2% of the students exhibiting high decisionmaking competence. Students' vocational selfconcept was found to be  to significantly related to career decisionmaking style.  The finding here confirmed that 87% of the students with highly crystallised vocational selfconcept also exhibited planful decisionmaking style, while 55.6% of students with poorly crystallised vocational selfconcept exhibited dependent or intuitive decisionmaking styles. Similarly, students' vocational selfconcept was also found to be significantly related to their careerplanning and career information processing skills.  However, no significant relationship was found between students vocational selfconcept and their career exploration skills. It was also found that career decisionmaking skills of planning, exploration and information processing bore significant correlations with one another.|Theses collection.|students' vocational selfconcept/parents' literacy status/ information processing/major ethnic groups/Faculties of Education*||||||Babajide, Ademola Deji|M|Psychological and Socio-Economic Correlates of Pensioner's Retirement-Life Satisfaction.||||||M. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This study examined the relationships between pensioners' retirementlife satisfaction and some psychological and socioeconomic variables, such as financial status, social participation and interaction, residential satisfaction health status, attitude towards death, relationship with significant others and neighbourhood satisfaction.  Furthermore, the effects of some of pensioners' demographic and occupational variables on their retirementlife satisfaction were investigated.  The variables were age, gender, marital status, family type, living arrangement, nature of retirement, retirement income and length of time in retirement. The subjects of this study consisted of two hundred pensioners that were selected by purposive sampling from Oyo, Ondo and Lagos States.  Nine hypotheses were generated for the study.  The data were collected through the administration of the Demographic and Occupational Data Inventory (for subjects personal and occupational information) and eight other measures.  These measures were the RetirementLife Satisfaction Index (RLSI), the Financial Status Questionnaire (FSQ), the Social Participation and Interaction Questionnaire (SPIQ), the Residential Satisfaction Questionnaire (RSQ), the Health Status Questionnaire (HSQ), the Attitude Towards Death Questionnaire (ATDQ), the Relationship with Significant Others Questionnaire (RWSOQ) ind the Neighbourhood Satisfaction Questionnaire (NSQ). The resulting data were analysed using Pearson ProductMoment Correlation, Multiple Regression, OneWay Analysis of Variance (OneWay ANOVA) and ttest statistics.  All the hypothesis were tested at 0.05 level of significance.The results of the study indicated that retirementlife satisfaction was positively and significantly related to financial status (r = 0.50), social participation and interaction (r = 0.35), residential satisfaction (r = 0.38), health status (r = 0.39), relationship with significant others (r = 0.66) and neighbourhood satisfaction (r=0.39). However, it has no relationship with  attitude towards death.  Other results also indicated that when all the variables specified above were considered with regard to their predictability of retirementlife satisfaction, the combination of financial status, relationship with significant others and health status accounted for half of the predictable variance in retirementlife satisfaction     0.72). In addition, it was found that the only significant predictors of retirementlife satisfaction were financial status, relationship with significant others and health status.The results also showed that there was a significant difference between the retirementlife satisfaction of pensioners in the different age groups with those in the younger age categories having higher.near, retirementlife satisfaction scores than those in the older age categories.  Furthermore, nature of retirement was found to have a significant effect on retirementlife satisfaction with voluntary retirees more satisfied than the nonvoluntary ones. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This study investigated the usefulness of the Joint Matriculation Examination (JME) in admitting students into Nigerian universities. Specifically, the study set out to examine the performance of the different categories of candidates who sat for JME and to assess the subsequent university academic performance of such students.  It also sought to compare the relative strength of the candidates entry qualifications as admission criteria. The study population consisted of 1,379 undergraduates randomly selected from the faculties of Arts, Education, Science, Social Sciences, Law and Pharmacy in three Nigerian universities.  The students were those in the 1987/88 and 1988/89 sets.  The JME scores, semester grade point averages (GPA's) and entry qualifications of the subjects were collected.For the 1987/88 set, GPA's were collected for the first three  semesters of undergraduate study while for the 1988/89 set GPA'S were collected for the first two semesters. The JME aggregate scores of the subjects were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA), while their GPA's were correlated with their JME aggregate scores, using Pearson ProductMoment Correlation method.  Intercorrelations were also carried out between the GPA'S. The results of the analyses revealed that there was a significant difference (P < 0.05) between entry qualifications and performance in JME composite for the 1987/88 set, and for the two sets combined, whereas there was no such significant difference for the 1988/89 set. It was also observed that there was a significant difference between entry qualifications and JME performance of the 1987/88 set in Arts (P < 0.05) and Science (P < 0.01), while there was such a significant difference (P < 0.05) for the 1988/89 set  in Social Sciences; but there was no significant difference in JME Performance of the students in Education, Law and Pharmacy for any of the sets.  The results further revealed a significant relationship between JME composite scores and university academic performance of the subjects (P < 0.001). This same result was observed in both sets and when the sets were combined.  Also, in each of the two sets of students, correlations between JME Total and Cumulative GPA (CGPA), JME English and CGPA, were lower than that between JME Total and JME English. Overall university academic performance of the students showed that first semester GPA's correlated significantly with other GPA's, the highest correlations were those between semester and cumulative GPA's, and JME Total correlated significantly with semester GPA'S.  Finally, the results showed that no entry qualification was superior to all others as an admission criterion for every selected course of study, and that JME aggregate score can predict a students academic performance during the first year of undergraduate study. The above findings showed that an examination or test result may tend to be unreliable when it is treated on the basis of a single testee, but proves reliable when treated on group basis.  The findings also showed that entry qualification is not a determining factor for a candidates performance in JME or in the university.|Theses collection.| Joint Matriculation Examination (JME)/ Nigerian universities/academic performance/admission criteria/undergraduates/grade point averages (GPA's)*||||||Ojo, Olugbenga David|M|Influence of Solo and Double Parenting on the Adjustment Problems of Secondary School Adolescents in Oyo State.||||||M.A.| 'Kemi Adamolekun.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University , Education Foudation and Counselling|1991|||OAU|||||ix, 87p||||||| English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. The performance of the subjects in English Language, Mathematics, Yoruba, Social Studies and Integrated Science as well as class position in a series of terminal examinations were used as measures of academic achievement. Equally, a study habit questionnaire was administered on all the students before and after the treatment to collect information on their study habits.  Ttest statistics was used to analyse the data collected. The level of significance was a significant difference between pretest and post test scores of the control and experimental groups regarding study habits (P < 0.05). On the other hand the control group did not improve in their study habits, (P > 0.05).Furthermore, post test scores of the control and experimental groups on study habits recorded a significant difference (P < 0.05). Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.| This study examined the strategies used by teachers and parents to control indiscipline behaviour among students.  It also investigated the perceptions of parents and students as to the effectiveness of these strategies. The study sample consisted of 850 subjects involving 500 students,  300 parents and 50 school teachers and principals.  They were selected by purposive and accidental sampling procedures. Three questionnaires were designed for the study, the Measure of Disciplinary Effectiveness as Perceived by Students (MDES), Measure of Disciplinary Effectiveness as Perceived by Parents (MDEP), and the Measures of Disciplinary Effectiveness as Perceived by School Authorities (MDESA), which were certified for validation by appropriate psychometric procedures.  These were administered personally by the researcher on the subjects over a period of six weeks.  The resulting data were analysed using percentage rankings. The result suggested that ten disciplinary methods were generally used by parents, namely caning and other forms of corporal punishment like "picking pins" refusal to give food, refusal to provide material needs (e.g. books, cloths, money etc.) lock out (lock the child outside the house), lock in (e.g. in a dark room, cupboard etc.) preventing the child from going to schools separating the child from playing with mates and compelling the child to work on the farm.  The most frequently used among the disciplinary methods by parents are caning, other forms of corporal punishment and separating the child from playing with mates while caning was rated highest as the most effective.The results also indicated that caning and asking students to cut grass were in all the selected schools the most common methods used by teachers to control indiscipline.  The results further revealed that these methods were in use in all schools, though they were not necessarily the most frequently used.  The most frequently used method by six (or 60%) of the schools is consulting with parents of offending students followed by caning and cutting grass.  The teachers also rated cutting grass as the most effective of the disciplinary methods.In conclusion, the study revealed that the students, parents and teachers did not share a common view on the most effective strategy to control indiscipline behaviour. Verbal reprimand had the highest ranking by students among the eighteen disciplinary methods used both at home and in the school.  The teachers rated cutting grass as the most effective while caning was rated highest by parents as the most effective of the disciplinary methods.|Theses collection.|strategies/teachers/ parents/ indiscipline behaviour /principals/disciplinary methods/ corporal punishment/offending students/*||||||Oyebisi, Elizabeth Oyepeju|F|Social Adjustment Problems and Academic Performance of Undergraduate Students of Obafemi Awolowo University.||||||M.A.|Kemi Adamolekun.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University , Education Foundation and Counselling|1991|||OAU|||||x, 115p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The study investigated the effects that confidence scoring procedure (CSP) have on the psychometric properties of three formats of multiple-choice (MC) test formats.  By the psychometric property, is meant the validity, reliability, discrimination, and difficulty indices of the objective test formats used for the study.  The purpose of the study was to determine whether or not the above properties would be improved if the tests were scored by the confidence scoring method.  Four null hypotheses were thus postulated for testing.Subjects used for the study consisted of four hundred and fifty (450) Senior Secondary Two Students selected by purposive sampling from seven secondary schools in Ife North Local Government Area of Oyo State.  Questionnaires, (a 50-item achievement test in Mathematics and in three formats) were administered on the students as class test meant to be part of their continuos assessment for third term of 1990 academic year.The three formats of the test constructed were mixed and testees didn't know that they were answering different forms of the same test.  The test scripts were collected from the students and scored by the confidence scoring method.  Data obtained were analysed using the Pearson's product moment formula, Kude and Richardson's formula 20, Analysis of variance, t-test, and Z-ratio.Using CSP, the result showed that the contribution of blind guessing to testees total scores was inversely related to the validity, reliability, discrimination, and difficulty indices of the three formats of MC test used.  Hence CSP improved significantly the reliability and the difficulty indices of MC tests, but did not significantly improve the discrimination and validity indices of the three formats used, except the validity of the 3-alternative MC, all at 5% level of significance. This finding indicated that CSP rewards partial knowledge of testees on MC tests and was superior to the conventional number right scoring method in reducing the contribution of blind guessing to testees' total scores.|Theses collection.|confidence scoring procedure (CSP)/psychometric properties/multiple-choice (MC) test formats/ Senior Secondary*||||||Shobande, Bolaji Funmilayo|M| Social anxiety and academic performance of mainstreamed physically disabled secondary school students in Oyo state.||||||M.A. |A. Ehindero||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University ,Science Education|1991|||OAU|||||xiii, 127p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The study investigated the effects of problem context, cognitive style and gender on the proportional reasoning ability of physics students.  In effect the objectives of the study were to identify some of the factors contributing to students' difficulty with physics tasks requiring proportional reasoning skills and findings appropriate intervention strategies in order to improve their performance in physics.  Three ratio types (speed, exchange and consumption) and their hierarchy of difficulty were investigated for both familiar and unfamiliar problems were also identified.Three hundred students from twenty randomly selected secondary schools in Oyo State were used for the study. Their ages ranged from 14-18 years.  The data for the research were collected using three validated instruments. These are two forms (familiar and unfamiliar) of Proportional Reasoning Test (PRT), the Group Embedded Figures Test (GEFT) and the Physics (proportional reasoning) Achievement Test (PAT). The data collected were analysed using the one-way ANOVA and 't'-Test statistical techniques.  All the results obtained were significant at 0.05 level of confidence.The results showed that ratio types used in physics problems influence the proportional reasoning ability of students.  Students found consumption ratios more difficult than exchange ratios and exchange ratios more difficult than speed ratios.  Also, students found physics tasks with unfamiliar settings more difficult than those with familiar settings.It was also observed that field independent students performed better than their field dependent counterparts on the physics (proportional reasoning) achievement test. In addition, the female students exhibited a lower proportional reasoning ability than their male counterparts.
