E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The study was designed to compare the effectiveness of teacherdirected and selfdirected problemsolving techniques on students' performances in electrolysis.  The study also considered the effects of the methods on the subjects' attitude to the learning of Chemistry. Three hundred and sixty senior secondary class two chemistry students took part in the study. The subjects were divided into three ability groups (High,, Medium and Low) according to their performances in the pretest.  Each of these ability levels was contained in each of the three groups that is, Problem Solving Technique (PST), SelfLearning Technique (SLT) (Experimental Groups) and Lecture Method (IM) (Control Group).A chemistry achievement test and a questionnaire on students attitude towards chemistry were administered.  Seven hypotheses were raised and tested using Analysis of Variance (ANOVA), Analysis of Covariance (ANCOVA) and Scheffe test.  The results of the analysis showed that PST group scored higher in posttet (mean score, 57.2%) than either the SLT (mean score, 50.0%) or LM group (mean score, 38.8%).  As for the performance of subjects in the three ability groups, those in the PST group performed significantly higher than their counterparts in the SDT and LM groups (P < 0.05). Comparing the ability levels in each group, there was no significant difference in the performances of those in the PST and SLT groups (P > 0.05). The influence of the methods on the attitude of subjects towards chemistry was found to be greater in PST group than in SLT and LM groups (P < 0. 05).The results indicated that teacher directed problemsolving technique was more useful in the learning of chemistry than the self-directed problem-solving technique.|Theses collection.|teacherdirected/selfdirected problemsolving techniques/students' performances/electrolysis/Chemistry/Problem Solving Technique (PST)/SelfLearning Technique (SLT) (Experimental Groups)/ Lecture Method (IM) (Control Group).*||||||Adesuyi, Victoria Abike|F|Relationship between Students Exposure to English Literature and Performance in WASC English Language among Secondary School Students in Ondo State.||||||M.A. |J.I. The Study also reviewed previous researches published in standard texts and learned journals in the area of curriculum studies and language arts.  The analytical techniques used in the study were the ttest and the ChiSquare methods of statistical analysis. The result of the study indicated that secondary schools performance in English language in the West African School Certificate Examination was better when they also offered literature in English than when they offered English language alone.  It was also found out that students who attended older schools, coeducational schools, and urban schools, and offered both literaturein English and English language performedbetter in school certificate examination in English Language, than those who offered the two subjects in relatively younger schools, monosex schools and rural schools, respectively. From these findings, the thesis concluded that secondary school students' performance in English Language could be enhanced if LiteratureinEnglish is made compulsory for all of them.It was further concluded that while only qualified teachers should be employed to teach English in all schools, library facilities and cocurricular literary activities should be provided in all secondary schools.|Theses collection.|secondary school students/LiteratureinEnglish/ english Language/school age/gender of students/ schools location/West African School Certificate Examination (ordinary level)/Ondo State/ coeducational schools/urban schools*||||||Afolayan, Moradeke|M|Attitudes of Ife and Ilesa Communities towards the use of Mother Tongue as a Medium of Instruction for Nursery Education||||||M.A|G.J. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The study surveyed the attitudes of Ife and Ilesa communities towards the use of mother tongue as a medium  of instruction in preprimary classrooms as recommended by the National Policy on Education (1977-1981). It also investigated the language currently being used in nursery schools and identified discrepancy between policy and practice.  Finally, reasons for this discrepancy were examined.The study sample comprised seven hundred and nine  subjects selected by stratified random procedure. It was made up of 500 parents, 180 teachers, 20 language  experts and 9 educational administrators from the Oyo State Ministry of Education.  There were three research instruments used in this study.  These were a questionnaires an observation guide, and an interview guide.  The instruments were personally administered by the investigator.  Subsequently, the data collected were analysed and used to answer the four research questions corresponding to the objectives of the study. Descriptive and inferential statistics including the means,  percentages and chisquare techniques were used for the analysis of the research questions. The results of the analyses strongly indicated that there were a general preference (76.92%) for the use of English as the language of instruction in the nursery schools contrary to the intentions of the National Policy on Education.  It was also shown that the reasons for the preference for English primarily included envisaged advantages accruing to pupils in areas of future academic opportunity and performance financial and employment advantages, and prestige. Further more, the study indicated that, since parents expected their children to benefit much from early learning of English, they pressured the nursery school authorities to adopt English medium.  Finally, it was observed from the study that the practice of adopting English medium was, by and larger similar in both Ife and Ilesa communities. |Theses collection.| Ife and Ilesa communities/mother tongue/medium  of instruction/preprimary classrooms/National Policy on Education (1977-1981)/nursery schools/educational administrators/Oyo State Ministry of Education/research instruments*||||||Akinwumi, lsaac Oyedele|M|Effectiveness of Feedback Remedial Measure in the Learning of Secondary School Physics. |||||| Ph.D|A.A. Taiwo||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University ,Special Education and Curriculum Studies|1991|||OAU|||||xiii, 230p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The study was carried out to compare the relative effectiveness of three methods of instruction among secondary school physics students.  The methods were Specific Feedback Remedial (SFR). Specific Feedback Only (SFO) and the Conventional Method (CM).  Effectiveness was determined by the level of performance of subjects that were exposed to each method.  Attitude modifications in subjects that were exposed to the three methods were also compared. Four hundred and eighty senior secondary one (SS 1) students  were randomly selected to constitute the sample. Group  based instructional package on the concept of motion was constructed based on physics SSS Syllabus by CESAC.  Specific remedial packages were also constructed to enable subjects which were deficient in certain areas of each week's work to remediate for such deficiencies.  The subjects concerned used the specific remedial packages as self learning devices. The instruments developed and validated for the study were the cognitive pretest, postachievement test, diagnostic test, and attitude towards physics scale. After independent induction sections, teachers assigned to the SFR and SFO groups used the Groupbased instructional package to teach the concept of motion to subjects in the two groups for a period of nine weeks.  At the end of each week, the SFR and SFO teachers administered a diagnostic test on the subjects in the SFR and SFO groups.  Feedback was also provided.  Subjects in the SFR and SFO groups were thus able to detect areas where specific learning difficulties existed.  Subjects in the SFR group were given specific remedial packages to correct specific learning difficulties while subjects in the SFO group were not given such packages. The subjects in the CM group were taught the concept of motion using the lecture method.  The group did not have the weekly diagnostic tests and specific remedial packages.  The attitude towards physics scale was administered on all the subjects in the groups namely SFR, SFO, CM and CON which was the control, before the pretest was given.  The same attitude towards physics scale was also administered after the posttest was given.  The data collected were statistically analysed using mean scores, ANOVA, ANCOVA, Scheffe's pair-wise comparison test and multiple ttests.The results showed that the SFR individuals performed higher in a physics achievement test (per cent mean gain in score 46.00%) than the SFO (29.49%) and the CM group (10.00%). The results of the ACOVA showed that the SFR group performed significantly higher in  the Physics achievement test than the SFO and the CM groups   (P < 0.01).  Results of the ANCOTA also showed that the SFT group performed significantly higher in a Physics retention test than the SFO and the CM groups (P < 0.01). The subjects in the SFR group cultivated a more positive attitude towards physics than the subjects in the SFO and the CM groups as revealed by ANOVA test ( P < 0.01). Performance of boys and girls were comparable in the SFR group while boys performed higher than girls in the SFO and CM groups. (P < 0.01). The strength of the SFR method laid in the use of specific feedback system and specific remedial packages.|Theses collection.|methods of instruction/secondary school physics students/Specific Feedback Remedial (SFR)/ Specific Feedback Only (SFO)/Conventional Method (CM)/Attitude modifications/instructional package/specific feedback system /specific remedial packages*||||||Durodola, Olufemi Daniel.|M|A framework for timber housing development in Nigeria||||||M.Sc. | O. T. Olateju||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University,  Building|1991||| OAU ||||| xvii, 182p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The objectives of this research were to investigate the efficacy of a timber building as an alternative to other types of buildings in Nigeria and identify ways and means of popularising timber building to increase its percentage within the housing stock. In order to achieve these objectives, preliminary discussions, questionnaires, field surveys and laboratory tests were carried out.  A total of 142 questionnaires were administered among the current users of such buildings, experts in construction wood technology, insurance, finance, fire and local government authorities. Prototype low cost houses using timber and block work designed by Oyo State Development and Property Corporation were costed and the costs compared.In order to determine cogent factors as identified by respondents for various issues, percentage of occurrence and ranking were used as demarcation factors.  Analysis of variance and student ttest were used to test various data obtained to determine their reliability.  For cost analysis, bills of quantities were prepared for the low cost houses using various materials and sent for costing to a firm of chartered quantity surveyors.The results showed that timber buildings can be viable alternatives to other types of buildings currently in use in Nigeria because of the materials, the cost and the service ability of the current timber buildings for various uses in south western Nigeria.  However, the cost analysts showed that as the quality of timber houses decreased so also did the cost, and that a standard timber building was likely to be more expensive than the conventional block wall building.The study concluded that despite the great potential timber building possess, its mass introduction concluded into the housing stock may face several hindrances including stock of hardwood, absence of bylaws supporting timber house construction and several others.  Recommendations on public education, development of building codes regulating timber buildings and adoption of timber buildings in public house were also made.|Theses collection.|timber building/construction wood technology/insurance/finance/fire/local government authorities/ Prototype low cost houses/Oyo State Development and Property Corporation/ stock of hardwood/f bylaws/timber house construction*||||||Kehinde, Stephen Olufemi|M|Strategies for competitive bidding in the construction industry in south west Nigeria||||||M.Sc.| O. T. Olateju||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University , Building|1991|||OAU|||||xv, 224p. |||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The objective of the research was to examine the bidding practices employed by construction firms in south west Nigeria in order to find ways of improving them.  Questionnaires and personal interviews were conducted on clients, consulting firms and contractors comprising of medium and large sized indigenous and multinational companies located in Oyo, Ogun, Ondo, Lagos and Bendel States.  The data were then analysed by using simple statistical tools, including the mean, standard deviation, variance and other measures of dispersion. The result showed that the majority of the respondents were from Lagos, but 30%, 34%" and 41% of clients, consultants and contractors respectively would not like their identities disclosed.  However, all the contractors sampled were in Category D, with 65%, of them having up to 1,500 workers while the rest had between 1,500 to 3,000 workers. Fifty percent of the clients, 70% consultants and 41% contractors preferred selective tendering over all the other forms but majority of the indigenous contractors preferred open tendering.  It was found that there was no scientific approach to bidding in the construction industry in the South West Nigeria. Further, while 70% of consultants preferred to prequalify contractors,  87% of the contractors preferred lobbying the clients or the consultants.  The success rate of tendering for large foreign contractors was 65.5% while that of large indigenous contractors was only 30%.  It was also discovered that clients were the final decision makers; 70% of them always participate in the final selection of the contractor and often but not always use the recommendations of their consultant.  Finally, it was discovered that the majority of tenders submitted differed only in the level of markup used and that the markups of the indigenous contractors were lower than those of the foreigners, varying between 16% to 41% for indigenous and between 28% to 52% for foreign contractors.However, tender sum and technical competence ranked highest in the selection of a contractor for a job.  Two models for competitive tender (for known and unknown competitors respectively), employing factors of probability, markup and the level of interest of the contractors were developed and tested using the tender information supplied by the clients consultants.  The results of the model testing indicated that the models were between 80% to 83% successful where the contractor is highly interested, 20% to 50% successful when he is an averagely interested bidder and 0% to 17% when he is an indifferent bidder.  It was concluded that the models satisfactorily predicted the changes of successful tendering in the Nigerian construction industry.  The need for interpersonal relationships cannot, however be entirely ignored.|Theses collection.|construction firms/south west Nigeria/consulting firms/contractors/ indigenous and multinational companies/construction industry/foreign contractors *||||||Akinola, Shittu Raimi|M| Comparative study of mass transit system in Oyo and Kwara States,  Nigeria||||||M.Sc|S. O. Fadadre||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University        Urban & Regional Planning| 1991||| OAU|||||xi, 136p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The study was designed to carry out a comparative analysis of mass transit system with reference to factors of demand and operations of the programmes in Oyo and Kwara States.  The specific objectives of the study include the investigation of the factors that determine the patronage of mass transit buses and the specific problems affecting mass transit operation in the two states.  The technique of random sampling survey was used for collecting data. The data was analysed using simple crosstabulation, graphical illustration, correlation and regression analysis.  The result of the analysis showed that the number of workers per bus in Trans City Transport Company (TCTC) was higher than that of Kwara Express.  While Trans City Transport Company operated mostly intraurban service, Kwara Express operated mostly intercity/state service. Further findings showed that majority of the respondents were adult in the two states.  The proportions of respondents in both states decreased as income increased.  The proportion of carowners who used the system in Ilorin was higher than that of Ibadan.Among the reasons why people used the system "low fare" had the highest percentage in the two cases, although more pronounced in Trans City Transport Company than in Kwara Express.  On the other hand, "convenience" was ranked higher in Kwara Express than in Trans City Transport Company.  Following this, "safety" was higher in Trans City Transport Company than in Kwara Express.Furthermore, the study revealed that there was a positive significant relationship between the distance travelled by commuters and their travel time and travel cost in the two cases.  Multiple regression analysis revealed that the variables used in the analysis could only explain 27.0% and 24.0% of total variation of distance travelled for Trans City  Transport Company and Kwara Express respectively.  Salient among the problems identified in the study were "long waiting time", inadequate number of buses, scarcity of spare parts and inadequate number of bus stops. It is therefore, suggested that the present mass transit ownership and operation be extended beyond that of state to include the third level of government (i.e. the local government) and private groups and individuals who are financially bouyant. The government must ensure adequate supply of buses and spare parts at tolerable costs|Theses collection.| comparative analysis/mass transit system / intraurban service*||||||Akinola, Shittu Raimi|M|Comparative study of mass transit system in Oyo and Kwara States, Nigeria.||||||M.Sc.| S. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.| Leisure pursuit is a function of demand and supply of recreational facilities.  The study of recreational potentials of Lekki Beach was aimed at evaluating the physical characteristics of the beach, its level of development and its recreational roles in Lagos State.  A field survey approach was adopted to assess the physical characteristics and level of provision of recreational facilities and to determine the users' recreational habits and demands at Lekki Beach. Also, relevant data were obtained through personal interviews of officials of Lagos Island Local Government and Ministry of Home Affairs and Tourism, Lagos State.  Statistical analytical techniques including frequency distribution, crosstabulation and multiple regression were employed to analyse the data to realise the various aims of the study.Analyses of physical survey data showed that Lekki Beach was highly underdeveloped despite its great potentials for recreational activities.  The beach was blessed with scenic landscapes with natural cool breezes, fine clean sands and relatively welldrained environment which can enhance the development of recreational facilities on a large scale and thus encourage tourism tremendously. Analyses of the recreational habits of the visitors to Lekki Beach showed that the beach was used for the following activities: swimming (51.1%); sunbathing (33.6%); dancing (33.3%); horse riding (29.9%); picking of shells (27.4%); informal football (25.1%) and resting/games (12.4%).Further analysis showed that the attraction of the beach and the activities pursued were influenced by the socio-economic factors of the visitors, their nationality, whether they come from Lagos State, the male and female population and the problems encountered by the visitors.  A further critical examination of these factors showed that Lekki Beach has proved to be very attractive to the visitors especially male population and foreigners. The problems facing the visitors in order of importance were transportation, distance, finance and difficulty in locating the beach. Other problems identified were lack of adequate management, inadequate funding and lack of recreational facilities, car parking, adequate security, social amenities and adequate landscapes, sanitation around beaches. The visitors to the beach were making demands on convenient station (70.3%), canteen/restaurant (60.5%), children play ground/amusement park (51.8%), hotel accommodation (50.3%), parking facilities/security 46.0%), landscaping (44.1%), picnic ground (41.2%, swimming pool (39.0%) and boating (38.2%).|Theses collection.|demand and supply/recreational facilities/Lekki Beach /Lagos State/Lagos Island Local Government/ Ministry of Home Affairs and Tourism, Lagos State/male population /foreigners/ hotel accommodation/parking facilities/security /picnic ground*||||||Ogbuefi,  Linus Ifeabunike|M|Planning and management of open spaces in Enugu.||||||M.Sc. |J.B. The method of study embraced three interrelated approaches. Firstly, a structured questionnaire survey of park users in Enugu was undertaken in order to determine what activities they are engaged in and their perceptions of the problems of park management.  Secondly, members of staff of Open Space and Park Development and Planning Department were interviewed to determine problems encountered in the management of parks in Enugu.  Thirdly, a physical survey of existing parks in Enugu was conducted to gain a first hand information on problems of these parks.The analysis of the survey of the parks in Enugu shows that Uwani had the highest concentration of parks (36%). Thus, the study demonstrated was because land areas set aside for parks in the original plan of Enugu have not been encroached on before Open Space Development Commission launched its action plan on the development of parks in Enugu in 1973.The study showed that youth visit parks more than the adults (88.9%) and the purpose of their visit is mainly for personal relaxation.  The analysis showed that the problem of parks in Enugu was largely poor maintenance (84.9%). Thus, the study demonstrated was due to inadequate funding and shortage of manpower.The transfer of the functions and personnel of the Open Space Development Commission to Anambra State Environmental and Sanitation Authority was a major contributory factor to the relative ineffectiveness of the Department since 1985. O. Fabayo||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University, Nursing|1991|||OAU|||||xiii, 200p|||||||English ||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The study assessed congruency between the expected roles of nurses in surgical units of a teaching hospital as elicited by nurses, patients and other selected health care team members e.g. doctors and physiotherapists and the actual roles that were being performed in such units. It also examined the extent of actual performance of such elicited roles by nurses in the wards.  Congruency in the rating of such performance by patients, nurses, and other members of the health care team on the wards was also examined.  The performance rating of the nurses was used to evaluate the adequacy of performance of elicited roles in surgical wards of Obafemi Awolowo University Teaching Hospitals Complex, IleIfe.A questionnaire of 55items, tested for reliability and validity was used to collect data from study sample. Purposive sampling was done to select 140 subjects comprising 60 nurses, 40 patients, 40 members of the health care team from the 8 surgical wards of the teaching hospital.  Data collected were analysed, using frequency counts, percentages and, chisquare test to assess for statistically significant differences in the group of performances and detect congruency in the rating.The study revealed that there was no difference between the elicited professional roles of the nurse, the nurses' perception of their roles, and the patients expected roles of the nurses and the actual roles that were being performed by nurses in the surgical wards of the teaching hospital. However, it was found that there was a statistically significant difference between the health care team members' roles expectation of the nurse and the actual performance of such roles by nurses in the surgical wards of the hospital. lt was found that there were statistically significant differences in the 3 groups rating of nurses performance of the 11 roles elicited.  Hence there were no congruency in the groups rating of the performance of the 11 roles.                      The study demonstrated that clients and health care team members' role expectation of the nurses in surgical wards were not different from the expected roles of the professional nurse in such units, but there was a difference between what was expected and what was actually done.  Therefore, strategies to improve the nurses' abilities to adequately play their roles to meet up with the expectations of consumers and other team members in the surgical units should be given top priority.|Theses collection.|nurses/surgical units/teaching hospital/patients/health care team members/doctors and physiotherapists/Obafemi Awolowo University Teaching Hospitals Complex, IleIfe/congruency*||||||Pungong, Jacqueline Ndientien|F| Effects of exercise intensity on the cardiorespiratory responses of athletes and nonathletes in Nigeria.||||||M.Sc.| I. O. Adeoshun// A. A. Ajayi||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University, Physiotherapy|1991|||OAU|||||xviii, 171p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Criteria for evaluating the cardiorespiratory functions of foreign population may not be suitable for evaluating Nigerian subjects. It is thus necessary to identify factors which determine high levels of fitness and athletic excellence of Nigerian subjects. This study was designed to investigate the effect of exercise intensity on the cardiorespiratory response to exercise of anaerobically-trained athletes and nonathletes in Nigeria. The relationships between anthropometric parameters (sex, height, weight and body surface area) and the cardiorespiratory variables were also investigated.Thirtyone nonathletes and anaerobicallytrained athletes within the age range of 1634 years participated in the study.  A 2 (sex) x2(activity levels) x4 (exercise intensity) experimental design was employed.  Subjects signed a consent form prior to the test.  On the test day, the height, weight and body surface area were measured after which the subject was asked to lie supine and the heart rate and blood pressure were monitored for about 30 minutes until a constant value was obtained.  The subject was then asked to sit upright on a bicycle ergometer and the resting cardiorespiratory functions were monitored for 5 minutes.  Exercises of 0, 1.5 and 3.0 Kp at 60 revolutions per minute for at most 5 minutes were prescribed for each subject with resting periods of 1520 minutes between the exercise intensities.Heart rate (HR) was monitored with a multipurpose poly graph while systolic blood pressure (SBP) and diastolic blood pressure (DBP) were monitored with a sphygmomanometer and stethoscope on the left arm.  Closedcircuit spirometry was used to monitor respiratory frequency (Rf), tidal volume (VT),  minute ventilation (VE) and rate of oxygen uptake (VO2).  To confirm VO2  measurements, the Fry's gas analyser was used for analysis of expired gas samples collected in Douglas bags. The analysis of variance for each cardiorespiratory variable was done at the Shephard Computer Centre, Ibadan.There was a significant (P < 0.05) increase in the cardiorespiratory functions after exercise except for DBP and VT which showed a decrease at 1.5Kp and 3.0Kp exercise respectively.  A significant (P < 0.05) difference occurred between the male and female HR, DBP, Rf and VO2 responses to exercise.  The VT at rest and 0Kp of anaerobicallytrained athletes and non athletes were found to be significantly (P < 0.05) different.  Height, weight and body surface area were found to have a significant relationship (P < 0.05) with HR, VT, Rf and VO2.  The cardiorespiratory variables were found to be highly related both at rest and at different exercise intensities.The experimental design employed in this study was for found to be more suitable for low intensity shortduration exercises.  The anaerobicallytrained athletes and nonathletes showed no significant difference in their functions indicating that the anaerobicallytrained athletes had not been training as necessary (aerobically). It is therefore necessary for Nigerian subjects to train regularly, making use of necessary gadgets.  During Medical Checkups, subjects should be prescribed different exercise intensities and their cardiorespiratory functions monitored.|Theses collection.|cardiorespiratory functions / foreign population/Nigerian subjects/athletic excellence/anaerobically-trained athletes/anthropometric parameters/heart rate/blood pressure/bicycle ergometer/Closedcircuit spirometry/ respiratory frequency (Rf)/ tidal volume (VT)/minute ventilation (VE)/oxygen uptake (VO2)/Medical Checkups*||||||Bakare, Omokafe ALaba|M|Comparative anatomy of the species of sida linn. (Malvaceae) in Nigeria.||||||M.Sc. |O.A. Olatunji.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University      Botany|1991|||OAU |||||xix, 304p.|||||||English ||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The comparative anatomical study of the ten species of Sida Linn. (Malvaceae) in Nigeria was carried out with a view to using these features along with other vegetative morphological features, to work out an identification and classification scheme for the species. Fresh as well as herbarium were used in the study of ten taxa while herbarium specimens only were used for S. ovata, S. rhombifolia subsp. rhombifolia and S. acuta subsp. carpinifolia.  The plant specimens were prepared for anatomical study by employing conventional anatomical procedures.The species possess distinctive anatomical characters which indicate close inter-relationship.  These features include the presence of both glandular and non-glandular trichomes; 4-6 collateral vascular bundles arranged in a circle as seen in the transverse section of petiole through the proximal region, while the vascular system is of close medulated type through the distal region of the petiole; anisocytic stomata; dorsiventral lamina; crystals which are druses of calcium oxalate; rays which are homogeneous, being upright cells; and fibres which are tracheid-like, commonly non-septate, non-storied and short in length.Some significant differences were observed in the anatomical characters that could be used to characterize each species.  For instance, the trichome types when assessed critically were used to distinguish some species from the others, viz: the stellate trichomes were recorded for all the species except for S. Linifolia where they were absent.  Columnar trichomes were observed in S. cordifolia, S. urens, and S. linifolia.  The flask-shaped trichomes were found in all the species except in S. linifolia, S. pilosa, S. urens and S. cordifolia.The anatomical evidence observed in this study supported the reduction of S. acuta and S. stipulata to S. acuta subsp. acuta and S. acuta subsp. carpinifolia respectively.  However, the previous taxonomic decision to split the S. rhombifolia complex into subspecies: S. rhombifolia subsp. alnifolia, S. rhombifolia subsp. rhombifolia and S. rhombifolia subsp. retusa was not supported on anatomical grounds in this investigation.  The morphological and anatomical features have been used to construct a workable artificial key.|Theses collection.|comparative anatomical study/vegetative morphological features/plant specimens/inter-relationship/non-glandular trichomes/collateral vascular bundles/anisocytic stomata/dorsiventral lamina//crystals/ calcium oxalate/homogeneous/species/artificial key*||||||Effiong, Nnene Mfon|M|Seasonal Changes in Gibberellic Acid and Abscisic Acid Content in three Tropical Rice Varieties.||||||M.Sc.|A. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|.The levels of endogenous gibberellinlike substances and abscisic acid were determined in three tropical rice (Oryza sativa L.) varieties TOS 5771, TOS 60l2 and TOS 9186 from one month old to maturity.  The aim of the study was first to explore the relationship between the growth phases and the hormonal levels in the rice varieties and secondly to investigate the relationship which may exist between the flowering of these plants and the local daylength prevalent in IleIfe.Acidic ethyl acetate fraction of the extract obtained from homogenizing the plant material was assayed by lettuce hypocotyl bioassay for gibberellic acid and diethyl ether fraction assayed by lettuce germination bioassay for abscisic acid.  The solvent system isopropanol: water (4:1 v/v) and benzene: ethyl acetate: acetic acid (75:20:5v/v/v) were used in the bioassay for gibberellic acid and abscisic acid respectively.  The height, internode lengths and fresh weights of the plants were also measured.The results showed the occurrence of gibberellic acid at Rf 0.50.9 and abscisic acid at Rf 0.3-0.7. TOS 6012 took 128 days to flower after seeding while TOS 5771 and TOS 9186 took 116 days and 113 days to flower after seeding respectively.  TOS 5771 reached a height of 123.4  13.20 cm at maturity followed by TOS 9186 with 117.4  7.15 cm and TOS 6012 with 102.95  0.85 cm.  TOS 6012 produced more tillers than the other two rice varieties. The level of the hormone dropped during internode elongation and remained low till maturity. The abscisic acid level in the three rice varieties showed no regular pattern.
