Adebona||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University        Botany|1991|||OAU|||||xiv, 149p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.| Corypha umbraculifera has a problem of seed dormancy which has affected its cultivation.  The aims of this research were to determine the effects of interaction of heating and soaking on seed dormancy, the relationship between lipid and hormonal levels and breaking of dormancy.Dormancy was broken by heating the seeds in the oven at 42oC for 110 weeks and soaked between 12 and 72 hours before planting.  Lipids were extracted from the seeds with chloroformmethanol (2: 1 v/v), separated by silicic acid column and thin layer chromatography (T.L.C.) and quantified by gas liquid chromatography (G.L.C.).  Gibberellin and abscisic acid were extracted with 80% methanol, purified by polyvinylpyrridone column and thin layer chromatography.  The T.L.C. developing solvent system for gibberellin was isopropanolwater (4: 1 v/v), while it was benzene: ethylacetateacetic acid (75: 20: 5 v/v) for abscisic acid.  Cytokinins were extracted with methanolwater-formic acid, separated by ion exchange chromatography and T.L.C. plates developed with butanolacetic acidwater (12: 3: 5 v/v/v).  Lettuce hypocotyl and lettuce germination bioassays were used to determine the activities of ethyl acetate and butanol-soluble gibberellins acid diethyl ethersoluble abscisic acid.  Soybean callus bioassay was used to determine the activities of water, ammonia and ethanolsoluble cytokinins.  Both percentage and days of germination were analysed with two way analysis of variance and Student's ttest.Heat treatment for 10 weeks and soaking for 24 hours increased the percentage seed germination to 77 and reduced the days of germination from 44 to 26. The dormant seed contained 12.5% lipids while the nondormant ones contained between 7.5 and 9.0%. Five classes of lipids obtained from the Corypha seeds were triglycerides, diglycerides, free fatty acid, cholesteryl esther and sterol.  The fatty acids were myristic, linolenic, palmitic, oleic, stearic and lauric acids.  There was complete disappearance of glycolipids and a drop in fatty acid level in the 10th week of heating of non-dormant seeds. The results of the bioassays shored that the hormone activities occurred mainly at Rf values 0.10.2, 0.30.5, and 0.70.9 for cytokinins, 0.00.3, 0.40.7 and 0.81.0 for gibberellins and 0.40.5 for abscisic acid.  The dormant seeds contained a high level of abscisic acid and a low level of basic ethyl acetate solublegibberellins.  During dormancy break, the level of abscisic acid declined while basic ethyl acetatesoluble gibberellins rose to a peak on the 4th week and then dropped on the 10th week.  Low levels of watersoluble and ammoniasoluble cytokinins were identified in the dormant seeds.  After dormancy break, both levels increased and maximum germination was triggered off.Sephadex LH20 chromatography of the isolated cytokinins revealed an increase in ammoniasoluble extract concomitant decrease in water soluble extract in the 10th week, thus suggesting interconversion of these hormones after dormancy break.  At higher concentration of the extracted cytokinins, a decrease in cytokinins activity was observed.|Theses collection.|Corypha umbraculifera/seed dormancy/cultivation/hormonal levels/thin layer chromatography (T.L.C.)/gas liquid chromatography (G.L.C.)/Gibberellin/abscisic acid/ Heat treatment/lipids*||||||Makinde, Pius Morakinyo|M| Studies of the Seasonal Changes in Bryophyte Population of Derived Savanna of South-Western Nigeria.||||||Ph.D. |E. A. Odu||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University       Botany|1991|||OAU|||||xii, 200p. |||||||English ||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Studies of seasonal variations in bryophyte population were carried out in Derived Savanna vegetation at selected locations of SouthWestern Nigeria with a view to investigating the effects of seasonal variation on the species  composition, vegetative and reproductive growth of savanna bryophytes. The studies also aimed at investigating the pattern of re-vegetation by bryophytes in the periodically disturbed ecosystem of the savanna.Monthly soil samples were collected from the sites over a 12month period and analysed in the laboratory for exchangeable cations (sodium, potassium, magnesium and calcium), nitrate nitrogen, moisture contents pH and organic matter content.  Soil temperatures of the sites were measured during the same period and related to vegetation growth to monitor effect on bryophyte growth.  Percentage cover, vegetative and reproductive growth of bryophytes were measured onsite over a 24month period using 20cm x 20cm permanent quadrats.  Moss shoots were subjected to water stress under controlled environment and at various relative humidities.The studies showed that the mosses present on the sites were Archidium ohioense, Bryum coronatum, Fissidens minutifolius,   F. subglaucissimus and Trachycarpidium tisserantii on derived savanna vegetation.  These mosses were more heat resistant than the forest moss species (Thuidium gratum and Racopilum africanum).  The species ordination on study sites showed Archidium ohioense as the most dominant species.  The topography of the sites aids runoff of rainwater and thus encourage leaching of nutrients across the slopes.  Nitrate nitrogen, pH, Sodium, Potassium and Magnesium and water were found to be the key soil factors that contributed individually to the varied distribution of the moss species on the sites.  The moss shoots exhibited a characteristic sigmoid growth curve commencing with the advent of the rainy season in March/April with accelerated growth phase in midrainy seasons, reaching a climax in September/October, the end of the rainy season. The adaptations for survival of the mosses include the ability to complete their reproductive and vegetative stages within the rainy season and their ability to regenerate profusely through gemmae, tubers, persistent protonema and shoot regrwoth.  The annual grass burning on the sites aids in the recycling of nutrients for the use of bryophytes and phanerogams during subsequent growth season.|Theses collection.|seasonal variations/bryophyte population/Derived Savanna vegetation/SouthWestern Nigeria/re-vegetation /exchangeable cations/Soil temperatures/relative humidities/adaptations*||||||Tedela, Olugbenga Patrick|M|Anatomical Studies of the Species of Pterocarpus Jacq. (PapilionoideaeFabaceae) in Nigeria. ||||||M.Sc.|O. A. Olatunji.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University ,Botany|1991|||OAU|||||xii, 91p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|. The vegetative anatomy of the six species of Pterocarpus viz:  P. santalinoides, P. mildbraedii,  P. osun,  P. erinaceus, P. soyauxii and P. lucens occuring in Nigeria were studied and described with the view to finding the anatomical features which may be employed along with other features for the identification and classification of the species in the genus.Fresh plant materials collected from different parts of Nigeria and herbarium specimens kept in the harbaria of Obafemi Awolowo University, IleIfe and Forestry Research Institute of Nigeria (FRIN), Ibadan were used for the study.  Transverse sections of the leaf and petiole as well as the transverse radial and transverse longitudinal sections of the wood were made using the sledge microtome.  Calculation of the stomata frequency, stomata index and guard cell area were determined from epidermal peels of both adaxial and abaxial surfaces of the leaves.Results show that the anatomical features which can be used to define the genus are paracytic stomata occurring only on the abaxial surface; unicellular, needle-like and non-glandular trichome ocurring only on the lower surface; Camptodromous venation, diffuse porous wood with growth rings; oval to elliptic solitary vessels which may occur in radial multiples of 2 and 3; storied rays which are predominantly uniseriate and homogenous and wood that is characterised by abundant parenchyma.P. santalinoides is distinct from some others in the absence of trichome on the petiole, the parenchyma that is apotracheal and the presence of up to 4 to 8 subsidiary cells around most of its stomata.  P. mildbraedii is characterized by the absence of trichome on the abaxial leaf surface, adaxial part of the midrib that is slightly raised into a smooth mound, and midrib outline in transverse section that is more or less triangular.  P. osun is distinct in that the walls of the abaxial epidermal cells are wavy while the adaxial surfaces vary from straight to slightly wavy.  P. erinaceus is characterized by the moderate distribution of trichome on the abaxial leaf surface.  P. soyauxii is characterized by an adaxial xylem strand in the midrib of the leaf.  P. lucens has some distinct anatomical features such as abundant distribution of trichome on the abaxial leaf surface and a distinct stomata index.|Theses collection.|vegetative anatomy/species of Pterocarpus/anatomical features/Obafemi Awolowo University, IleIfe/Forestry Research Institute of Nigeria (FRIN), Ibadan/transverse longitudinal sections/Camptodromous venation/abaxial leaf surface*||||||Ajayi, Oluwole Lucas|M|Determination of radionuclides in building materials used in some Nigerian dwellings.||||||M.Sc.| J. B. Olomo//C. A. Adesanmi||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University, Engineering Physics|1991|||OAU|||||xi, 96p.|||||||English ||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The activity of radionuclides in some building materials used in Nigeria for dwellings was determined using NaI(TI) detector.  This was with a view to obtaining preliminary data on the radioactivity levels of 238U, 232Th and 40K in some building materials, such as cement, rock, sand, burnt brick and asbestos. Samples were collected from towns covering seven states suspected to contain low or high terrestrial activity levels by using scintillation counter for onthespot monitoring.  The samples were reduced to grain size, oven dried at about 110oC for 24 hours and sealed for a minimum of 28 days before counting at the Nuclear Physics Laboratory of the Department of Physics, Obafemi Awolowo University, lleIfe.  This is to allow a stage of secular equilibrum between 238U , 232Th and their daughter series.Photopeaks at 0.609 MeV, 1.12 Mev and 1.764 MeV of 214Bi were used to identify 238U; 0.911 Mev of 228AC and 2.615 MeV of 208TI  were used to identify 232Th and natural potassium, 40K, was identified with its 1.461 MeV x-energy. The average specific activities of 238U, 232Th and 40K in cement, rock, sand, burnt brick and asbestors ranged from 182.7 to 301.7 Bq Kg-1, 86.0 to 211.3 Bq Kg-1 and 141.5 to 646.6 Bq Kg-1 respectively. Comparison with similar work done in some other countries reveals that some activity levels which could the considered average occurred in cement and asbestos while activity levels were high in rocks, sand and burnt bricks suggesting that activity levels of our building materials need thorough investigation before they can be used for building construction.|Theses collection.|radionuclides/building materials/NaI(TI) detector/radioactivity levels/ scintillation counter/onthespot monitoring/Nuclear Physics Laboratory of the Department of Physics, Obafemi Awolowo University, lleIfe*||||||Ocan, Onesmus Ojok|M|The Petrology of Rocks around Idanre, SouthWestern Nigeria.||||||Ph.D. |M. A. Rahaman.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University        Geology|1991|||OAU|||||xxi, 397p. |||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Idanre area is a part of the Nigerian Basement Complex lying in the PanAfrican mobile belt East of the West African Craton and West of the Congo Craton.  The area is underlain by the migmatitic gneiss complex (consisting of grey gneisses of tonalitic to granodioritic composition, granite gneisses, finegrained granites and minor pegmatites, vein quartz, amphibolites and ultramafic rocks), members of the Older Granite Suite and the associated charnockitic rocks.  The present work was aimed at investigating the granitecharnockite association and to determine the petrogeneses of the rock units of the area.Field mapping and petrographic analyses of the collected samples were carried out in order to determine the contact relations between rock groups, their texture and mineral compositions.  A total of 136 specimens were analysed for their major and trace element compositions by XRay Fluorescence Spectrometry technique (13 grey gneisses, 13 amphibolites and ultramafic rocks, 34 charnockitic rocks and 76 granitic rocks).  The geochemical data were plotted on different variation diagrams in order to characterize them and determine their petrogeneses.  Critical minerals in gneissose charnockitic rocks were analysed by electron microprobe analytical techniques and the results were used in geothermobarometric computations to determine the physical conditions under which they formed. UPb isotopic analyses of zircons extracted from granites and charnockitic rocks were used to date the emplacement of the granitecharnockite association.Results of the analyses indicate that grey gneisses, theoldest recognisable member of the migmatite gneiss complex are of sedimentary origin.  The other components of the migmatite are of igneous origin.  The granites and charnockites are late to posttectonic metaluminous to slightly peraluninous rocks characterized by high amounts of K2O and high field strength elements.  They form a composite diapiric intrusion of mantlederived magmas, emplaced about 586  5 Ma ago.The evolution of the area started about 2500 Ma ago with the initiation  of crustforming processes characterized by magnetism of tonalitic to granodioritic composition.  Rapid erosion of this juvenile crust resulted in the deposition of immature sediments (greywackes) and minor basic volcanics. Metamorphism and deformation of this sequence and emplacement of granites during the Eburnean orogeny 2000  200 Ma ago resulted in the formation of the migmatitic gneiss complex. This basement was reactivated and intruded by granitic and charnockitic rocks shortly after the continentcontinent collision at the eastern margin of the West African Craton about 600 Ma ago.|Theses collection.|Idanre area/ Nigerian Basement Complex/ PanAfrican mobile belt/West African Craton/Congo Craton/migmatitic gneiss complex/petrogeneses/ mineral compositions/ sedimentary origin/Field mapping /perographic analyses/Fluorescence Spectrometry technique/geochemical data/basic volcanics.*||||||Idornigie, Alexander Irumekhai.|M|A study of the use of resistivity type curves for groundwater development in Edu local governmnet area of Kwara State.||||||M.Sc. |M. O. Olorunfemi.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University         Geophysics|1991|||OAU|||||xi, 114p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The study of electrical resistivity and well/borehole data for groundwater development in the Edu Local Government Area of Kwara State has been carried out.  This is with a view to identifying the different aquifer units and their characteristics; the subsurface structures/tectonics and their influence on the general hydrogeological conditions in the area. The qualitative interpretation of resistivity type curves resulting from 54 Vertical Electrical Soundings (VES) revealed that simple type curves (e.g. H, HA, KH types) are reflective of the Basement Complex area, while complex type curves (e.g. HK, QHK, KQQ types) are indicative of sedimentary parts of the study area.  The type curves, based on distinctive geoelectric and geologic characteristics, were classified into four groups.From the quantitative interpretation of the sounding curves aided by lithological logs from the boreholes, a maximum of four layers were identified from the Basement Complex area. These include the top soil, sand/pebbly sand/clayey sand layer, the weathered basement and the fresh bedrock.  In the sedimentary environment, the number of layers recorded ranged between four and seven.  The sequence is composed of complex alternations of gravel, sand/pebbles/clay and sandstones.  The depth to the fresh bedrock in the basement area is between 7.4m and 91.6m. The bedrock was not mapped in the sedimentary environment.The geoelectric sections taken along five different traverses in the study area indicate that there are two sets of faults. One set (faults F1 and F2) runs almost parallel to the River Niger in the NWSE direction, while the other set (F3 and F4) runs at high angle to the first set, and trends approximately in the NESW direction.  Faults F1 and F2 whose downthrown sides are towards the NE     seems to break up the study area into three blocks or zones with different hydrogeologic characteristics.  The first zone which is mainly underlain by basement rocks lies to the South of fault F1, while the second zone which constitutes the transitional zone between the basement and sedimentary rocks lies between faults F1 and F2.  The third zone lies to the North of fault F2 and it is predominantly underlain by sedimentary rocks.  This third zone has the thickest overburden with a relatively high groundwater yield. The physiographic elements, such as rivers and topography, in this area seem to be structurally controlled.From the available geoelectric data, it is hereby inferred that the Bida Basin may have evolved as a result of step-faulting.  A new structural/geological map for the study area has also been evolved. The investigation of the relationship between the overburden coefficient of anisotropy, and groundwater yield, (Y) in the Basement Complex area shows that, on a local scale, the latter generally increases with the former.  Metamorphic rocks are characterised by low values of anisotropy coefficient, while igneous rocks have higher values.|Theses collection.|electrical resistivity/well/borehole data/groundwater development/aquifer units/hydrogeological conditions/ Vertical Electrical Soundings (VES)/edimentary environment/edimentary environment/igneous rocks*||||||Ajayi,Comfort  Folasade|M|Green's function for singular boundary value problems||||||M.Sc.|Y.A.S. Aregbesola.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University , Mathematics|1991|||OAU |||||vi, 57p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research. |This work is concerned with the study of the theory of Green's functions and their applications to certain classes of Boundary Value Problems (BVP).  The investigation was carried out to look into the conditions governing the existence and uniqueness of Green's function for nth order BVP, and when established, how to obtain the Green's function and to use it in obtaining the solution of the problems.The fourth order BVP arising from beam deflection theory, which previous workers had considered on a finite interval, is studied in this work on an infinite and semiinfinite interval. The solutions of singular BVP with vanishing coefficient on one of the ends of the interval are also considered.  The existence and uniqueness of solutions for the problems considered are established.It was observed that Green's function can be obtained for differential operators which are self adjoint.  In particular a (2nl)th order linear differential operator cannot be made self adjoint and so Green's function of such equations cannot be obtained.  However, when the equations are self adjoint or can be made self adjoint, complicated BVP can be easily solved with the use of Green's function method by reducing the equation to integral equations. In this respect, certain classes of singular BVP other than those considered here can be easily handled. |Theses collection.|theory of Green's functions/Boundary Value Problems (BVP)/existence and uniqueness/beam deflection theory/finite interval/linear differential operator*||||||Muse, Wasiu Adesola|M|Investigation on the morphology, nature and development of the male accessory reproductive gland of the variegated grasshopper Zonocerus variegatus L. (Orthoptera: Acridoidea, pyrgomorphidae).||||||Ph.D.|R. A. Balogun||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University,  Zoology| 1991||| OAU||||| xxii, 181p. |||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Cassava (Manihot esculenta, Cranz), a major source of carbohydrate to millions of people in Tropical Africa, is heavily attacked by the pest, Zonocerus variegatus (Linnaeus) in West and Central Africa.  This work investigated the morphology and development of the male accessory gland of adult male Z. variegatus and the nature of its secretion in the dry-season adult grasshoppers with respect to its protein, amino acid and sugar constituents.  This is with a view to providing information that would further enhance the biological control of the insect.The nymphs of Z. variegatus were collected on the campus of Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife and they were maintained on Chromolaena odorate (L.) King and Manihot esculenta in illuminated cages. Newly emerged adult males and females were isolated, maintain on cassava shoots and subsequently used in experiments.  The gross morphology, histology, protein, amino acid and carbohydrate contents of the accessory glands were studied using standard histological and biochemical techniques.The accessory gland consists of eleven pairs of slender tubules of varying lengths, and five gland types are identified.  The gland comprises a basement membrane and an epithelial layer.  As it developed, the cells of the epithelial layer decreased in height and the diameter of its lumen increased simultaneously, suggesting an apocrine mode of secretion.Protein concentration of the glands increased continuously from day 0 to 35 days of development, the increase being highest between day 7 and 14-day-old insects.  Copulation studies suggest that protein materials transferred from the male to the female during mating in replenished after 12 hours.  Electropherograms of the gland extracts of day 0 to 56-day-old adult insects gave a variable number of protein bands.  Protein fraction 8 appeared for the first time in 14-day-old adult insects.  Accessory gland types revealed a mixture of heterogenous proteins having molecular weights ranging from 8,900 to 46,800.A wide range of free amino acids was obtained from the glands at day 0 to 28 days of development with proline, alanine, glycine, glutamic acid and serine occurring in highest concentrations.  The quantities of total free amino acid fluctuated with the development of the accessory gland.  Galactose, glucose, fructose, cellobiose, trehalose and lactose were detected in the gland extract with increase in concentration from day 0 to 42 days of development.  The presence of protein fraction with molecular weight of about 30,000; high concentrations of proline alanine, glycine and glutamic acids, which were earlier implicated in the stimulation of oviposition in some species of insects, and the positive effect of the injection of male accessory gland into the adult female Z. variegatus, all point to the fact that the accessory glands of adult male Zonocerus variegatus contain oviposionstimulating substance.|Theses collection.|Cassava (Manihot esculenta, Cranz)/carbohydrate/Tropical Africa/pest, Zonocerus variegatus (Linnaeus)/morphology and development/Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife /accessory gland/Protein concentration/Copulation studies/-Copulation studies*||||||Oba, Olusanya Akindele|M|The impact of international trade and finance on Nigeria's economic growth 1960-1987.|||||| Ph.D. |A. O. Olaloye||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University , Economics|1991|||OAU |||||vii, 199p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This study examined the impact of international trade and finance on Nigeria's economic growth during the period 1960-1987.  The large number of empirical studies on trade and growth over the years failed to resolve the theoretical controversy over the contribution of trade and external finance to economic growth of developing countries.This study has quantitatively assessed the relative impacts of trade and external finance on Nigeria's economic growth.  It shed more light on the validity of various views expressed on the subject.  It has also contributed to a proper appraisal of the various policies employed for managing international trade and finance for the promotion of economic growth in Nigeria.An econometric model comprising four equations, viz: growth equation, capital formation equation, export equation and import of capital goods equation was developed.  The model was applied to the Nigeria situation in the period 1960-1987.  The method of ordinary least squares estimating techniques was used to obtain the results of estimated equations of the model.  The results showed that foreign loans, foreign private investment and export as percentage of GDP have no doubt had important beneficial effects on economic growth in Nigeria.  Foreign loans and foreign private investment were, however, found to be negatively related to domestic capital formation.  Capital goods imported and exports were found to be essential for domestic capital formation in Nigeria.The necessity for Nigeria's involvement in international trade was established by our thesis; relative export prices and percentage change in world income were important in the simulation of the demand for capital goods such as machinery and equipment.The results of the impact multiplier analysis of exogenous variable changes in 1977, 1985 and 1987 revealed that export price incentives and expansions of world economic activity would tend to encourage export earnings in Nigeria.  Furthermore, the results also revealed that foreign loan has negative direct and indirect effects on domestic capital formation, while foreign private investment has positive direct and indirect effects.  This result suggests that different forms of external finance can have varied effects on the productivity of investment in Nigeria.Our thesis is that the achievement of self-sustained economic growth in Nigeria requires the generation of domestic savings through sound economic policies aimed at raising export performance, the cumulative effect of which will be of wider benefits to Nigeria's prosperity and financial stability.|Theses collection.|international trade/finance/Nigeria's economic growth/ empirical studies/external finance/economic growth/developing countries/econometric model/capital goods/Foreign loans /foreign private investment /exogenous variable/financial stability*||||||Ogunrinola, Isaiah Oluranti|M|Employment and earnings in the urban informal sector of Ibadan||||||Ph.D.|A.O. Olaloye.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University, Economics|1991|||OAU|||||xiv, 259p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|This study examined the contributions of the urban informal sector of Ibadan to income, employment generation, and skill formation.  It also investigated whether or not the sector provides permanent employment for some members of the urban labour force.  The methodology of the study involved the use of questionnaires to elicit desired information from informal sector enterprises as well as formal and informal sector workers in manufacturing and technical services from selected enumeration areas of Ibadan. The analytical techniques relied on the use of employment and earning regression models as well as informal employment probability model.  Also, summary statistics like mean, mode, median, ratios and percentages were used.The estimated employment model shows that the level of capital employed, earnings, amount of education of owner, quality of training of owner and the type of industry where an enterprise operates significantly affect the level of employment.  Such employment is found to be permanent for 86 per cent of informal sector operators, while 94 per cent of the formal sector workers interviewed expressed strong desire of moving to the informal sector whenever they can save up the required starting capital. This fact is also confirmed by the informal employment probability models estimated for the urban labour force of Ibadan.  Thus, the result of our study does not uphold the probabilistic migration hypothesis with respect to the role of informal sector in the urban urban labour market of Ibadan.With respect to earnings, the informal sector workers compare favourably with their formal sector counterparts.  Sixty-one per cent earn more than N200 per month while the mean monthly earnings is N583.  Our earnings distribution model estimated shoes that variables like sector of employment, migration status, education, quality of training, labour market experience and the type of industry in which an enterprise operates significantly affect the distribution of earnings among the urban labour force. In terms of skill development, the apprenticeship system is the most dominant form.  Ninety percent of current entrepreneurs were thus trained, while a total of 2,200 apprentices had been previously trained by these master. At present, the 544 enterprises sampled have a total of 2,119 apprentices that are being trained.  However, in terms of the extent of skill utilisation, it is found that a considerable amount of underemployment ranging from 21 to 36 percent exists in the sector.Apart from its contributions to employment, earnings and skill formation; this study shows that the urban informal sector , rather than disappearing with time, is a major and growing element of development in the urban labour market of Ibadan.  Thus, the government and its agents (e.g. the National Directorate of Employment), skill development, the apprenticeship system and researchers are called upon to focus more attention to the sector to sustain and enhance the sector's contributions to development.|Theses collection.|urban informal sector/Ibadan/income/employment generation/skill formation/urban labour force/technical services/informal employment/skill development/apprenticeship system/National Directorate of Employment*||||||Oluwatimehin, John Medaiyese|M| Sediment dynamics in some streams on quartzites in central South-Western Nigeria.||||||Ph.D.| L.K. Jeje//O.O. Ogunkoya.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University, Geography    |1991. |||OAU|||||xiv, 258p.|||||||English  ||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Little information is available on sediment production from different surfaces in the humid tropical environment.  This information is especially vital not only for the geomorphological purposes of estimating the rate of surface lowering but also because the knowledge of the sediment load if rivers is vital for planning the use of such rivers for water supply projects.The objective here is to analyse the spartio-temporal variations in suspend sediment and solute load and yield characteristics of twelve small streams draining quartizites and quart-schist on the pre-Cambrian Basement Complex of Southwestern Nigeria.  These were analysed with respect to their land use and rainfall pattern based on data collected between April 1985 and May 1986.  An analysis of some of the elements of the solute content of stream water was also carried out.For this exercise, data on the drainage basins were obtained through map analysis and from field measurements.  Data on stream discharge values were obtained based on stream flow rating and the use of the small OTT current metre.  Data on suspended sediment and solute 1 ad were obtained from water sample analysis, while data on soil were obtained from the analysis of soil samples in the laboratory.The multivariate interrelationship between the morphometric, land use and rainfall parameters and between these and the sediment yield parameters were determined using correlation and multiple regression.  A classification algorithm was used to show the multivariate relationship between sediment yield and land use and basin physiographic parameters.  The pattern of suspended and solute transport in the streams, especially during storm-period, were examined graphically using hydrographs and hysteresis loops.  Three major groups of sediment response were identified: the single stream rise events in which sediment can either peak before or after discharge or may even correspond with it; the multiple rise events often associated with rainfalls of long duration with sediment peak before or after discharge peak; and the random or mixed response patterns in which sediment concentration respsonse exhibits no clear pattern.  Controlling factors of sediment availability, duration, frequency and intensity of storm event, antecedent precipitation indices, exhaustion and flushing effects.The results show that although the streams which are more or less of the same order and drain areas underlain by similar rock type, and within the same climatic region, exhibited great variations in their flow, sediment load and yield.  Suspended sediment concentration ranged from 6 mg/l and 2480 mg/l during the rainy season.  Specific suspended sediment yield varied between 2.1 tonnes/km-2/yr-1 and 44.4 tonnes/km-2/yr-1 with an average of 13.9 tonnes/km-2/yr-1.  Specific solute yield ranged from 6.0 tonnes/km-2/yr-1 to 42.5 tonnes/km-2/yr-1 with an average of 18.9. tonnes/km-2/yr-1  Solute yields are generally higher in the forested basins while suspended sediment yield is higher in the cultivated basins.  Spatial variations in suspended sediment concentration during the rainy season was related partly to land use variation and partly to routing conditions along the channels.Statistical analysis shows that land use and rainfall factors accounted for over 68% and 82% of the variance of total suspended sediment and solute yields respectively among the basins.  Over 92% of the total sediment yield in all the basins were transported during the rainy season with the maximum daily suspended yield contributing between 2.5 and 23.5 percent of the total suspended load in the basins during the study period.Nitrate, phosphate, potassium and magnesium levels in the stream water are generally low with nitrate, phosphate and potassium levels in the cultivated basins higher than the forested and the fallowed basins.  The standard limits for suspended and dissolved solids in drinking water have not been reached nor the limits for ions and cations exceeded. Agricultural and farming activities within the drainage basins are potential sources of water pollution by sediments, pesticides and fertilizers.Value of sediments data drom the study could be a useful index of catchment dynamics with which to assess the effects of man on the landscape. The action of man in disturbing the equilibrium of geomorphological and hydrological processes, as with agriculture is evidenced by increases in sediment production.|Theses collection.|sediment production /humid tropical environment/geomorphological purposes/water supply projects/Southwestern Nigeria/drainage basins/potassium and magnesium levels*||||||Dzobo, Joselin Mawunyo|F|Preparation and separation of fatty acids from palm oils. ||||||M.Sc.|A.N. Anozie||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University, Chemical Engineering    |1991|||OAU|||||xiii, 185p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The present economic crisis in the country has brought into focus the need for local sourcing of industrial raw materials.  One of such industrial raw materials is fatty acid from vegetable oils. A modified Twitchell process involving hydrolysis was used to prepare fatty acids from palm oil and palm kernel oil.  Solvent crystallization using methanol as solvent was used for separation into olein  and stearin fractions.  The effects of water to oil ratio, temperature,  catalyst level and time on the hydrolysis were evaluated and the kinetics of the hydrolysis studied.  Similarly, the effects of fatty acid mixture to solvent ratio, type of solvent, final temperature of cooling and rate of cooling on the solvent crystallization process were evaluated. The kinetics of the hydrolysis was found to be first order for the first 6 hours.  After this period, the reaction deviates from first order kinetics due to the effects of the reverse reaction.  The first order kinetics confirms that the reaction is homogeneous which occurs by water dissolving in the oil phase.  The rates of reaction constants of 0.32 hr-1 and 0.21 hr-1 were obtained for the hydrolysis of palm and palm kernel oils respectively.  These values are greatly affected by change in temperature.It was found that a double stage hydrolysis at 100oC using 0.5% (w/w) catalyst to oil ratio with 25% (w/w) and 50% (w/w) water to oil ratio for palm oil and palm kernel oil respectively increased the degree of completion from 75  98% for palm oil and 70  87% for palm kernel oil. The total reaction  was found to be 12 hours. Each stage took 6 hours to complete with sweetwater being withdrawn at the end of each stage. In the separation process, it was found that a fatty acid mixture to solvent ratio of 2030% (w/w) gave the best possible  separation.  The two solvents used showed no difference in their effect on separation. An increase in the rate of cooling from 0.7oC/min to 0.9oC/min produced a poorer quality olein fraction.  The final temperature attained during cooling has an effect on the quality of the olein fraction.  Lower temperatures produce low quality olein fractions.|Theses collection.| local sourcing/industrial raw materials/fatty acid/vegetable oils/modified Twitchell process/Solvent crystallization/Lower temperatures*||||||Iwuala, Justin Okechukwu|M|Application of spouted bed systems in gari processing.||||||M.Sc.|O. Akinjola.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University       |1991|||OAU|||||xiii, 123p. |||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The spouted bed system was developed by Mathur and Gishler in 1954 during an attempt at drying agricultural grains using fluidized bed.  The spouted bed technique is a variant of fluidization which permits agitation of solid materials that are too coarse and uniform in size for good fluidization.  Later modifications of the original spouted bed system design, which include the draft tube spouted bed (DTSB) and the sideoutlet spouted bed has extended the application to small particles (dp < 1mm) and thus placed spouted beds in direct   competition  for  applications involving fluidized beds.  The  DTSB has been applied successfully in many areas which include drying of animal blood, combustion, tablet coating, particle granulating and chemical reactor operations.  The present study involved the application of the DTSB system in 'garification' stage of gari processing.  This entailed the design and fabrication of the DTSB system and the use of the fabricated DTSB as a 'garifier'.The design of the experimental DTSB was based on the determined physical particle properties (moisture content, particle size, gelatinization temperature) and predicted spouting properties of product gari and pregarified gari. The DTSB system consisted of a pyrex glass of thickness 0.2 x 102m with a 60o conical base followed by a 5.8 x 102m diameter and 0.76m height cylindrical section with 2 x 102m inlet region and a draft tube insert of 1.5 x 102m internal diameter and 0.24m in length.  The draft tube is supported in the drying chamber by a 3-glass rod tripod of 3cm each. The heating chamber consisted of an air inlet and outlet regions of 2 x 103m internal diameter, followed by a 3.1 x 102m diameter and O.80m long cylindrical section. It was discovered that fermented cassava flour could not be garified without a spouting aid at any moisture content below 60%.  Using already processed gari as the spouting aid, fermented cassava flour was readily garified provided its moisture content was greater than 30%. In effect, the minimum moisture content before gelatinization could occur was higher than that required in existence processing methods which is about 24%. Although fermented cassava was found to gelatinize at about 60oC using an amylogram, no gelatinization was observed in the DTSB until the bed temperature reached 130oC. The DTSB techniques yielded a gari product of very low moisture content when compared with other methods. In addition, the cold water swelling capacity of the gari produced was found to be relatively highe than that produced using conventional methods.|Theses collection.|agricultural grains/fluidization/bed system design/ physical particle properties /moisture content/ particle size/ gelatinization temperature/fermented cassava*||||||Akinwale, Oladotun Coker|M|The effects of high velocity gradients in water coagulation.||||||M.Sc. |Olusola Ogedegbe||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University, Civil Engineering       |1991|||OAU|||||xiii, 104p|||||||English ||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|An overview of the trend of the nation's economy within the past one decade leaves no doubt as to the desirability of any effort aimed at minimising the spending of not only the hardearned foreign currencies but also the local one. Purchase of aluminium sulphate (alum)  commonly used in the nation's waterworks is gulping colossal amounts of money yearly. Any effort to substantially reduce this therefore becomes meaningful, laudable and one in the right direction.  It is against this background that this study was undertaken to investigate the effects of high velocity gradient, G (intense rapid mixing) in water coagulation,, with and without addition of coagulant.The typical raw water used for the study was obtained by damming a portion of the stream in front of the Civil Engineering Building at Obafemi Awolowo University, IleIfe.  A 32litre sample of the raw water was positioned ready for the run in a tank and using a calibrated highshear stirrer, the water was subjected to selected levels of G200, 500 and 800 per second for 2, 8, 16, 24 and 32 minutes. In cases where coagulant was used to supplement G, it was added immediate the rapid mixing was begun.  The results were analysed using turbidity removal, pH and level of finished water alkalinity as yardsticks.It was found that turbidity removal generally continued to improve with increasing G with or without coagulant, with more substantial improvement obtained when coagulant was applied.  However optimum coagulant dosage was 20 mg/l alum or 30 mg/l ferric chloride for all levels of G applied.Application of velocity gradients without coagulant generally had no significant effect on the pH and level of finished water alkalinity.  On the other hand, depressions in the pH values and levels of finished water alkalinity resulted when G was supplemented with coagulants, with greater depressions given by the ferric chloride than the alum.Conclusively, high velocity gradients with and without addition of chemical coagulants have substantial effects on water coagulation.  On the basis of the three yardsticks of turbidity removal, pH and level of finished water alkalinity, application of G alum gave the best results.|Theses collection.|foreign currencies/high velocity gradient/pH/level of finished water alkalinity/turbidity removal*||||||Asemota, Godwin Norense Osarumwense|M|Development of a generalized algorithm for steady state and contingency load flow investigations||||||M.Sc.|M. O. Omogiui.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University, Electronics & Electrical Engineering   |1991|||OAU|||| |xii, 138p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Loadflow information is vital for the successful operation of an electrical power system in normal and contingency conditions.  The established methods of Loadflow Computation employing either the Gause-Seidel or newtonRaphson algorithms do not consider contingencies such as sudden loss of generation and transmission line.  Additional algorithms are employed to obtain the system performance under such conditions and a consequent delay in obtaining solution in contingency situations.  An algorithm which combines existing methods such that Load flow computation under normal as well as contingency conditions is developed and employed to simulate a model power system.The generalised algorithm employs the fastdecoupled technique which separates electrical power into its real and reactive parts.  For a typical sevenbusbar network, the power flow equation is linearised around a specified operating point and the algorithm was developed such that load flow solutions are obtained under steady state and contingency situations. Contingency analysis is simulated by the removal of transmission lines, transformers and generators of the seven busbars system, one at a time, to investigate the load flow pattern.  An optimal generation strategy that aims at producing and supplying the most economical power in a system is also investigated.  The simulation is carried out on an IBM PC/AT digital computer running on Fortran.The results from the simulation show rapid convergence for the nonlinear load flow equations, even without acceleration factor.  The total optimal real power generated is 10.78pu at the minimum cost of fuel. The variance of power flow of the lines about their mean position varies between 0.0 and 0.415. The load flow algorithm can easily be extended to cope with larger network. It can be implemented for online estimation of load flow when suitable modifications and possible extensions are made to the algorithm.|Theses collection.|Loadflow information/electrical power system/contingency conditions/Gause-Seidel or newtonRaphson algorithms /fastdecoupled technique/nonlinear load flow equations*||||||Fagbohun, Olumuyiwa Oludare|M|Development of an automatic generation controller for a practical electric power generating system.||||||M.Sc. |O.A. Komolafe.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University, Electronics & Electrical Engineering|1991|||OAU|||||xiii, 131p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The electric power demand by consumers vary continually and it is necessary that the power generated be varied to achieve generationload demand balance.  When any imbalance between the the generation and load demand occurs, the frequency of the system deviates from its nominal value.  This, among other effects, affects the performance of frequency sensitive loads. It is therefore necessary to formulate a generationload demand balance strategy to kee the frequency fluctuations within acceptable limits of the nominal value. In this work, the conventional method of controlling power generation and frequency under chaning power demand by the National Electric Power Authority (NEPA) was studied and its deficiencies highlighted.  A microprocessor based automatic generation control safer bias designed and simulated on a digital computer.The control system consists of a supervisory  controller for the control centre and an area controller for each generating station, both linked by a communication network. The supervisory controller compares the power system frequency with a reference frequency of 50Hz. The error is used to compute the required generation change and this change is distributed among generating stations according to predetermined criteria. The required changes are encoded and transmitted to the generating stations.  Each area controller decodes the received signal and effects the required  generation change so that the operating frequency is maintained close to its nominal value.The performance of the designed controllers was simulated on a computer.  To maintain the system frequency within +0.2% of its nominal value, the system controllers were found to respond to a change in generation request in less than thirty seconds compared with about the five minutes it takes to get on generating station to respond using the present method. This result satisfies the design criteria for the maintenance of frequency at nominal value, fast response to demands and improved efficiency and reliability. |Theses collection.|electric power/generationload demand balance/nominal value/frequency sensitive loads/frequency fluctuations /National Electric Power Authority (NEPA)/microprocessor /automatic generation control safer bias/communication network/generating stations*||||||Oyebisi, Timothy Oyedepo|M|Development of a telemetry system for the measurement of groundfoot forces in human gaits||||||Ph.D.|L.A. Buraimoh-Igbo||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University, Electronics & Electrical Engineering|1991||| OAU|||||xxii, 227p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|In rehabilitative procedures for the restoration of certain functional normalities in pathologic gait it is always desired first to quantify the groundfoot forces exerted on the ground by the body during ambulation.  This allows for identification of the degree of the abnormalities in pathological gaits thereby, providing diagnosis and hence the required treatment to prescribe.This thesis discusses the development of a telemetry system for the measurement of groundfoot forces in human gaits.  The system consists of both a mobile subassembly and a stationary subassembly. The mobile subassembly consists of an instrumented shoe unit, transmitting-end signal processing module and an FM transmitter.  The mobile subassembly which is battery powered and compactly packed is to be carried by a subject whose groundfoot forces are being measured.  The stationary subassembly which is at the operator base is made up of an FM receiver, receivingend signal processing module, an analogue processing module and an interface module made up of RS232C serial interface and GPIB IEEE 488 parallel interface units.  The outputs of the interface module are fed into the inputs of an HP85 minicomputer for data acquisition and analysis.  The outputs of the analogue processing module are fed into the inputs of a chart recorder to obtain optional and alternative analogue display of the groundfoot force data.The passive components used to build the system have tolerances in the range 0.1% to 1% and temperature coefficient of between 50ppm/oC and 75ppm/oC.  These together with the use of high performance active devices make the system to have a maximum measurable groundfoot force of 100kgf with +1% (or -1%) error.  The system has a range of 100 metres while the bandwidth of each force channel extends beyond 30Hz.  The gait waveform obtained for normal subject is a true representation of the well known pattern of groundfoot forces.  From the shapes of these waveforms, the degree of abnormalities in certain pathological gaits are identified and quantified.  This indicates that the systems can be effectively used as a clinical tool and as a research equipment in the studies of human gaits.|Theses collection.|rehabilitative procedures/functional normalities/pathologic gait/ambulation/telemetry system/mobile subassembly/stationary subassembly/tolerances /parallel interface units*||||||Bamigbade, Ajibade Kolawole|M|Evaluation of some nonwheat flours for water manufacture||||||M.Sc. |I.A. Adeyemi.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University, Food Science & Technology|1991. |||OAU|||||xii, 69p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Wafer constitute a specialized type of biscuits conventionally baked from wheat flour batter. In this study, the manufacture of wafers from nonwheat flours is investigated.  Wafer samples produced from cocoyam flour and starch, green banana and breadfruit flours were evaluated for some quality attributes, acceptability and storage stability.Flour and starch were prepared from cocoyam tubers, green banana and mature unripe breadfruit. Experiments were carried out to determine for flour and starch yield, proximate composition, Brabender amylograph pasting characteristics, laboratory and pilot optimum water absorption and batter consistency. Wafers manufactured from flour and starch samples were evaluated for proximate composition, weight, thickness, bulk density, flour acidity, moisture uptake, colour and sensory attributes. Flour and starch yield for cocoyam was 73.06 and 48.84% respectively.  The nonwheat flours had low protein contents which ranged between 1.70 and 7.89%, while corresponding value for wheat flour was 8.9%.  The range obtained for fat and ash contents were 0.08  2.20% and 0.29  4.05% respectively.  All the nonwheat flour samples were found to absorb more water than the wheat flour.  Amylograph pasting viscosity data showed breadfruit flour to be most stable while banana flour was the least stable.Data obtained for wafer quality weight (0.14-0.22 g/cm2), thickness (1.37-2.14 mm) and bulk density (0.08-0.13 g/cm3).  Storage stability test showed banana wafer to be comparable with that of wheat wafer while cocoyam flour wafer was the least stable.  Breadfruit wafer picked up highest amount of moisture at 32.3% relative humidity while wheat wafer absorbed the least amount of moisture.  The non-wheat wafers were found to be acceptable by more than 80% of panelists, however there was no significant difference in the overall acceptability of the sample.|Theses collection.|Wafer/nonwheat flours/storage stability/batter consistency/ proximate composition/weight, thickness/bulk density/flour acidity/moisture uptake/colour and sensory attributes*||||||Unokiwedi, Chukwuemeka Charles|M|Nutritional evaluation of warankasi prepared from cow milk partially substituted with melon milk.||||||M.Sc.|J.B. Fashakin.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University, Food Science & Technology|1991|||OAU|||||x, 94p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Protein shortage is a perennial problem in most developing countries of the world.  Consequently, a great deal of attention has been focussed on finding alternative protein sources to either supplement or replace the animal protein sources which are scarce and expensive.  Plant protein sources have been found attractive both on cost and availability.  Warankasi, a soft unripened cheese, was produced from whole milk partially substituted with melon protein.Experiments were conducted to investigate the level of substitution of melon seed milk into whole milk in the production of warankasi.  Fresh cow milk was obtained from Cogi near Ede while melon milk was produced in the laboratory from melon seeds obtained from Sabo market, IleIfe.  The substitution was carried out at the ratio of 3:1 (i.e. 25% melon milk to 75% whole milk).  Cheese was produced by the application of Sodom apple (Calotropis procera) juice extract where the active enzyme has been identified as "calotropain".  The cheese thus produced was named "waragusi".  It was later fed to experimental animals for a period of 28 days.The results showed that the composition of waragusi (dry weight basis) was 41.68% protein, 48.83% fat, 6.28% ash and 3.12% carbohydrate.  The yield with respect to melon milk, waragusi and warankasi were 74.34%, 22.16% and 24.90%) respectively.  This waragusi compared favourably well with whole warankasi in terms of organoleptic properties such as Aroma, Texture, Colour and Flavour. The bioassay procedure also showed that the composite cheese enabled experimental animals to grow such that the parameters; Protein Efficiency Ratio (PER) and Net Protein Ratio (NPR) showed no significant differences (P> 0.05) with those obtained for whole cheese (warankasi). Values of (PER), 1.94 + 0.23 and 2.43 0.39; and (NFR) 2.37 0.24 and 2.92 0.39 were recorded for waragusi and warankasi respectively. It was thus concluded that melon milk and other suitable vegetable milk offer potential sources as regards substitution in the production of cheese.  The advantages of these substitutions in the total eradication of Protein Energy Malnutrition (PEM) and general malnutrition was greatly highlighted.|Theses collection.|Protein shortage/developing countries/animal protein sources/Plant protein sources/Warankasi/organoleptic properties/Protein Efficiency Ratio (PER)/Net Protein Ratio (NPR)/ bioassay procedure*||||||Adetunji, Adelana Rasak|M|Use of cyanide solution from cassava for the extraction of gold||||||M.Sc.|G.O. Egunjobi//J.A. Ali.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University , Metallurgical & Materials Engineering|1991|||OAU||||| xi, 140p.|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|The two major techniques of extraction of gold from its ore are the amalgamation and cyanidation methods.  The principal reagents for amalgamation and cyanidation methods are mercury and sodium cyanide (NaCN) respectively. Neither of these reagents is manufactured locally.  Cassava has been found to contain cyanogenic glucoside from which hydrocyanic acid is liberated.  This work is therefore intended to investigate the suitability of cyanide solutions extracted from cassava for the extraction of gold.  It is also intended to compare the gold yields from a given deposit by employing the methods of amalgamation and cyanidation and deduce therefrom the better method of extraction of gold from the deposit.The Modified Lambert method was employed in extracting cyanide from cassava and analysed for concentration. Various cyanide concentrations were prepared from both the solution obtained from cassava and standard NaCN.  The gold ore employed had earlier been preconcentrated from the source.  Part of the ore was retained as received while the rest was ground to 230 mesh to facilitate cyanidation process. The standard method of cyanidation was used at laboratory level in treating known quantities of ore with the various solutions.  Also known quantities of ore were treated with mercury for amalgamation.  It was found that the yields from cyanide solutions from cassava were relatively lower than the yields from equivalent concentrations of standard NaCN.  However, for cyanide solutions from both sources, the yields increased with concentrations.  The efficiency of cyanide solutions from cassava compared with the standard grade sodium cyanide (NaCN) in terms of gold yield for equivalent concentrations was found to range from about 60% to 78%.  Also the yields from the amalgamation process were lower than the yields from both sources of cyanide especially at relatively high cyanide concentrations.|Theses collection.|extraction of gold/amalgamation and cyanidation methods/cyanide/cassava /cyanidation process/ cyanide concentrations*||||||Adetunji, Rasaq Olayide|M| Evaluation of influence of process variables on the corrosion performance of hotdipped galvanized steels.||||||M.Sc.|J.A. Ali.||Ile Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi  Awolowo  University , Metallurgical & Materials Engineer|1991|||OAU|||||xviii, 124p. |||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H.O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorise the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organisations for the purpose of private study or research.|Hotdipped galvanized steels find applications as shiphull, reinforcing steel, pilings and rails in marine environment.  This environment is highly corrosive because of its salinity with high percentage of sodium chloride. The influence of galvanizing temperature, immersion duration,, withdrawal speed, aluminium and antimony addition to the zinc bath on the corrosion performance of hot-dip galvanized steel sheets in 5% sodium chloride environment were investigated and evaluated.  This work is expected to establish the optimum process variables and thickness of the coating evolved, which are vital to the improvement of the corrosion resistance of galvanized sheets, particularly in marine environment.The investigations involved hotdipping of three gauges of clean steel sheets in "pure" molten zinc at 430oC, 450oC, 470oC and 490oC for 30 seconds, 60 seconds, 90 seconds and 120 seconds and withdrawing them at speeds of 3m/min, 4m/min, 5m/min and 6m/min.  Small amounts of aluminium, antimony and combinations of the two elements in proportions of 0.05%, 0.1%, 0.15%, and 0.2% of each element were added to the zinc bath in form of aluminiumzinc alloy and antimonyload alloy.  The galvanized sheets were tested for corrosion performance according to ASTM standard B 117 (1964).  Weight losses of the tested specimen were determined.It was found that, the corrosion resistance of the coatings increased with increase in galvanizing temperature from 430oC to 450oC, but decreased thereafter. It also increased with increase in immersion time from 30 seconds to 60 seconds and decreased thereafter.  The corrosion resistance of the coatings increased with increase in withdrawal speeds having maxima at 4m/min and 5m/min for gauge 22 and 28 sheets respectively.  However, for gauge 18 sheets it decreased with increasing withdrawal speed.  The optimum process variables were determined to be 450oC as galvanizing temperature, 60 seconds as immersion time, 3m/min, 4m/min and 5m/min as withdrawal speeds for gauges 18, 22 and 28 sheets, respectively.  The coating thicknesses obtained from these optimum variables were 85 um, 90 um and 101 um for gauges 28, 22 and 18 sheets, respectively.  Antimony was the most effective in increasing corrosion resistance, followed by aluminium plus antimony and lastly, aluminium.  The optimum concentrations of the elements were found to be 0.05% for aluminium, 0.15% for antimony and the combination of the two for aluminum plus antimony addition.|Theses collection.|Hotdipped galvanized steels/ reinforcing steel/marine environment/salinity/galvanizing temperature/immersion duration/withdrawal speed/corrosion resistance*||||||Akinbile, Olufemi Adeniyi|M|The role of politics in the development of secondary schools in Ogun State, 1976 - 1986||||||M.A. History of Education|S.S. Obidi||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Educational Foundations & Counselling|1996|||OAU|||||x,119p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This study examined the role of Politics in the development of Secondary Schools in Ogun State from 1976 to 1986.The historical research method was used for the study. Data were collected from Primary sources, such as documents and interviews, and were supplemented with data from secondary sources like books, journals and newspapers. Data from these sources were collated, analysed and discussed to determine the role of politics in the development of secondary schools in Ogun State during the period. Simple statistics such as percentages were used for the analysis.It was found that politics affected the development of secondary schools in Ogun State between 1976 and 1986. The scope and provision of secondary education increased substantially between 1976 and 1979. During this period, when the Federal government launched the Universal Free Primary Education Scheme throughout the country, Ogun State which hitherto, enjoyed free primary education under the Action Group government of Chief Obafemi Awolowo, continued to enjoy it under the military government. In order to make provision for the increased number of pupils who would leave primary schools for secondary schools and to sustain the support of the citizens of the state, the state military administration built more  secondary schools between 1976 and 1979.  In fact, thirtytwo new secondary schools were established in the state during this period. From 1979 to 1983a partisan polity was a major influence in the development of secondary schools in the state The ruling political party in the state, the Unity Party of Nigeria, had as one of its party programmes, Free Education at all levels, It was this policy that three d the provision of secondary education in the state during the period. Consequently, many secondary schools were established. Throughout the state and students  increased more ten ever before. The number of secondary schools rose from one hundred, at the beginning of 1979, to three hundred and thirty-five, by 1983. In addition, the awareness of the people of the state on education increased during this period; and  the need to encourage more pupils to attend secondary schools forced the state government to provide more opportunities for primary wheels leavers to benefit from secondary education. When a military government assumed office in the state in 1983, it  re-examined the provision of secondary education. Thus, between 1983 and 1986, secondary education in the state witnessed a lot of fundamental changes. The military government, having found that the standard of secondary education was falling due to the politicization of education by the past civilian regime, introduced some corrective measures. These measures led to a drastic fall in the number of secondary schools in the state. Student enrolment also decreased; since secondary education was no longer free. It became clear that the politicization of education did not help the development of education in the state; rather it lowered the standard and quality of education. Perhaps that was why the military government took steps to remedy the situation.|Theses Collection|Politics/secondary education/Universal Free Primary Education Scheme/Action Group government/Chief Obafemi Awolowo/military government*||||||Akinremi, Francis Akinsode|M|Organisation and administration of sporting activity programmes in tertiary institutions in Kwara and Osun State||||||M.A. Physical Education|S.A. Data were collected with two structured questionnaires; the Athletes Sports Questionnaire  (ASQ) and Sports Personnel  Questionnair (SPQ) which were served on the subjects. Data collected were analysed descriptively using percentages.The results of the analysis revealed that facilities and equipment in the institutions were inadequate in number and were not properly maintained.. This inadequacy was indicated by 67% and 55% of the athletes and sports personnel respectively. It was also found that sports officials were not adequate in number while some were incompetent in terms of experience. This was indicated by 36.24% and 10% by the athletes and sports personnel respectively. International Relations|Jide Owoeye||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, International Relations|1996|||OAU|||||x115p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This study, critically examines the role of the Afro-Asian bloc in the international system, with a brief surveyof the historical underpinnings that culminated in the Conference of April 1955, in Indonesia. The study also critically the political and economic influence of the Afro-Asian bloc within the International system, from the 1960s upward, due basically to their preponderance in size within the United Nations General Assembly.The method adopted in the study is descriptive and analytical in nature. Data were sourced secondarily mainly, through the use of published works on the central themes of the subject  matter under review. However informal interviews were conducted on Afro-Asian relations with a critically synthesized comparative analysis of the various data collected.Our findings reveal that, politically, the Afro-Asian bloc performed creditably well within the international arena unlike in the economic realm. Due to their common colonial experience, they were able to stand firmly successfully and with one voice at the U.N. General Assembly to fight against colonialism` apartheid and racism among other issues.Economically, even though the bloc performed creditably to some extent, yet all their efforts in making sure that the World became a better place to live in, where the principles of justice and equity would be the order of the day through the quest for New International Economic order (N.I.E.O,) became unrealisable,  due mainly to the recalcitrant posture of developed Countries unwilling to shift grounds, or even when such grounds were shifted, they were mainly made non-operational. As a result of the foregoing, the study posits that only formidable south-south co-operation could make negotiations the North fruitful, and that the Afro-Asian bloc, if revamped, would certainly go a long way in ameliorating the new perils being witnessed by members in the New World order.|Theses Collection|Afro-Asian bloc/Conference of April 1955, in Indonesia/international system/United Nations General Assembly/colonial experience/apartheid/racism/principles of justice and equity/New International Economic order (N.I.E.O)*||||||Akinlade, Oladipo Rasak|M|An assessment of muscovy duck ( Cairina moschata) production||||||M.Sc. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Three studies were conducted to assess the production potential of Muscovy Ducks. The first was a survey of 72 duck producers, 12 respondents each in 6 local government areas of Lagos State. The questionnaire sought base-line information pertaining to: flock characteristics, management practices, and production constraints. Administered questionnaires were subjected to non-parametric, descriptive and inferential statistics as appropriate.Only the extensive management system was used by all the respondents. The mean flock size was 6.8 with a drake: duck ratio of 1:2. Water and supplementary feeds (mainly 'eri' and maize grains) were provided daily for ducks. Majority (63.9%) of raisers had experienced disease outbreak in their flocks, and virtually all (95.8%) respondents were interested in receiving veterinary services for their flocks. Disease and mortality were the major production constraints mentioned. The improved productivity of Muscovy ducks will require interventions to prevent and control disease.The second study was a hatchability trial. A total of 69 Muscovy duck eggs were collected from 8 villages in Lagos, Osun and Kwara States. The eggs from Kwara State had significantly (P<0.05) lower mean weights (59.0+2.9g) than those from Lagos (66.95.8) and Osun (61.5+5.4) States. Only eggs from Lagos and Osun States hatched, and their mean duckling hatch weights did not differ significantly (P>0.05) and had a pooled mean value of 39.1 grams. The low hatchability (16%) is attributed to problems with sources of eggs, and conditions of transportation and incubation of the eggs. The third study was a 10-week On-farm feed supplement trial. Three Muscovy duck raisers flocks within the Obafemi Awolowo University staff quarters were each assigned different daily feed supplements as treatments (Ti, T1 20g of unconventional feed, T2 and T3 were raiser determined amounts of commercial feed and maize grains respectively. Though significant differences (P<0.05) in mean daily feed intake were noted - T1 71.622.1, T2 13.80.9, and T3 17.46.6, all treatments resulted in live body weight gains. Treatments significantly (P<0.05) affected body weights of mature ducks: Ti, 1855.8+106.9; T2, 1652.5+61.3; T3, 1276.0+122.2 and drakes: T1, 3695.0+192.7; T2, 2640.0+60.8; T3, 2387.8147.8) and weight gains of grower drakes: T1,15.214.1; T2, 6.2+4.5; T3,-5.0+22.9. This study has shown that Muscovy ducks were kept by the extensive management system in small flock sizes in Lagos State. Also, hatchability of artificially incubated duck eggs was lower than expected, while the unconventional feed supported lower growth rate than conventional feeds.|Theses Collection|Muscovy Ducks/production constraints/mean flock size/veterinary services/disease/mortality/daily feed intake/conventional feeds  *||||||Adeyemi, Toyin Faramade|M|Biodegradation of Oso condensate by Pseudomonas putida and Pseudomonas fluorescens||||||M.Sc.
