Merrill)||||||M.Sc. Botany|A.A. Adelusi||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Botany|1996|||OAU|||||xii,116p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Soybean (Glycine max (Linn.) Merrill) seedlings grown in pots filled with top soil autoclaved at 120C for 15 minutes were subjected to weed competition and light stress to study the effects of the stresses on the growth and yield of this important grain legume.Weed competition stress was achieved by growing soybean with spurge weed (Euphorbia heterophylla Linn.) . Light stress on the other hand, was imposed by planting soybean under the shade provided by crepes myrtle (Largerstroemia indica Linn.) tree. There was another treatment which was a combination of the two stresses. 100 ml of water was supplied to each pot daily. This was supplemented with 200m1 of Long Ashton nutrient solution which was supplied twice weekly.During the crop's critical period, weed stress reduced dry matter production by 20%, light stress by 81% while a combination of the two stresses reduced it by 83%. At the end of the experiment, weed stress had increased dry matter by 3.5%, light stress still reduced it by 72 % while a combination of the stresses reduced it by 82%.Generally, plants in direct sunlight did better in terms of root length, leaf area and dry matter, and these increased at successive harvest intervals. Dry matter production was significantly different between light levels (P < 0.01) and the effect of light was dependent on time P < 0.001. Dry matter yield was not significantly different at culture levels (P < 0.05).The calculated growth analysis in terms of leaf area index (LAI), leaf area ratio (LAR), leaf weight ratio (LWR), specific leaf area (SLA), leaf area duration (LAD), relative growth rate (RGR), unit leaf rate (ULR) and the measured biochemical compositions namely chlorophyll, ash, moisture, crude fibre, fat, and nitrogen-free extract did not show a regular pattern at successive harvests.The results of relative yield (RY) showed that the crop became more competitive than the weed after its (crop) critical period in sunlight while the weed was generally more competitive under shade. Relative yield of the mixture was greater than 1.0, indicating that the yield of the mixedculture was greater than the mean of the two monocultures.In the reproductive phase, early anthesis was observed in all the stressed plants. Reproductive phase was shortened in the shade irrespective of culture but this was prolonged under weed competition stress in direct sunlight.At the density studied, competition from the weed prolonged the reproductive phases of the crop in both light regimes. Seed yield in mixedculture in full sunlight was significantly different from that of the other three treatments (P < 0.05).Thus, a higher economic return would be obtained when soybean is grown in mixture with C-4 plants. A cheap and natural means of controlling E. heterophylla and related weeds in soybean fields will include employing farming systems that will reduce irradiance and at the same time expose the crop to sunlight.|Theses Collection|Soybean/grain legume/weed competition stress/growth analysis/biochemical compositions/chlorophyll/ash/moisture/mixedculture/monocultures/E. heterophylla/ irradiance/photosynthesis  *||||||Ahura, Anna Nguamo|F|The effectiveness of staff discipline in higher educational institutions in Benue State of Nigeria||||||M.Sc. Public Administration|E.J. Erero||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Public Administration|1996|||OAU|||||x,119p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This thesis examined the effectiveness of staff discipline in higher educational institutions in Benue State of Nigeria. The Selected institutions were: College of Education, Katsina-Ala and Akperan Orshi College of Agriculture, Yandev. The study covered the years between 1989 and 1994.The methodology employed was theoretical, descriptive and statistical. Primary data were collected through questionnaire and interview methods. Secondary data were collected from the central Administration Offices in each of the institutions. Other relevant information were obtained from files, gazettes, addresses and speeches of the Rector/Provost, Newspapers, unpublished works on the two institutions and other relevant publications.The study established that there exists a relationship between discipline and environmental factors. These include the impact of culture, staff perception of fair discipline, and the role of the state in the management of the institutions. Although both institutions had rules and regulations, and procedures guiding disciplinary action variations were however observed regarding compliance with rules and regulations in the two institutions. Staffs of the College of Agriculture, Yandev were found to be more disciplined than the staff of the College of Education, Katsina-Ala.On the basis of the findings, the study made some policy recommendations which could assist in improving the effectiveness of staff discipline in higher educational Institutions of learning in Benue State. It was recommended that all heads of Departments should have interviews with their subordinates, during which their performance on the job in the previous years is reviewed and they are advised and instructed as to how to improve on their performance. A further recommendation was that Departments in the higher institutions of Learning need to give conscious attention to training and retraining of staff, to eliminate discriminatory practices against women and other cultural norms and values which conflict with organisational rules and regulations.On a final note, it was recommended that management should assess superiors on the basis of the performance of their subordinates. In addition, at the end of every five years, there should be a review of staff conditions of service and out-dated rules be removed or reviewed.|Theses Collection|Higher educational institutions/staff discipline/Rector/Provost/training/retraining of staff/cultural norms*||||||Ajayi, Titus|M|Locational factors supporting viable modern small-scale manufacturing industries in Ondo State, Nigeria||||||M.Sc. Geography|Z.S. Famisa||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Geography|1996|||OAU|||||xii,82p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This study carried out identification and analysis of the locational factors that support viable modern small-scale manufacturing industries in Ondo State, bearing in mind that locational factors fundamentally underlie the success or failure of small-scale industrial establishments.Three towns (Akure, Ado-Ekiti and Ondo) in Ondo State were selected as survey locations on the grounds of time constraint, cost and convenience. From these towns, a total of 160 small-scale industrial establishments which covered seven types of industrial activities namely: bakery, wielding, cloth weaving, furniture making, block making, sawmilling and iceblock making were surveyed. The methods of analysis employed were frequency analysis, percentile tabulation, content analysis, Likert-type scale and Stepwise multiple regression analysis.Small-scale industrial establishments in the study area conformed with the conceptual postulations that they produce mainly for the local market; are owned mostly by sole-proprietors and their main sources of capital is the personal savings of the operators. The three factors that had good response counts were nearness to market, availability of cheap land and -nearness to raw materials.Eight locational factors represented the independent variables in the stepwise regression model, while the dependent variable is the types of industrial activities. The independent variable in the regression equation provided an explanation for 29.6% of the variation in the dependent variable. Nearness to raw materials explained 11.7% of the variation; Availability of capital contributed 8%, nearness to labour 6.6% and nearness to market 3.3% respectively. The Likert-type scale shows that .3 factors, namely market, land and raw materials are the top-ranking locational factors and as such favourable for the successful location of small-scale manufacturing industries in the study area.In all, the findings imply that the locational factors that accounted for the success and viability of small-scale industrial establishments in the study area are spatio-economic factors, with the non-economic factors playing a supportive role.|Theses Collection|Manufacturing industries/small-scale enterprises/locational factors/sawmilling/local market/sole-proprietors/sources of capital/personal savings/nearness to market/availability of labour/Likert-type scale *||||||Akanle, Titilayo Olajumoke|F|Foraminiferal biostratigraphy and paleoecological deductions of Abiteye-3 and Makaraba-31 wells, Niger Delta||||||M.Sc. International Relations|Kayode Soremekun||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, International Relations|1996|||OAU|||||vii,91p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Interaction among actors in the international system ranges from conflict to cooperation. The relationship between Nigeria and Cameroun is no exception. It is against this backdrop that this study examines the changing character of the relationship between the two countries particularly in the period between 1981 and 1994.Although Nigeria and Cameroun share political, economic and cultural, affinities, these have not helped much in preventing mutual suspicion and misunderstanding between the two countries. Perhaps, the fluctuations in their relations are largely reflective of features like the colonially inspired fragmentation of ethnic groups across borders, unstable boundary demarcations and competitive economic and political institutions inherited at independence.Within this context of fluctuating relations, the study analyses the background conditions that shape and determine relations between Nigeria and Cameroun with the specific objective of exploring the factors and forces that ushered in the era of conflict between the two countries in the period under study. We also sought to identify and analyse the areas of cooperation between the two states.In the course of the study, data were obtained from two main sources: Primary and Secondary. The primary source includes pronouncements by top government officials as available in gazettes, government releases, publications and news papers. These were complemented by secondary sources of information from relevant literature such as books, journals, magazines, seminar papers and other academic publications.Given the geographical proximity as well as-the historical and political links between the two countries, the study observed that any approach to the border crisis that aims at a technical demarcation of the boundaries as the basis for the solution of the recurrent border conflict is doomed to fail. In the light of this observation. the study proposed the institution of a `collaborative regime' for the administration of the disputed trans-border areas. This would involve joint management of security, joint exploitation of fishery and minerals resources in their common territorial waters and joint industrial enterprises which would be in the direct interest of the peoples residing in the contested areas. This collaborative regime will hopefully stem the recurrent outbreak of armed conflict and diplomatic tiff between the two countries.|Theses Collection|International system/conflict/co-operation/politics/independence/culture/armed conflict and diplomatic tiff/Nigeria and Cameroun*||||||Adisa, Banji Olalere|M|The impact of farmers' co-operative societies on adoption of improved farm practices in Osun State of Nigeria||||||M.Sc. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The study was undertaken to assess the impact of Farmers' Cooperative Societies on the adoption of improved farm practices in Osun State. Five Local Government Areas (LGAs) were purposefully selected from the twenty-three Local  of involvement in arable crop production. Ten villages were randomly selected (two from each Local Government Area) from each of the five selected LGA. However, between five and twenty respondents (Cooperators and Non-Cooperators) were randomly selected on the basis of the strength of the Cooperative Societies and the population of the Non-Cooperators in each of the selected villages. Therefore, three hundred respondents (150 Cooperators and 150 Non-Cooperators) participated in the study.Structured interview schedule was developed and used for data collection. The statistical tools used in data analysis were frequency counts, mean, percentages, ranking, Chi-square, Correlation and Contingency Coefficient.The findings revealed that the Cooperators adopted more improved practices (land preparation, fertilizer application, Maize varieties, improved varieties of cassava, herbicides, spacing and seed dressing) than the Non-Cooperators. It was also revealed that the farmers joined the Cooperatives for various reasons. These reasons include: access to credit facilities; the desire to help others; the desire to improve their standard of living; moderate interest  rate; leadership training opportunities; adult education facilities; improved income; opportunity to share other farmers' experiences; contact with Extension Agents; and  opportunity to participate in community development activities.Problems associated with the Farmers' Cooperatives in the study area were managerial, structural, financial, logistics and unstable governmental policies. Agricultural Economics|E.O. Idowu||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Agricultural Economics|1996|||OAU|||||xiv,126p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The study examined the impact of land tenure systems on land use intensity in Egbado North and Egbado South Local Government Areas of Ogun State. The major objective of the study was to identify those factors inherent in the customary land tenure systems that are likely to affect land use intensification within the areas of study.Primary data were collected through an intensive farm level survey during the 1993/94 farming year from one hundred and eighty (ISO) farmers in the two Local Government Areas. The major technique of data collection was the use of structured questionnaire and on-the-spot observation. Data analyses were carried out using ordinary least-square stepwise regression, descriptive analysis and inter-correlation techniques.The findings indicated that each farm household cultivates an average of 10.3 hectares. The most important method of acquiring interest in farmlands is through partrilineal inheritance systems. The promulgation of the Land Use Act has not affected agricultural production and productivity at the local or farm level where it was  presumably meant to have its major impact. Some factors found to exert significant influences on land use intensity include land hunger as measured by competitors to specific farmland, and farmers perception of soil fertility. Moreso, the owner operators were not found  better than the tenant farmers in the use of farmlands.It was concluded that no single indicator can effectively represent land use intensification in all places, at all times and in all situations. The implications of the findings are that there is need for a review of the present Land Use Act to reorganise individual fragmented holdings through land consolidation. Measures to offset yield decline under intensified agriculture would be more effective and supported by farmers if planners acknowledge that the determinant of land use intensity is multivarious.|Theses Collection|Land tenure systems/land use intensity/farm level survey/partrilineal inheritance systems/Land Use Act/soil fertility/agriculture/Nigeria*||||||Adepoju, Haolat Folake|F|Strike as an instrument of collective bargaining in the Oyo State civil service. 1978-1993||||||M.Sc. It was also found out that it is only the presence of a strike that can force most public sector employers to negotiate and that is why strike activity tends to increase by the day.In conclusion,the study made some policy recommendations which could improve industrial relations practices generally and collective bargaining in particular. It was recommended that both management and labour-should develop positive attitudes and orientation towards collective bargainingas an institution thereby reducing incidence of strikes. (1985 - 1993)||||||M.Sc. Public Administration|S.B. Ayo//A.O. Sanda||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Public Administration |1996|||OAU|||||ix,91p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|There is general awareness of the importance of bureaucracy in any society especially one without a legislative arm of government as we presently have in Nigeria under the military. There is the perceived need for the bureaucracy or thecivil service to be responsive to societal needs. To this extent constant efforts are made at improving its performance so as to meet the demands; of the political system andthesociety.One of such efforts at improving the performance of the civil service was through the 1088 Civil Service Reforms enunciated by the Babangida led military regime. The reforms were the most important for their wider implications as it was extended to the state and local government levels. The reforms also altered the basic features of the Nigerian Civil Service which had been in place since the British Colonial Administration which established the Civil Service.Three research methods were adopted in carrying out the study. They are the library and documentary research, unstructured interviews and discussions with Civil Servants and finally, a questionnaire survey was distributed to sample opinions of Federal Civil Servants and non civil servants (the professional) in relation to the civil service reforms put in place. A total of 400 questionnaires were distributed while 258 or 64.5% were retrieved.The study found out that the perfection of hierarchy in the Nigerian Civil Service is not synonymous efficiency. Also, we found out that the concentration of awesome powers of financial management and disciplinary powers in the Minister/Commissioner may hinder public accountability. Furthermore, it was discovered that making the Ministers at the federal level and the commissioners at the state level the accounting officer in the Ministries has further reduced public accountability in the Civil Services in Nigeria.In addition, the professionalisation of the civil service personnel and structure has not enhanced efficiency and effectiveness in the civil services. This is due to the fact that civil servants are required to serve their career in one department or unit in the ministry without allowance for moving around to gather experience.Finally, since continued emphasis on correcting structural deformities of the bureaucracies as well as on administrative reforms and personnel turnover would do no more than scratch the surface of the problem, this study submits that a system transformation and the creation of a peoples's bureaucratic militia are the very first steps towards  making the Nigerian civil bureaucracy an effective agent of socio-economic development. |Theses Collection|Bureaucracy/Civil Service Reforms/military regime/British Colonial Administration/public accountability/Nigerian civil bureaucracy/Babangida led military regime  *||||||Adetoye, Peter Abiodun|M|Nigeria - Liberia relations under Samuel Doe.||||||M.Sc. A brief survey of the historical underpinnings that existed between Nigeria and Liberia under Sergeant Doe were carried out. How the Doe coup of 1980 in Liberia marked a turning point in the Nigeria-Liberia relations was explored. The ill-will that prevailed between Nigeria and  Liberia before the reign of General Babangida in Nigeria and the subsequent understanding between the two countries were evaluated. The study also examined Nigeria's ECOMOG initiative in Liberia as one of the Nigeria's major policy thrusts in Liberia.The method adopted in the study included the descriptive and analytical approaches. Data were sourced primarily by conducting informal interviews and from published works on Nigeria-Liberia relations. A comparative analysis of the data collected was done. Our findings revealed that under military regime, foreign policy decision-making processes tended to be personalized by the military leaders. This led to the marginalization of public opinion and specialized institutions responsible for foreign policy issues. The study established that Nigeria-Liberia relations under Samuel Doe and Ibrahim Babangida transformed from chronic suspicion and hostility that existed between the two countries to that of under-standing and co-operation. It was discovered that under Samuel Doe, Nigeria-Liberia relations was deeply rooted in Supranational interactions and not in mutually benefitting diplomatic or economic agreements. It. is intended to determine the sequence and age of strata penetrated and attempts a biostratigraphic zonation and correlation of the strata penetrated by the two wells.A total 20 ditch-cutting samples from the two wells were analysed and then processed for foraminifera, using conventional micropaleontological techniques. A total of 76 species, 40 genera and 22 families of both planktonic and benthonic foraminifera were recovered. However, the planktonic zones established include:	Globorotalia	margoritae zoneandGlobigerinoides obliquuus zone in both wells. International Relations|Amadu Srsay//Sola Akinrinade||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, International Relations|1996|||OAU|||||xiv,168p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This work examines the problems encountered by Nigeria and Israel in the course of their newly restored diplomatic relations, as well as the prospects of those relations, with special focus on the 1990s. The work identified and analysed the present and future implications of the new relations for both countries and the International System, and highlighted the prospects, merits and Limitations of closer ties between Nigeria and Israel. It also identified the problems which both countries would likely encounter in the course of the new relations and suggested possible solutions to such perceived problems.For methodology, both primary and secondary sources materials were relied upon. Official data such as official gazettes, governmental speeches and reports, economic statistical data, U.N.O and O.A.U. resolutions and reports, were aggregated and matched with findings that were unearthed through extensive interviews with scholars, diplomats, civil servants and interest groups. These, together with published books, journals, doctoral dissertations, newspaper and magazine reports were used to execute the research. The findings revealed that contrary to general expectations, the newly established relations have not yielded much economic or diplomatic break-throughs for either country neither has it solved Nigeria's need for industrialization through scientific/technological assistance from Israel or its United States ally. Aside minor gains through tourism, cultural exchanges, trade, educational and technical assistance, as well as diplomatic co-operations, the foundation of a strong and virile future relation is just being laid. However, the realization of such foundation work could be marred by political instability (mainly in Nigeria) and distrust between both countries and their nationals. In the light of these findings, it is recommended that Nigeria does not need the wholesome transfer of Israeli technology to the country, but a redirection of its scientific and technological breakthroughs for industrial production purpose. Nigeria needs Israel's assistance for this. Both countries will also derive mutual benefits from economic co-operation. Nigeria can also learn some lessons from Israel's effective means of curtailing religious uprising in its territory. Finally, Israel should not interprete peace with the Palestinians as connoting final peace in the Middle East until she is ready to revisit its Nuclear arms programme, as this is likely to affect its future relations with Nigeria.It is, however, concluded that domestic and not external variables, will most likely dictate the level and extent of deep commitment to the relations, as both countries have realised their need for mutual benefits through the relationships.|Theses collection.|Diplomatic relations/O.A.U. resolutions and reports/political instability/economic co-operation*||||||Aderounmu, Ganiyu Adesola|M|Design and simulation of a digital communication controller for a local area network||||||M.Sc Computer Science|Francis Joseph Ogwu||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Computer Science|1996|||OAU|||||x,141p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng| http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Communication controllers find extensive application in the area of data communication where they are employed to serve as an interface device between two or more workstations. This work describes the design and simulation of a digital communication controller to link two workstations over a distance. Thus providing resource-sharing and improved performance of distributed computer systems to the communities.Various modules of the digital communication controller viz: receiver, transmitter, memory, processor and the handshaking logic interface were specified. Mathematical model was developed for the following modules viz: receiver, transmitter, and memory, using probability distribution theory. The design of the transmitter, receiver, and memory modules were carried out based on the mathematical model developed. A flexible software was designed using assembly programming language and implemented on IBM PS/2 (International Business Machine Personal System 2) model 55SX microcomputer to provide handshaking between the communication controller and a workstation. Simulation of the receiver and the transmitter modules was also carried out based on the mathematical model developed.In the analysis of the communication controller, two models, point-to-point and multidrop were considered. The computer simulation result shows that point-to-point model with a packet size of 1024 bits, a message size of 4096 bits, a bit error rate of 10-9, and a maximum transmission distance of six kilometers between two workstations can be employed as design parameters in the event of actual construction as against the multidrop model. The point-to-point model indicates a communication system that can provide a variety of efficient communication primitives which enhances reliability|Theses collection.|data communication//point-to-point model//multidrop//extensive application*||||||Owokade, Adebola Lekan|M|Assessment of non-residential students' problems in colleges of education in Osun and Oyo state||||||M.A. Ed. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This study examined the effect of flowcharted advance organizers on the retention and transfer of the skills needed for library information retrieval by fresh undergraduates of Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile-Ife. It was carried out as a response to the need to seek viable strategies that could enrich the teaching of library skills to students just entering the tertiary level of education. Two hundred and forty students selected by stratified random sampling were assigned to four groups, A, B, C, and D, each presented with a different learning package. Group A was given the complete package of flowcharted advance organizer plus the learning material. Group B was given the learning material only while Group C was given only the flowcharted advance organizer. Group D was given the placebos. Six hypotheses were generated for the study. With the aid of two instruments, the Library Skills Mastery Test (LSMT) and the Library Skills  Transfer Test (LSTT), data were collected and analysed using the analysis of variance (ANOVA) and the t-tests. The t-tests were followed by further analysis using the Least Significant Difference (LSD) method. All the hypotheses were tested at the 0.05 level of significance.The results of the study revealed that the flowcharted advance organizer plus the learning material group (Group A) did not perform significantly better than the learning material only group (Group B). The results further revealed that the group exposed to	the flowcharted advance organizer plus the learning material
(Group A) and the group exposed to the learning material only (Group B) performed significantly better than the control group (Group D) that was not exposed to either of the treatments;both Group A and Group B were significantly better than the flowcharted advance organizer only (Group C). It was also found that the
enhanced performance of the flowcharted advance organizer plus the learning material group (Group A) and the learning material only group {Group B) was most noticeable on the achievement test. Finally it was found that the learning material (LIT) was the most important element of the learning packages presented to the groups.|Theses Collection|Flowchart/library information retrieval/Library Skills Mastery Test (LSMT)/Library Skills  Transfer Test (LSTT)/enhanced performance  *||||||Olateju, Mojisola Ajibike|F|Patterns of interaction in the sciences and humanities in the medium of English as a second language||||||PhD, English|Akindele Femi//Awonuga, C.O.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, English|1996|||OAU|||||xiii,178p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This Thesis examined the patterns of interaction in the science and humanity lessons in the Senior Secondary Schools using the medium of English as a Second Language (ESL) in three states in Nigeria. It aimed at finding out who controlled such classroom interaction and the strategies used, and at discovering the similarities and differences between patterns of interaction in the science and humanity ESL lessons. The -thesis further investigated how the above objectives could help in improving teaching strategies and pupil communicative ability in an ESL situation.The data for the study were collected from twelve Secondary schools drawn from Oyo, Osun and Ondo States of Nigeria. Four subjects were chosen from the school curriculum and these were: Biology, Chemistry, Economics and English. Audio recordings of lessons in these four subjects were made in each of the schools selected for the study. Discourse analysis approach to naturally occurring conversation was carried out on the texts on the basis of the Birmingham School theory represented in Sinclair and Coulthard (1975), Burton (1981), Berry (1981), Coulthard and Montgomery (1981) and Ventola 11987).The study showed that the teacher controlled and dominated both the science and humanity ESL, lessons. The strategies used by the leachers to control the lessons included simultaneous chorusing of answers by pupils on one hand and by Teacher/Pupil on the other hand as well as the use of hearing checks and reprimand of pupils. The study showed that there was the prevalence of language interlarding/code switching. This was used as a means of making explicit certain concepts that the pupils found difficult to grasp in English and also to check or correct an erring pupil. The study further found that the science and humanity lessons were similar in that they were both structured in terms of Initiation, Response, Feedback (IRF). They were different in the sense that there were more informatives and directives in the science lessons than in the humanities. On the one hand, there was paradiscourse in the sciences but none in the humanities. On the other hand there were more eliciting exchanges in the humanities than in the sciences. The study concluded that in the two lesson types, pupil contributions were fewer than those of the teacher. This was seen as an indication of teacher dominance of ESL classroom lessons.|Theses Collection|Language/Englisg Language/code switching/language interlarding*||||||Ayoade, Dupe Victoria|F|Correlation studies between the levels of lead and tin in soil samples around a lead smelting plant by x-ray fluorescence spectrometry||||||M.Sc. Chemistry|Nwosu,T.N.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Chemistry|1996|||OAU|||||xii,97p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Soil samples around Makeri Lead and Tin Smelting Company, Jos, Nigeria, were analysed for the lead and tin contents by x-ray Fluorescence spectrometry with the aims of determining the levels of these elements (pollutants) in the soil around the factory site. The extent of the spread of these elements into the soil and along the horizontal distance from the factory site is to be ascertained. Also, the suitability of x-ray fluorescence technique for the analyses of these elements (Pb and Sn) in the soil samples is to be assessed The soil samples were collected at different locations around the lead smelting plant at different distances from the factory site and at different soil depths(0-15, 15-30cm) and at selected control areas( remote from the factory). The samples were dried, ground and made into pelletes, and analyzed with computerized x-ray fluorescence spectrometer. Standard reference materials from national institute for standards and technology were used to determine the precision and accuracy of the technique.Generally, soil samples around the smelting plant (within 1km radius) were found to contain high level of Pb and Sn. The levels of these elements were found to decrease with increasing soil depth and horizontal distance from the factory site. The mean levels of lead and tin in the surface samples (0-15cm) collected at a distance of 50m from the factory were found to be 9499.40.6ppm and 876.132.2ppm respectivelyAt 500m distance, the levels of tin and lead were 253.722.7ppm and 599.32.7ppm respectively. The surface soil lead level was 5,211.80.4ppm at 100m distance from the factory while the levels in the surface soil samples at the farm location, staff quarters,  dam area and administrative block were 186.32.0ppm, 202.71.6ppm, 78.91.1ppm and 342.01.7ppm respectively. The two control soil samples were found to contain 62.74.1ppm and 73.91.4ppm of lead and 103.923.4ppm and 102.727.5ppm of tin in the surface.Judging from the UNEP and WHO tolerance limits for these elements in the soil ( and comparing with the Pb and Sn levels in the control soils) the conclusion was that soil samples around the smelting plant were grossly polluted.|Theses Collection| Makeri Lead/Tin Smelting Company*||||||Arayela, Olatunde|M|Problems and prospects of roadside development in Akure||||||M.Sc, Urban and regional planning|Fadare, S.O.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Urban and regional planning|1996|||OAU|||||xi,102p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or   research|The study was designed to carry out analysis of the problems relating to property development along the  right-of-way in Akure with a view to evaluate the effectiveness of the application of planning standards. The specific objectives of the study include investigations into the factors affecting property development along the main road and a review of the application of planning regulations in relation to development of adjacent facilities along the right-of-way. The technique of accidental sampling survey was used for collecting data and the result of the analysis showed that there were problems of street-trading along the main road as a result of ineffective application of planning regulations.Further findings showed that there were illegal conversions of buildings from one use to another without the approval of the Town Planning Authority, contravention of the regulation on road set-back, the problem of traffic congestion and non-provision of lay by and bus-bays. Other findings include the haphazard presence of mechanic and allied trades workshops along the main road, dumping of refuse along the road curb, and the problem of storm water drainage.  Furthermore, the study revealed irregular water supply, erratic power distribution, inadequate waste disposal system and the problem of renovation of buildings along the road.It is therefore suggested that provision should be made for lay by and bus-bays at the identified bus stops along the main road to ensure a smooth flow of traffic thereby reducing road congestion. Also, the regulation on road set-back should be strictly enforced in order to effectively combat on-street trading and haphazard presence of mechanics and allied workshops along the roads. The research also recommended provision of refuse collection receptacles in front of each building which would be emptied everyday in refuse collection vans to be provided by the government and dumped outside the city where it can be treated. On the illegal conversion of buildings without recourse to the Planning Authority, the research recommended that property developers should always seek the approval of the Planning Authority before embarking on change of use of their previously approved building plans.Furthermore, it recommended provision of functional infrastructural facilities to ensure regular flow of potable water, efficient drainage system and provision of effective sanitary system for each building.|These Collection|Planning standards/planning regulations/Town Planning Authority/traffic congestion/lay by/bus-bays/water drainage/power distribution/waste disposal system/renovation/infrastructural facilities *||||||Theses collectionOluwayemi, Osobusola Rufus |M|The effect of cassava based diets on the growth performance of indigenous pigs||||||M.Sc., Animal Science|Ilori,J.O.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Animal Science|1996|||OAU|||||viii,44p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Cassava pulp was soaked in cold water for four days, sundried and ground into a meal before it was incorporated into growing local pig rations at 0, 15, 30, 45, and 60% level. Cassava meal (CM) at dietary levels of 15 and 30% supported a faster and more efficient rate of growth in pigs than the complete cereal based diet (0% CM) and 45% CM diet. No differences in performance were observed between pigs receiving the control and the 45%' CM diets.The performance of pigs on the 60% CM diet was much lower than that of pigs on the control diet. Overall, pigs receiving the 15%CM diet had a faster and more efficient rate of weight gain than those on all the other treatments.Dry matter digestibility for all the pigs was highest in pigs on the control diet (0%CM) while the pigs on the 15% CM diet had a higher digestibility than those on the 30, 45 and 60%CM diets. No difference was observed in the dry matter digestibility in pigs receiving the 30 and 60%CM diets. Energy digestibility was highest in pigs receiving the 60% CM diet while pigs on the 0,15 and 45% CM diets had similar energy digestability. The efficiency of energy utilization was highest in pigs on the 15% CM diet and lowest in those on the 60% CM diet. The control and 45% CM diets produced efficiency of energy utilization that were similar. The cost of feed/kg decreased as the level of cassava meal in the diet increased. The cost/kg liveweight gain was slightly lower for pigs fed the cassava based diets than the complete cereal based diet. Overall, this study has shown that cassava can be used to replace corn and formulate the most economical ration for pigs at levels up to 15% of the diet without any adverse effect on the growth performance of local growing pigs.|Theses collection|Cassava pulp/growth/diets/digestibility/energy/pigs *||||||Ofoezie, Ifeanyi Emmanuel|M|A study of urinary schistosomiasis transmission in resettlement communities borderning Oyan river dam, Ogun State, Nigeria.||||||PhD., Zoology|Asaolu,S.O.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Zoology|1996|||OAU|||||xx,273p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The patterns of endemicity, transmission and reinfection following selective chemotherapy of urinary schistisomiasis  were investigated in Oyan Reservoir, Ogun State, Nigeria and, two adjacent resettlement communities (Abule-titun and Ibaro), established in 1984. The study was carried out between August 1990 and May 1993 an follow-up to a preliminary disease survey which in 1988 showed that Schistosoma haematobium was widespread in both communities.A comprehensive census of the communities and a questionnaire assessment of peoples perception of schistosomiasis were undertaken. Individuals were parasitologically examined in April/May 1991 and 1992 using sedimentation and dip strip techniques. Infected persons were treated in 1992 with standard dose praziquantel and school children were re-examined 1 month later for treatment efficacy and 3, 6 and 12 months post treatment for reinfection. Seven water contact sites were surveyed monthly for snails by a scoop and search method. Snails collected were identified to species and examined for Schistosoma infection using the shedding method. Six of the sites were observed quarterly for water contact patterns. Prevalence of infection rose from 30.2% among 650 persons examined in 1991 to 61.6,, among 591 persons examined in 1992. Geometric mean intensity of infection increased from 308 to 355 eggs/10ml urine in 1991 and 1992 respectively. Intensity was highly dispersed as only 20%, of the population excreted 95% and 80% of total egg output in 1991 and 1992 respectively. Infection patterns in 1991 and 1992 were comparable in all sex, village and tribal groups, but prevalence, incidence and intensity of infection in both years were significantly higher in children than in adults, with peaks in the age group 10 - 14 years. Compared with the 1988 situation, pattern of infection had progressed from its initial epidemic state to an endemic  state. Treatment efficacy among children 1 month post treatment 89% parasitology cure and 99.2% reduction in the overall  pretreatment intensity. Reinfection was 9.1%, 19.8% and 41.00% at 3, 6 and 12months post treatment with a tendency to decrease with increasing age. Economic contact activities accounted for 4Q% of most indices of water contact suggesting that alternative water supply might be relevant in stemming G Donal- contact activities.The snail species identified in the reservoir are Bulinus globosus,   B. forskalii, B. truncatus, Lymnaea natalensis, Indoplanorbis exutus and Potadoma spp., but B. globosus was identified as the local intermediate host. Transmission occurred mainly between August/September and December/ January.Factors identified as affecting seasonal and focal distribution of snails are rainfall, temperature, water level and water discharge patterns in the reservoir. In particular, the escalation of transmission between 1991 and 1992 was attributed to a prolonged water conservation during the hot dry season of 1991.|Theses collection.|Endemicity/transmission/schistosomiasis/chemotherapy/praziquantel/population/infection/parasitology *||||||Odejobi, Odetunji Ajadi |M|Simulation modelling of an intelligent linguistic processor for continuous speech recognition||||||M. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The use of speech in man-machine communication is becoming increasingly important, and research in this area is now a serious part of computer science activity, relating to signal processing, pattern recognition and artificial intelligence. Simulation modelling of a continuous speech recognizer is presented in this work.The proposed model consists of linguistically structured components which represent, as much as possible, various aspects of "natural" speech recognition processes. Acoustic phonetics and prosodic characteristics of speech were represented and processed using knowledge-based structures and rule-driven algorithms. Tools and algorithms, such as fuzzy logic, neural-network, Markov algorithm, reinforcement learning algorithm and automata theory were used to produce powerful mechanism for the successful simulation of the system's components. Some of the components of the system namely; the acoustic to phoneme mapping, speech template constructor, learning, and speech recognition modules were simulated using Intel 80X86 Assembler and Borland c++ running on an 80386 based microcomputer system.The test and evaluation mechanism as well as an environment proposed for the system could not be used to generate the performance level of the entire system, since only some of the system's components were simulated. However, observation of the result of the simulated components revealed that this approach can produce efficient performance, although with high memory and processing requirements.|Theses Collection|Simulation/modelling/communication/artificial intelligence/speech/linguistic/phonetics/*||||||Sanni, M. Abayomi|M|The oil dimension of Anglo-Nigerian relations||||||M.Sc.International Relations|Soremekun, Kayode||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Inernational Relations|1996|||OAU|||||viii,152p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Oil an energy source of growing importance in economic life, also takes on a political importance. It is in this respect, that this study examined the Oil Dimension of Anglo-Nigerian Relations,This study was carried out with the specific objective of examining and analyzing the role and position of oil in Anglo-Nigerian relations. We also sought to examine the origins of these oil related linkages. And in the process, appreciated the importance of oil in Anglo- Nigerian relations. This study is an enrichment of our understanding of the dynamic linkages between politics and economics. It also made up for the gap in extant literature on Anglo-Nigerian relations as regards oil.The significance of oil in Anglo-Nigerian relations, manifests the centrality of Britain in the evolution of the Nigerian oil industry. This centrality took root in the Colonial legislations, which made oil a point of domination in Anglo-Nigerian relations.  However, it moved from a point of domination to a point of hostility, when Britain evolved from a major consumer of Nigerian oil to a major producer of the same variety of crude. This movement of oil from a high point of domination, to a point of hostility, was a result of British displeasure over the Nigerian nationalization of the Barclays Bank and all the assets of the BP in Nigeria. The nature of the hostility and/or competition, was such that the BNOC was underselling the Nigerian oil by the price undercutting of the British Brent.The international and domestic climates in which Nigeria was able to embark on the nationalization of the BP have changed. These changed circumstances paved way for the return of the BP-Statoil into the Nigerian oil industry and an influx of multi-national oil companies of American and French origins.An obvious stronger presence of American and French companies the Nigerian oil industry notwithstanding, the return of the BP significant: in Anglo-Nigerian relations. This is made more significant when the 50% percent ownership of Britain in the Shell Group is considered, moreso with Shell producing more than 50% of t Nigerian 0.1.|Theses Collection|Crude-Oil/energy/politics/international relations/Nigerian oil industry/colonial legislations/nationalisation/Shell Group *||||||Abegunrin, Omotola Omolade|F|Petrophysical evaluation of two reservoir sands in five wells in the western part of the Niger Delta||||||M.Sc. Applied Geology|J.I. Nwachukwu// B.D. Ako||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Geology|1996|||OAU|||||xii,189p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The petrophysical characteristics of two reservoir sands in five wells drilled in the western part of the Niger Delta were  studied using borehole geogphysical (open hole) logs. These include Caliper log, Spontaneous Potential (SP), Gamma ray (GR). Lithodensity log (LDL), Compensated Neutron log (CNL) and Dual Laterolog (DLL) Microspherically Focused (MSFL) combination logs obtained from Shell Petroleum Development Company of Nigeria Limited. The evaluated petrophysical characteristics include porosity, permeability, fluid saturation, formation resistivities, resistivity of water, and reservoir thicknesses among others.Identified lithologies in the wells were sand, shaly sands and shales. The sands are the reservoir rocks while the non reservoir rocks are the shales. Two reservoirs designated A.O and B.O sands were studied in each of the five wells. These sands are separated by thick shale bodies over-lying and underlying each of the sand reservoirs. The A.O sand occurs between 6445ft (1954m) and 6635ft (2022m) while B.O sand occurs between 6684ft (2037m) to 6873ft (2095m). Slaty sands occur intermittently within the larger sand bodies.Gross and net sand thicknesses range from 88ft (27m) to 137f1 (42m) and 76ft (23m) to 126ft (38m) respectively for the A.O. sand, while the values are 89ft (27m) to 126ft (38m) and 71ft (22m) to 114ft (35m) respectively for the B.O sand. Net oil sand ranges from 4f3 (1.2m) to 42ff (13m) and 7ft (2m) to 72ft (22m) for A.O and B.O sands respectively. Both reservoir sands exhibit wide range in grain sizes ranging from very fine grained to coarse grained.The A.O sand porosity ranges from 12.04% to 36.61% with an average of 28% while B.O sand porosity ranges from 18.42% to 34.20% with an average of 26%. Low porosity values were obtained for the shaly sand intervals. In general, both A.O and B.O sands have excellent porosities. Permeability ranges from 0.06 x 102md to 498.07 x 102md with an average of 51.86 x 102md for A.0 sand and from 0.01 x102md to 288.80 x102rnd with an average of 46.61 x 102md for B.O sand.Saturating fluids identified from computed values of water saturation, porosity, resistivity and SP logs were oil and fresh water. Oil occurs on top of water. The oil water contact occurs at different depths in the sands ranging from 6481ft to 6516ft (1975 - 1986m) for A.O sand; and from 6739ft to 6762ft (2054 - 2061m) for B.0 sand.Both reservoir sands in the five wells with the exception of B.O sand in well 2 were found to contain hydrocarbons which in most intervals are moveable. Estimated hydrocarbon reserves total 15.10MMm3 (94.98 MMbbl) for the A.O sand and 11.95MMm3 (75.15MMbbl) for the B.O sand. These are viable reserves which have resulted in their economic exploitation by Shell Petroleum Development Company Nigeria Limited.|Theses Collection|Reservoir sands/Petrophysical evaluation/borehole geogphysical (open hole) logs/fluid saturation/Shell Petroleum Development Company of Nigeria Limited/Niger Delta/Slaty sands/porocity values/hydrocarbons  *||||||Abiola, Asimiyu Gbolagade|M|The impact of deficit budgeting on the economic development of Nigeria. 1970-1991||||||M.Sc. Economics|A.O. Olaloye||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Economics|1996|||OAU|||||xiv,144p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|In Nigeria, federal expenditures have consistently exceeded federal revenues most of the time since 1970. While deficit budget is not new in the economic history of Nigeria, the rather persistence of the deficits during peace time has been the cause of much concern to most observers of the Nigerian economy. Most of the existing studies on deficit budgeting have been qualitative; with few studies demonstrating any empirical relationship between deficit and economic development. The study therefore attempted to fill this gap by providing an empirical relationship between deficit budgeting and economic development of Nigeria. The question of whether deficit has been self-perpetuating in Nigeria was also addressed.Two models of analysis were specified and estimated. In the first model, we regressed Gross Domestic Product k GDP), on deficit financing, changes in price level and rate of interest. We applied Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) method to the time series data. for the period 1970-1991. In the second model, we regressed total public spending, on the share of Federal Government spending financed by taxation, per capita income, total population and per capita consumption. Similarly, we applied Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) method to the time series data, for the period 1970-1991.The results of our analysis suggest that deficit financing has a negative impact on GDP, with a one percent increase in deficit financing generating a 4.23 percent decrease in GDP. However, changes in price level and rate of interest were found to have positive relationships with GDP.Also, we found that federal deficits increase federal expenditures. Similarly, an increase each in both per capita income and total population produces a more than proportionate increase in the unit cost of public goods. Our results further suggest a lower growth rate for per capita consumption relative to public consumption. Thus, deficit budgeting has been self-perpetuating in Nigeria. The consistent higher growth rate of public consumption relative to per capita consumption confirms the dominance of public sector in Less Developed Countries.On the whole, deficit budgeting is not undesirable. What is rather undesirable in the Nigerian case, has been deficit, on unproductive activities. Thus, we recommended among other things, that in future, deficits should be expended on productive activities. The rationale behind this position, is that productive activities will be able to generate returns to liquidate both the principal and the interest payable.|Theses Collection|Deficit budgeting/federal expenditures/economic development/Gross Domestic Product/taxation/per capita income/total population/per capita consumption/Less Developed Countries/Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)*||||||Adedeji, Adetayo Victor|M|Preparation and characterization of (Co -V - O and Cr v O) pyrolytically deposited thin films||||||M.Sc.
