E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Metal Organic Chemical Vapour deposition of mixed oxides thin films of Co-V-O and Cr-V-O were deposited at a temperature of 420 C from proper mixtures of metal acetylacetonates. The films deposited on sodalime glass substrate were characterized using a combination of Energy Dispersive X-Ray Fluorescence (EDXRF) and Rutherford Backscattering Spectroscopy (RBS) for the identification of the elements present, surface composition study and thickness determination. The deposited thin film with atomic composition CO0..31V1..37 O5 and Cr0.5V2O5 were respectively found to be 166nm and 127nm thick.For the optical characterization, absorption spectra in the ultraviolet/visible region were analysed to obtain the band gap energies of the materials. Direct allowed optical band gap energy of 2.23 eV was obtained for Co-V-O while Cr-V-O showed a phonon assisted transition with an indirect optical band gap energy of 2.05 eV.The electrical characterization using Van der Pauw method of resistivity measurement indicated that the materials: are semiconducting. Contribution to the over-all thermal conductivity resulted from electronic conduction and hopping conduction mechanisms. The activation energies were calculated from suitable plots of natural logarithm against the reciprocal of temperature. The activation energies for Co-V-O and Cr-V-O were obtained to be 0.274eV and 0.403eV respectively for electronic conduction, 0.297eV and 0.431eV respectively for hopping conduction.Thermoelectric effect on the materials showed that both materials are p-type semiconductors.|Theses Collection|Organic metal/Chemical Vapour deposition/metal acetylacetonates/sodalime/Energy Dispersive X-Ray Fluorescence (EDXRF)/Rutherford Backscattering Spectroscopy (RBS)/atomic composition/ultraviolet/visible region/optical band gap/Van der Pauw method of resistivity/Thermoelectric effect *||||||Oyewale, Adesina Ayobami|M|Evaluation of the problems and prospects of cow milk industry in osun state||||||M.Sc,Technology Policy and planning|Ogbimi, F.E.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Agric Econs|1996|||OAU|||||xi,108p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Protein shortage is a problem in Nigerian diets. Milk is rich in protein, but its production and consumption in Nigeria is very low. This study is aimed at assessing the problems facing the dairy industry in Osun State. The study was carried out using the instruments of questionnaires surveys and interviews. The respondents were dairy farms, government officials, herdsmen and residents in Osun State. Their responses were analysed using frequency and percentage estimates.The respondents identified capital, land, pasture, high yielding animals, equipment and trained personnel as necessities for the development of the dairy industry in Osun State. Herding is done in the state in the savanna area only. The herdsmen keep cattle, sheep and goat but milk only cattle. Our survey showed that foreign cows were imported for milk production in some diary farms. These have almost been wiped out by diseases. This has led to the closure of the dairy farms and their associated processing plants. Eighty two percent of the herdsmen surveyed mentioned animal diseases as problems confronting cattle rearers. None of the herdsmen gave concentrates to the animals. Thirty six percent of them reported they did not give grains to the animals because grains are expensive, 34% believed that supplementary feeding is not necessary, while 40% saw supplementary feeding as something contrary to their culture. It was estimated that 10,368 tonnes of milk were produced from cattle while about 540 and 1,000 tonnes could have been obtained from goats and sheep respectively in Osun State in 1994.Among the respondents who said they like taking milk, the largest number preferred evaporated milk, followed by powdered milk and lastly fresh milk. This preference of preserved milk suggests that there is need to popularise fresh milk Consumption. A dairy development model that involves the use of the existing herds of cattle, sheep and goat was developed for Osun State. This model is premised on improving animal health and feeding, upgrading the local herds through artificial insemination and cross breeding, the use of co-operatives as the nuclei of dairy development and the establishment of a coordinating body for milk and dairy production. |Theses Collection|Protein/diets/milk/dairy industry/herdsmen/cattle rearers *||||||Okotoni, Matthew Olu|M|Personnel development in the Nigerian Federal Civil Service with reference to Oyo and Kwara States||||||Ph.D, Public Administration|Ayo, Samuel Bamidele ||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Public Aministration|1996|||OAU|||||xii,226p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This thesis examined personnel deployment as an aspect of field administration in the Nigerian Federal Civil Service with special reference to Oyo and Kwara States. The thrust of the thesis is that effective distribution and utilization of personnel is a sine-quanon for the success of any organization.Both primary and secondary sources of data collection were employed for the study. The primary data include questionnaire, interview, analysis of records and documents and participant observations. Other data sources include Library documents (i.e. bibliographical studies, and comparative studies in published and un-published works) statistical package programme was used for the analysis to determine percentages, means and standard deviation.The study discovered that competent personnel required to carry out social and economic services at the state and local government levels are either not available or are grossly inadequate. This is because, they tend to concentrate at the headquarters in Lagos up to 1990 and Abuja since 1992. As a result of this, the Federal Government has not succeeded in making significant impact on the lives of the common people either in terms of service delivery or mobilization for productive activities. The retention of civil servants in the headquarters has been influenced by factors like access to more authority and power by the civil servants and availability of more facilities and privileges for them. This position validates our first hypothesis which stated that, the concentration of senior federal civil servants in the headquarters is strongly connected with the lack of power, authority, privileges and incentives for officers in the field.The study also discovered that it is those states that harbour more of federal projects that attract larger federal personnel. In this perspective, Oyo State is an empirical example. Our second working hypothesis is therefore validated.It was observed as well that the activities of the field offices are hampered by problems related to finance; poor communication; lack of incentives; lack of vehicles and equipment; social effect of transfer; inadequate office and residential accommodation; language and cultural barrier; poor staffing; lack of free hand to operate, etc. In concluding, a number of recommendations were proffered. These include - adequate, regular and timely funding; improved communication; adequate delegation; the need for more effective deconcentration of personnel; effective coordination of field services among the various federal ministries and the various tiers of government in Nigeria; better remunerations and incentives; more equipment and vehicles; greater autonomy; a more decent office and residential accommodation for field officers; regular feedback from the headquarters; etc.|Theses collection.|Administration/Nigerian Federal Civil Service/service delivery/mobilization/authority/power/incentives *||||||Onipede, Anthony Oladehinde|M|A comparative study of the bacteria isolates from clinical specimens obtained from patients in four university teaching hospital in south-western Nigeria.||||||M.Sc, Microbiology|Ako-nai, K.A.//Lamikanra, A.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Microbiology|1996|||OAU|||||x,114p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research| The study characterised the micro-organisms recovered from the specimens received from four (4) teaching hospitals in South Western Nigeria.Six hundred and eighty-seven (687) specimens  processed based on  standard principles in a clinical microbiology laboratory. The primary isolation media used were blood agar, eosin-methylene blue agar, mannitol salt agar and sabouraud dextrose agar. The isolates were identified based on cultural, morphological and biochemical characteristics. Final identification was based on the API 10s kit. Antibiotic susceptibility pattern of bacteria was determined by the disc diffusion method.The general pattern of consecutive specimens received from the teaching hospitals showed a similar trend. Mid stream urine was the most common specimen received, accounting for 40.5% of the entire specimens.Pathogenic organisms isolated from the respective hospital were relatively similar but the frequency of recovery of each species varied from one hospital to another. Fifteen different genera of micro-organisms were cultured in all. These include Escherichia, Citrobacter, Klebsiella,	Enterobacter,  Proteus, Pseudomonas, Aeromonas. Others are Salmonella,  Shigella,  Arizona,  Serratia,  Yersinia,   Vibrio,  Edwards Ella and Staphylococcus.The result of this study showed that the most prevalent group of micro-organism were the Gram - negative bacilli which accounted for 78.23% of the total isolates; in contrast, Gram - positive organisms contributed only 21.87%. Aeromonas (11.70%) in this study is of interest and it highlights the emerging role of this organism in urinary tract infection in the hospital setting. A variety of micro-organisms were recovered from wound swabs; however, Staphylococcus aureus was the most common single isolate (28.9%).The antibiotic resistance patterns of the bacterial isolates cultured in this study were compared. The majority of the organisms had multiple resistance to the antibiotics commonly prescribed in the hospital under study. A total of 81.3% bacterial isolates tested were resistant to ampici l l in, 81.1% to trimethoprim, 85.9% to tetracycline, 90.3% to sulphasomudine, while 73.10% of isolates were resistant to chloramphenicol and 43.2% to gentamicin.In conclusion, the study shows the similarity of pathogenic organisms isolated from clinical specimens from the teaching hospitals studied. It also highlightedthe emerging role of Aeromonas as a nosocomial pathogen. The in-vitro sensitivity testing of isolates also revealed the prevalence of multiple antibiotic resistant bacteria to commonly employed antibiotics in the South Western region of Nigeria. Therefore a continuous surveillance of bacteria to antimicrobial agents with a view to containing their spread is recommended.|Theses Collection|Micro-organisms/hospitals/mannitol salt agar/sabouraud dextrose agar/pathogenic/urine/Staphylococcus aureus/Aeromonas/gentamicin/antimicrobial agents*||||||Adesola, Emmanuel Funsho|M|An analysis of Nigeria's external relations with international financial institutions||||||M.Sc, International Relations|Soremekun, Kayode||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, International Relations|1996|||OAU|||||xi,133p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This work critically examines the existing relationship between Nigeria and two Bretton Woods institutions, namely: the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), otherwise known as the World Bank. The two international financial institutions were established on July 22, 1944. at independence in 1960, Nigeria formally joined both the IMF and World Bank. Since then, the countrys experience within the two institutions has been a mixture of understanding and confrontation.The study, critically evaluates the origins, structures and modes of operation of the two Bretton Woods institutions as well as their activities and involvement in Nigeria. Furthermore, it dwells on how the two institutions are controlled. The politics of Structural Adjustment Programme (ASP) are evaluated and a prognosis of dimensions which Nigeria  IMF/World Bank relations may likely take offered. The study reveals that due to the circumstances that led to the establishment of these Bretton Woods institutions, the major characters that were instrumental to their formation of those members with highest quota in the two institutions utilize them in order to promote their respective core or selfish interests. This is done to the detriment of Nigeria and other Third World countries within the periphery of the international system.As a result of the foregoing, the interaction between Nigeria and the Bretton Woods twins (the IMF and the World Bank) will continue to be characterized by co-operation at a time, disagreement at another. Much of this depends on the prevailing socio-economic and political situation in the country.|Theses Collection|International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)/Bretton Woods*||||||Alumona, Victor Sunday|M|Scepticism and the pratice of rhetoric in protagoras and gorgias||||||Ph.D, Philosophy|Bedu-Addo, J.T.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University,Philosophy|1996|||OAU|||||xv, 196p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This thesis examined the nature and forms of persuasive arguments in some extant treatises used by Protagoras and Gorgias as models for training their pupils. In addition, the thesis attempted to ascertain how the forms of arguments identified in these treatises could have influenced the pupils of the Sophists to become sceptics.The methodology employed was textual critical analysis and philosophical argumentation. Protagoras' "The Myth of Protagoras", the Homo Mensura dictum as expressed in Plato's Theaetetus and Gorgias' "Encomium on Helen" and the treatise "On Nature or The Non-Existent" were studied. The interpretations of these works in books and journals were also critically examined.The thesis found that Protagoras used a series of arguments in such a way that no member of the arguments in the series turned out to be absolutely valid: Each of them needed correction or support in one form or another. It was discovered that Gorgias used arguments to eliminate all possible grounds for holding that a knowledge claim can be true without qualification. The thesis concluded that diligent pupils who studied these arguments either by rote or by rigorous analysis, in order to emulate the way they are adduced could plausibly have developed a strong disposition to adopt the Sophistic Scepticism which informed the arguments they studied.|Theses Collection|Persuasive arguments/Protagoras/Gorgias/models/treatise/sophists/sceptics/Philosophy*||||||Adeyefa, Zachariah Debo |M|Spectral investgations of solar irradiance under Arctic and Tropical weather situations||||||Ph.D. Physics|J.A. Adedokun//E.E. Balogun||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Physics|1996|||OAU|||||xix,195p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Investigations of spectral and broad-band solar radiation characteristics were carried out under Arctic and Tropical weather conditions. The main objective was to gain a good insight into solar radiation and atmospheric turbidity characteristics from the measurements of the direct, global and diffuse spectral and broad-band irradiances under the two weather regimes.The experiments were carried out at Abisko (68 21' N, 18 49' E, about 200 km north of the Arctic Circle in northern Sweden) between 1990 and 1994 and at Ile-Ife (7 30'N, 4 31'E, south western Nigeria) between December 1991 and February 1992. The Angstrom atmospheric turbidity coefficients p, 0.5 (referring to atmospheric turbidity at 1um and 0.5m respectively) and a (wavelength exponent closely associated to the size of the scattering particles and the frequency of their distribution) for the wavelength interval, 350-1038 nm were derived from series of spectroradiometric measurements both at Abisko and at Ile-Ife.The Mount Pinatubo volcanic eruption of June 1991 in the Philippines, led to a significant increase in the average values of B (from 0.03 in 1990 to 0.14 in 1992) and P05 (from 0.07 to 0.17) at Abisko. The mean value of the coefficient, a, decreased from 1.18 (before the eruption) to 0.21 (after the eruption). Consequently, there was a considerable decrease in the direct irradiance especially in the visible region, varying between 18% and 30% at solar elevations of 40 and 15 respectively. The change in the total radiation was less than for the direct irradiance (about 1.4% and 8% at solar elevation angles of 40 and 15 respectively). It is shown, that the largest decrease in atmospheric turbidity occurred within March/April 1992 and September/October 1993. Results obtained up to July 1994, indicate that the turbidity values are almost back to their pre-Pinatubo magnitudes.The values of the turbidity parameters , and 0.5 for Ile-Ife between December, 1991 and February 1992 are high with averages of 1.09 and 1.41 respectively while the average value of a was about 0.5. The mean background harmattan conditions had values ranging from 1.02 (at 350 nm) to 0.54 (at 862 nm) while the spell conditions had higher turbidities varying between 1.87 at 350 nm and 1.44 at 862 nm. There was a severe reduction in the direct solar irradiance at Ile-Ife during this period while a significant increase in the diffuse radiation was observed. The global irradiance though reduced, was less sensitive to changing harmattan conditions. The parameters  and 0.5 have been shown to decrease when the Inter-Tropical Discontinuity (ITD) moves north of a station during the harmattan period and to increase when it migrates south of it. Deviations from the Angstrom law were observed (at Abisko and at Ile-Ife) when a decreased to about 0.2.This study shows that flat-plate solar energy devices that use radiation from sun and sky should be used under changing harmattan conditions rather than concentrators which use only the direct component. The deviations from the Angstrom law indicate that the Angstrom law is not valid for all characteristics of atmospheric aerosols and also emphasize the importance of using multi-spectral regression methods for the determination of a and B in preference to the Volz technique. The spectral and broad-band database resulting from this work could be used as a source of "ground truth" for satellite remote sensing applications as well as inputs for solar radiation modelling studies.|Theses Collection|Solar radiation/Arctic and Tropical weather conditions/atmospheric turbidity/wavelenght/Angstrom atmospheric turbidity coefficients/spectroradiometric/Mount Pinatubo volcanic eruption/ Inter-Tropical Discontinuity (ITD)/Volz technique *||||||Momodu, Justin Ibhafidon |M|Studies of the use of hammer mill for size reduction of cassava in gari production||||||M.Sc, Agricultural Engineering|Ige, M.T.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Agricultural Engineering|1996|||OAU|||||xii, 113p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Cassava milling in a hammer mill is a wet milling operation; for which the hammer mill inspite of its potentials to reduce and/or eliminate the disadvantages associated with the present grating and pulverization methods, is not noted for. Reported output from the hammer mills are usually based on grains of below 16% moisture content wet basis. Cassava tuber has moisture of about 60-70% wet basis. The use of the hammer mill in the size reduction of cassava tuber in gari production will contribute immensely to the knowledge of wet milling operation. It is also an added advantage to the various uses of the hammer mill and give to the cassava processors an industrial machine.A hammer mill was constructed for the grinding of cassava tubers and pulverization of dewatered cassava mash in gari production. Effect of parameters such as number of hammers, rotor speed and screen opening on throughput capacity and mash density, moisture content and the particle size of cassava mash and pulverized product were investigated, and compared with that from conventional methods (grating of cassava tubers using graters and pulverization using sieves). A 4x3x4 factorial experiment was designed to permit the screening of the effect of three variables on the mill grinding performance.Statistical test of significance shows no significant effect of treatments on mash density. The effect of increase in number of hammers on cassava cake moisture content was significant at 95 % confidence level (P < 0.05). Increasing the rotor speed and screen sizes seems not to affect the moisture content of pressed cassava mash. Analysis of the effect of the factors on the fineness modulus (F M.). shows that the effect of number of hammers and increasing rotor speed were highly significant at 99% confidence level (P < 0.01), while screen opening was only significant at P < 0.05. The effects reveals that, increasing number of hammers and rotor speed resulted in decrease in F.M., while increase in screen diameter resulted in increase in F.M.Using the hammer mill as a pulverizer, the results of the effects of screen opening on the moisture content (M.C) and fineness modulus (F.M) of pulverized cassava cake shows a decrease over the initial cassava cake M.C. of 51.55% and F.M. of 4.68 as the screen opening decreases (from 12, 10, 8 and 6 mm 4.).  Percent decreases of M.C. over the initial were 0.1, 2.6, 3.5 and 7.1 respectively for 12, 10, 8 and 6 mm diameter screen. While percent decrease of F.M. over the initial were 14, 50, 54 and 108 for 12, 10, 8 and 6 mm diameter screen respectively.The hammer mill throughput values are significantly greater than the conventional methods values in grinding and pulverization. The difference is highly signficant at 95% confidence level. The screening of the effect of the two pulverization methods on the moisture content and the fineness modulus of the products shows some level of difference in moisture content of the pressed cassava mash granulated by the hammer mill as compared with the sample manually sifted. The treatment do not appear to have any effect on fineness modulus and uniformity index of the pulverized sample.|Theses Collection|Cassava/hammer mill/wet milling/gari/cassava mash *||||||Fejamilehin, Adenike Olubunmi|F|The relationship between psychological stress and sports injuries among athletes in Obafemi Awolowo University||||||M.A.Ed. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The reproductive biology of some selected mosses was investigated in open and forest areas within the Ife Ondo forest zones of the west tropical rain forest belt. The study was carried out to investigate the reproductive strategies of mosses in the prevailing non-uniform, unstable habitats.The mosses: Thuidium gratum (P. Beauv.) Jaeg; Hyophila involuta Hook Jaeg; Stereophylhun radiculosum Hook Mitt; Racopilum africanum Mitt; Bryum coronatum Schwaegr; Barbula lambarenensis (Hook) Spreng.; Calymperes ufzelii Octoblepharum albidum Hedw and Bryum cruegeri Hampe., were sampled fortnightly from their various substrates and scored for the presence or absence and the stage of development of sex organs and sporophytes. Viability test of the spores of these selected mosses were carried out by determining their percentage spore germination. Spores. gemmae and regenerants or vegetative parts of these mosses were dispersed onto their respective natural substrates to determine their effectiveness in shoot establishment. Spore output and spore sizes of these mosses were determined by using haemacytometer counting chamber and Ocular micrometer respectively. The effect of photoperiods on gamete formation were also investigated by subjecting B. coronatum and H. involuta, the two commonest mosses producing sporophytes, freely to different light periods.Results showed that all the selected mosses except B. cruegeri are fertile. In addition, B. lambarenensis, H. involuta and C. afzelii are superfertiles (reproduce asexually and sexually). All these mosses are also perennial except H. involuta that is an annual. Phenological studies showed that the fertile mosses follow a defined sequential reproductive cycle that  lasted for a maximum months except B. lambarenensis that reproduces sexually at alternative years, Production of gemmae was found to be more, correlated with dioecism than inability to fruit, No momoeciuos species was found to produce gemmae. Gemmae were found to be more effective than spores in the establishment of new moss population. However, coronatum can successfully be propagated through spores on natural substrates. Estimates from the spore output and spore sizes showed an inverse relationship between these two variables. All the selected mosses are homsporous except C. afzelii that was anisosporous. Photoperiods and water availability (rainfall) are important factors in the sexual reproductive cycle of B. coronatum and H. involuta. The problem of fluctuating environmental factors coupled with the welldefined Contrasting dry and rainy seasons would certainly make the mosses  develop adequate reproductive strategies to ensure their survival in these study areas.|Theses Collection|Habitat/mosses/sex organs/sporophytes/haemacytometercounting chamber/Ocular micrometer/Gemmae/Photoperiods  *||||||Mohammed, Mairo Balaraba|M|The role of seaports in the economic and political integration of the West African sub-region||||||M.Sc. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The foraminiferal biostratigraphy and palaeoecology of the strata penetrated by Ete-1 and Bonny-5 wells have been studied. A total of 105 ditch cutting samples from the two wells were analysed for their foraminiferal content using the conventional method of hand rubbing under tap.Based on the planktonic foraminiferal fauna a Late Miocene age was assigned to the two wells. Two informal biostratigraphic zones were erected for each well based on planktonic foraminifers.In Ete-1 well, the informal planktonic foraminiferal zones are Orbulina universa - Globigerinoides praebulloides whilst	in	Bonny-5	well, Orbulina  suturalis Globigerinoides immaturus and Globigerina nepenthes Globigerinoides ruber zones were established.Three informal benthonic foraminiferal zones each were established for the two wells. In Ete-1 well, the zones are Florilus costiferus - Clavelloides tenuistriata zone, Textularia sp. - Lenticulina rotulata zone and Lagena sulcata - Eggerella bradyi zone. In Bonny-5 well, the zones are Heterolepa - pseudoungeriana - Ouinqueloculina rhodiensis zone, Lenticulina rotulata - Heterolepa crebbsi zone and Lenticulina inornata - Nodosaria raphanistrum zone. Analysis of the benthonic foraminifera for bathymetry and the Planktonic - Benthonic (P/B) ratio for the two wells revealed a gradual decrease in bathymetry between the basal and upper sections of the wells, with a distinct tendency towards sequential shallowing in water depth. This was attributed to a probable higher rate of sediment fill relative to subsidence rate. Further palaeoecological analysis revealed that the sea which deposited the sediments in the two wells was warm and for most part of the time was of normal marine salinity. The inferred environment of deposition based on the ecology of some dominant foraminiferal faunas in the lower sections of the wells was a continental shelf marine environment. The upper sections with paucity of foraminiferal fauna and P/B ratio of less than 0.1 indicate a nearshore transitional environment of deposition.|These Collection|Biostratigraphy/palaeoecology/planktonic foraminifers/marine environment/bathymetry/deposition *||||||Fatoke, Louwaseyi Adedamola|M|Depositional environments and provenance of sediments penetrated by wells in the niger delta||||||M.Sc, Applied Geology|Adediran, S.A// Rahaman M.A.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Geology|1996|||OAU|||||xii, 155p|||||||||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This study set out to examine toxic waste dump as an environmental and development problem in Africa. It sought to understand the phenomenon in it's international context. In so doing, it hoped to properly situate toxic waste dump in it's proper position among environmental and development problems in Africa.The study is descriptive and based on documentary analysis. The informal interview method of data collection was also employed. On the basis of the data collected, the study identified that toxic waste dump could result in serious environmental degradation and continued poverty and underdevelopment in Africa. It also revealed that international efforts are grossly inadequate and incapable of protecting Africa from toxic wastes being dumped by the industrialized countries.The study elucidates on the relationship between environment, international politics and economics, identifying that there is an international waste problem  dumping inimical to development. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Forestry serves as a foundation for industrialisation and enhances the stability of the rural population. Forestry resources in Nigeria have been depleted to the point of exhaustion and high forest is in great danger of becoming extinct due to various human activities. This study was therefore designed to examine the forest policy in South western Nigeria, evaluate the implementation of the policy, and investigate the effect of forest policy on supply of wood and wood products and the ecosystem.Data were collected from foresters, farmers/hunters and saw-millers/timber contractors in South western States of Lagos, Ogun, Oyo, Osun, Ondo Edo and Delta States. Both Structured and unstructured questionnaires and personal indepth interviews were used to collect information from the respondents. The sample for the study comprises 297 foresters, 70 farmers hunters and 35 saw millers/timber contractors. The data were thereafter analysed with percentage, liken scale and correlation co-efficient.The result showed that the implementation of the policy was hindered by frequent changes in government, political opposition during implementation, inadequate financing and lack of incentives for foresters. Out of 24 roles which the Federal government was expected to perform in respect of forestrysub-sector, only 33.7% of the respondents agreed that the Federal government promoted wildlife species multiplication schemes while 35.4% also agreed thatnational wildlife development activities were adequately co-ordinated. In the case of State governments, only 33.7% of the respondents agreed that the enactment and enforcement of wildlife legislation was adequately performed, while 16.8/a agreed that the establishment of green-belts in urban area were adequately performed. With the compliance of forest policy by farmers, timber contractors/saw-millers and hunters, there were lots of malpractices. These were encroachment on reserved forests by farmers, illegal felling of trees and bush burning. The malpractices contributed to deforestation.Emphases should be placed on reversing the trend of deforestation in the South because the major problems which impede the implementation of forestry programmes in South Western Nigeria are deforestation and wood energy problems. There should be an intensive public enlightenment campaign to ensure that the major cause of ecological problems-man-is sufficiently made aware of his responsibility to nature, his fellow human being and his environment. Lastly community an private forests should be encouraged by the various local governments so as to solve the fuelwood problem.|Theses collection.|industrialisation/Structured and unstructured questionnaires/personal indepth interviews/deforestation *||||||Ukwatar, Osanu|M|Degradation of crude oil by pseudomonas aeruginosa||||||M.Sc, Chemical Engineering|Layokun, S.K||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Chemical Engineering|1996|||OAU|||||x, 113p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Crude oil provides a source of carbon and energy for microbial growth. Nitrogen is a limiting component for growth and the amount and source of available nitrogen can affect growth with an attendant limitation on degradation. The objective of this work was to degrade crude oil in mineral salts medium of equal concentration of nitrogen from different sources namely; Urea, Potassium nitrate and Ammonium sulphate and to calculate the extent of degradation with time for each medium. The organism of choice was Pseudomonas aeruginosa because of its substrate versatility.Three mineral salts media of equal concentration of nitrogen from different sources (Urea, Potassium nitrate and Ammonium sulphate) were prepared and sterilised. Each medium was then inoculated with a pure culture of Pseudomonas aeruginosa after the addition of filtered and sterilised crude oil. Fermentation in shake flasks was done for each medium for two weeks at 150rpm and 30C. Samples were withdrawn every 48 hours and analysed on gas chromatograph to show the extent of degradation.At the end of the experiment, Pseudomonas aeruginosa had degraded the crude oil and 87.6% of the original crude oil introduced into Urea medium disappeared. In Potassium nitrate and Ammonium sulphate media, 87 and 86.5% of the initial crude oil introduced disappeared respectively Also, it was found that the initial rates of degradation were 1.8, 1.6 and 1.5 hr -1 for Urea, Ammonium sulphate and Potassium nitrate respectively.|Theses collection| microbial growth/substrate versatility/Fermentation / gas chromatograph/*||||||Idowu, Thomas Oyebode|M|Bioactivity-guided fractionation of acalypha hispida burm||||||M.Sc, Pharmaceutical Chemistry|Ogundaini, A.O.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Phamaceutical Chemistry|1996|||OAU|||||ix, 78p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The genus Acalypha comprises about 570 species occurring as herbs or ornamental plants, some of which are native to West Africa or introduced to the region. Plants of this genus are well known in traditional medicine. Leaf decoction of Acalypha hispida Burm, is reported in literature to be administered in the treatment of gonorrhoea infections, wounds, ulcers, boils, abcesses and as mashed compress in leprosy. It is also used as a laxative and in the treatment of asthma. Preliminary antimicrobial screening in our laboratory on 50% aqueous ethanolic extracts of six Acalypha plants showed that A. hispida and A. wilkensiana possess a wide spectrum of antimicrobial activity. The literature evidence butressed by our own initial screening encouraged detailed investigation into the bioactive compounds of A. hispida leaves.A 50% aqueous ethanol extract of A. hispida leaves was partitioned between water and the following organic solvents viz:- chloroform, ethylacetate, and n-butanol. Acetone precipitation of the aqueous crude extract was also effected. The aqueous and organic fractions of each solvent were subjected to antimicrobial screening using E. coli, Ps. aeruginosa, S. aureus and B. subtilis to situate activity. n-Butanolic fraction was found to be the most active of all the fractions tested. A series of bioassay-guided chromatographic fractionation of this fraction was then carried out in order to isolate the active compounds.Two ellagitannins, corilagin and geraniin were isolated as the antimicrobial principles of A. hispida leaves. The procedure involving a sephadex column and Accelerated Gradient Chromatography (AGC) for final cleaning on silica gel was optimal for their isolation. The structure of the compounds were elucidated by chemical derivatisation, 2D nmr (1H and 13C) and ms studies. The same two compounds were isolated from A. wilkesiana as the compounds responsible for the antimicrobial activity in a parallel study in our laboratory.The study has resulted in the improvement of the isolation procedure and full characterisation of the two ellagitannins responsible for the antimicrobial activity of A. hispida.|These Collection|traditional medicine/gonorrhoea infections/antimicrobial activity/bioassay-guided chromatographic fractionation*||||||Sangobiyi, Olusegun Akanbi|M|Investigation of fading problems on digital microwave radio links in a tropical region||||||M.Sc, Electronic and Electrical Engineering|Ajayi, G.O||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Electrionic and Electrical Engineering|1996|||OAU|||||xv, 87p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Fading effect constitutes propagation problems at microwave frequencies. This effect has been extensively investigated for both analogue and digital systems in the temperate regions. Although fading effect on analogue propagation has been investigated and effective solutions found, the effect on digital microwave propagation in the tropics is still not much known. This study, therefore,investigates fading characteristics as it affects digital microwave signal propagation in a tropical region.The Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC) microwave links on 7.5GHz, 34 Mbit/sec, installed on Benin-Abudu and Mosimi-Atlas Cove routes were used as a case study. It was noticed that fading effect characterised by high bit error rate (BER) and serious signal distortions particularly during Harmattan season were common. An attempt is made at finding corrective measures (system design measures and fading effect counter-measures) capable of offering high system reliability with wide application in the tropical region.|Theses Collection|temperate regions/digital microwave signal propagation/Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC) microwave/ high bit error rate (BER)*||||||Igo, Benjamin Onovughakpo|M|Performance enhancement in the delta state civil service through training and manpower development||||||M.Sc, Public Administration|Laleye, O.M||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Public Administration|1996|||OAU|||||xii,136p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The quest to make the Nigerian civil service result-oriented has been an important concern of successive civil and military administrations. Among the various reform efforts which have been undertaken in this direction, the 1988 civil service reforms has been the most elaborate and far-reaching. The linchpin of the reform package was the professionalization policy which sought to, among other things, train and develop civil servants to acquire relevant professional knowledge, skill, attitudes and ethical norms of behaviour in order to enhance their job performance.Accordingly, training and manpower development is now a primary focus of attention in the civil service of all the states in the federation, that of the Delta State inclusive, and at the federal level. However, the adequacy of the current approach in the Delta State civil service has emerged as an issue of concern among civil servants in the system. The study therefore sought to critically assess the approach with a view to identifying the inherent problems as well as advance suggestions to assist the process to achieve the goals of the professionalization policy in the state civil service and indeed, the Nigerian civil service in general.Essentially, the methodology adopted for assessing the current approach to training and manpower development in the state civil service was historical, theoretical, descriptive and statistical. Primary data were sourced through the use of questionnaire, interviews/discussions with relevant civil servants and participant observation. On the other hand, secondary data were obtained from official documents in Ministries/Extra-Ministerial Departments in the state civil service as well as other published and unpublished works.The findings of the study confirmed that the current approach to training and manpower development in the state civil service is inadequately planned. The position, among other findings, was revealed by the fact that the selection of training and development programme was usually not informed by the identification of the needs of staff. Staffs were usually sponsored to undertake programmes in which they had earlier indicated interest. Another significant finding was that the attitudes of a preponderance of staff were not supportive of the training and manpower development process. Indeed, most civil servants have no confidence in the process as being capable of assisting them to acquire relevant professional competence, attitudes and ethical behaviours requisite to enhance their job performance.Obviously, the continuation of the approach to training and manpower development in the state civil service portends grave dangers for the achievement of the goals of the professionalization policy. Accordingly, possible solutions to the problems inherent in the approach are suggested.|Theses Collection|Nigerian civil service/military administrations/professionalization policy/job performance/manpower development *||||||Ikwuka, Nneka Angelique|F|A study of enhanced oil recovery potential of nigerian reservoirs||||||M.Sc. Chemical Engineering|Adewusi, V.A.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, |1996|||OAU|||||xviii, 193p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Steam, miscible CO2 and polymer injection processes are the principal enhanced oil recovery methods of improving oil production from heavier and also light oil reservoirs. The potential of these processes for improved recovery from Nigerian oil reservoirs has been evaluated. Specific cases studied are the virgin, light oil reservoirs (C-2 and C-3 sands) in Ewan field, heavier oil reservoirs (D3.000E, D5.000A and E 1.000E sands) in Ekulama field and water flooded light oil reservoirs (D-4 and D-7 sands) in Agbada field.Process screening criteria were first applied to available reservoir data and this resulted in the assignment of steam, CO2 and polymer processes to the Ewan, but only CO2 process to Agbada and Ekulama subject reservoirs. Incremental oil recoverable from each reservoir - process combination was then estimated using appropriate analytical predictive models. Sensitivity studies were also carried out to assess the effects associated with changes in the operating pressure, fluid injection rate, pattern area and other important reservoir and process parameters.Peak recoveries were found to exhibit remarkable sensitivity to operating parameters. At the basecase conditions, with 124.2 acres pattern spacing, it was established that oil recoveries up to 15%, 20% and 45% original oil in place (OOIP) corresponding respectively to more than 0.20 STB of oil/MCF of CO2, 0.75 BBL of oil/bbl of steam and 15STB of oil/lb of polymer are attainable by CO2, steam and polymer injection processes in Ewan C-2 and C-3 reservoirs, with the C-3 exhibiting greater potential. In the Ekulama cases, oil recovery by miscible CO2 process was highest in E 1.000E sand reaching 24% OOIP as compared to less than 2% and 6% in D3.000E and D5.000A sands respectively. Similar recoveries predicted for Agbada D-4 and D-7 sands are respectively 8.5% and 28.5% oil in place at abandonment (OIPA). These trends evidently depict the relative potential of the assigned processes for improved oil recovery in the subject reservoirs.|These Collection|Steam/miscible CO2/polymer injection/analytical predictive models/fluid injection rate*||||||Tewogbade, Ismail Tayo|M|The role of the frontline states in a post-apartheid South Africa||||||M.Sc. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This is a comparative study of the ambient air total suspended particulate matter (TSPM) collected seasonally within the Delta Steel Company (DSC), its neighborhood and Ile-Ife during the wet and dry seasons.The study involved the (i) determination of levels of TSPM collected on Whatman-41 filter papers with two Aztec low-volume samplers, (ii) elemental characterization of the TSPM using the Energy Dispersive X-ray Fluorescence (ED-XRF) technique, (iii) assessment of the health impacts of TSPM by comparing the levels with the Federal Environmental Protection Agency (FEPA) standard of 250g/m3 and (iv) apportionment of source contribution to the collected TSPM levels applying Factor Analysis (FA) and Chemical Mass Balance (CMB) techniques.The average total suspended particulate matter (TSPM) concentrations measured at both wet and dry seasons inside the Complex (excluding the shopfloors) were respectively 206.6g/m3 and 337g/m3. Outside the Complex, within the neighborhood, the average wet and dry seasonal TSPM loadings measured are 52.9g/m3 and 280.5g/m3 respectively. The mean TSPM concentration decreased exponentially with increasing distance from the shopfloor to farther locations.The following elements were present in most of the samples: Al, Si, P, CI, K, Ca, Ti, V, Mn, Fe, Ni, Cu, Zn and Na while these ones, which were also highly enriched outside and within the Complex at the two seasons, are distinctly shown as DSC dust marker elements: Ca, V, Cr, Mn, Fe Ni, Cu, Zn, Pb, Co and As.Concentrations of toxic trace elements such as Cu, Mn, Co, As, V, Pb and possibly Ni, Cr and Zn were observed to have values 1 to 10 times their maximum allowable levels at bothseasons within the Complex and at outside locations less than 10km. Toxicity potentials (TP) values of unity and above were observed at locations within the workarea while values less than unity occurred at other locations during the wet seasons. In the dry season, TP values above unity were reported at all locations.The predictions produced contributions from the following sources, within the Complex, at dry season: fugitive solidified-iron-cutting, hot flame (42.5%), iron and steel-making process dust (27.2%), marine sprays (22.3%), Ovwian-Aladja soil (6.5%), lime-making process dust (1.4%) and the vehicular exhaust (0.1%). During the wet season, the source-contributors are iron and steel-making process dust (67.5%), the iron-cutting hot flame (30.2%), lime-making process dust (1.1%), marine sprays (0.7%) and vehicular exhaust (0.5%). Outside the Complex, during the dry season, the contributors are marine sprays (93.7%), Ovwian-Aladja soil (3.5%), DSC dust (1.2%), paint dust (0.6%), oil/fuel combustion (0.5%) and vehicular exhaust (0.4%). During the wet season, the sources are DSC dust (54.1%), oil/fuel combustion (24.3%), marine sprays (18.7%), vehicular exhaust (11.1%) and paint (1.8%).The findings of this study imply that fugitive and process emissions have pronounced impact on the air quality of the steel complex while the complex itself contributes appreciably to the air particulate of its neighbourhood (up to 3km) at full operation.|Theses collection.|total suspended particulate matter (TSPM)/Federal Environmental Protection Agency (FEPA)/Toxicity potentials (TP)*||||||Babalola, Chinedum Peace |M|Pharmacokinetic studies of quinine in man||||||Ph.D, Phamaceutical Chemistry|Ogunbona, F.A.||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Phamaceutical Chemistry|1996|||OAU|||||xiii, 240p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The emergence and spread of chloroquine resistant falciparum malaria worldwide has led to the re-introduction of quinine by the WHO as the drug of choice for the management of cerebral and complicated malaria and as an alternative drug in the treatment of multi-drug resistant falciparum malaria. There were no available pharmacokinetic data of quinine in African subjects prior to the commencement of this study. With the renewed interest in quinine such data are essential for the rational clinical use of the drug. Thus, the pharmacokinetics of quinine was investigated in Nigerian subjects in order to provide a pharmacokinetic data bank towards effective use of this antimalaria drug in the sub-continent.A simple, sensitive and specific reversed-phase high-performance liquid chromatographic method was developed for the analysis of quinine in biological fluids. The method, which was used to study the pharmacokinetics of quinine in healthy volunteers and patients, resolved quinine from its major metabolite, 3-hydroxyquinine, and its isomer, quinidine.After single doses of 500 mg quinine were administered to three groups of twenty volunteers in a parallel design study as the intravenous infusion, capsule and tablet preparations, quinine was well absorbed from the capsule preparations with a bioavailability of almost 80% and above while a bioavailability of about 40% was observed for the tablet. The various pharmacokinetic parameters computed following intravenous and oral administration of the drug were not significantly different (p > 0.05) thus suggesting that the route of administration may not affect the disposition of quinine in man. Higher blood quinine levels were observed in the subjects when compared with reports of similar studies from Southeast Asia thus suggesting the possibility of inter-ethnic variation in the disposition of quinine.An oral dose of 10 mg/kg of quinine gave parasite and fever clearance times of 36.0  6.92 h and 18.0  2.68 h respectively, indicating therapeutic efficiency in acute uncomplicated malaria. A comparison of pharmacokinetic parameters during malaria and after recovery revealed consistently higher plasma quinine levels in malaria with more than a two-fold increase in plasma AUC and more than a two-fold reduction in oral clearance (Clp/F) and apparent volume of distribution (Vd/F).After a single oral administration of 500 mg quinine to four volunteers, the tmax and t112 of quinine in saliva and plasma were similar (p > 0.1). A good correlation (r = 0.93) was also observed between saliva and simultaneous plasma levels of quinine. The results indicate that quinine is transferred into saliva by a passive process and that saliva may prove useful for therapeutic drug monitoring of quinine in man.After single oral doses of 250, 500, 750 and 1000 mg quinine to seven volunteers in a randomized cross-over design, increases in Cma and AUC were linear and proportional to the doses (r2 > 0.9). The tmax, t12, Vd/F and Clp/F values were all similar, regardless of the dose (p > 0.05). The occurrence of side effects of the drug was dose dependent. These findings suggest that quinine disposition is linear and not capacity-limited over the dose range studied.|Theses collection.|falciparum malaria,WHO, d-phase, antimalari, metabolite, 3-hydroxyquinine, plasma AUC *||||||Omotosho, Mashood O.|M|A study of the current peace initiative in the middle east||||||M.Sc, International Relations|Ojo, Olusola||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, International Relations|1996|||OAU|||||ix, 117p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|This thesis examined the relevance of staff attitudes to the effectiveness of management training and development in the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation. This study became expedient by reason of the fact that, while the need for an organised and systematic approach to training and development in the Public Sector has been stressed in the literature of management and administration, there exist no attempt at linking ineffectiveness in training and development to staff attitudes. This was considered a gap in the body of knowledge, which this study sought to fill.The methodology	employed	for this study was theoretical, descriptive and statistical. Both primary and secondary sources of data were used for this study. Primary data were collected through questionnaire and interview methods, while secondary data were collected from relevant library and documentary sources.In our discussion of the management training and development system and practice of the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation, this study identified and highlighted the indices of ineffectiveness in the system (management training and development) as inadequate and unsystematic planning,un- organised implementation and apparent negligence of evaluation. Our observation and available objective data also revealed that the absence of adequate and systematic planning, organised implementation and appropriate evaluation, is a product of lack of true support and commitment to management training and development by both top management and trainees.Also, in our assessment of the level of top management commitment, our study found out that there exists a generally low level of commitment by top management to management training and development in the Corporation. In like manner, the findings of our study showed that trainees are not favourably pre-disposed towards management training and development in the Corporation. Thus the findings of the study indicated that there exists a relationship between staff attitudes and the level of ineffectiveness in the management training and development system of the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation.Essentially, the study made some useful recommendations that could bring about an effective management training and development system in the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation. In this direction, it was recommended that management training and development should be systematically planned, properly organised. and appropriately evaluated in the Corporation. It was further recommended that top management and trainees should be truly committed to the management training and development system of the Corporation. Finally, it was recommended that the Federal Government should, considering the strategic role of the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation in the management of the nation's economy, approve adequate financial resources for the training and development programmes of the Corporation.|Theses Collection|Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation/management training/development/level of commitment/Oil sector*||||||Obi, Olutayo Olumide|M|The effect of nutrition and health interventions in rural poultry production in Osun State||||||M.Sc. Animal Science|E.B. Sonaiya||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Animal Science|1996|||OAU|||||x,76p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|Two main studies were conducted. The first was a survey to obtain information on profitability of rural chicken production in Osun state. Average flock size was 17 birds. Ninety-eight percent of the respondents offered grain supplements and average feed supplementation cost per bird per month was N 7.70. Basket coops were the common type of overnight housing provided and the depreciated cost was about N 0.103 per bird per month. The average price of a mature cock was N 79, while hens and growers cost N 58 and N 29, respectively. The farmers were willing to pay N 4.30 per bird for vaccination against Newcastle disease and N 6.70 per Kilogram of compounded feed. Gross margin estimation shows that the farmers realize a positive margin of N 4.50 from the sale of growers at 3 months of age and N9.00 and N 30.00 on hens and cocks, respectively, when sold at 6 months of age.The second study was conducted on-farm to study the effect of offering supplements (commercial growers mash) and vaccination against Newcastle disease on the productivity of scavenging village chickens. The treatments were villages in. which supplementation, vaccination, a combination of supplementation and vaccination were offered. The control was the village in which no experimental supplement or vaccination was offered to the scavenging birds. Data were collected on body weight changes, apparent average supplemental feed intake, flock size, number of eggs laid, number of chicks hatched, and number of chicks surviving at 2 , 4 , 6 and 8 weeks. The data collected was analyzed for means, standard deviations and percentages. The means were compared and separated using one-way analysis of variance and Duncans New multiple range test.The results indicate a drop in average apparent daily intake (g/bird) of the experimental supplements after the first period for the different groups except the cocks whose consumption fluctuated down the periods. The average daily weight gain (g/bird/day) fluctuated over time for birds in all treatments. The vaccination treatment had the highest average daily gain of 2.78 g/bird/day but this was not significantly different from other treatments. The average clutch sizes of hens in both supplementation and supplementation + vaccination treatments (9.26 and 8.78 eggs) were significantly higher than those in the vaccination and control treatments (6.70 and 6.33 eggs). The overall average clutch size was 8.36 eggs while the average number of chicks hatched was 6.08 a hatchability of 72.7%. Mortality was highest in the control treatment (65.0%).Supplementing 50% of the calculated requirements of scavenging chickens with commercial growers mash and timely vaccination against Newcastle disease improved the productivity and the gross margins obtainable from rural chicken production system.|These Collection|Feed supplementation/vaccination/nitrition/flock size/mortality/hatchability/rural chicken production*||||||Oladimeji, Hakeem Olawale|M|Bioactivity- guided fractionation of Acalypha  Wilkesiana||||||M.Sc. Pharmaceutical Chemistry|T.A. Olugbade||Ile-Ife, Nigeria|Obafemi Awolowo University, Pharmaceutical Chemistry|1996|||OAU|||||xi91p|||||||English||Obafemi Awolowo University, H. O. Library, Ile-Ife, Osun State. E-mail: ul@library.oauife.edu.ng|http://library.oauife.edu.ng||||I hereby authorize the Hezekiah Oluwasanmi Library to copy my thesis in whole or in part in response to request from individual researchers and organizations for the purpose of private study or research|The genus, Acalypha (Family, Euphorbiaceae) consists of about 570 species and varieties including weeds and ornamental shrubs. Members of this genus are used extensively in traditional medicine in various cultures (African, Oriental, Indian, European and Oceanian) to treat a number of infections including skin fungal infections, respiratory disorders and gastrointestinal infections.In this work, six Acalypha species namely A.,ciliata, A. indica, A. hhispida and A,. wilkesiana varieties (Red, Golden-yellow and Lace varieties) were screened for antimicrobial properties and brine shrimp toxicity. Only A. ciliata, a weed, demonstrated LD50 200ppm in the brine shrimp assay. The ornamental plants, A. hispida and the three varieties of A. wilkesiana demonstrated significant antibacterial activities against E. coli, S. aurens, B. subtilis and Ps. aeruginosa. Only A. hispida and the red Acalypha showed significant anticandidal (C. pseudotropicalis) activity as well. Hence, one of these two, the red Acalypha was selected for detailed studies. The red Acalypha has been specifically reported to he used extensively in the treatment of bacterial and skin fungal infections like Pityriasis versicolor, Impetigo contagiosa and Tinea versicolor in traditional herbal medicine in Nigeria.Studies involving solvent-partitioning of the aqueous ethanolic extract located antimicrobial activity in the butanol fraction.Subsequent bioactivity directed this fraction successively on sephadex LH-20 and polyamide 6S column revealed the antibacterial principles as a mixture of two polyphenols. Minimum effort liquid chromatography of' the mixture on silica resolved the mixture into two compounds which were identified using spectroscopic methods, one as cofilagin and the other tentatively identified as geraniin. Both compounds isolated demonstrated antimicrobial activities against the five test organisms. While corilagin and geraniin have been previously reported from other sources, the antimicrobial properties of these ellagitannins have not been hitherto reported. Although corilagin is well known to be an artefact resulting from in-process hydrolysis of geraniin, the natural occurrence of this tannin in red Acalypha was confirmed, in the present study, by its thin-layer chromatographic detection in fresh leaves.|Theses collection.|Ornamental shrubs/gastrointestinal infections/antibacterial/skin fungal infections *
